column2: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Jan. 10, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Perennial sellers are not actively tracked. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. All four children’s lists appear each week on the Book Review’s Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children’s titles.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Jan. 10, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

EVERY Wednesday since mid-August 2005 -- approximately 175 straight Wednesdays -- a couple of dozen women and men have gathered in front of the National Guard Armory here for 90 minutes, starting at 4:30 p.m., to hold a peace vigil against the war. They carry signs that Paula Rogovin, a teacher, always keeps handy in the trunk of her Toyota, demanding that the troops be brought home. They hold four-foot-high numbers updating the latest death toll of American soldiers that Tom Urgo, a plumber, painted and lacquered.

A listing on Jan. 11 about 44 Places to Go in 2009 included several errors. The entry about Las Vegas (No. 5) misspelled the surname of the director of the Center for Business and Economic Research at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. He is Dr. R. Keith Schwer, not Scher. The Dakar, Senegal, entry (No. 10) misspelled part of the name of a cultural center. It is the Institut Français Léopold Sédar Senghor, not Sédor. The Monument Valley entry (No. 27) located the park incorrectly. It is in northeast Arizona, with a small section extending into Utah; it is not in northwest Arizona. And the Stockholm entry (No. 35, on the Web site) misspelled the surname of a Finnish architect and designer. He is Alvar Aalto, not Alto.
JAY LENO Nice to have you all here. As you all know, George Bush is no longer president, so there'll be no monologue.

ROTHSTEIN--Patricia Ann, Ph.D. (age 60) died suddenly on January 18, 2009. She is survived by sons David Robbins and Keith Dashefsky; grandson Ryan Robbins; siblings James Rothstein (Judi) and Peggy Wollins (Jonathan); nephews Andrew and Michael Rothstein, Donald and Evan Wollins; close friend Raymond Hawkins, Ph.D. She will be missed.

FRIEDMAN--Edward B.,CPA. The Partners and Staff of Barash Friedman Friedberg & Adasko, CPA's P.C. mourns the passing of our beloved Managing Partner. No words can express our gratitude for five decades of devoted service to our firm. He will be deeply missed by us, our clients and friends. Our heartfelt condolences to his family in this time of mourning.

Address: 25 LeRoy Place, #506, New Rochelle, N.Y. The Property: This 900-square-foot one-bedroom one-bath condominium in a former Bloomingdale's department store has 14-foot-high ceilings, tall windows and commanding views of the city and Long Island Sound. The five-story Art Deco brick-and-stucco building, which has doorman and an elevator, was renovated in 2003. This unit, just below the penthouses, has an open floor plan, a large kitchen-dining area, hardwood floors and its own washer and dryer. Taxes are $2,393 a year; the monthly common charge is $410.

LEYDEN--Bernard, 85, died January 22, 2009. He resided in New York City and Palm Beach, FL. Devoted and loving husband to Alice Leyden and the late Helen Katzman. Father, business partner and best friend to his son Brian (Diane). Cherished grandfather of Lauren and Robert Potter and Brandon Leyden. Loving father to son Joel and and grandfather of Lior, David and Amanda who reside in Israel. Baby brother to Tillie and the late Henry. Loved by Alice's children Harry (Laurie) Gray; grandpa to Charlie and Max and Robert (Karen) Gray; grandpa to Caroline and Alexander. ''Uncle Bernie'' to three generations of loving family. He enjoyed reading, talking politics, finding the best sale and a great meal. He will be deeply missed. Funeral Sunday, January 25, 2009 12 noon at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

Film nominees include Frank Langella, Sean Penn, Brad Pitt, Mickey Rourke, Anne Hathaway, Angelina Jolie, Meryl Streep and Kate Winslet; television nominees include Ralph Fiennes, Paul Giamatti, Laura Linney, Susan Sarandon, Michael C. Hall, Jon Hamm, William Shatner and Tina Fey. Forest Whitaker will present James Earl Jones with the 45th Life Achievement Award. MUNYAN--Shirley Boberg, a longtime resident of Manhattan, died on January 20, 2009 at the age of 86 years. She is survived by her husband, Winthrop R. Munyan, a resident of Manhattan, by two sisters, Marjorie Boberg Aurelius of Birchwood, Wisconsin, and Imogene Boberg Christian, a resident of Lilydale, Minnesota, and several nieces and nephews. Mrs. Munyan was born October 12, 1922 in St. Paul, Minnesota, the eldest daughter of Walfred Eric Boberg and Florence Johnson Boberg. She attended the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. Mrs. Munyan had a long career associated with Stewart Dougall and Associates in marketing research and retailing, and, thereafter was a Senior Supervisor at R.H. Macy & Co., Inc., Herald Square, New York City, for 13 years. She was a member of the Pan Pacific and Southeast Asia Women's Association and a past President of its New York Chapter. She was also an active board member of the International Council of Women and the Oratorio Society of New York.

The stock market ended in the red for a third consecutive week, but hope for an expansive recovery plan emerged in Washington Friday afternoon, giving investors a small measure of relief. For most of the week, financial stocks served as a barometer for the overall market, with steep drops on Tuesday and Thursday as investors worried about struggling banks and their effect on the economy. A day of strong gains was sandwiched between.

THE NEWSBarack Hussein Obama was sworn in as the 44th president of the United States on Tuesday as tens of millions of people watched. BEHIND THE NEWS The son of a black man from Kenya and a white woman from Kansas, Mr. Obama inherited a White House built partly by slaves and a nation in crisis at home and abroad. He recited the oath with his hand on the same Bible that Abraham Lincoln used at his inauguration 148 years ago. Vowing to usher in ''a new era of responsibility,'' Mr. Obama cautioned that the challenges facing the country ''are serious and they are many'' and ''will not be met easily or in a short span of time. But know this, America, they will be met.''

HOROWITZ--Bess (Gold berg), died peacefully at age 92 in West Orange, NJ on January 21. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY and Sarasota, FL, she was the wife of the late Dr. William Horowitz and was predeceased by her sister, Helen Solomon. A dancer with Martha Graham in the late 1930s and 1940s, she later became a college reference librarian. Mother to Paul (Ruth) and Zebulun David (Ann) and grandmother to Daniel, Sarah, Ze'ev, Max and Lynn.

HENNESSY--G. Michael, 80, passed away January 20, in Manhattan, of infectious complications from pneumonia that developed following knee replacement surgery. For many years a highly-regarded furrier whose G. Michael Hennessy Furs label is found inside hundreds of his beautiful furs. Proud of his service as a U.S. Marine Corps Officer in Korea. Beloved husband of Rubye Graham Hennessy. Also survived by three sons, Robert, Wally and Mike, all of whom followed him into the fur trade; daughter Andrea, grandsons Nick, Charles and Thomas Hennessy, sister Marion Taggart. Predeceased by daughter Alexandra. An avid opera lover, world-wide traveler and proud Irishman. Memorial service will be held Sunday, February 15, 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbells, 81st St. and Madison Ave. hennessylatona@verizon.net

ERNST--Frank J. (Michael), died on Saturday January 3, 2009 of lung caner at Caprini Hospital in New York City. He celebrated his 86th birthday last month. Mr. Ernst was the youngest of ten children of Charles and Julie Ryan Ernst. All are predeceased. He grew up and was educated in Chicago-moving to New York City in 1962. He is survived by nine nieces, two nephews, several great-nieces and nephews and his partner, Stephen T. Donohue. A Madison Avenue merchant for many years, he previously was a floor manager at Lord & Taylors and purchasing agent for Lyons International. At his request, he was buried in Chatham, MA, his summer home, on January 9. The funeral Mass at Holy Redeemer Catholic Church was attended by relatives and friends.

NAGLER--Lauren. The Continuum Health Partners and Beth Israel Medical Center communities extend their condolences to our esteemed colleague and dear friend Harris Nagler, MD, Chairman of the Sol and Margaret Berger Department of Urology, over the death of his beloved sister, Dr. Lauren Nagler. Our sympathy is extended to the entire Nagler family and all of Lauren's loved ones. Stanley Brezenoff President & CEO, Continuum David Shulkin, MD President, Beth Israel Louise Klebanoff, MD President, Medical Board

KATZMAN--Anita Butensky, died peacefully in Seattle, WA on January 17 at the end of a long walk with Alzheimer's, accompanied at the end by cancer. She was three weeks short of her 89th birthday. Anita was a renaissance woman--a published author, political activist, women's rights advocate, PR director, patron of the arts, real-estate investor, supporter and activist in community and Jewish organizations, mother and grandmother. Anita was born in New York in 1920 to Louis Butensky, co-founder of National Auto Rental , a major NY truck leasing firm, and Sylvia Fox. Raised in Brooklyn, she was a graduate of Erasmus Hall High School and NYU. She met and married Nathan (Nat) Katzman during World War II. They lived much of their married life in New Rochelle, NY where they raised their four children. Nathan was a leading national figure in the truck leasing industry and long time president of National Auto until his death in 1965. Following his demise Anita moved with her two younger children to Sarasota, Florida where, over the next two decades, she became a pillar of the local community: serving on the boards of the Asolo State Theater, the Selby Library Association, the Jewish Community Council, and the League of Women Voters, amongst others. She was also instrumental in the founding of The Women's Resource Center, A Woman's Place halfway house, and First Step alcohol treatment center. Anita gave unceasingly of her time and resources while continuing to pursue her bliss -writing. Her book, ''My Name is Mary'' was published by Harper & Row during this period. She was named Woman of the Year in Sarasota in 1987 and was featured on the cover of West Coast Woman in 1988. She is survived by her children Mark Katzman, Drew Katzman, Bruce Katzman, Mindi Dupille, her grandchildren Jeffrey, Nathaniel, Natalie, and her stepgrandchildren John David and Margaux. She is dearly missed. Donations in her memory should be directed to the Alzheimer's Association.

RUBENSTEIN--Sylvia, 92, January 20, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Arthur, devoted mother of Helaine Nieder (Joseph), and the late Ruth Bernstein, adored grandmother of Jan, Elizabeth, Alan, Anne, David, Laura and great-grandmother to six.

An article on Jan. 11 about the options and possible reactions of the United States if Pakistan's nuclear weapons fell into the hands of jihadists misstated part of the name of an American military unit that has run simulated responses to such an event. It is the Joint Special Operations Command, not the Joint Special Forces Command.

ELSBERG--Ted. Born December 1, 1931. Died January 17, 2009. Adored husband of Adrienne, beloved father of Karen (Jonathan) Mendez and of David (Natalie) Elsberg, cherished grandfather of Payton, Brett and Dylan Mendez and of Benjamin and Laura Elsberg, dearest brother-in-law of Mel Wichter, precious brother of Marilyn Butchen and esteemed friend to many. Former captain of the Erasmus Hall High School basketball team, former captain of the New York University basketball team, former president of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, former president of the American Federation of School Administrators. A man of illustrious and unique accomplishments. His death brings us unbearable sorrow. Memories of him will bring us joy forever.

Antigua Antigua has long been synonymous with tucked-away upscale resorts like Jumby Bay and the newer Hermitage Bay, where rates can run $500 to $1,000 a night. But the island's vibe is actually more natural than showy, and there is a variety of more affordable lodging options, from budget guesthouses to small inns, including in the popular Dickenson Bay and English Harbour areas. So the rest of us can enjoy this gem of a Leeward Island as much as the Oprahs and Claptons of the world do.

DODGE--David Stuart, 86, of Princeton, NJ, died peacefully Tuesday, January 20, 2009, of cancer. Beloved husband of Margaret White Dodge; Cherished father of Nina Dodge, Bayard and Paula Dodge, Melissa Dodge and Mark Rutherford, and Simon Dodge, and stepfather of Dr. Richard and Mary White, Jr., John E. White, and Lee and Sergio Galvis; Loving grandfather of Bayard and Andrew Dodge and Sarah and William Rutherford, and his eight step-grandchildren; Devoted husband of the late Doris (Westfall) Dodge and brother of Grace Dodge Guthrie. He was predeceased by his sister Margaret Garrett and his brother Bayard Dodge. A Memorial service will be held 11am, January 31, 2009 at the Princeton University Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American University of Beirut: 3 Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10017.
Film Stephen Holden

LAST April, The Times published an investigation of a Pentagon public relations program intended to win favorable coverage of the Bush administration's war on terror through retired officers working as military analysts on television. The report, ''Behind TV Analysts, Pentagon's Hidden Hand,'' revealed a program that gave the analysts talking points and unusual access to top officials -- contacts, the article said, that some of the officers hoped would benefit military contractors with whom they had ties. Nine days ago, the Defense Department's inspector general concluded that the program did not violate Pentagon policies and regulations, and said investigators found no case in which an officer used information or contacts obtained through the program to get a competitive advantage for a contractor.

MASSEY--Ruth Leah, writer and photographer, passed away peacefully at home on January 4, 2009. Born in Marienbad, she worked for the UN and UNDP. Her work took her around the world, photographing and writing about developmental projects. Beautiful in mind and spirit, devoted friend and loving mother, she will be missed by many. She is survived by her daughter, China Jorrin. Donations can be made in her memory to Doctors Without Borders.

ADAM--Alexander Jay 11/84--1/25/07 (www.alexadam.com) Darling Al/m, It has been two years since you lost your fight with Ewings Sarcoma. How we long for beautiful, bright, kind, complicated, wickedly funny you. It was astonishing how you bumbled masterfully through life, somehow always getting exactly what you wanted. You faced the hideous pain and indignity of cancer with deep grace and boundless courage. In the very face of death you made us laugh. Irreverent you would be pleased to know that we have, as you wanted, established The Alex Adam Award at Princeton, for the ''most talented undergrad with the worst GPA''. You would have won it in a heartbeat. With love, Mom and Dad, Nick and Dash.
GOLDMACHER--Joel. We mourn the loss of Joel Goldmacher, beloved husband of Judi, father to Neil, Jonathan and Tracey. Grandfather to Andie, Laine, Evan and Matthew. We will miss you.

BEFORE starting their new line, Alex & Eli, Anna Zeman and Aja Singer believed there were only two options when it came to women's suits: Yves Saint Laurent, which was the unobtainable ideal; or ''low-rise pants with a wide tab and pinstripes,'' as Ms. Zeman derisively put it. ''There was a need for beautiful suiting that was effortless and distinctive,'' she said. ''That you could feel like yourself in. And be able to afford.'' Alex & Eli fills that void. The label's first collection includes high-waist, lightweight wool trousers and cigarette pants, slouchy jersey tank tops and smoking jackets intelligently designed with removable sleeves -- all in chic, sun-bleached desert tones, with prices that peak at $480. Consider it your third option.
Television Ginia Bellafante

OUTPOSTS Taking the oath of office on Lincoln's leather-bound Bible, in a capital partly built by slaves, Barack Obama was a man in a hurry in an hour of peril. In that spirit, he was a man who had already memorized a few lines that another had not. Thus, he moved quickly, in an 18-minute speech, to the theme that will carry or break the new president: sacrifice. The easy, the lazy, the days of quick riches and shortcuts, of excuses personal and political -- over, he declared.

SCHNEER--Charles H.,Film producer, has died at age 88 in Boca Raton, Florida, January 21, 2009. A graduate of Columbia University, he was introduced to filmmaking when inducted into the Signal Corps making training films during World War II. After working with Universal Pictures and Columbia Pictures he became an independent producer of films of varied genres. A creative and highly disciplined filmmaker and longtime resident of London, England during his production years, he collaborated with Ray Harryhausen in creating many fantasy and adventure films which used stop motion photography. Among his films, which were milestones unique to their time, are The Seventh Voyage of Sinbad, Mysterious Island, Jason and the Argonauts, The Three Worlds of Gulliver, First Men in the Moon and, his last film, Clash of the Titans. He was an active member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and was Chairman of the London Events Committee from 1989-1998. An avid tennis player, he was a member of The Queens Club in London for over 40 years. He charmed and delighted those who knew him well. He will be missed and remembered. For over 68 years until his death, he was the beloved husband to his wife Shirley Sussman Schneer and was the respected and beloved father to his three daughters, Lesley Silver, Stacey Lee and Bettine Greifer (deceased). He is also survived and loved by his three grandchildren Ben Lawrence, Jenessa Freid and Jared Lee and by his four great - grandchildren Jack Lawrence, Daniel Lawrence, Grayson Freid and Beckett Freid. He also leaves a sister Babette Schneer Katz who resides in Mamaroneck, NY. In lieu of other forms of remembrance, donations may be made to the Mayo Clinic Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, c/o Department of Development, Mayo Clinic, 200 First St. SW, Rochester, MN 55905

OLSON--Jesse. The officers and staff of 1199 SEIU, United Healthcare Workers East, mourn the January 19 death of former Exec. VP Jesse Olson. Olson personified the dedication and commitment of the inspired generation that built our union. He was a key leader in the union's growth from a 5,000-member New York City pharmacy union in 1959 to what is now a 300,000member health care union ranging from Massachusetts to Maryland. For several decades Olson was one of the central figures assisting 1199 founder Leon Davis in the union's rapid growth. As head of the union's professional and technical division, he led in organizing and dramatically improving the salaries and benefits of 30,000 New York City health care workers ranging from x-ray techs to switchboard operators. Born in Manhattan in 1924, Olson served in the U.S. Navy in World War II. He joined 1199 in 1948 as a pharmacist and became an active shop steward. When the union began a major organizing drive in New York's hospitals in 1959, Olson took a pay cut of $65 a week to join the union staff as an organizer. He later said he did it in order to do ''Gods work'' by helping organize exploited hospital employees who were then called New York's ''forgotten workers.'' When he retired in 1998 after a 50-year union career, Olson said he was proud of assembling a top notch staff of dedicated organizers and of participating in the union's civil rights activities. He was part of the union honor guard defending Paul Robeson in the great singer's violence marred 1949 concert in Peekskill, NY, joined civil rights marchers in Selma, AL in 1965, and was able to vote for Barack Obama last November. Olson, 84, died near his home in Cranbury, NJ. Survivors include his wife of 58 years, Adele; children Paul and Nina; and two grandchildren. George Gresham, President Maria Castaneda, Secretary Treasurer

''We are certainly in the midst of a once-in-a-lifetime set of economic conditions.'' Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, after the company announced the first broad layoffs in its history. It plans to lay off 5,000 of its 94,000 employees over the next 18 months.

MYERS--Wayne Alan, an eminent psychiatrist, psychoanalyst, and beloved husband and father died from lung cancer on Friday January 16, 2009. At the time of his death he was tended to by his devoted wife of forty years, Joanne, his daughter Tracy, his son Blake and his daughter-in-law Susan Grobman. Dr. Myers is also survived by his son-in-law Harris Fishman, and three grandchildren: Wyatt, Charlotte and Sophie. Emeritus Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical College and a Training and Supervising Analyst at The Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, Wayne Myers was a prolific contributor to his field. He published five books, including Shrink Dreams, a New York Times notable book in 1992; forty-eight book chapters and articles and nearly fifty reviews, commentaries and letters. His expertise included clinical process and technique, geriatrics and pioneer contributions to the intensive treatment of the aged, and studies in applied analysis and literature. He was an original and lucid thinker whose writings illuminated the clinical work of the residents and psychoanalytic candidates whom he taught and supervised. A superbly empathic and knowledgeable practitioner with a huge private practice, for many years he chaired Columbia's Admissions Service. Wayne Myers was born in New York on December 13, 1931 and graduated from The Bronx High School of Science. He went on to obtain a B.S. Phi Beta Kappa from the University of Arkansas in a mere two years before matriculating at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, where he received his medical degree in 1956. His psychiatric residency at Cornell/New York Hospital was interrupted by service in Korea, where Captain Myers became at twenty-eight Battalion Commander of the Fifteenth Medical Battalion. After completing his training at The New York Psychoanalytic in 1969, he moved on to teach and supervise candidates at Columbia in 1977, where he remained a mainstay until his death. A private service was held for the family and close friends.

WITH his multicolored, multilayered, collagelike spring collections for Louis Vuitton (right) and his own house, Marc Jacobs has revived a kind of Arts and Crafts aesthetic that feels especially fitting. Of particular interest are his belts: sumptuous mishmashes of fabric and skin, color and shine, wide obi wraps and skinny, bauble-festooned cording that allow for D.I.Y. experimentation. Fish that braided Mary McFadden belt from your closet, pick up some inexpensive fabric and wrap them around a structured jacket for a striking new look. From top:

In his first major order of business as the Jets' coach, Rex Ryan finished hiring his coordinators on Saturday. Ryan will retain Brian Schottenheimer as the offensive coordinator, the team confirmed. Schottenheimer was a candidate for the head coaching job that went to Ryan, who persuaded Schottenheimer to stay.

FRISS--Solomon, of Margate, NJ, died on January 22 at age 94. Beloved husband of Ruth (Lieberman), father of Lynn (the late Larry) Feinberg of Piedmont, CA; Abby (Philip) Rogers of Rockville, MD; and Debby (Barry) Scheinholtz of Berkeley Heights, NJ; a brother, Isadore, of Jerusalem, Israel; five grandchildren, Matthew, Jonathan and Benjamin Rogers and Sarah and Eli Scheinholtz, and three step - grandchildren, David, Brian and Stephen Feinberg. He was a 1940 graduate of Harvard Law School and a partner in the law firm of McGahn & Friss in Atlantic City, NJ, for 30 years.

LAFFERTY--Muriel M. We will love and miss you forever. You will never be forgotten. You were a best friend to me and a second mother to Joyce. As you would say ''Grieve not, nor speak of me with tears, but laugh and talk of me as if I were beside you there. I loved you so....Twas Heaven here with you.'' All our love always, Beverly & Joyce Dollinger
To the Editor: Re ''For a Chapel on the Park, the Bell May Soon Toll'' (Jan. 18), about the imminent sale and demolition of the Holy Trinity Chapel and the Catholic Center at New York University:

MIKE FIGGIS, the experimental British filmmaker and photographer, does not know half of the New York notables he shot in and around the Prada SoHo store over the last two weeks -- people like the fashion designer Derek Lam, the Elle editor Anne Slowey and the author Paul Auster (him, he knew). Rather, it was the immediate process of printing the portraits on-site, and displaying them the following day at Milk Gallery, that was most interesting to him. ''Galleries have yet to adapt to today's culture,'' Mr. Figgis said. ''Showing stuff shot years ago in these fantastic frames -- it's wonderful but a little dead. This show has life to it.'' I enjoyed Molly Worthen's portrayal of Mark Driscoll and Seattle's Mars Hill Church (Jan. 11), but I had to laugh at her notion of Calvinism as some fringe element of Christianity. Driscoll and Mars Hill seem solidly aligned with the bulk of evangelical doctrine, and Driscoll's ''hip'' approach to Christianity doesn't put much meaningful distance between him and other American churches that teach the Gospel as outlined in the Bible. As a late-40-something, Midwestern, unstylish, noncussing fellow evangelical Calvinist, I have a word for Driscoll: Preach it, brother.

WHITE--Indrea (nee Kintisch), died January 22, 2009. At peace after a valiant battle with multiple sclerosis and its complications. Loving and beloved mother, motherin-law, grandmother, wife, friend, sister; she gave unstintingly of herself and found joy in all the little things that make life worth while. She was an artist whose paintings brought light into the world, embracing vivid color and images. She had a big laugh and an exuberance for life. We will all miss her. CROSS--Seth, formerly of Southampton and New York City and lately of Larchmont, NY died of complications from lung cancer on January 5, at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle. He was 79 years old. Seth traveled the world while working as a Director of the Polychrome Corporation in Yonkers. A memorial service will be held in April.

DORNBLASER--Mary M. (Hellier), 65, of Marion, MA died unexpectedly on January 3, 2009. She was a graduate of the Kingswood-Oxford School and Sweetbriar College where she spent her junior year living in Madrid. A longtime resident of New York City with the exception of 1970--1972 when she lived in Paris, Mimi, as she was known, initially worked as a translator for the Spanish government. She later became Special Events Director and Executive Assistant to Phillips Talbot of the Asia Society until his retirement. While with the society, she was a member of a delegation representing the Ford administration on a trade mission to China. She was a member of The Colony. Mimi is survived by her husband, George, a step-daughter, Sarah of New York City, a niece Sally Thomas of Toccoa, GA, and a nephew, Ted Hellier and his wife Susan of South Portland, ME as well as a grand-niece and several grand-nephews. Mimi would have appreciated it that any donations made on her behalf be sent to the Kingswood-Oxford School, West Hartford, CT. A memorial service will be held in Marion during the spring. Interment will be private.

DeWITT--Eugene (Gene) A.,passed away early Thursday morning after a four-year battle with cancer. He was a devoted husband to Dianne DeWitt, father to Kate DeWitt and his four step-daughters and their husbands, Anna and Andrew Silverman, Stacey and Remy Bertin, Elexis and Christopher Lewis, and Jacqueline Mariash. He was also a caring and giving grandfather to Cooper Silverman. Gene was a graduate of Tufts University, and for more than 40 years built a well-respected career in marketing advertising and media strategy advising some of the worlds largest and smartest advertisers on how to develop and implement breakthrough communications strategies. Along the way, Gene worked with AT&T, BMW, British Airways, Coca-Cola, Chrysler, Discovery Channels, DuPont, General Electric, General Motors, Johnson & Johnson, L'Oreal, McDonald's, Pepsi Cola, Sears and The Wall Street Journal. Gene was also an avid supporter and contributor to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Manhattan Theatre Club, The Metropolitan Opera and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations be given to Saint Bartholomews Church by visiting www.stbarts.org/donation .asp or by calling 212-378-0222. Services will be held at Saint Bartholomews Church on Park Avenue between 50th and 51st Street on Tuesday, January 27 at 3pm. Gene's loss will be deeply felt. With all our love.

STERN--Barbara, esteemed Professor of Marketing at Rutgers University, Dr. Stern passed away peacefully on January 15. She is survived by her mother Rose, sister Carole, and daughters Leslie and Wendy. Donations in her memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York at www.vnsny.org.

DODGE--David S. The Board of Trustees of the American University of Beirut (AUB) regrets the death of former President and Trustee Emeritus David S. Dodge, a longtime friend of the University whose family has led AUB for generations. Born in Beirut in 1922, Mr. Dodge was the son of former AUB President Bayard Dodge, the grandson of former President Howard Bliss, and the great-grandson of Daniel Bliss, who founded AUB in 1866. ''His personal and professional dedication to the University went deep to his core, and his kindness and generosity touched anyone who was fortunate enough to work with him,'' said Dr. Thomas Q. Morris, chair of the AUB Board of Trustees. Mr. Dodge was elected to the Board of Trustees in 1961, and served as acting president (1981-1982) until he was taken hostage in Lebanon and held for one year. He resumed his activities with the board in 1983 and served as president of the University in 1996-1997. He was a former president of both the Near East Foundation and the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation and a devoted alumnus of Princeton University. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to AUB in Mr. Dodge's memory. Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Chair, Board of Trustees Peter F. Dorman, Ph.D., President, AUB

DELANEY--Martin. The board of trustees and staff of amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, mourn the passing of our longtime friend and colleague Martin Delaney. The founder of Project Inform, a pioneering HIV/AIDS treatment education and advocacy organization, Mr. Delaney was a towering figure in the fight against AIDS. His courageous and intelligent leadership was instrumental in accelerating the approval and delivery of lifesaving treatment for countless people living with HIV/AIDS. In 2001, Mr. Delaney was a richly deserving recipient of amfAR's Award of Courage. He was an inspiration to us all and will be greatly missed. Kenneth Cole, Chairman of the Board, Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chairman, and Kevin Robert Frost, Chief Executive Officer.

BLUMBERG--Gerald. The leadership, staff, and global community of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourn the passing of our dear and most beloved friend, Gerald Blumberg. Jerry was dedicated to the Weizmann Institute both in spirit and in deed, professionally and personally. Jerry's work as an attorney led him to the Weizmann Institute, but in the more than 35 years that followed, it was Jerry himself who took the lead. As an authority in estate planning and charitable giving, Jerry lent his legal expertise to the American Committee. He was a former American Committee Vice President, an Honorary Vice Chairman, and a member of the President's Circle; he was also a Governor Emeritus of the Weizmann Institute. In him, the Weizmann Institute found a transformational figure whose passion would be inherited by his son, Larry-who now serves as the American Committee's National Chairman. Jerry's three decades of involvement embodied and fueled inspiration and innovation, now passed down from generation to generation. His legacy will forever be felt, and his spirit lives on through his children and grandchildren. We send heartfelt condolences to Jerry's wife, Rhoda, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Exec. V.P. & CEO American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute

ELKIND--Rodney Lincoln, on January 20, 2009. Rod was born on February 12, 1917, in New York City. After attending Cornell and the University of Florida, Rod married Bunny Halwer in 1942. They were a devoted couple for the next 66 years until her passing. After military service in WWII, Rod and Bunny lived in Manhattan, where they were early members of the Stuyvesant Town community. Rod became an export executive, traveling the world on business in the 1950's, 1960's and 1970's, an era when travel in South America, Eastern Europe, India, and Asia was far more adventurous than today. But the main focus of Rod's life was his marriage and family. Rod and Bunny were inseparable; in later years she even accompanied him on his business trips overseas. They enjoyed the theater, bridge, and spending time with their many dear friends. After retiring in the early 1980's they continued to enjoy those relationships at Heritage Village in Southbury, Connecticut, and in West Palm Beach, Florida. Rod particularly enjoyed being part of local theater productions and poetry readings. With his deep, mellifluous voice, many thought he might have had a career as a professional singer. In 2006 Rod and Bunny moved to Oak Tree Villa, in Scotts Valley California, where Rod passed away just a few weeks before his 92nd birthday. Along with his marvelous baritone, Rod will be remembered by all who loved him for his kindness and generosity of spirit. Always the first to reach out a hand to those in need, he could always be counted on to come through when his friends or family needed help or support. He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Dr. Les Elkind and Francine Genta of Santa Cruz, California, grandchildren Maren Giuliano, Gabriel Browne, Joshua DeCristo, and Laughlin Elkind, nephew Larry Elkind, of Hollywood, Florida, and a growing number of great-grandchildren. He will always be remembered by his many friends and family as a wonderful husband and father, and a decent, kind and loving soul.

THE 10 Filipino nurses were branded by the Suffolk County, N.Y., district attorney as derelict in their duties, accused of abandoning five chronically ill children, four of whom were on ventilators, and one terminally ill man by quitting their jobs in 2006 in a labor dispute. But in a strongly worded ruling, a New York State appeals court, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, has barred District Attorney Thomas J. Spota from prosecuting the nurses and said that he had joined with their employers in forcing them into ''involuntary servitude'' by using criminal sanction to force them to work against their will, thus violating the nurses' constitutional rights.

FLETCHER--Roland (Flick), 85, of Topsham and Center Lovell, ME, and formerly of Bronxville, NY died January 14, 2009 following a brief illness. He attended Loomis, Amherst, Yale, and Columbia Dental School. For 39 years, he had a highly successful dental practice in Rockefeller Center. After retiring, he volunteered for local hospitals and pursued his passions of fly fishing, golf, gardening, genealogy and history. He is survived by his children, Louise, Gregory, and Bennett, Bennett's wife and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mid Coast Hospital, Brunswick, ME 04011.

BLUMBERG--Gerald, 97, died at home on Friday, January 23, 2009 of no apparent cause except old age. Born and raised in Far Rockaway, Jerry was an academic star: Far Rockaway High School (1927), Cornell University (Phi Beta Kappa 1931) and Harvard Law School (1934). Three years later, following a stint at the Depression-era New York State Mortgage Commission, he boldly opened an independent law office. As a lawyer, Jerrry revealed in complex challenges. He was a superb dealmaker, negotiator and advisor, and many of his clients became his closest friends. In 1977, his son Larry joined him in practice, fulfilling a lifelong dream of both father and son. The law firm, Gerald & Lawrence Blumberg, LLP, celebrated its 30th anniversary last year. Jerry was never pretentious, and had a great sense of humor, equally enjoying being the perpetrator or the butt of practical jokes. He loved Faraway Farm, home for nearly 60 years, particularly his red clay tennis court, where he played with gusto. From age 80, he swore by his indoor lap pool, where he spent many hours swimming against the current until well into his 90's. Jerry believed in philanthropy and devoted over 35 years of service to Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science, and he passed these values to his children and grandchildren. Most of all, Jerry was in love with and devoted to Rhoda, to whom he was married for 64 years. Nothing in life gave him more happiness and pride than her success as an award-winning author of young adult non-fiction literature. Jerry is survived by Rhoda, four children and their spouses: Larry (Robin Lynn), Rena, Alice (David Rubin) and Leda (Steve Cole), nine grandchildren and spouses: Bill Gottlieb (Emily), Daniel Blumberg, Carla Steckman (David), Gregory Rubin, Ilana Blumberg, Dana Volk, Osheana TashombeBlumberg, Amalia Rubin and Eliza Volk, and by two greatgrandchildren: Benjamin and Samantha Gottlieb, and his sister, Zelda Blechman. Funeral services will be on Monday, January 26th at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, 31 Glengary Road, Croton - on - Hudson, New York. Donations in Jerry's memory may be made to the American Committee for the Weizman Institute of Science, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

On his first radio broadcast after a 12-week suspension, the British talk-show host Jonathan Ross once again provoked the ire of listeners, the BBC reported. In October, Mr. Ross and the comedian Russell Brand set off a controversy now known as Sachsgate when they left a series of lewd messages on the answering machine of the actor Andrew Sachs during a radio show hosted by Mr. Brand. After a public outcry, Mr. Brand resigned, and Mr. Ross was suspended from shows he hosted on BBC1 and Radio 2. On Sunday, during Mr. Ross’s return radio broadcast, his co-host Andy Davies told a story about an affectionate Spanish neighbor, and Mr. Ross said that Mr. Davies should give the woman “one last night before the grave.” The remark was criticized in the British media but in a statement, the BBC said the broadcast “contained no offensive language, named no individuals and there was clearly no intention to offend anyone.”

In a turn of events almost as thrilling as winning the 20-million rupee prize on an Indian game show, the cast of “Slumdog Millionaire” received the Screen Actors Guild’s award for outstanding performance by a motion picture cast at a ceremony on Sunday night. The award, received by cast members Dev Patel, Anil Kapoor, Irrfan Khan and Freida Pinto, is likely to boost the film’s fortunes at the Academy Awards; “Slumdog Millionaire” and its director, Danny Boyle, were both nominated for Oscars on Thursday. The television series “30 Rock” was honored by the guild for best comedy ensemble, and “Mad Men” won best drama ensemble. Sean Penn was named best lead actor in a motion picture for “Milk,” Meryl Streep was chosen best lead actress for “Doubt,” and Heath Ledger was honored as best supporting actor for his performance in “The Dark Knight.”
FULL STORY: ‘The Graveyard Book’ Wins Newbery Medal

The Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists said in a statement that they have agreed to guidelines under which they will work together on negotiations with the advertising industry. The two unions had fallen out over separate negotiations with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents the Hollywood film and television studios. AFTRA agreed to a new contract with the producers’ alliance in July, around the same time that SAG’s talks with the producers collapsed. SAG is still without a film and television contract, and its membership continues to wrestle with the possibility of a strike. The contract that governs SAG and AFTRA members’ work in television and radio commercials is to expire on March 31; the unions are scheduled to return to negotiations with commercial producers on Feb. 23.

Sara Nelson, the editor in chief of Publishers Weekly, the main trade magazine to the book industry, has been laid off in a restructuring by the publication’s parent company, Reed Business Information.

For months, theatergoers have clamored for new blood on Broadway, and now they’re going to get it. The Nederlander Organization said in a statement that it had acquired the rights to produce a musical based on the Michael Jackson album “Thriller” and its groundbreaking video, in which the King of Pop transforms into a werewolf while he’s on a date. The production will feature songs from the “Thriller” album as well as Mr. Jackson’s record “Off the Wall.” Mr. Jackson is expected to participate in the musical’s creation. In a statement, James L. Nederlander, the president of the Nederlander Organization, said, “I love the idea of making ‘Thriller’ a musical. Girl meets boy, they fall in love, boy has big secret, now what…” A creative team for “Thriller the Musical” was not announced.

G. Wayne Clough was officially installed as the 12th secretary of the Smithsonian Institution on Monday at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian in Washington, D.C. Dr. Clough, a former president of the Georgia Institute of Technology, took over as secretary in July. Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., who serves as chancellor of the Smithsonian, presented Dr. Clough with a ceremonial brass key. Discussing the fact that the secretary receives a key instead of taking an oath, Mr. Roberts joked, “I don’t know who decided that, but I’m happy about it.” Dr. Clough delivered an address during the ceremony, which also included an academic procession. At a meeting earlier in the day, the Smithsonian’s governing board of regents voted to approve a revised request for information policy consistent with the principles of the Freedom of Information Act.

A new documentary on competition and exploration in the warming Arctic.

I may have to get out my heavy gear again. I've been to the Arctic three times for the newspaper since 2003 -- visiting the North Slope, North Pole, and Greenland to examine what mix of human and natural forces is driving the warming and ice retreats and the implications of having increasing amounts of open water in summers in a region increasingly seen as a resource trove and shortcut for shipping. But the stories are coming fast and furious, and they are as much about geopolitics as geoscience.

Since I began the road to recovery from alcoholism a decade and a half ago, people have frequently asked me how I have changed. I tell them that the process of recovering from an addiction is a kind of moral de- and reconstruction. You tear yourself apart, examine each individual piece, toss out the useless, rehabilitate the useful and put your moral self back together again.

Every generation has a tendency to fret about changing moral values and risky behavior among young people. The myth and the reality of teen sexual behavior is the topic of my Well column in Tuesday's Science Times. Despite lots of media hype about an epidemic of oversexed teens, the truth is that today's teenagers often are more conservative about sex than previous generations.

Even though venture capitalists raised $28 billion in 2008 to invest in new start-ups, they are holding that money tight. Venture investing slowed to a crawl in 2008, the first year since 2003 that total investments declined. When investors did decide to dole out dollars, they were more likely than not to invest in green technology start-ups.

Just when Jack Flack thought John A. Thain was going to go down as the best-scrubbed, crisply parted scapegoat in the history of Wall Street, the Mechanical One stood up for himself. The move was wise. If Kenneth D. Lewis also crashes at Bank of America, Mr. Thain's legacy will very likely be upgraded to that of a tone-deaf bot who was caught up in another one of those big, complicated financial messes that nobody really understands.

The down-spiraling economy has disrupted the plans of the strategists at Google; profit has fallen, staff has been reduced around the world, and earlier this month, the search engine giant elected to slam the door on the Google Notebook, its cloud-computing site for saving data culled from the Web.

Texas Instruments announced across-the-board losses and employee layoffs on Monday. One of the areas hardest hit was the division that creates the DLP technology used in most rear-projection TVs. Revenue in that group, which also includes calculators and microprocessors, dropped 30 percent and profit dropped 70 percent.

Generally, in computer-speak, added features equals higher prices. In the case of the low-end MacBook, however, Apple Computer may have found it to be cost-efficient to upgrade the components while maintaining the price point.

Verizon has announced that will offer a home cellphone booster, called a femtocell, that will compete with Airave from Sprint and HotSpot@Home from T-Mobile. AT&T hasn't announced it, but it is preparing a similar product, currently called the 3G Microcell.

It was not so long ago that most mainstream marketers steered clear of sponsoring television programming that tackled the contentious subject of the lives of gay men and lesbians. Large national advertisers, seeking to avoid alienating or offending mass audiences, would shy from buying commercial time during such shows. That left the slots to be filled with spots from companies that care less about the content of the programs in which they pitch products - or not filled at all.

PARIS -- Sunday in Paris was the night to be out. Men's fashion week came to a close at Club Sandwich, a monthly down-and-dirty party held at Club Neo in the Eighth Arrondissement. Tout le fashion crowd was out letting loose -- deadlines be damned -- as were random bedazzled boys, drag queens and one or two porn stars. But even among the poseurs, the person who received the most attention was Casey Spooner, the Fischerspooner frontman.

Pfizer's $68 billion deal to buy the rival drug maker Wyeth ranks among the largest pharmaceutical deals of all time. Update | 12:14 p.m. Perhaps the most interesting thing about Dow Chemical's press release Monday is that it makes no legal argument for the delay in closing its Rohm & Haas deal. The Dutch financial services company, ING Groep, which took an injection of 10 billion euros last year during the financial meltdown has today announced that it has posted its second quarterly loss in a row, this time for 3.3 billion euros. The company will also tap into 22 billion euros of Dutch state loan guarantees for its troubled loan portfolio, Reuters reported.

Lance Armstrong departed Australia confident that the two key areas of his comeback were on track. Armstrong, the seven-time Tour de France winner, finished 29th over all in the Tour Down Under. He was 49 seconds behind the winner, Allan Davis of Australia, but said he was satisfied with his ability to keep up with top riders after three and a half years out of professional cycling. Armstrong, 37, told reporters that his fitness was more advanced at this stage of the season than at any time in his career and that after his time away, he still has the legs to match younger riders. He also said that his quest for an eighth win in the Tour de France in July this year, the competitive goal of his comeback, was “right on line.”.

SMITH--William B. Rt. Rev. Msgr, STD; of Yonkers on January 24, 2009. Ordained May 28, 1966 from St. Joseph's Seminary. Son of the late George F. and Helen O'Connell Smith, brother of the late James T. and George M. Smith, uncle to James T. Smith, Jr. and George F.X. Smith, brother-in-law of Anita G. Smith and Betty Smith. Graduated from Xavier H.S. and Cathedral College. Msgr. Smith served as a Professor of Moral Theology at St. Joseph's Seminary since 1971. He also served on the Board of Ethics of St. Vincent's Hospital; Board of Trustees of Calvary Hospital; was the Chaplain to Missionaries of Charities in the South Bronx; was a member of the Fellowship of Catholic Scholars (President 1981-1983); celebrated Sunday Mass at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale for many years. Calling hours are between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Monday and 2 to 4pm Tuesday at St. Joseph's Seminary. Mass of The High Priest 7:30pm Tuesday at St. Joseph's Seminary. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday January 28 at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Joseph's Seminary or Calvary Hospital.

Stung by criticism after vandals changed Wikipedia entries to erroneously report that two United States senators, Edward M. Kennedy and Robert C. Byrd, had died, the online encyclopedia appears ready to introduce a system that prevents new and anonymous users from instantly publishing changes. The idea is that only registered, reliable users would have the right to have their material immediately appear to the general public visiting Wikipedia. Other contributors would be able to edit articles, but their changes will be held back until one of these reliable users has signed off, or flagged the revisions. (Registered, reliable users would see the latest edit to an article, whether flagged or not.)

BLUMBERG--Gerald. Gerald & Lawrence Blumberg, LLP, notes with sorrow the death of our founding partner and mentor. Jerry defined himself as a ''Counsellor at Law'', avoiding narrow specialization. Since he established the practice in 1937, clients were attracted by his intense focus, breadth of knowledge, creativity and sense of humor. He instilled in us what a privilege and responsibility it is to be our clients' trusted advisor. We have all benefitted from and will miss Jerry's sage advice and friendship.

DeWITT--Eugene (Gene) A.,passed away early Thursday morning after a four-year battle with cancer. He was a devoted husband to Dianne DeWitt, father to Kate DeWitt and his four step-daughters and their husbands, Anna and Andrew Silverman, Stacey and Remy Bertin, Elexis and Christopher Lewis, and Jacqueline Mariash. He was also a caring and giving grandfather to Cooper Silverman. Gene was a graduate of Tufts University, and for more than 40 years built a well-respected career in marketing advertising and media strategy advising some of the worlds largest and smartest advertisers on how to develop and implement breakthrough communications strategies. Along the way, Gene worked with AT&T, BMW, British Airways, Coca-Cola, Chrysler, Discovery Channels, DuPont, General Electric, General Motors, Johnson & Johnson, L'Oreal, McDonald's, Pepsi Cola, Sears and The Wall Street Journal. Gene was also an avid supporter and contributor to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Manhattan Theatre Club, The Metropolitan Opera and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations be given to Saint Bartholomews Church by visiting www.stbarts.org/donation .asp or by calling 212-378-0278. Services will be held at Saint Bartholomews Church on Park Avenue between 50th and 51st Street on Tuesday, January 27 at 3pm. Gene's loss will be deeply felt. With all our love.

ZANE--Jerome, D.D.S. AKA ''Papa Jerry,'' will be remember as a man of abundant good humor, adored by his students, colleagues, staff, family, and all who have had the good fortune to have known him. Our deepest sympathies to his immediate and extended families. Alan Wasserman and the Staff at 550

MOYLAN--Thomas J.,a bon vivant and lover of all things Irish. Predeceased by his life partner, David Conroy. We had the good fortune of knowing him for 35 years and of being introduced to the ''Old Sod'' by Tom. We loved and will miss him. Madeline and Harold Wohl

A five-year-old online prank that mocked former President George W. Bush pointed its snarkiness at President Obama last week as he was sworn in as president. If you searched ''failure,'' on Google, or ''miserable failure'' on Yahoo's or Microsoft's search engines on Friday, the top result you were likely to get was a link to the biography of President Obama on the official Whitehouse.gov Web site. Before the inauguration, those searches linked to President Bush's biography on the site.

President Barack Obama and his top advisers sought over the weekend to broaden the appeal of his proposed $825 billion economic-stimulus package and to defend the way they are pushing it through Congress. But some senior Republicans said Sunday that as the stimulus plan stands, they would oppose it. The new administration has begun a campaign to build momentum behind the economic-stimulus plan and propel it to passage by mid-February. The White House released a report Saturday revealing details about the package, which would pay for a variety of projects, like laying 3,000 miles of transmission lines for a national electric grid, securing 90 major ports and guaranteeing health insurance for 8.5 million Americans in danger of losing coverage.

The time-tested way for governments to create jobs in a hurry is to pour money into old-fashioned public works projects like roads and bridges. President Obama's economic recovery plan will do that, but it also has some ambitious 21st century twists. The $825 billion stimulus plan presented this month by House Democrats called for $37 billion in spending in three high-tech areas: $20 billion to computerize medical records, $11 billion to create smarter electrical grids and $6 billion to expand high-speed Internet access in rural and underserved communities.
NEW YORK DAYBOOK

CONNOLLY--Leonard J.,Esq., for Lattingtown, LI suddenly on January 24th, 2009, age 71. Beloved husband to Janet nee Maroney, loving father to Deirdre (Hamish Norton), Ursula (Bill Weiss), Janet (Kaj Gyr) and Annie (Chris Lodge). Proud grandfather of William, Nina, Wilson, Blair, Dylan, Oliver, Angus, Graham and Marina. After graduating from St. Francis College and Cornell Law School, Len spent his entire career as a corporate attorney in NYC, first with Olwine Connelly Chase O'Donnell and Weyer and then with Dechert, LLP. After his retirement he became an adjunct professor of law at Hoftsra Law School. In the last few years he conducted a well regarded seminar on Corporate Governance. In addition to his legal work, Len had a general interest in reading, writing, politics, and his emails to family and friends were amusing and delightful to read. Len served the Village of Lattingtown as Village Justice for many years and participated in the State Magistrates Association. He also served the Homeowners Association, Lattingtown Harbor Association, for a term as Treasurer and also as General Advisor. He was a member of the Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club and was, until a few years ago and enthusiastic ice dancer, a tennis player and a roller blader. He was still able to enjoy ballroom dancing and biking. Len was admired for his wonderful sense of humor, his intelligence, and his sense of fair play. His family will miss him terribly. Visitation at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas, 26 Franklin Avenue, Glen Cove, Tuesday 2-4 and 79pm. Mass at the Church of St. Patrick Wednesday 11am. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

GELLMAN--Yale, born September 16, 1934 died peacefully January 24, 2009, was a longtime resident of Great Neck, NY. He was born in Yonkers and grew up in the Bronx where he graduated as valedictorian of Evander Childs High School. He went on to graduate Phi Beta Kappa from NYU earning a full scholarship to Harvard Law School where he obtained a J.D. degree. He retired as a partner of Proskauer Rose LLP. He is survived by his beloved family: Estelle, his wife; Douglas, Russel and Beth, his children; Alexandra, his granddaughter; and his beloved sister Theodora ''Doris'' Yudin. Before the advent of the digital camera, Polaroid reigned supreme when it came to photographs you could view in an instant. When the company announced last year that it would cease film production and abandon the technology that made it famous, the format seemed doomed to disappear. Now a group of Polaroid enthusiasts is trying to create an entirely new instant film product, compatible with Polaroid cameras, that would keep the medium alive.

BLUMBERG--Gerald, 97, died at home on Friday, January 23, 2009 of no apparent cause except old age. Born and raised in Far Rockaway, Jerry was an academic star: Far Rockaway High School (1927), Cornell University (Phi Beta Kappa 1931) and Harvard Law School (1934). Three years later, following a stint at the Depression-era New York State Mortgage Commission, he boldly opened an independent law office. As a lawyer, Jerrry revealed in complex challenges. He was a superb dealmaker, negotiator and advisor, and many of his clients became his closest friends. In 1977, his son Larry joined him in practice, fulfilling a lifelong dream of both father and son. The law firm, Gerald & Lawrence Blumberg, LLP, celebrated its 30th anniversary last year. Jerry was never pretentious, and had a great sense of humor, equally enjoying being the perpetrator or the butt of practical jokes. He loved Faraway Farm, home for nearly 60 years, particularly his red clay tennis court, where he played with gusto. From age 80, he swore by his indoor lap pool, where he spent many hours swimming against the current until well into his 90's. Jerry believed in philanthropy and devoted over 35 years of service to Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science, and he passed these values to his children and grandchildren. Most of all, Jerry was in love with and devoted to Rhoda, to whom he was married for 64 years. Nothing in life gave him more happiness and pride than her success as an award-winning author of young adult non-fiction literature. Jerry is survived by Rhoda, four children and their spouses: Larry (Robin Lynn), Rena, Alice (David Rubin) and Leda (Steve Cole), nine grandchildren and spouses: Bill Gottlieb (Emily), Daniel Blumberg, Carla Steckman (David), Gregory Rubin, Ilana Blumberg, Dana Volk, Osheana TashombeBlumberg, Amalia Rubin and Eliza Volk, and by two greatgrandchildren: Benjamin and Samantha Gottlieb, and his sister, Zelda Blechman. Funeral services will be on Monday, January 26th at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, 31 Glengary Road, Croton - on - Hudson, New York. Donations in Jerry's memory may be made to the American Committee for the Weizman Institute of Science, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

In a crisis, calls for loose rules now seem dangerous, outdated and unsafe. The road back will be a long one.

There was plenty of talk in Davos last year about the state of the private equity industry, which was reeling after the end of a long boom.

Banks are hoarding their capital — we’ve known that since the credit crisis began in August 2007. It turned into an economic crisis because executives in the rest of the economy — media companies, machine tool makers and chemical manufacturers — started doing the same.

Mr. Wen will be in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday to address the annual winter meeting of the World Economic Forum while China will be carrying on with the weeklong celebration of its most important holiday, the Lunar New Year.

Many of the participants at the World Economic Forum will be thinking about big, global solutions to the current financial mess. But should they also be thinking small?

Rebecca Saletan, the former publisher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Books, who resigned from that job in December, will join Riverhead Books as its editorial director, Riverhead said. Ms. Saletan, a veteran editor who has worked on books including Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “It Takes a Village” and Mohsin Hamid’s “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” stepped down from Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, the publisher of Philip Roth and Günter Grass among other authors, on Dec. 10. A week earlier, the publisher temporarily stopped acquiring new books after its parent company, Education Media and Publishing Group, said it would not allocate as much money to its consumer books. At Riverhead, a division of Penguin Group whoses authors include Khaled Hosseini, Junot Díaz and Aleksandar Hemon, Ms. Saletan will report to Geoffrey Kloske, the Riverhead publisher. She is scheduled to start on March 2.

The Gus Van Sant film “Milk” was among the five movies nominated by the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation for outstanding wide-release film in its 20th annual media awards. The organization, which said in a release that its awards seek to recognize “fair, accurate and inclusive representations of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community,” also nominated the films “Vicky Cristina Barcelona,” “Brideshead Revisited,” “Nick and Norah’s Infinite Playlist” and “RocknRolla” in this category. The television series “Brothers & Sisters,” “The L Word,” “South of Nowhere,” “Torchwood” and “True Blood” were nominated for outstanding drama, and “Desperate Housewives,” “Greek,” “Reaper,” “Skins” and “Ugly Betty” were nominated for comedy. The winners will be honored a series of ceremonies in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco in the spring.

The Bolshoi Theater has canceled a tour of Mexico and a new production of “Otello” planned for April, citing budget cuts as it faces a financial crisis, Agence France-Presse reported. On Tuesday, the Moscow theater’s general director, Alexei Iksanov, told the newspaper Novye Izvestia that declining oil prices and the devaluation of the ruble would inevitably lead to cuts in the Bolshoi’s budget. “It would be naive to believe that culture will be financed as before,” he said, according to Agence France-Presse, adding, “We need to understand this as something inevitable, without hysteria or panic.” The company is still unable to perform in its historic theater near Red Square, which began a $700 million renovation in 2005 that will likely not be completed until 2011.

The Smithsonian Institution has frozen hiring for its 67 most senior non-federal positions and asked for some departments to consider budget reductions of 5 to 8 percent, its chief executive, G. Wayne Clough, said on Monday. Mr. Clough, who began the job in July and was officially installed as secretary on Monday, instituted the freeze on Jan. 16, and eliminated salary increases and bonuses for those employees. A hiring ban has been in effect since October for Smithsonian workers who are employees of the federal government. Mr. Clough asked the Smithsonian’s offices — not its museums — to report back on the potential impact of the budget reductions by Feb. 6. “He will then decide whether to implement” cuts, said Linda St. Thomas, a Smithsonian spokeswoman. The Smithsonian’s endowment has decreased by 25 percent over the last year to $783 million, and it is grappling with a $2.5 billion cost to maintain and repair its buildings.

Albert Uderzo, the 81-year-old illustrator and co-creator of Astérix, the Gallic cartoon barbarian, has hit back against his daughter’s assertion that he has sold out the popular character, Agence France-Presse reported. Earlier this month, Mr. Uderzo’s daughter, Sylvie, protested his decision to sell a majority stake in his company Albert-Rene, the publisher of the adventures of Astérix, to the French conglomerate Hachette Livre. In a letter to Le Monde, she wrote, “It’s as if the gates of the Gaulish village had been thrown open to the Roman Empire.” (Ms. Uderzo retains a minority stake in Albert-Rene.) In a statement, Mr. Uderzo called his daughter’s accusation “undignified,” adding that it was intended “to insult Astérix readers by confusing my abilities as an author with that of a publishing house shareholder,” according to Agence-France Presse.

Space was supposed to be the final frontier for Gene Roddenberry, but a second portion of the “Star Trek” creator’s remains is now scheduled for a trip into the great unknown, along with the remains of his wife, Majel Barrett Roddenberry, The Associated Press reported. Before her death on Dec. 18, Ms. Roddenberry made arrangements with the company Celestis Inc. to have her cremated remains sent into space in a container with a portion of Mr. Roddenberry’s ashes. Celestis launched some of the remains of Mr. Roddenberry, who died in 1991, into orbit in 1997. A rocket payload carrying the remains of the “Star Trek” actor James Doohan and the astronaut Gordon Cooper on a flight offered by Celestis fell back to earth in 2007, and a second rocket carrying their remains failed to reach orbit in 2008. No date was announced for the launch of the Roddenberrys’ ashes.

Stan Lee, the venerable comics creator, and Marvel Entertainment were among the defendants named in a lawsuit Monday filed by investors who say they are owed profits from movies and other works that feature Marvel characters, The Associated Press reported. The plaintiffs are shareholders in Stan Lee Media Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy in 2006, and they say they are due profits from any properties based on characters that Mr. Lee helped to create, including movies like “Spider-Man,” “X-Men” and “Iron Man.” Mr. Lee has previously sued Marvel for profits generated by his characters, and sued Stan Lee Media for copyright infringement and other claims. In that suit, Mr. Lee’s lawyers said he did not give Stan Lee Media any interests in characters he created for Marvel.

Unplugged and ubiquitous.

I could have stayed and watched the Chanel show again. In theory, anything as repetitive as an all-white fashion show, staged before a white background of paper cutouts, should have been boring. Our brains demand a little more stimulation-because that's what we get most days-and when we see an all-white or all-black show, the effect wears off pretty quickly. But it seems to me that the Chanel show wasn't really about white (or black and white) clothes, any more than it was about paper, although writing paper was Karl Lagerfeld's starting point. The reason I could have stayed for an encore was that the collection expresses perfectly the difference between haute couture and ready-to-wear. Couture offers someone like Lagerfeld the luxury of concentrating on a single idea. The whiteness of the show-the white wool suits edged with tiny white braid, the white plisse chiffon spilling from vented white sleeves, the white plastic flowers embroidered on white silk-reinforced that notion. Lagerfeld was like a fly that dropped onto a leaf and then surveyed all. But the leaf told him everything.

In this publication by the Economic Research Service of the USDA, we learn that raising livestock in the United States is now almost exclusively industrialized and centralized. In studies performed between 1987 and 2002, researchers found that production from larger farms (when compared to small operations) increased by 60 percent in broilers (chickens), 100 percent in cattle, 240 percent in dairy and a whopping 2,000 percent in hogs. "Recent surveys," the report says, "indicate that production has continued to shift to larger operations since 2002."

It's an idea that at first blush seems almost more fantastic than congestion pricing: closing 42nd Street to vehicular traffic from river to river and creating a 2.5-mile street-level light rail line, at a cost of around $500 million, that would ferry passengers across the entire width of Midtown in a mere 21 minutes. But with New York City seeking ways to mitigate congestion, and with the federal government offering infrastructure money to cities, the proponents of the idea hope they will at least get a hearing.

Race | He became the most important black person in America -- a biracial man abandoned by his father and raised by his mother -- and favored a non-confrontational style of politics. Also, he was a Republican. Booker T. Washington is a subject ripe for a reassessment in the age of Obama, a new biography suggests, along with his emphasis of economic self-improvement over social agitation. [Wall Street Journal, New Yorker]

Despite their objections and those of their union, Pavel Datsyuk and Nicklas Lidstrom will accept Gary Bettman's invitation to sit out tonight's Red Wings-Blue Jackets game, their punishment for having skipped the All-Star Weekend in Montreal.

I've vacationed in Key West, Fla., so often (about twice a year for the last 12) that it feels like a home away from home. During our last visit, my partner and I noticed it wasn't quite the gay haven of the past. There were fewer people moving up and down Duval Street, the town's main drag, and the bars were relatively quiet. But this is still my favorite key, and even in a sleepy state, it's a good time for uninitiated visitors to get their feet wet. So here's a starter list of both classic sights and insider spots.
Watching Dow Chemical's chief executive, Andrew Liveris, on CNBC Tuesday morning, I felt as if I were watching some sort of mockumentary. (Watch the interview here.)
On Tuesday morning, a few hours before she was sworn in as a United States senator, Kirsten E. Gillibrand placed a telephone call to former Mayor Edward I. Koch.

As noted in The Food Section website, the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus has recommended that D'Artagnan stop advertising that its foie gras is raised humanely without force feeding.

Kevin and I got up to the cabin site this weekend. We began to put the joists for the second-floor loft in place. These will give us something to stand on when we lift the rafters to the top of the frame.

Generally, only three producers are allowed to be eligible for an Academy Award for best picture, but the executive committee of the producer's branch of AMPAS has decided that "The Reader" will go forward with four named producers: Anthony Minghella, Sydney Pollack, Donna Gigliotti and Redmond Morris.

CafePress, a Web site that lets users create and sell custom goods, announced Tuesday a partnership with Sellit to help online retailers peddle their wares in multiple places around the Web.

A remarkable overhead view of the World Trade Center site, with the clearest visual outline yet of the north pool of the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, was released Tuesday by the Port Authority.

After President Obama signed an executive order on Monday directing the Environmental Protection Agency to reconsider its refusal to grant California a waiver to regulate tailpipe-based greenhouse gas emissions, several automakers issued statements pledging to work with the administration.

Gov. David A. Paterson has no shortage of critics who are willing and eager to ridicule how he handled appointing the state's new United States senator.

I've been keeping a record of what I've been eating as I'm on the road talking about my new book. Not quite as stressful a week as last, but still I spent very little time in familiar places, so I had very little control over food choices. I feel, too, as if winter is taking a bit of a toll on me; we're at the point where you can't even get a good apple or clementine -- oranges and grapefruits are pretty much it.
What we're looking at on the Web today ...
It's pretty amusing to watch Hewlett-Packard and Cisco Systems come to grips with what amounts to a Data Center Death Match.

The Senate Banking Committee held a hearing on Tuesday to look into the disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff's reputed $50 billion Ponzi scheme, how it escaped detection for years and what regulatory changes are needed to prevent a repeat.
As it prepares to cleave itself in two, Citigroup has again reshuffled its management, as the staggering financial giant strives to crawl out from under crushing multibillion-dollar losses.

Food lovers might want to take a careful look at the Culture pages of The Times today and at a profile of the band Franz Ferdinand, written by Melena Ryzik. Read down into it, and you'll learn of an interesting connection between the band - or at least its bassist, Bob Hardy - and the restaurant world.
Archaeologists of the future might be able to learn something about present-day humans by studying the facade of 34 Union Square East.

Like many dishes that rely on a combination of spices, a tagine, which is a slowly braised Moroccan stew, may look more intimidating to cook than it is. Even with shortcuts, the results are exotic in flavor and appearance. My version may not compare to those that begin with toasting and grinding spices and peeling grapes, but it is easily executed and still divine.

For all those lucky enough to have an ornamental fireplace at home, here's a unique addition to your hearth. Partners & Spade, the brand consultancy firm started by Andy Spade and Anthony Sperduti, is now offering a custom painting service as part of its new boutique operation at 40 Great Jones Street in New York City. (Among other curios, it sells antique globes and Rene Ricard canvases as well as an aviary.) The company will commission the artist Ann Wood to create a unique log painting made to measure for your mantel (starting at $1,500). Billed as a collaborative effort, the package takes an estimated four to five weeks to complete, and clients are encouraged to contribute as to the color of the flames, andiron style and preferred background image. Wood's artwork was previously featured in the film "Junebug." To view the existing perpetual flame floor model, stop by Partners & Spade on weekends from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. or weekdays by appointment.
Honda announced on Monday that the 2009 S2000 roadster would be the last. The decision was not entirely unexpected after the company scrapped plans last month for the next NSX.

The Service Employees International Union, in its most aggressive move yet to criticize the finance industry, has called on Bank of America to remove its chief executive at the bank's board meeting Wednesday.
William Dudley was named on Tuesday to lead the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, succeeding Timothy F. Geithner, who was sworn in Monday as Treasury secretary.

Arthur G. Nadel, a Florida hedge fund manager that recently went missing, turned himself into federal authorities Tuesday morning, nearly a week after the Securities and Exchange Commission charged the 76-year-old with fraud in connection with his six hedge funds.

You see it every time you go to a bookstore or library: "The New York Times Best Seller," conspicuously displayed across covers and tucked under titles. But what about the details behind the label: how long has that book been on the Times best-seller list, and how far up the scale did it climb? Our new Best Sellers API will help you answer those questions and more.

One big question in the stimulus discussion is how much we should be worried about lags in implementation. Every economics textbook -- mine too! -- warns that stimulus based on public spending has a habit of peaking much too late, and therefore ends up being counterproductive. Now that we have a genuine CBO estimate of the timing of the stimulus plan, how worried should we be about the effects coming too late?
Frank Bruni checks in on Cabrito in the main review and, in a brief, visits Salumeria Rosi.

Outrage is growing in Michigan -- and nationally -- over the death of Marvin Schur, 93. Mr. Schur froze to death in his home after the municipal power company restricted his electricity because of an unpaid bill.

I've written off and on about how the divide in the United States over how quickly to curb carbon dioxide emissions has little to do with the now familiar red state versus blue state dynamic, and is more about which regions have grids and economies most wedded to coal and oil, and which don't.
Now that George W. Bush has left the White House, European Union leaders are piling pressure on President Barack Obama to adopt regulations on climate change.

When Terry Nayman was 14 years old in Poland she saw Nazis burn her father's beard and knock her mother's teeth out. She never imagined that 70 years later she would talk to two people about it in her Lower East Side apartment.
As you may have heard, Monday was a bloodbath for many workers. At least 11 prominent companies announced work-force reductions around the world. More have been announced today.

Andrew Cuomo, New York's attorney general, said Tuesday that he has subpoenaed John A. Thain, the former Merrill Lynch chief executive, over bonuses paid out by the firm just before it was taken over by Bank of America.
Panasonic today unleashed a host of new cameras, many of which are equipped with a 25mm ultrawide-angle lens for those who want to go really wide with their images.

I'm one of those odd people who likes to read manuals. Most people think that's a bit strange. Still, writing about technology gives me a chance to read a lot of manuals -- and even to have written a few of my own over the years.
