The last time the Bagger touched an Oscar, it was tethered to a podium by a strong steel cable in a tourist display in Times Square. (He gave a speech anyway.) As he felt its heft and fondled its contours, he could not help but wonder, "What's this baby worth?"
Reader response to two recent Green Inc. posts made it very clear that while compact fluorescent light bulbs are undeniably more efficient, many consumers find them less than appealing.
President Obama is clearly in no rush to terminate some Bush administration policies. The not-so-covert attacks into Pakistani territory are a prime example.
Some of the most powerful memories are those infused with both food and family. That's why I was so taken by a Chinese New Year essay by Cheryl Lu-Lien Tan, a writer for The Wall Street Journal.

On a day when news of more than 75,000 layoffs came down in all sectors of the economy, it is silly to point to a single one that suggests Armageddon is nigh, but the Bagger can tell you seeing Anne Thompson's name on the cut-down list at Variety sent a shudder through the community.

The day after his confirmation, and just days after The Times reported that some big banks receiving government bailout money were still lobbying the government - giving the appearance, at least, of using taxpayer money to lobby for more taxpayer money - Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner issued new guidelines designed to curb lobbyists' influence in the bailout program.

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Tuesday set forth modest goals for Afghanistan, saying that success should be defined as an Afghanistan that is not a safe haven for Al Qaeda, whose people reject the rule of Taliban insurgents and support a legitimate government.
Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: Cold outside. Lousy cold. Here is how cold it was. It was so cold today that Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts screwed up while ordering chowder.

It turns out that Blagojevich said he had considered Oprah Winfrey for the Senate. That's ridiculous! Oprah's way too powerful to waste her time in the Senate, although she has enough money to buy the seat.
Facing outrage from some lawmakers, Citigroup now says that it will not take delivery of a brand-new $50 million corporate jet.

I chatted yesterday with Andrew C. Revkin, a Times environmental reporter, about the implications of President Barack Obama's decision to revisit California's quest to enact tougher emissions and efficiency standards on cars. The auto industry has long resisted the idea, but at least 13 other states are now lined up to follow California's lead.
David Carr reports from the 2009 Screen Actors Guild Awards.

People who are outraged about Merrill Lynch's 11th-hour bonus payments may be missing the larger problem, Dave Krasne, a private equity partner (and former Merrill employee) said in an op-ed Tuesday in The New York Times.
After Deadline examines questions of grammar, usage and style encountered by writers and editors of The Times.

Brad DeLong is upset about the stuff coming out of Chicago these days -- and understandably so. First Eugene Fama, now John Cochrane, have made the claim that debt-financed government spending necessarily crowds out an equal amount of private spending, even if the economy is depressed -- and they claim this not as an empirical result, not as the prediction of some model, but as the ineluctable implication of an accounting identity.
Astellas Pharma, a Japanese drug-maker, on Tuesday unveiled a $1 billion unsolicited bid for CV Therapeutics, pursuing a hostile approach after its American partner spurned its advances months ago.

History | Sure, things are bad now, but it will all be over in 2012. The world, that is, according to the way some interpret the Mayan calendar, the Cumaean Sibyl, the Bible, solar activity, asteroid probability and what have you. If you can't wait that long, go see the movie this fall. [New York Post]

In an unusual gesture - unusual for coming so early in his term, almost exactly a week after his inauguration - President Obama is traveling at midday to Capitol Hill to meet with opposition lawmakers to press the case for his $825 billion economic stimulus plan.

Dow Chemical's chief executive told CNBC on Tuesday that the chemical giant is very sorry that it can't close its $15 billion merger with Rohm & Haas right away. Furthermore, it understands why Rohm has now slapped it with a lawsuit in Delaware's Court of Chancery, which would seek to force completion of the deal.

Dr. Antonia C. Novello, a onetime New York health commissioner and a former United States surgeon general, turned her staff into her personal servants, according to a report from the New York State inspector general's office that The New York Times obtained exclusively. The inspector general, which has referred a criminal case to the Albany County district attorney, says that Dr. Novello turned her staff at the Health Department into her personal chauffeurs, porters and shopping assistants during her seven-year tenure.
LYON -- The Bocuse d'Or culinary competition started this morning with a mini-scandal. The whole, unpeeled Norwegian wild prawns were frozen.

Updated | 5:38 p.m. As Mark Landler reported in The New York Times on Monday, President Barack Obama chose Al Arabiya, an Arabic-language news channel based in Dubai, for his first formal television interview in the White House. Alan Cowell reports this morning on how it went.

As some industry observers wonder whether Twitter, the microblogging service that is reportedly raising a venture capital round valuing it at $250 million, should sell itself, GigOm's Om Malik argues that the start-up should hang tough.
Hedge fund veteran John Paulson reaped hundreds of millions of pounds on bets against Royal Bank of Scotland, the firm revealed.

The whole concept of "Master of the Universe," the term coined by Tom Wolfe to describe the Wall Street's powerful financiers, has been turned on its head, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

Education is one area the Internet has not yet transformed, and a new crop of start-ups and venture capitalists are rushing to fill that void, creating Web tools that serve as home tutors for children who need help outside the classroom.

When the markets were booming, billionaire colleges like Harvard, M.I.T. and Stanford tapped their swelling endowments and launched spending binges on faculty, buildings and scholarships, The Associated Press reported.
Netflix's board has authorized the DVD rental and Internet streaming service to spend up to $175 million buying back its own stock, The Associated Press reported.

William C. Dudley, an aide to now-Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, has been officially chosen to succeed his old boss as the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to news reports.

Amid the global debate about the pitfalls of nationalizing troubled companies, Japan on Tuesday outlined a plan to inject state funds into ailing companies in exchange for stakes in them, a move that echoes the partial nationalization of some banks in the United States and Europe, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.

Halliburton will pay a $559 million fine to end an investigation of its former KBR unit if the U.S. government approves the settlement, the largest penalty against a U.S. company for charges of bribery under federal law.
Xkoto, a database-virtualization start-up, has nabbed $3 million in fresh financing from return backers GrandBanks Capital and GrowthWorks Canadian Fund.
How did B. Ramalinga Raju, the chairman of one of India's largest information technology companies, carry out the biggest financial fraud in this country's history? Apparently it does take a village.

The banking giant Barclays - like the British government whose bailout money it has spurned - faces a crisis of confidence among investors who are reluctant to take the word of anyone, banker or politician, at face value.
John Thain has already bowed out, and Citigroup is sending just half as many people to Davos as last year's delegation.

Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage, reported a record $3.8 billion quarterly loss on Tuesday, hit by the cost of integrating Lehman Brothers' operations, soured trades and its exposure to Iceland and Bernard L. Madoff, Reuters said.

American International Group has received bids for its aircraft leasing unit from sovereign wealth funds in Singapore, China and the Middle East, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

This month Pfizer's chief executive, Jeffrey B. Kindler, held a breakfast for venture capitalists atop a hotel in San Francisco. Some guests took it as a sign that Pfizer was serious about buying young biotechnology companies or licensing their technology.
This year, the talk emanating from the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland, has so far been focused on how little star-power the gabfest is generating this year.

In the middle of the ocean. On prefab floating platforms." Financial troubles at luxury yacht builder Ferretti could put a crimp on the private equity owner's style.
Wall Street posted modest gains on Monday, but strong currents of hope and fear continued to tug the uncertain financial markets in opposite directions, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.
Japanese shares led Asian markets higher, climbing 4.9 percent after Tokyo launched a $16.7 billion scheme on Tuesday to help firms threatened by the financial crisis.

Autonomy's $775 million deal for Interwoven has The 451 Group wondering why Autonomy, which it says has long dismissed content management as an old-school way to address exponential content growth, saw value in this deal.

Even today the landmark, featured in a Stephen King horror movie, wouldn't mind some of that bailout dough. [Wall Street Journal]
Spanish property site Idealista.com has put together a list of what it calls the 100 most expensive homes in Spain.

Food | Perhaps you've been awake at night pondering the question, "How many different kinds of regional varations of pizza exist?" A New York businessman sought by federal authorities in connection with a suspected $380 million Ponzi scheme has been arrested and charged with one count of mail fraud.
A woman gave birth to eight babies in Southern California, the world’s second live-born set of octuplets.

Mark Gottfried resigned as Alabama’s basketball coach Monday, leaving in the middle of his 11th season amid criticism of the team’s play and the departure of a star player. He will be replaced by the assistant Philip Pearson. Alabama is 12-7. Gottfried’s teams have missed the N.C.A.A. tournament the last two years, and he was criticized over the recent departure of point guard Ronald Steele. The university said Steele departed because of an injury, but Steele said there was more to his decision.
Loss
It turns out that the finish of the 47th Rolex 24 sports car race at Daytona International Speedway on Sunday was closer than anyone realized.
Photos from the world premiere of Athol Fugard’s new play.

Danica Patrick has a new partner on her team: Michael Andretti will work as her strategist. Patrick’s team, which is co-owned by Andretti, announced the move. The decision allows Kyle Moyer, who made the calls for Patrick’s No. 7 car last season, to fill the same role for Andretti’s son, Marco. Andretti, who won 42 races in his career, has never served as a strategist.

The motor racing governing body F.I.A. and the Saudi Arabian Motor Federation agreed not to count the Hail Baja Rally for Baja championship points after F.I.A. learned that officials at the four-day event, which starts Tuesday, had denied a Russian woman’s request to compete. The Saudi federation opted to stage the race on its own after deciding not to comply with the F.I.A.’s ruling to let women behind the wheel. “We cannot accept women in the race,” said Mishaal al-Sudairy, the Saudi federation’s chairman.

Jimmie Johnson, the three-time reigning Nascar Sprint Cup champion, had surgery to repair a tendon and a nerve in his left middle finger after cutting himself with a kitchen knife Sunday. Johnson said in a statement that the injury was above the knuckle and that it happened while he was preparing for the final segment of the Rolex 24 sports car race. Johnson was attempting to customize his firesuit by cutting a small hole.

Terry Labonte, a two-time Nascar Sprint Cup champion, will attempt to qualify for the Feb. 15 Daytona 500 in a Toyota fielded by Prism Motorsports, co-owned by Randy Humphrey and the former Nascar driver Phil Parson.

Sean Casey, a three-time All-Star, planned to announce his retirement as a player Tuesday and that he would join the MLB Network, according to Tony Petitti, the network’s president. Casey played in the major leagues from 1997 to 2008, hitting .302 with 130 home runs and 735 runs batted in for Cleveland, Cincinnati, Pittsburgh, Detroit and Boston.
An elderly man died in a house fire in Queens on Monday night as firefighters battled flames and what they called cluttered, Collyers’ Mansion conditions.
The first soccer game with both sexes since 1979 led to punishment on Monday, as a soccer club said it had suspended three officials involved and handed out fines.
Indonesia’s top Islamic body barred Muslims from practicing yoga that contains Hindu rituals like chanting, citing concerns that it would corrupt their faith.
Tens of thousands of antigovernment protesters took to the streets of the capital on Monday, burning the state-owned television and radio station.
Russian news agencies said Moscow could start building a naval base in Georgia’s breakaway Abkhazia region this year.
A bomb rigged to a bicycle exploded in northwestern Pakistan on Monday, killing at least 5 people and wounding 20.
A Yemeni official said gunmen fired on a police checkpoint near the United States Embassy in the capital, Sana, on Monday.

In almost every Super Bowl, a player emerges from the ranks of the largely unknown. Last year, the Giants' David Tyree, right, made one of the most memorable catches in Super Bowl history and also caught a touchdown pass after a season in which he made five receptions. With that idea in mind, I'll write this week about players who might find themselves in a similar situation in Super Bowl XLIII.
China was found to have failed to protect and enforce copyrights and trademarks on a wide range of goods.
Andrew Ross Sorkin, a Times reporter, discusses the agenda for Davos 2009.
Saturday’s column by Gail Collins misidentified the French official hospitalized after being attacked by his dog. He is the former president, Jacques Chirac, not the current one.
Among today's headlines:
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Continued sectarian violence is just one of the many problems in Diyala Province that make holding fair elections almost impossible.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on June 17 about Tony Schwartz, a media consultant who helped create the “daisy ad” for Lyndon B. Johnson’s 1964 presidential campaign, envisioning a nuclear explosion, misstated the date of Mr. Schwartz’s death. It was Sunday, June 15 — not Saturday, June 14. A family member pointed out the error recently in an e-mail message.
Mr. Zwerdling was a founder of Back Stage, the weekly theater newspaper that is widely considered the casting bible for performers.
Mr. Schneer was a noted film producer who for a quarter-century helped the Oscar-winning special-effects wizard Ray Harryhausen lay waste to Washington, San Francisco, Rome and many other places.
Ms. Vierny was the model whose ample flesh and soft curves inspired the sculptor Aristide Maillol, rejuvenating his career, and who eventually founded a museum dedicated to his work.

An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a boom in the construction of office towers in Calgary, Alberta, misstated the occupation of Richard White, a former official of the Downtown Association who commented on the bold designs of the city’s new buildings. He works as a business development, media and government liaison for an architecture firm, but he is not an architect.

An article on Monday about the sale of films at the Sundance Film Festival misidentified the corporation that owns Rainbow Media Holdings and IFC, among the most active buyers at this year’s festival. Rainbow Media Holdings and IFC are part of Cablevision Systems, not Comcast.
Resolved to learn English after leaving Colombia for the United States, Blanca Bohorquez struggled to balance her work schedule with language classes.

An article last Tuesday about the advantages of holding passports issued by more than one country overstated reports linking terrorists in Mumbai to citizens holding American and British passports. While some witnesses said the terrorists singled out American and British citizens, officials have uncovered no evidence showing that was the case.

The Big City column in some editions on Monday, about an interactive project showcasing the hip-hop history of the Bronx, misspelled the surname of one of the artists involved. She is Claudia Bernett, not Burnett.
Suppliers of home heating oil from Maine to Maryland have agreed to gradually reduce sulfur levels in their oil in an effort to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide.

A map on Wednesday with the continuation of an article about President Obama’s extended family mislabeled the state from which some of his forebears were driven out for their abolitionist views, according to family lore. The text of the map said, correctly, that the state is Missouri, but the map highlighted Mississippi.
Jerel McNeal had a season-high 27 points to lead No. 8 Marquette to a 71-64 victory at Notre Dame, sending the Irish to their fourth consecutive loss.
Kevin Durant scored 9 of his 18 points in the third quarter, when the Oklahoma City Thunder took control of the Nets in a 94-85 victory.
Pfizer’s plan to buy Wyeth may pack a nasty side effect for the New York region, in the form of layoffs and the likely shuttering of one company’s headquarters.
Nate Robinson sealed the Knicks’ victory over the Houston Rockets by stealing the ball from Luis Scola and drawing a foul with 18.1 seconds left.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the self-made billionaire founder of the Bloomberg financial information firm, was the leading individual living donor in the United States.
FRONT PAGE.
Officials have offered little detail on potentially explosive political questions about how much to push down interest rates on mortgages versus municipal bonds or corporate debt.
A New York City man pleaded guilty on Monday for his role in attacks on people on election night last year after Barack Obama’s victory.
An S.E.C. civil complaint charges that Citigroup knew early on that the auction-rate securities market was unstable but continued to underwrite and sell bonds.
Federal prosecutors have given UBS “several weeks” to hand over scores of United States client names or face possible indictment over its offshore banking services.
The Masters of the Universe are falling on hard times too, at least by their own gilded standards.
Gov. David A. Paterson has been trying to undo the damage resulting from his selection process for the Senate seat, but his latest remarks may have confused matters more.
Pfizer’s move to buy Wyeth dims the hopes of struggling small biotechnology companies that wanted to sell themselves or their products to larger businesses.

G. Wayne Clough was officially installed as the 12th secretary of the Smithsonian Institution on Monday in a ceremony at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian in Washington. Mr. Clough a former president of the Georgia Institute of Technology, took over in July as secretary, or chief executive. Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. (above left, with Mr. Clough), who serves as chancellor of the Smithsonian, presented Mr. Clough with a ceremonial brass key. Noting that the secretary receives a key instead of taking an oath, Justice Roberts joked, “I don’t know who decided that, but I’m happy about it.” Mr. Clough delivered an address during the ceremony, which also included an academic procession. At a meeting earlier in the day the Smithsonian’s board of regents voted for a revised policy on information requests consistent with the principles of the Freedom of Information Act.

For months theatergoers have clamored for new blood on Broadway, and now they’re going to get it. The Nederlander Organization said in a statement that it had acquired the rights to produce a musical based on the Michael Jackson album “Thriller” and its groundbreaking video, above, in which the King of Pop transforms into a werewolf while he’s out on a date. The production will feature songs from the “Thriller” album as well as Mr. Jackson’s record “Off the Wall.” Mr. Jackson is expected to participate in the musical’s creation. In a statement James L. Nederlander, the president of the organization, said: “I love the idea of making ‘Thriller’ a musical. Girl meets boy, they fall in love, boy has big secret, now what ...?” A creative team for “Thriller the Musical” was not announced.

The Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists said in a statement that they have agreed to guidelines under which they will work together on negotiations with the advertising industry. The two unions had fallen out over separate negotiations with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents the Hollywood film and television studios. The federation agreed to a new contract with the producers’ alliance in July, around the same time that the Screen Actors Guild’s talks with the producers collapsed. The guild is still without a film and television contract, and its membership continues to wrestle with the possibility of a strike. The contract that governs both unions’ members’ work in television and radio commercials is to expire on March 31; they are scheduled to return to negotiations with commercial producers on Feb. 23.

PLAYER In Italy, Silvio Berlusconi, the president of A.C. Milan, said the club would like to keep David Beckham past the expiration of his loan deal from M.L.S. ''Beckham is a champion,'' he told the Italian news media. ''We will try and hold on to him.'' Bruce Arena, the Los Angeles Galaxy's coach and general manager, said the team expected Beckham to return when the loan agreement expired March 8. CLUB In England, fans of Leicester City, which will celebrate its 125th anniversary next season, were asked to vote online for their favorite design for the team's home jersey. Sixty-five percent of 20,000 voters chose a plain shirt, free of sponsor advertising. ''The fans have voted, and we have listened to them,'' Milan Mandaric, the club's chairman, said on the team's Web site.

SMIGEL--Louis, of New York City, died January 26th after a valiant battle with lung cancer. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School, New York University and Vanderbilt law school, he was an outstanding attorney in both private practice and while working with the attorney general Louis Lefkowitz, HUD and other government agencies. He is survived by his beloved family, his wonderful wife Lois, his children Stephen (Julie) and Beth, his grandson Harrison, his mother-in-law Judy, his brother Irwin (Lucia), his sister Eileen and nieces Bellanca and Betsy, nephews Robert and Jonathan. He was one of the very few of us loved by everyone, to say he will be missed is an understatement. He will be cherished forever. Services today 9:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St., New York, NY 10024.

SHAPIRO--Barry. Dear friend and best neighbor for 35 years. Our hearts are filled with memories of good times spent with your beloved Roz, Lisa and Hal. We will remember forever your extraordinary generosity and many thoughtful deeds. Linda and Martin Silver Scott and Bonnie Silver Shanna and Bruce Leuchter

WILLNER--Aaron, passed away on January 24 at age 88. He will be sorely missed by his adopted niece and nephew, Roberta Lee and Syd Steinhardt, and by his many friends and admirers at the Brotherhood Synagogue and Sirovich Senior Center. Donations to the Brotherhood Synagogue in his memory are greatly appreciated.

CONNOLLY--Leonard J.,Esq., for Lattingtown, LI suddenly on January 24th, 2009, age 71. Beloved husband to Janet nee Maroney, loving father to Deirdre (Hamish Norton), Ursula (Bill Wiess), Janet (Kaj Gyr) and Annie (Chris Lodge). Proud grandfather of William, Nina, Wilson, Blair, Dylan, Oliver, Angus, Graham and Marina. After graduating from St. Francis College and Cornell Law School, Len spent his entire career as a corporate attorney in NYC, first with Olwine Connelly Chase O'Donnell and Weyer and then with Dechert, LLP. After his retirement he became an adjunct professor of law at Hoftsra Law School. In the last few years he conducted a well regarded seminar on Corporate Governance. In addition to his legal work, Len had a general interest in reading, writing, politics, and his emails to family and friends were amusing and delightful to read. Len served the Village of Lattingtown as Village Justice for many years and participated in the State Magistrates Association. He also served the Homeowners Association, Lattingtown Harbor Association, for a term as Treasurer and also as General Advisor. He was a member of the Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club and was, until a few years ago an enthusiastic ice dancer, a tennis player and a roller blader. He was still able to enjoy ballroom dancing and biking. Len was admired for his wonderful sense of humor, his intelligence, and his sense of fair play. His family will miss him terribly. Visitation at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas, 26 Franklin Avenue, Glen Cove, Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass at the Church of St. Patrick Wednesday 11am. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

O'SHAUGHNESSY--Wiliam P.,97, of Rutherford, NJ formerly of New York City, passed away on January 25, 2009. Born in New York City, William was an insurance underwriter for Cigna Insurance of New York City. He was an Army Veteran of WWII as well as a parishioner of St. Mary RC Church, Rutherford, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth (1969) and the late Elsa (1997). Devoted stepfather to Elizabeth Crowley and Gary Hall. Loving uncle to John O'Shaughnessy and his wife Rossana, and Peter O'Shaughnessy and his wife Jeanine. William is also survived by seven stepgrandchildren 18 step-greatgrandchildren and many loving cousins. Funeral from the Macagna Diffily Onorato Funeral Home 41 Ames Ave., Rutherford, NJ on Thursday January 29, 2009 at 8:30am, thence to St. Mary RC Church, Rutherford, NJ where a Funeral Mass will be offered at 9:30am. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Visiting hours Wednesday 79pm.

Chinatown welcomed the Lunar New Year on Monday with a firecracker ceremony and cultural festival featuring dancers and other performers, colorful costumes and delighted spectators. The noisy ceremony in Chatham Square, intended to ward off evil spirits, ushers in the Year of the Ox, and will be followed by arts and cultural demonstrations through the week, a parade on Sunday at noon and a closing celebration with lion dances on Feb. 8.

ROSEN--Irving, peacefully, January 24. Loving and beloved husband, best friend, comrade in arms to wife Martha for over 63 years. Adoring and adored father to daughter Shelley. Caring uncle to two nieces, Lise and Maya, three nephews, Alan, Gary and Steve and two grandnephews Charlie and Josh. He will be missed, loved and remembered forever. Private family service.

Steelers safety Troy Polamalu discussed covering Larry Fitzgerald, who has been the star of the playoffs. Polamalu, who is 5-foot-10, compared the 6-3 Fitzgerald to receivers such as Terrell Owens and Randy Moss. ''They go up to get the ball, but they're getting behind people,'' Polamalu said. ''Larry obviously does that as well, but he's out-jumping people. Guys have been in position to make plays on him but they're just not making them because Larry's such a good playmaker. He's a great athlete. Guys are in position. That's the thing. When you're in position and he's still making plays, there's nothing you can do. You have to realize he's a great player and not get too frustrated.''

Red Alert from the Obama White House on Monday: e-mail was down. The crowd that texted, YouTubed and Twittered its way to 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue struggled on Monday with a White House e-mail breakdown that had President Obama's aides distributing information on, of all things, paper. The press secretary, Robert Gibbs, began his daily briefing at 1:45 p.m. by apologizing for the failure.

As defensive end Bertrand Berry sat on the Cardinals' plane, he read his Bible and listened to his iPod and tried to fight back tears. He thought back to all that he had been through -- the year in the Canadian Football League, the cancer his wife survived, the rough years in Arizona. ''It's overwhelming when you really stop and think about it,'' he said. Between early-season games at Washington and at the Jets, the Cardinals stayed on the East Coast. Coach Ken Whisenhunt said that trip helped prepare the Cardinals for this week on the road, in that ''this is one distraction we're not faced with for the first time.'' GREG BISHOP

KLENICKI--Rabbi Leon. The officers, National Commission and staff of the Anti-Defamation League mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Rabbi Leon Klenicki, longtime ADL Interfaith Affairs Director and Co-Liaison to the Vatican. During more than 30 years at ADL Rabbi Klenicki worked tirelessly to promote understanding and respect between Christians and Jews. A renowned scholar, theologian and interfaith relations pioneer, he received many recognitions, including from the Vatican for his contribution to Catholic-Jewish dialogue. Rabbi Klenicki was deeply committed to Judaism, the Jewish people and the State of Israel. We will miss his wisdom, wit and humanity. May his memory be a blessing. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Myra and the entire family. Glen S. Lewy, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

SCHWARTZMAN--Gilbert ''Gil'', on January 26, 2009 at age 86. Born April 4, 1922 in New York to Harry and Sophie Schwartzman. Gil served in the Army Air Corps in WWII and became an inventor with over 100 American patents. He was President and owner of Dab-O-Matic in Mt. Vernon, NY. Survived by his beloved wife Helen of 16 years, cherished daughters Joanne (Rich), Patti (Peter), Toni (Philip), Karen (Bob), stepdaughters Abby (John) and Beth, adoring grandchildren Daniel, Sara, Libby and step-grandchild Michael, and caretakers Sammy, Baah, Rosalba, Edgar and Victor. Memorial service Thursday 1pm at Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck. 914-381-1809

On behalf of the Board of Directors and other volunteers, the entire staff, the children and adults we serve, and their families, we extend heartfelt sympathy to Tim's sons Christopher and Michael, as well as the entire family. WEINGRAD--Sylvia (Sunny), passed away on January 19, at her home in Lake Worth, FL, in her 90th year. She was loved and is sorely missed by her children Heidi, Daniel and Mitchell and her grandchildren Julie, Rachel, Mark, Harris and Marlon. A few years ago, a faculty committee at Harvard produced a report on the purpose of education. ''The aim of a liberal education'' the report declared, ''is to unsettle presumptions, to defamiliarize the familiar, to reveal what is going on beneath and behind appearances, to disorient young people and to help them to find ways to reorient themselves.'' The report implied an entire way of living. Individuals should learn to think for themselves. They should be skeptical of pre-existing arrangements. They should break free from the way they were raised, examine life from the outside and discover their own values.

The hotel business has collided head-on with the bad economy and the tight credit market. Hotel revenue is down sharply. Big new projects, planned in the boom days, are either sitting unfinished or left on the drawing boards. And some high-end hotel owners now face an unhappy situation -- how much can they cut prices to fill their rooms before they damage their hotels' luxury cachet?

GERONEMUS--Robert M.D.,60, passed away January 24, 2009. Beloved husband and best friend for 21 years to Laurie. Cherished father of Heather, Christina, Rachel and Mia. Brother of David (Mitzi). Adored son of Berle and the late Clement. Uncle of Kate and Laura. He was a graduate of Cornell University A.B., University of Illinois M.S. Physics and M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He was a former Chief Resident in Medicine at Mt. Sinai Hospital New York and was widely published in his field of practice. He was an affiliate Clinical Associate Professor at FAU and was a senior partner of South Florida Nephrology. Associates in Lauderdale Lakes, FL. RAGGIO--Olga. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of Olga Raggio, recently retired Distinguished Research Curator and former Chairman of the Department of European Sculpture and Decorative Arts. One of the great scholar-curators of European art and culture, she made innumerable contributions to the Museum in the course of her nearly 60 year career. She was well-known for her role in organizing ground-breaking exhibitions, such as The Vatican Collections: The Papacy and Art in 1981, and for exemplary publications such as The Gubbio Studiolo and its Conservation, 1999. She supervised numerous acquisitions and gallery reinstallations that have enriched the experience of the museum-going public. By her example to curators and by teaching graduate students in art history, she mentored many who now continue to play key roles in her field and who extend her scholarly approach to the arts throughout the world. She was greatly admired and will be deeply missed. Thomas P. Campbell, Director Ian Wardropper, Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Chairman, European Sculpture and Decorative Arts
PERLE--George. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. His loss will be deeply felt.

SMITH--William B. Rt. Rev. Msgr, STD; of Yonkers on January 24, 2009. Ordained May 28, 1966 from St. Joseph's Seminary. Son of the late George F. and Helen O'Connell Smith, brother of the late James T. and George M. Smith, uncle to James T. Smith, Jr. and George F.X. Smith, brother-in-law of Anita G. Smith and Betty Smith. Graduated from Xavier H.S. and Cathedral College. Msgr. Smith served as a Professor of Moral Theology at St. Joseph's Seminary since 1971. He also served on the Board of Ethics of St. Vincent's Hospital; Board of Trustees of Calvary Hospital; was the Chaplain to Missionaries of Charities in the South Bronx; was a member of the Fellowship of Catholic Scholars (President 1981-1983); celebrated Sunday Mass at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale for many years. SLASS--Robert H.,President and founder of Rotor Clip. Robert H. Slass passed away Sunday, January 25, 2009. He was 80 years old. He is survived by his wife, Gloria, two sons, Jonathan and Craig and six grandchildren, Evan, Emily, Jacob, Jenny, Madison and Michael. Mr. Slass was a pioneer in the metal stamping industry, founding his own firm, Rotor Clip Company, in 1957. A graduate mechanical engineer, Mr. Slass was known for his passion and devotion to engineering and its practical applications to manufacturing. According to employees, he loved being an engineer and was regarded by many as a teacher and a friend. Mr. Slass was a staunch supporter of U.S. manufacturing and the opportunities he believed it held for our country's population. Rotor Clip was a showcase of his skills and talents, both as a mechanical engineer and as a businessman. Despite the threat of foreign competition, he was able to capture a significant portion of the marketplace for retaining rings, making Rotor Clip an exception to the so-called demise of US manufacturing rule. He believed that the enduring spirit of our country is one of hard work, knowledge and creativity and that in these principles lies our continued success both as anation and as a people. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made in Bob Slass' memory to: The Cancer Institute of New Jersey Foundation; St. Jude's Children Research Hospital.

Putin struck a conciliatory tone toward the West. He explicitly wished the new administration of President Obama well, and urged cooperation on energy security, the economy and even disarmament.

As the list of Davos no-shows keeps growing — you can cross Bob Diamond, the head of Barclays’ investment banking unit, off the list — one thing has become increasingly clear: For many people, the usual cachet of mingling with the movers and shakers in Davos has been turned on its head this year.

George Soros, the billionaire fund manager and philanthropist, offered a generally dire outlook on the economy Wednesday afternoon in an interview in Davos with Maria Bartiromo of CNBC. But he also gave a prescription for what is ailing banks around the globe.

UPDATE: A lawyer for John Landis has told The Associated Press that he would sue to stop production of the “Thriller” musical if necessary. In a statement, James L. Nederlander said, “I’m confident that these past differences can be worked out.”ORIGINAL POST: Having filmed Michael Jackson dancing in a graveyard, the filmmaker John Landis now seeks to bring the King of Pop somewhere equally as frightening: a court of law. Last week, Mr. Landis, the director and co-writer of the video for Mr. Jackson’s “Thriller,” filed suit against Mr. Jackson for unpaid profits from the video and a making-of documentary, Variety reported. The suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, says that for the past four years Mr. Jackson and his company Optimum Productions have failed to pay Mr. Landis money he is owed from these film projects or to account for the profits. On Monday, the Nederlander Organization announced that it had acquired the rights to produce a musical based on “Thriller” and its video, an homage to horror movies in which Mr. Jackson turns into a werewolf and a zombie.

The Los Angeles Opera has become the latest performing arts group to announce cutbacks as it copes with the declining economy, The Los Angeles Times reported. The opera company announced Tuesday that it had laid off 17 employees, representing 17 percent of its staff, and was imposing pay cuts of around 6 percent for its remaining workers, though some higher-paid employees received an 8 percent cut. Plácido Domingo, the company’s general director, said that he had deferred his salary last year to help cut costs, according to The Times.

And how many years must Bob Dylan wait before he licenses one of his most beloved ballads for use in a British television commercial? The answer, my friends, is 47. Mr. Dylan, the trickster troubadour, has once again baffled his fans by giving permission for his protest song “Blowin’ in the Wind” to be used in an advertisement for the Co-operative Group, Agence France-Presse reported. The song, which Mr. Dylan began performing in 1962 and appears on the 1963 Columbia Records album “The Freewheelin’ Bob Dylan,” is the first that he’s allowed for use in British commercials; the company, which operates supermarkets as well as travel, legal and funeral services, is a proponent of ethical and accountable trading practices. A spokesman for Sony, the parent company of Columbia, said that Mr. Dylan “has a career based on surprising people, on people not being able to second-guess him,” according to Agence France-Presse.

Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) remains at No. 1 on the Billboard chart for the seventh week in a row and eighth over all, with 63,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. With low sales all around and no new blockbusters, this week’s Top 10 looks a lot like last week’s: Beyoncé’s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) holds at No. 2, and Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) remains No. 3. The only new entry is a Mariah Carey compilation, “The Ballads” (Columbia), which reached No. 10 with 29,000 sales.

Yahoo, the Internet portal, is looking to extend its brand to television by developing a half-hour newsmagazine with Twentieth Television, a unit of News Corporation. The program, called “Yahoo Buzz” and inspired by the Web site of the same name, will be syndicated to television stations as early as this fall. Just as users of Yahoo.com are able to vote for news articles to receive more attention on the Web site, the television show will use those rankings to determine the day’s top 10 stories. “It’ll truly be what people are buzzing about,” said Bob Cook, the president and chief operating officer of Twentieth Television. One co-host is expected to be Ananda Lewis, a former host on MTV.

TAMPA, Fla. -- Kurt Warner isn't the only member of the Cardinals who has taken an unlikely route to success in Arizona. Bertrand Berry did, too. He was drafted out of Notre Dame in the third round by the Colts in 1997, only to be released after the 2000 season. That was followed by a stint at a Rams training camp, a couple of games with the Edmonton Eskimos of the C.F.L. and then three seasons in Denver, where he rose from reserve to starting defensive end. Though he had a strong final season in Denver, making 11 1/2 sacks, he was still relatively unknown throughout the league.

In the last few weeks, the precipitous fall in bank share prices in the United States and the U.K. triggered much discussion in both countries about the idea of nationalizing banks and creating a new "bad bank" to take over their toxic assets. Now bank share prices are recovering, and while the nationalization strategy is fading -- the Washington Post reported this morning that both Timothy Geithner and Lawrence Summers think it's a bad idea -- the "bad bank" notion is apparently catching on with the administration, according to a Wall Street Journal report today, which says that's why U.S. stocks, led by bank shares, are rallying today.

Perhaps it was just a case of Saturn returning, but for the musician/fashion designer Madeline Davy, 2003 was a turning point. It was then, at the age of 27, the former Corbis photo researcher quit her job and undertook not one but two full-time creative pursuits. "My job was mind-numbing," says Davy, who studied painting at RISD. "I initially quit just to paint and spend more time in my studio -- but things took a different turn."Or different turns: her fashion label Octopi recently unveiled its exquisite spring 2009 collection, and she's half of the electronic duo Free Blood, which just released its party-starting debut album, "The Singles" (Rong/DFA Records). On the surface, these two divergent creative expressions would appear to have little in common, but upon further inspection, there may be more aesthetic similarities than initially meets the eyes and ears.

I am not a speed reader, like my colleague Jack Curry, so there is no way I can quickly finish my copy of "The Yankee Years." With temperatures plummeting, drivers in New York City are more likely to leave their car engines idling for a few minutes before getting on the road. The City Council has a message for such drivers: Don't do it.City law generally prohibits letting the engine of a motor vehicle (other than emergency vehicles) idle for longer than three minutes while parking, standing or stopping. Construction vehicles are also prohibited from idling. As an an air-pollution control measure, state regulations restrict the idling of buses on school grounds and ban the idling for more than five minutes of on-road heavy-duty and nondiesel vehicles that transport people or property.

With each passing day, Shea Stadium, the home of the Mets since 1964, fades further from Citi Field, the team's new home. In the last few weeks, demolition crews have been ripping down entire sections of Shea from both ends of the outfield decks. What was once a semi-enclosed bowl in Flushing, Queens, with seats for 57,000 people is now just the skeleton of a grandstand.

When it comes to weird rituals, the Mailing of the Ballots is right up there with Viking burials and some of the things you hear about Skull and Bones. The Oscar ballots went out this morning to 5,810 voters, but not without a media rain dance in and around the lobby of the academy's temple on Wilshire Boulevard here. The services were held up a bit by a monstrous Westside traffic snarl, reportedly caused by a freeway collision that froze the grid. I huffed in 15 minutes late, just in time to get brushed aside by a pushcart loaded with 14 postal trays filled with -- could it really be? -- The Ballots. Two guys dressed in dark and darker -- they would be Brad Oltmanns and Rick Rosas, the high priests from PricewaterhouseCoopers -- stood watch as seven of the trays were arranged on tables. Five young acolytes then proceeded to riffle their fingers through the envelopes, as 20 or so news cameras invested the moment with importance.

There seems to be an amazing amount of misunderstanding of the basics of fiscal policy, even among people who should know better. Leave on one side the remarkable parade of economists who think that the savings-investment identity proves that government action can't increase spending; PGL points us to a higher-level fallacy: the widespread belief that Ricardian equivalence doesn't just say that tax cuts have no effect -- which it does -- it also says that private consumption automatically offsets any rise in government spending, which is just wrong.

The inbox contained a new poster for "Gomorrah," which is about to get a U.S. release. While the Bagger knows that the Italian film about the criminal demimonde has been criminally excluded from this year's final five for best foreign-language movie, he can't get the movie out of his mind. There is a kind of moral certainty to the film - deeply corrupt, remarkably brutal - that makes everything make sense within the four corners of the movie. It's full of likable, familiar types, but they just happen to have the habit of blowing people's brains out. What does it say about culture when primordial evil expresses itself in a kid who might live right down the block? The poster does a good job of flicking at the hanging questions and many others.

The assignment is part of a push by CNN to enhance its international coverage.

"As deflation fears increase, and interest rates fall close to zero, the allure of such currencies may resurface." [Economist]

Yet because of environmental concerns and cost, American desalinization tech is a better sell in the Mideast than in ever more parched areas at home. [Fast Company]

Mark Johnson, who won Olympic gold as part of the 1980 “Miracle on Ice” team, on Tuesday was appointed the coach of the United States women’s team for the 2010 Vancouver Games. “I’ve played in playoff games in the N.H.L.; I’ve had an opportunity to win championships here at Wisconsin. But to me the biggest platform is the Olympics,” Johnson, the women’s coach at Wisconsin, said during a conference call from Madison.

Reinfried Herbst led an Austrian 1-2 finish in a World Cup night slalom in Schladming, Austria, and Bode Miller finished eighth. Herbst, who led after the opening leg, won in a combined time of 1 minute 37.32 seconds. He beat Manfred Pranger by 1.16 seconds for his second victory of the season and fifth over all. Ivica Kostelic of Croatia was third and extended his lead in the overall standings. Miller, the defending overall champion, finished in 1:39.34. Nine of the 30 racers missed a gate in their second run on the Planai course because of tough conditions after a recent heavy snowfall.

Robert Cheruiyot of Kenya will compete for his fourth consecutive Boston Marathon title and Dire Tune of Ethiopia will return to defend her title in the women’s division in the 2009 race on April 20. Cheruiyot won his first Boston Marathon title in 2003, then won the race three consecutive years from 2006 to 2008. His time of 2 hours 7 minutes 14 seconds in 2006 established the course record. Dire won in Boston in 2008 by two seconds over Alevtina Biktimirova of Russia, the closest finish in the women’s division.

The former heavyweight Scott LeDoux, 60, has Lou Gehrig’s disease, also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. It is a normally fatal disease that cripples the body and takes away the ability to speak, but LeDoux said he will not let the diagnosis stop him from living a full life. LeDoux has continued his work as a commissioner in Anoka County — a suburban county north of Minneapolis — and as the executive director of the Minnesota Combative Sports Commission.

Landon Donovan made his official debut for Bayern Munich, entering in the 67th minute of a 5-1 victory at Stuttgart in a German Cup match. On loan from the Los Angeles Galaxy, Donovan replaced Luca Toni and narrowly missed scoring one minute into his debut. Donovan, who scored four goals in five exhibition matches during the winter break, hopes for a permanent transfer to Bayern.

An article on Saturday about Sam Adams, the mayor of Portland, who is under fire after admitting that in 2005 he had a sexual relationship with an 18-year-old intern, included a quotation from Christopher Stowell, the artistic director for the Oregon Ballet Theater, who attended a rally in support of the mayor. Mr. Stowell said that while he was upset with the mayor, he believed that instead of allowing him to resign, “I think we should force him to do the job.”.

An obituary on Jan. 11 about the Rev. Claude Jeter, an influential gospel singer, included several errors. The recording of “Mary Don’t You Weep” by his group, the Swan Silvertones, was released in 1958, not 1962. “Yesterday and Today” was his last solo album, not the only one, and it was released in 1988, not 1991. And part of the title of a book by the gospel expert Anthony Heilbut, who produced “Yesterday and Today,” was misstated. It is “The Gospel Sound: Good News and Bad Times,” not “Hard Times.”.

A film notebook on Friday about the Sundance Festival referred incorrectly to a character in the movie “Big Fan,” which was shown at the festival. While often called “QB” in the film, the character, Quantrell Bishop, is a linebacker for the New York Giants, not a quarterback.
Queen Marie Antoinette’s weeping beech, which survived the French Revolution, was toppled after gales swept across France and Spain over the weekend.
A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Friday about the naming of a new director of the Princeton University Art Museum misstated his surname. He is James Steward, not Stewart.
An independent tribunal established ordered the British government to publish the minutes of two cabinet meetings held on the eve of the 2003 invasion of Iraq.
Firefighters found 25 charred bodies in a looted department store in the capital, Antananarivo, on Tuesday, a day after antigovernment protesters took to the streets.
Money sent home by Mexican emigrants fell 3.6 percent to $25 billion in 2008, the first drop on record, the central bank said Tuesday.

A picture caption on Saturday with a music review of the John Escreet Project, at the Jazz Gallery, misstated the surname of the bass player pictured. He is Zack Lober, not Brewer. (He was filling in for Matt Brewer.).
Blowfish testicles sickened seven diners in northern Japan and three remained hospitalized Tuesday after eating the poisonous delicacy.
Thousands of Greek farmers kept blocking roads across the country on Tuesday as they demanded government aid and tax breaks because of a drop in commodity prices.
American officers distributed $40,000 on Tuesday to relatives of 15 people killed Jan. 19 in a United States raid.

The Popular Demand listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday about online viewers of the presidential inauguration misstated the proportion of viewers who saw the event at CNN Web sites. CNN.com and the network’s online video site attracted the largest share of online viewers at 25.1 percent, but they did not draw “the majority” of online viewers.

An article on Tuesday about Pfizer’s $68 billion acquisition of a rival drug maker, Wyeth, misstated the price of two previous Pfizer acquisitions. The company paid $90 billion, not million, for Warner-Lambert in 2000, and $60 billion, not million, for Pharmacia in 2003.
Is it too much to hope that the latest chapter in the Albany sleaze series will finally persuade New York officials that they serve the taxpayers — not the other way around?
President Obama ought to press Congress to continue the fight for equal pay for equal work by passing the Paycheck Fairness Act.

The About New York column on Saturday, about James P. Cullen, a retired Army brigadier general who witnessed President Obama’s signing of an executive order banning torture, misstated the surname of another former military officer who has spoken out against the use of torture in gathering intelligence. He is Rear Adm. John D. Hutson, not Huston.
Jamie Langenbrunner scored twice and Brendan Shanahan had his second goal in three games, leading the Devils to a 4-1 win over the Senators.

An article last Wednesday about the Bush family’s return to Midland, Tex., on Inauguration Day referred incorrectly in some editions to Congressional races by the elder and younger George Bushes. The elder Mr. Bush ran for Congress while living in Houston, not Midland. Years later, the younger Mr. Bush indeed ran for Congress, but it was when he was living in Midland, so he did not seek “his father’s Congressional seat.”.

Alberto Gonzales’s smug self-assurance should be another reminder to the White House of the need for an unsparing review of all of President Bush’s policies on torture, wiretapping and executive power.

We invited some professional designers to submit proposals (below) for what they think the Super Bowl logo should look like. They were given a blank slate — no rules or guidelines at all in terms of how the image should look.

An article on Friday about the first briefing by Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, quoted incorrectly from his comment about how President Obama was settling in. He said, “I do think he enjoys, to use a phrase, ‘living above the company store.’ ” Mr. Gibbs did not say that Mr. Obama “enjoys the phrase ‘living above the company store.’ ”.
Cardinals running back Edgerrin James has had a difficult season in Arizona, but he has dealt with everything like a professional.

A listing last Wednesday about restaurants that have received four stars in The New York Times misstated the number of times Le Bernardin has received four stars, the highest rating. The restaurant received four stars in four reviews, not three. (In addition to being awarded four stars by Frank Bruni in 2005, Ruth Reichl in 1995 and Bryan Miller in 1986, it also received four stars from Mr. Miller on Feb. 3, 1989.).

Rebecca Saletan, the former publisher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Books, will join Riverhead Books on March 2 as its editorial director, Riverhead said. Ms. Saletan, who has worked on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “It Takes a Village” and “The Reluctant Fundamentalist” by Mohsin Hamid, among other books, stepped down from Houghton Mifflin Harcourt on Dec. 10. A week earlier, the publisher temporarily stopped acquiring titles after its parent, Education Media and Publishing Group, said it would not allocate as much money on consumer books. At Riverhead, a Penguin Group unit whose authors include Khaled Hosseini and Junot Díaz, Ms. Saletan will report to Geoffrey Kloske, the Riverhead publisher.
Flour meant especially for brioches gets dazzling results.

Fox dominated the ratings on Monday with the combination of “House” and “24,” which led their time slots at 8 p.m. and 9 p.m. with 15.6 million and 12.1 million viewers, respectively, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC was the night’s runner-up with “The Bachelor” (10.6 million) and “True Beauty” (7 million). CBS ranked third with repeats of its comedy lineup followed by a rerun of “CSI: Miami,” which led the 10 p.m. hour with 9.2 million viewers. NBC finished in fourth place, earning 6.7 million viewers for the finale of “Superstars of Dance,” followed by the two-hour conclusion of its mini-series “The Last Templar” (8.3 million).
“Milk” was among five movies nominated by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation for outstanding wide-release film in its annual media awards.

Roberto Bolaño’s widow is challenging his growing reputation as a hard-living literary outlaw with drug problems, while some of his friends are questioning other aspects of the life story he constructed for himself.

The annual Shiite pilgrimage to Karbala has run into a scheduling conflict of a contemporary sort: Saturday’s provincial elections.

The Bolshoi Theater, above, has canceled a ballet tour of Mexico and a new production of the Verdi opera “Otello,” planned for April, citing budget cuts as it faces a fiscal crisis, Agence France-Presse reported. The Moscow theater’s general director, Alexei Iksanov, told the newspaper Novye Izvestia that declining oil prices and the devaluation of the ruble would inevitably lead to cuts in the Bolshoi’s budget. “It would be naïve to believe that culture will be financed as before,” he said, according to Agence France-Presse. The company is still unable to perform in its historic theater near Red Square, which began a $700 million renovation in 2005 that is expected to end in 2011.

Stan Lee, the comics creator, and Marvel Entertainment were among the defendants named in a lawsuit filed on Monday in federal court in Manhattan by investors who say they are owed profits from films and other works that feature Marvel characters, The Associated Press reported. The plaintiffs are shareholders in Stan Lee Media Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy in 2006, and they say they are due profits from any properties based on characters that Mr. Lee helped create, including movies like “Spider-Man,” “X-Men” and “Iron Man.” Mr. Lee had previously sued Marvel for profits generated by his characters, and sued Stan Lee Media for copyright infringement and other claims. In that suit, Mr. Lee’s lawyers said he did not give Stan Lee Media any interests in characters he created for Marvel.
A second portion of the cremated remains of Gene Roddenberry, creator of “Star Trek,” is scheduled for a trip into the great unknown together with those of his wife.
A man shot and killed his wife and five young children before taking his own life Tuesday, possibly out of despair from losing a job, the authorities said.
When you’re in the audience at a play about breast cancer, you don’t expect to laugh a lot. But in Andrea Lepcio’s top-notch play, spontaneous applause tends to break out.
Yahoo reported a net loss of $303 million for the quarter on a number of one-time charges and sales were slightly down as more marketers pulled back on spending.

GOLDENBERG--Rona. The Board of Governors, Members and Staff of Elmwood Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member and friend, Rona Goldenberg. We wish to express our deepest sympathies to her family. Services Thursday, 11:45 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th St., New York, NY.
SIEGEL--Eleanor. Aunt Elly, I shall cherish the memory of your sparkling eyes and vivacious spirit. With love and admiration, Cynthia

UPDIKE--John. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with deep sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, a novelist without peer. The world of letters has lost an irreplaceable master.

SHOWING HIS EMOTIONS Todd Haley talked about his run-in with Anquan Boldin at the N.F.C. title game. ''The other night, they were showing clips of Bill Parcells in the Giants' day, and I didn't feel so bad because I'm like, there's my guy and he's getting after Phil Simms and getting after the defense,'' Haley said. ''So, it's the way I am. There are a lot of great coaches who are quiet leaders and there are a lot of great coaches who are more emotional guys, and I just happen to fit into the emotional, fiery side, I guess.'' GREG BISHOP

PETRELLI--Adam Michael, 31, passed away January 22, 2009 in New York City, NY. He will be missed by his those who survive him, including his father, Anthony Petrelli and his wife Shonya Petrelli; his mother, Mary Gallo and her husband Craig Gallo; his brother Brian Petrelli and his wife, Erica and their children, Joseph and Vincent; his brother Michael Petrelli and his fiance, Molly Mulligan; his sister, Katie Bond and his brother, Caleb Bond. Visitation will be held at Olinger Chapel Hill Mortuary, 6601 S. Colorado Blvd. in Littleton, CO, Wednesday, January 28th from 4-7pm. Recitation of the Rosary will begin at 7pm. A service will be held for Adam at Greenwood Community Church, 5600 E. Belleview Ave. in Greenwood Village, CO on Thursday, January 29th at 3pm. There will be a memorial service held in New York City later in February. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association by going to www.americanheart.org. To view Adam's memorial website and share your memories and condolences, please visit www.mem.com

DONAHUE--Warren F.,of the Bronx, Armonk, and North Ft. Myers, Florida. Beloved husband of the late Mildred Smith. A scholar of history, he published a treatise on the rise and fall of democracies in the Western world, The Remarkable Pattern of Western History, which plotted the course of democratic development over the past 2,000 years. He is survived by a brother, Thomas R., of Washington, DC, 12 nieces and nephews and 31 grandnieces and grandnephews. He will be waked at The McMahonLyon-Hartnett Funeral Home on Thursday, January 29th from 4-6pm and 7-9pm. A funeral mass will take place on Friday at 10am at Church of St. Patrick in Armonk, New York with burial to follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

LOFRUMENTO--Maria. The Hunter College Community mourns with deep sorrow the death of its proud alummna and beloved educator. A strong, indefatigable presense at Hunter College High School, Maria began her tenure at HCHS teaching French and Spanish. She served as chairman of the department and as principal from 1971 until her retirement in 1984. She has enriched the lives of generations of students. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Ave., New York, NY 10065, ATTN: Room E1313. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College

KAY--Bertram M. (Buddy). Born August 30, 1925, died January 25, 2009. Served in the Pacific Theater as a marine in WWII, received the Purple Heart, graduated Syracuse University, then became Senior Vice President of Morgan Stanley-Dean Witter for over 30 years. Son of the late Frank and Dorothy Kay, survived by his wife Elizabeth, two daughters Lisa and Tracey Kay, stepdaughters Liz Carlton and Sue Gordon and four loving grandchildren Sara, Anne, Robin and Patrick. Contributions may be made to ''Buddy's Team'', care of Alzheimers Association of Connecticut, 279 New Britain St., Suite 5, Kensington, CT 06037.

SMOOT--Katharine (''Kitty'') Smull, M.D.,born 1915 in New York City, died peacefully at her home in Laurel Hollow, NY late last week. Wife of the late William Sydney Smoot, she is survived by her daughter, Sally Smoot Ingraham, and her grandchildren, David Smoot Ingraham and Sarah Jennings Ingraham. After attending The Chapin School, Vassar College and the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, she became a medical researcher whose work at the University of Chicago in the 1950s helped reduce the prevalence of childhood rheumatic fever in America. She was also an avid sailor who, in 1954, braved Hurricane Carol in open ocean while cruising near the Isles of Shoals in a 40 foot cutter. SHAPIRO--Anna, age 99, died comfortably at home on January 26, 2009. Anna was the beloved Grandmother of Raj Brandston, Sarah Brandston, and Ivy Crewdson. Greatgrandmother of Lilianna Francis Crewdson and Walker Elias Crewdson. The adored mother-in-law of Ellen Phelan and the very much-loved mother of the late Joan Brandston (1976) and Joel Shapiro. For over fifty years Anna was the adored wife and soul mate of Joseph Shapiro. They met as undergraduate students at Washington Square College. While Joe was attending Medical School, Anna did research at the pioneering immunological laboratory of Albert Sabin at Bellevue. During WWII while Joe ran the medical services at Walters Army Base in Texas, Anna set up one of the first early childhood education programs in Texas. Anna was a radical and original thinker but also extremely practical and immensely charming and intelligent. Anna maintained her intense curiosity and enthusiasm into advanced age. After WWII Anna worked tirelessly in Sunnyside, Queens as a community activist, advocating rational choice within the public schools, based on pedagogy rather than political ideology. In the late fifties, Anna became a science teacher in the public schools. She was a wonderful, inspiring and charismatic teacher. She completed her Ph.D. in microbiology and then worked on infectious diseases at Haskins Laboratory at Pace University with Seymour Hutner. Anna had a rich life and has left an inspiring legacy. Aside from her achievements as a scientist: Anna loved music, she was an accomplished pianist, a wicked scrabble player, visually sophisticated and advanced in her taste, a wonderful and adventurous cook, and most importantly a warm compassionate friend who always encouraged others to pursue their dreams. She was a beacon of light and deeply loved by all who knew her. The service is Thursday, 12:45pm at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in Anna's memory can be sent to: The Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors Program, One Gustave Levy Place, Box 1216, NYC, NY 10024.

JONES--Emily Strange, 89, died on January 20, 2009, after a brief illness. She was born in Rochester, NY, daughter of the late Dr. Leonard W. and Helen S. Jones. Miss Jones graduated from Vassar College in 1940, and moved to New York City where she worked first as a children's librarian, and then for many years as the Executive Director of the Educational Film Library Association (EFLA). EFLA, which sponsored the annual American Film Festival Blue Ribbon Awards, called its top prize the ''Emily'' in Miss Jones' honor. After her retirement, Miss Jones taught a film course at C.W. Post College, NY. Miss Jones was an avid birdwatcher, and was a founding member of the New York City chapter of the National Audubon Society. She traveled all over the world to view birds in their natural habitats, and was regarded as an expert on bird identification. She was a founding member and past president of the New York Gesneriad Society. She was also a passionate theatergoer. For many years, she owned a sailboat and enjoyed sailing on Great South Bay. She retired to Rappahannock Westminster Canterbury in Irvington, Virginia in 1997, where she lived until her death. She was preceded in death by her parents, brothers, Nathan F. Jones and Kearney L. Jones, sister, Constance J. Burkhart, and particular friends Jessie B. Kitching and Martha C. Bentley. She is survived by her nieces, Helen J. Plaisance of Charlottesville, VA; Sidney R. Jones of Jakarta, Indonesia; her nephews, Andrew L. Jones, Roderick F. Jones of New York City, and Brian A. Burkhart of Rochester, New York; two great-nieces, Katelyn Burkhart of Geneseo, NY, and Leah Burkhart Dix of Burlington, VT; two cousins, Emily Rankin of CT and Betsy Fredell of Webster NY; Helen's partner, Amy Griffith, also of Charlottesville VA, and a devoted friend and companion, Barbara Butler, of Kilmarnock, VA. A Memorial Service will be held 1:00pm February 14, 2009 at Rappahannock WestminsterCanterbury, lrvington, VA. A private graveside ceremony will be held in the spring at Mount Hope Cemetery in Rochester, NY. Memorial contributions can be made to the New York City Audubon Society, the New York City Gesneriad Society or any local Audubon Society chapter.

Weeks after the Walt Disney Company announced that it would no longer be a producer of the “Chronicles of Narnia” fantasy adventure movies, Aslan the lion has come roaring back with 20th Century Fox, Variety reported. Walden Media, which produced the first two movies in the series, “The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe” and “Prince Caspian,” with Disney, will instead pair up with the Fox 2000 studio to develop and produce a third film, “Voyage of the Dawn Treader.” Disney said in December that it would not be a partner on this film for budgetary and logistical reasons; the first “Narnia” movie grossed $745 million worldwide but its sequel took in $419 million. “Voyage of the Dawn Treader” is scheduled for a holiday 2010 release.

A classical music critic at The Cleveland Plain Dealer who filed suit against the newspaper after he was removed from his job has dropped all but one of his claims against the paper and its editor, The Plain Dealer reported. In December, the critic, Donald Rosenberg, sued the newspaper and the Musical Arts Association, the parent company of the Cleveland Orchestra, saying that the orchestra had waged a “campaign of vilification” against him because of his negative reviews, and that the newspaper had given into the orchestra’s demands. Mr. Rosenberg, who is still a music reporter and dance critic at The Plain Dealer, has dropped his claims that the paper defamed him and violated Ohio’s free speech principle; he is still asserting that his reassignment constituted age discrimination. Mr. Rosenberg’s claim that the Musical Arts Association committed tortious interference with his job remains unchanged. The Plain Dealer reported that Mr. Rosenberg’s lawyer said the suit had been amended to ensure that it would be tried in state rather than federal court.

The Opera Orchestra Of New York said that it had canceled the remainder of its season, citing the financial crisis and decreased financing. In a news release, the company said it had canceled a concert with the Italian bass Ferruccio Furlanetto, scheduled for Feb. 27, but that a planned production of Wagner’s “Rienzi” would be rescheduled for its 2009-10 season and a production of Cherubini’s “Medea” would instead be the opening performance of its 2010-11 season. In a statement, Norman Raben, the chairman of the opera company’s board, said, “We regret the need for this decision, but feel it is the most responsible action to take in the current economic climate.” Tickets purchased for these events online or by phone will be refunded automatically; tickets purchased in person can be refunded at the Carnegie Hall box office. Patrons who purchased tickets through Opera Orchestra of New York should call 212-799-1982.

This week’s shakeup of leadership at the Screen Actors Guild, in which Doug Allen was fired as its chief negotiator, has resulted in plans to resume long-stalled contract negotiations with movie and television studios. In a joint statement late Wednesday night, the guild and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said talks would resume on Tuesday and Wednesday at the headquarters of the producers’ organization. Although plans are still in the early stages, both sides are eager to ratchet down the public sniping – coming almost entirely from S.A.G. – and are expected to institute a press blackout surrounding negotiations. The two sides have been deadlocked on a new contract since June, with payment for Web-distributed productions the key issue.

Six architectural teams will compete to design the new National Museum of African American History and Culture on the National Mall in Washington, the Smithsonian announced on Thursday. The candidates, all two-firm teams, are Foster + Partners in a joint venture with URS; Diller Scofidio + Renfro in association with KlingStubbins; Freelon Adjaye Bond and SmithGroup; Devrouax & Purnell Architects/Planners, P.C. and Pei Cobb Freed & Partners Architects; Moody Nolan Inc. and Antoine Predock Architect PC; and Moshe Safdie and Associates Inc. in association with Sultan Campbell Britt & Associates. The winner will be expected to complete the design within three years with construction scheduled to start in 2012 and be completed by 2015. The museum will be on Constitution Avenue between the Washington Monument and the National Museum of American History. The finalists were chosen by a Smithsonian panel from 22 candidates who responded to an invitation last summer to architects to submit their qualifications.

Perhaps it’s true that even bad publicity is better than no publicity: The revival of David Mamet’s play “Speed-the-Plow,” which sparked headlines after losing its original star, Jeremy Piven, has recouped its initial investment of $2.26 million. Jeffrey Richards, one of the producers, said he was “delighted that the show has proved so popular and durable through an unusual period.” Mr. Piven, who opened the show in October to strong reviews, abruptly quit last month because of what a doctor described as mercury poisoning. Mr. Richards and the other producers filed a grievance on Jan. 16 against Mr. Piven with Actors’ Equity Association over his withdrawal; the actors’ union has not set a date for considering the grievance, Mr. Richards said. Two popular Broadway actors stepped into Mr. Piven’s role — first Norbert Leo Butz, and then William H. Macy, who will see the show through to the end of its limited run, on Feb. 22.

Leaders of New York’s Public Theater said on Thursday that they have signed an agreement with the Broadway producer Elizabeth I. McCann that avoids legal action, threatened by Ms. McCann, over the upcoming transfer of the musical “Hair,” which is scheduled to begin rehearsals on Friday.

Fund-raising by candidates for political offices in New York City dropped markedly in the most recent six-month filing period that ended on Jan. 11, the city's Campaign Finance Board reported on Thursday. The playoff races are about to start in earnest, which means it's time for us to begin our annual corrective to the N.H.L.'s cockamamie way of listing teams' records. The league standings may look like the traditional won-lost-tied, but they're not -- that last column, "OT," is for losses that the N.H.L. has decided will not count as losses. It's all deliberate, of course, so that a bunch of mediocre teams look like they're playing well above .500. It fools a lot of people.

While the Abstract Expressionists were mainly painters and sculptors, Aaron Siskind is perhaps the only photographer to be considered a member of the group. Siskind (1903-91) began his photographic career as a documentary shooter, but he eventually moved from discernible subject matter to something more emblematic. For instance, his wall-graffiti series titled "Homage to Franz Kline" recalls the painter's haphazard brushstrokes and nonfigurative work.

Yesterday Gallup released a report on its survey of political party affiliation by voters at the state level. The SIHH watch fair in Geneva, showing for the first time in January rather than with Baselworld in April, was a nice daylong diversion from the fall-winter '09 men's-wear fashion shows in Milan and Paris. Instead of playing musical chairs at the shows, I strolled around the halls of the convention center checking out the new offerings in the Richemont Group watch world, assembling my best in show.The big news was the premiere of Ralph Lauren's luxury watch collection, four years in the making. Mr. Lauren was in Geneva to host a celebratory dinner for the line, which will be available in April in Ralph Lauren stores and select shops. I was a bit surprised to find that the entry price points were around $12,000 - but then again, he decided to forgo the obvious licensee route and take a more hands-on approach with the design, working with companies like Piaget and Jaeger le Coultre on the movements.
