My Thursday column argues that we need an investigative commission looking at torture and other abuses, and that the chance is slipping away. President Obama and some other Democrats are worried of antagonizing Republicans whom they will need to advance the Obama agenda, but it should be possible to devise a commission that has enough Republicans high up that it will never be perceived as a witch hunt. That's why I came up with the idea for a McCain-Scowcroft Commission -- and please offer your own ideas for the leadership and membership.

An open secret: In press boxes throughout the country, when we sportswriters really need to see what happened, we watch on television, too. Why? Because members of the news media - the same people who are supposed to report what happened back to everyone at home - have a worse view than those at home.

Amouage is a niche house - and a very expensive one, at that - that is run out of London but has its roots in the Middle East. Those roots are essentially two: the house's wealthy Omani financial backers (the royal family, actually) and its Arabian peninsula olfactory aesthetic. I have often found that Amouage scents bear more of Arab culture's obsession with incense than I can assimilate (Arabia is one of the great originators of the use of incense), heavy and thick, perhaps mixed with smoky, all-but-charred roses, the whole contraption's volume set to "Overwhelm." (The grimace-inducing French corollary is animalic notes: the civet fecal smell of Jicky; Jicky's armpit-and-dirty-underwear grandson, Kouros; and so on. The American contribution to this list would be the army of American perfumes smelling of scrubbed shower tile and aluminum foil -- though, for the record, this genre was created, inconceivably, by a French perfumer.)

As I was leaving the Valentino show at the Sorbonne last night, I overheard a young man say to a woman from the Roman house: "Beautiful." And she answered, with a huge sigh, "It's Valentino again!" It was as though she were talking about an amnesia victim who had made a miraculous recovery.

The owner of a leather-goods factory was sentenced to a year in prison Tuesday for harboring and concealing illegal immigrants at the plant, which agents raided in 2007. The man, Francesco Insolia, pleaded guilty in November. He said in court he took full responsibility for not taking any action after being informed that illegal immigrants were working in his factory in New Bedford. “I’m responsible for the conduct,” Mr. Insolia said. “Never in my worst nightmare would I think I’d find myself in the position I am in today.” Mr. Insolia’s company, Michael Bianco Inc., was ordered to pay $1 million for 18 counts of knowingly hiring illegal immigrants from 2004 to late 2006. When the factory was raided in March 2007, federal authorities arrested 361 workers, most of them from Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras.

The pilots of two Phoenix news helicopters had so many distractions that they lost track of each other, resulting in a midair collision that killed four, a National Transportation Safety Board panel said. The panel said the probable cause of the accident in July 2007 was that the two helicopters drifted too close together because the pilots were focused on watching a police car chase and reporting the event for their television stations. The five-member board unanimously recommended that television stations no longer have helicopter pilots also report while they fly unless the stations can demonstrate that the pilots can do both safely. One of the Phoenix stations involved in the crash now has a second pilot do reporting, while the other station no longer has pilots report as they fly, investigators said.

Foreign diplomats based in the United States can now buy tobacco products tax-free. Under a State Department rule that took effect Tuesday, no federal, state or local tax will be levied on cigars, cigarettes and pipe tobacco for diplomats whose countries extend the same privilege to American envoys. A notice in the Federal Register says the department took the action to improve tax-exemptions for American diplomats posted abroad.

The mayor of Gulfport pleaded not guilty to charges that he lied to get disaster assistance to repair a beachfront home after Hurricane Katrina. The mayor, Brent Warr, and his wife, Laura, pleaded not guilty to charges in a 16-count indictment. Mr. Warr said that the charges had nothing to do with his role as mayor and that he would continue to run Gulfport, a coastal city of about 73,000 people. The Warrs are accused of seeking a grant for a storm-damaged beachfront home they owned but did not live in. The government is seeking forfeiture of $222,798. Mr. Warr, 45, and his wife, 43, also are accused of making false claims to their insurance company.

A resolution congratulating Barack Obama on his election as president was rejected by a committee of the Arkansas House of Representatives after lawmakers objected to language in the measure that referred to the United States as “a nation founded by slave owners.” Eight of the 11 members of the panel, the State Agencies Committee, who opposed the resolution were Republicans, and one Republican joined five Democrats in supporting it. Two Democrats abstained. Opponents said the measure inaccurately presumed that all the nation’s founders were slaveholders. The resolution’s sponsor, Representative Stephanie Flowers, Democrat of Pine Bluff and the daughter of a pioneering black Arkansas lawyer and judge, said that “it’s unfortunate that we can’t accept the truth of our history,” and that she saw “no reason” to rewrite passages that some Republicans said were “divisive.”.

The Gulf of Mexico Fishery Management Council, which regulates fishing in federal waters in the gulf, approved regulations that would for the first time allow aquaculture in federal waters of the United States. The move, contested by environmental groups, must be confirmed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which oversees fisheries councils nationwide. Shellfish aquaculture is common in state waters, which typically extend to three miles offshore, and there are some small finfish operations there. But finfish aquaculture in federal waters has been delayed by, among other things, the slow progress in the Congress of regulatory legislation. Critics of finfish aquaculture say the farms can spread diseases and note that the demand for fish pellets used to feed farmed fish is sharply depleting wild stocks of fish like menhaden. Advocates say the farms could help reduce fish imports, which account for 80 percent or more of fish eaten in the United States.

An obituary on Saturday about Constance E. Cook, a former New York State assemblywoman who was co-author of the law that legalized abortion in the state, misstated her parents’ surname. It was Eberhardt, not Cook.

An article on Jan. 20 about online notification of people exposed to sexually transmitted diseases referred incorrectly at several points to inSPOT, a notification system developed by the nonprofit agency Internet Sexuality Information Services. Eleven cities and 10 states now have inSPOT Web sites, not 9 cities and 3 states. Denver is included in Colorado’s site, but does not have its own. And the notification system includes heterosexuals, not just gay men. (Initially, it was exclusively for gay men, but expanded its audience in 2006.).

An article on Saturday about the book “The Other Side of Desire: Four Journeys Into the Far Realms of Lust and Longing,” by Daniel Bergner, referred incorrectly to an enterprise of a woman known as the Baroness who is interviewed in the book. While she hosts what she describes as New York’s longest-running fetish party, she does not run an S&M dungeon.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the United States Figure Skating Championships referred incorrectly to the previous top accomplishments of Brandon Mroz, an 18-year-old high school senior who finished second. He was second twice at the junior national championships — not at the world junior championships, where he was fourth the past two years.

An article on Jan. 20 about the financial problems of home builders misstated the actions that JPMorgan Chase took against Brown Family Communities, a borrower in Arizona. The bank took control of five subdivisions built by Brown Family Communities by winning appointment of a court receiver for the properties, not by foreclosing on loans. The article also may have left an incorrect impression that Brown Family Communities went out of business after the bank took control of the properties. The builder had announced its intention to go out of business before the bank acted, blaming its financial straits on earlier steps taken by JPMorgan Chase and other banks.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about a community board’s rejection of plans by Fordham University to expand its Manhattan campus — plans that include selling some of its property — referred incorrectly to the American Red Cross, also a nonprofit. The organization’s Greater New York division sold its Manhattan headquarters in 2004; it did not give up air rights.

An article on Tuesday about a feud between Democratic lawmakers from the coasts and those from the Midwest and Plains over global warming legislation misidentified the research institute where Steven Chu, the new secretary of energy, was director. It is the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, not the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.

An article on Saturday about President Obama’s efforts to win support for an $825 billion economic stimulus plan referred incorrectly to the Senate version of the bill. It would indeed provide subsidies (for up to nine months) to help workers who lose their jobs keep their health insurance coverage under a law known as Cobra; it would not exclude such subsidies.

CBS’s “NCIS” attracted its third-largest audience ever, 19 million viewers, on Tuesday night, despite competing with Fox’s “American Idol” at 8, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although Fox easily led the night over all, garnering 25.2 million for “American Idol” and 12.1 million for “Fringe,” CBS finished a not-too-distant runner-up, winning the remainder of the night with a repeat of “The Mentalist” (15.1 million) followed by a new episode of “Without a Trace” (12.8 million). NBC was third in total viewers but got a boost from “The Biggest Loser,” which averaged 11 million total viewers from 8 to 10. At 10, NBC’s rerun of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (7.1 million) edged past “Primetime: What Would You Do?” (6.3 million) on ABC, which was fourth for the night.

And how many years must Bob Dylan wait before he licenses one of his most beloved ballads for use in a British television commercial? The answer, my friend, is 47. Mr. Dylan, above, has once again baffled his fans by giving permission for his protest song “Blowin’ in the Wind” to be used in an advertisement for the Co-operative Group, Agence France-Presse reported. The song, which Mr. Dylan began performing in 1962 and appears on the 1963 Columbia Records album “The Freewheelin’ Bob Dylan,” is the first that he’s allowed for use in British commercials. The Co-operative Group, which operates supermarkets as well as travel, legal and funeral services, is a proponent of ethical and accountable trading practices. A spokesman for Sony, the parent company of Columbia, said that Mr. Dylan “has a career based on surprising people, on people not being able to second-guess him.”.

Bruce Springsteen has announced dates for his tour to promote his album “Working on a Dream,” which was released on Tuesday. The 47-date tour with the E Street Band begins on April 1 in San Jose, Calif.; includes shows at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., on May 21 and 23; and continues with dates in Europe over the summer. The band is scheduled to perform in Tampa, Fla., at the Super Bowl halftime show on Sunday. ... The group will complete its season at the Cherry Lane Theater, at 38 Commerce Street in the West Village. Intar’s production of new plays by Eduardo Machado, the company’s artistic director, and Nick Norman is scheduled to begin on Feb. 15 and run through March 7.

Having filmed Michael Jackson dancing in a graveyard, the filmmaker John Landis now seeks to place him somewhere equally as frightening: a court of law. Last week Mr. Landis, the director and co-writer of the video for Mr. Jackson’s “Thriller,” filed suit against Mr. Jackson, asking for unpaid profits from the video and a making-of documentary, Variety reported. The suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, says that for the past four years Mr. Jackson and his company Optimum Productions have not paid Mr. Landis money he is owed from these projects or accounted for their profits. On Monday the Nederlander Organization announced that it had acquired the rights to produce a musical based on “Thriller” and its video, a homage to horror movies in which Mr. Jackson turns into a werewolf and a zombie.

Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) remains No. 1 on the Billboard chart for the seventh week in a row and eighth over all, with 63,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. With low sales all around and no new blockbusters, this week’s Top 10 looks a lot like last week’s: Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) holds at No. 2, and Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) remains No. 3. The only new entry is a Mariah Carey compilation, “The Ballads” (Columbia), which reached No. 10 with 29,000 sales. ... Kelly Clarkson’s song “My Life Would Suck Without You” received 280,000 downloads in the song’s first week online and will jump 96 spots to No. 1 on this week’s Hot 100, to be published on Thursday. That’s the biggest one-week leap to No. 1 in the 51-year history of the chart, which considers airplay as well as sales.

The Los Angeles Opera announced Tuesday that it had laid off 17 employees, representing 17 percent of its staff, The Los Angeles Times reported. The company said it was imposing pay cuts of around 6 percent for its remaining staff, though some higher-paid employees received an 8 percent cut. Plácido Domingo, the general director, said that he had deferred his salary last year to help cut costs, according to The Times. ... Harold A. Sorgenti will step down as the chairman of the Philadelphia Orchestra, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. Mr. Sorgenti was scheduled to leave the position in September but has instead taken a leave of absence to “focus on business interests,” an orchestra spokeswoman told The Inquirer. The orchestra is now without a chairman, president or music director.

President Dmitri A. Medvedev has asked that a bill to expand the definition of espionage and state treason, a measure backed by Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, be revised. The bill had prompted an outcry in the media and among government critics, and Mr. Medvedev's request appears to represent a rare example of public opinion influencing policy in Russia. ''Possibly there is a danger that the concepts of state secrets, high treason and spying could be construed too broadly,'' Vladislav Y. Surkov, the first deputy presidential chief of staff, said Tuesday, according to the Interfax news agency. ''The bill will be adjusted.'' Mr. Medvedev has been under close scrutiny by Kremlin watchers for signs of a break with the hard-line policies of Mr. Putin. But it was unclear whether Mr. Medvedev's request signified any real division between them. Officials and government critics have argued for years that the current definitions of treason and espionage in Russia needed refinement. But critics said the bill would have allowed officials to equate government criticism with state treason.
GOLDBERG--Matilda. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Lucy, Robert and the entire family. May her memory remain for a blessing.

BUCHMAN--Lewis Charles, 81, retired president of Grayblock Ribbon Co. With heavy hearts, his loving family announces his passing on January 25, 2009. Service February 1, 2009, 1:30pm, National Funeral Home, 7482 Lee Hwy., Falls Church, VA. (703)560-4400. Burial at King David Memorial Gardens.

NIRRENGARTEN--Rev. Andrew G.,a good and faithful priest, entered new life peacefully and prayerfully on January 25 at age 71 after a long illness. He was a loving brother to his three sisters: Sr. Barbara, OP, Mary Bellacosa (Joseph) and Catherine Weber (Ronald), uncle to Michael, Peter, Barbara, Christopher and Jacquelyn and friend to many people. Father Andy devoted 42 years ministering to the people of the Diocese of Rockville Centre. ''A priest forever according to the rite of Melchizedek.'' May he rest in God's peace. Memorial donations can be sent to the Sisters of St. Dominic, 555 Albany Ave., Amityville, NY 11701. Funeral services entrusted to O.B. Davis Funeral Homes, Port Jefferson Station, NY.

BROOKS--Mildred Alice, 94, died January 20, 2009, in Rockville, MD. A scientist, herbalist and naturopath, she shared her love of nature with her biology students in Texas and New York and with the children of Camp Treetops in Lake Placid, NY. She is survived by her sister Patricia Evans, nephew Scott Evans, nieces Stacie and Candice Evans, and grandnephew and grandniece Caleb and Tess Gilligan-Evans. A lifelong fighter for equal rights, Miss Brooks lived to see the inauguration of Barack Obama before she went to rest. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mildred Brooks Nature Program Endowment at Camp Treetops. Gifts can be sent to Box 187, Lake Placid, NY 12946 or made online at http:// www.nct.org/ page.cfm?p=212.

Canada's parliamentary turmoil abated, at least temporarily, on Wednesday after an opposition alliance backed down from its efforts to defeat the government. Prime Minister Stephen Harper, a Conservative, had presented a budget on Tuesday promising tens of billions of dollars in new spending, much of it in areas like housing that the party had never previously championed. On Wednesday, the Liberal Party's leader, Michael Ignatieff, broke with the two other coalition parties and offered conditional support for the budget, which effectively guaranteed that it would pass.

GOLDBERG--Matilda G. (Matty), on January 28. Widow of Samuel Goldberg, Ph.D. She will always be missed by her loving and bereft family. Children: Lucy and Robert Becker, Barbara J. Berg and Arnold Schlanger, grandchildren: Nancy and Scott Margolin, Alison and Michael Dalewitz, Jonathan Becker, Andrew Schlanger, great-granddaughter: Olivia Margolin. A graduate of Barnard College, with masters degrees in history and library science, she was a lifelong educator and activist, deeply respected by all who knew her. Matty was a woman of uncommon intellect and beauty, intense family loyalty, a passion for social justice. The void she leaves will never be filled. Funeral services: 11am Friday, Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street, New York.

The About New York column on Jan. 10, about the additional $370 million in taxpayer-backed financing the Yankees were seeking for their new stadium, said that the city was pitching in $660 million to replace parkland lost during the stadium construction, and for transportation costs. After the column was published, city economic development officials, who currently estimate those costs at $306 million, challenged the $660 million figure. The $660 million includes what it will take to pay for the city's planned financing of the replacement parkland, transportation and related infrastructure costs through 40-year general obligation bonds, with interest.

NAGIN--Lawrence M.,died on Wednesday, January 28, 2009, of complications from cancer. Larry, a third-generation Californian, was born on February 14, 1941, in San Francisco; the son of Maurine M. Nagin and David L. Nagin. Within a few months, Larry moved with his family, including his loving sister, Fredericka, and his beloved ''Ria'', Marie E. Jacobs, to Los Angeles. Larry attended public schools in the City of Los Angeles and received a Bachelor of Arts in International Relations from the University of Southern California in 1962. He then attended The University of California, Hastings College of the Law, graduating with a Juris Doctor degree in 1965. He became a Member of the State Bar of California, and remained a member for more than 42 years. From 1966 to 1968, Larry served as a Deputy Public Defender for the County of Los Angeles. From 1968 to 1974, Larry was in private practice in the City of Beverly Hills. From 1974 to 1980, Larry served as Special Counsel to the City Attorney of the City of Los Angeles, and then Senior Assistant City Attorney representing the Los Angeles Department of Airports. In 1980, Larry began his career as an airline industry executive when he joined the Los Angeles-based Flying Tigers as its General Counsel. Flying Tigers was, at that time, the world's largest all-cargo airline. In 1986, Stephen M. Wolf became the airlines Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. In 1988, Larry moved to Chicago, where he joined United Airlines as Executive Vice President and General Counsel, serving again under Stephen M. Wolf, the Chief Executive Officer. Larry helped navigate United through a period of tremendous growth and transformation that ultimately resulted in an employee buyout of the company in 1994. Larry then became of counsel to the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LP, in its Chicago office, until March 1996 when he joined the Virginia-based, US Airways, again under the leadership of Mr. Wolf. Since retirement from US Airways in 2002, Larry had been a Senior Strategic Advisor with the law firm of O'Melveny & Myers LLP, in their New York City office. From the time Larry was a young boy he had a passion for the airline industry--he spent time at Los Angeles International Airport watching airplanes take off and land. He pored over airline schedules and collected airline memorabilia. He always felt fortunate to have transformed a childhood love of airplanes into a lasting and singular career in aviation. Larry leaves his beloved wife of 41 years, Sherrie, his two adored sons, Daniel, a Professor at the University of Virginia School of Law, and Benjamin, a partner in the law firm, Sidley Austin LLP, Daniels wife, Tomiko Brown-Nagin, Ph.D., also a Professor at the University of Virginia School of Law, and Benjamins wife, Melissa Kotlen Nagin, a lactation consultant and writer for About.com; five precious and beloved grandchildren: Zachary Samuel Nagin, Sarah Rose Nagin, Alexander Gabriel Nagin, Julius Brown Nagin, and Avishai Brown Nagin; his adored sister Fredericka and her children, David Miller (Judy Miller M.D.), Deborah Miller and Jennifer Tidstrand (Douglas Tid strand). In addition, he is survived by his loving brother-inlaw, Robert Gandin, DDS, his loving sisters-in-law, Mindy Gandin, Louise Feinberg, Marsha Gandin, and many dear nieces and nephews. Services will be held on Friday, January 30, 2009, at 9:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Street at 81st Street, New York, NY. Interment will follow at Westchester Hills Cemetery, 400 Saw Mill River Road, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. The family requests that memorial contributions be made to The Lawrence M. Nagin Faculty Enrichment Fund; University of California, Hastings College of the Law; 200 McAllister Street, San Francisco, CA 94102. The fund was created by Larry to support faculty research on issues of social justice.

The owner of The St. Petersburg Times put its Congressional Quarterly subsidiary up for sale on Wednesday, trying to separate the most profitable part of the business from the more troubled flagship newspaper. Executives of the parent company, the Times Publishing Company, said that with the financial crisis in the newspaper business hitting Florida markets especially hard, it no longer had the resources to keep expanding Congressional Quarterly Inc. A sale would also generate cash to help shore up The St. Petersburg Times newspaper.

SHAPIRO--Anna, age 99, died comfortably at home on January 26, 2009. Anna was the beloved Grandmother of Raj Brandston, Sarah Brandston, and Ivy Crewdson. Greatgrandmother of Lilianna Frances Crewdson and Walker Elias Crewdson. The adored mother-in-law of Ellen Phelan and the very much-loved mother of the late Joan Brandston (1976) and Joel Shapiro. For over fifty years Anna was the adored wife and soul mate of Joseph Shapiro. They met as undergraduate students at Washington Square College. While Joe was attending Medical School, Anna did research at the pioneering immunological laboratory of Albert Sabin at Bellevue. During WWII while Joe ran the medical services at Walters Army Base in Texas, Anna set up one of the first early childhood education programs in Texas. Anna was a radical and original thinker but also extremely practical and immensely charming and intelligent. Anna maintained her intense curiosity and enthusiasm into advanced age. After WWII Anna worked tirelessly in Sunnyside, Queens as a community activist, advocating rational choice within the public schools, based on pedagogy rather than political ideology. In the late fifties, Anna became a science teacher in the public schools. She was a wonderful, inspiring and charismatic teacher. She completed her Ph.D. in microbiology and then worked on infectious diseases at Haskins Laboratory at Pace University with Seymour Hutner. Anna had a rich life and has left an inspiring legacy. Aside from her achievements as a scientist: Anna loved music, she was an accomplished pianist, a wicked scrabble player, visually sophisticated and advanced in her taste, a wonderful and adventurous cook, and most importantly a warm compassionate friend who always encouraged others to pursue their dreams. She was a beacon of light and deeply loved by all who knew her. The service is Thursday, 12:45pm at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in Anna's memory can be sent to: The Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors Program, One Gustave Levy Place, Box 1216, NYC, NY 10024.

As lawmakers pressed the Obama administration for details of how it would assist financial firms that have been rapidly deteriorating, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said Wednesday the administration is working on a comprehensive plan to ''repair the financial system.'' He discouraged speculation that the plan would include the nationalization of some banks.

SCHUMACHER--Allen E.,died Friday, January 23rd, 2009 in Holmdel, New Jersey of Waldenstrom Macroglobulinemia, at 82. He was resident of Smoke Rise, Kinnelon, New Jersey since 1975. One of the giants of marine insurance, retired 1987 Chairman and CEO of the American Hull Insurance Syndicate, a world leader in ship insurance. Served US Army active duty until 1945/reserves until 1958, rank, Captain, awarded Purple Heart, BA in economics University of CaliforniaBerkeley, graduated in 1949 (a fraternity brother of Phi Kappa Sigma). His Marine Insurance career began, in San Francisco, in 1950. A Full Member of the Association of Average Adjusters, (Voted Chairman) 1973-1974. He was Chairman of U.S. Salvage Association, Board of Managers-American Bureau of Shipping, and an active executive of Seamen's Church Institute. He was brilliant, intense, funny, loving, dedicated, conservative, articulate, intellectual, wry, professorial, a lover of soft music and a dry martini, but most of all, his love of his wife and his children knew no bounds. Surviving are his loving wife Gloria, married 60 years, daughter Lana, son Mark, grandchildren Dawn, Deborah, James, Julianne, and three great-grandchildren. In respect of his wishes Allen was privately cremated. Funeral services were entrusted to the Shore Point Funeral Home and Cremation Services, 3269 Highway 35 in Hazlet, NJ 07730, through whom condolences can be sent by mail or by web to: www.shorepointfh.com select obituary and Mr. Schumacher's name to leave condolences. A memorial Service will be held on Saturday, February 7, 2009 at 2pm at the Community Church of Smoke Rise, Kinnelon, New Jersey 07405. Use the North Gate of Smoke Rise off Route 23 south bound.

BRADY--James. The staff of Parade magazine mourns the loss of a dear friend and colleague, James Brady, author, journalist and writer of Parade's popular ''In Step With'' celebrity profile column. ''Jim was a friend to the 73 million Americans who looked forward to his column each week, and he was a friend to all of us here at Parade,'' said CEO and Chairman Walter Anderson. ''He was also a decorated war hero and a towering figure in American journalism. He will be extraordinarily missed.'' Walter Anderson, Chairman

AS more commuters ride bikes, more cyclists put themselves in danger. Should riding across the Williamsburg Bridge at night really be a deadly adventure sport? From 2007 to 2008, the New York City Department of Transportation recorded a 35 percent increase in the number of commuter cyclists, and an observational study released by Hunter College last fall found that the majority of city riders don't obey safety rules. While state law requires the use of white headlights and red taillights when riding between dusk and dawn, 45 percent of cycling fatalities in New York City still occur during low-light hours, according to Transportation Department statistics.

In the post-Bush post-bubble era, it’s almost as hard to find a military hawk as it is to find a free-market capitalist.
President Barack Obama’s willingness to talk to Iran seems to have put the Iranian leadership in an uncomfortable spot — both in Tehran and in Davos, Switzerland.

Davos Diary’s sibling site The Lede has followed up on one of the most-discussed incidents at the World Economic Forum so far: the heated exchange between Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the prime minister of Turkey, and Shimon Peres, the president of Israel over the recent Israeli assault in Gaza.

The financial and economic crisis has put advocates for the world’s poorest nations on high alert, and they are prowling the halls of the main conference center here in Davos buttonholing anyone who will listen.
Brazil is walking tall in Davos.

The picture for the private equity industry has gotten a lot darker since the World Economic Forum of 2007 — a year when Davos habitués may remember John A. Thain, the head of the New York Stock Exchange at the time, telling the crowd that the explosive growth in private equity couldn’t go on forever.

Maria Bartiromo of CNBC interviewed the former British prime minister Tony Blair at the World Economic Forum in Davos on Friday, leading off with a series of questions on the situation in Gaza and finishing off with the economy.

Visions of better, more comprehensive or simply different global governance are a dime a dozen at Davos, and given the magnitude of the economic crisis, that is hardly a surprise. But when the vision belongs to a German head of government who stands a good chance of getting re-elected later this year, it’s worth a listen.

On Friday in Davos, Sir Richard Branson (pictured above, left), the billionaire British businessman, led a delegation of executives and leaders from nongovernmental organizations in a simulation of what it is like to live in a refugee camp.
Duncan Niederauer, the chief executive of NYSE Euronext, offered a whiff of optimism amid the Davos gloom on Friday as he talked about the market for initial public offerings.
Don’t start preparing for private equity’s funeral, just yet.
President Barack Obama had not asked, but Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner of France answered anyway.

Kenneth S. Rogoff, a professor at Harvard University and former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is offering updates on his experience at this year’s World Economic Forum as a guest blogger on Davos Diary.

Even as Congress looks for ways to expand President Obama’s $819 billion stimulus package, the rest of the world is wondering how Washington will pay for it all, The New York Times reported. And by the rest of the world it meant the politicians and business leaders gathered at the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland.

Casting for the coming Broadway transfer of “Hair” has been completed, the Public Theater announced. Among the final cast members announced for the musical revival are Will Swenson, who appeared in the Broadway musicals “110 in the Shade” and “Lestat,” as Berger, and Megan Lawrence, a Tony Award nominee for “The Pajama Game,” will play Mother. The show is scheduled to begin previews at the Al Hirschfeld Theater on March 6 and open on March 31.

At its spring preview showcase this week in Manhattan, Sega made a strong impression with a lineup of coming Wii exclusives aimed at adults and core gamers.

The struggling Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles announced staff layoffs and budget cuts on Friday. The museum said it plans to reduce its staff by 20 percent and reduce operating expenses to achieve an annual savings of approximately $4.4 million. The decision, which eliminates 32 full and part-time jobs, was made as part of a plan to restore the museum’s financial health, according to a statement released by the museum. “It is my responsibility to lay a new foundation for the museum’s long-term financial stability,” Charles E. Young, the museum’s chief executive officer said in the statement announcing the cuts. The museum has been without a director since Jeremy Strick resigned from the beleaugered museum in December.

Fearing that a recession-driven drop in New York City tourism will hurt Broadway ticket sales, theater industry leaders and city officials on Friday announced a new advertising campaign to urge people in Manhattan and the tri-state area to see more shows – but they stopped short of any broad move to bring down ticket prices.

A few weeks ago, Zack Snyder nearly became the director who came closest to making a movie version of “Watchmen” without actually getting it released in theaters. He had been busy editing his adaptation of the graphic novel, written by Alan Moore and illustrated by Dave Gibbons, knowing that he was the latest in a long line of directors — including Terry Gilliam, Darren Aronofsky and Paul Greengrass — who had been unable to bring the comic-book epic about dysfunctional superheroes to the big screen.

It took ArtsBeat two hours to drive the 25 miles to Uniondale last night to see Metallica play its first show on Long Island in roughly four years, a journey made all the slower by the legions of men selling bootleg Metallica t-shirts along the sides of the Meadowbrook Parkway. We’ll leave a critical evaluation of the show to Jon Caramanica, who is busily typing away at home (we’ll post his review as soon as it comes in), and a visual one mostly to the great Michael Nagel, who shot the band for The Times (we’ll move his photographs along likewise). Instead, in the manner of a first-responder shouting to his colleagues, we offer the cell-phone snapshot above, three observations, and a few questions.

The annual rock-music smorgasbord known as the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival has announced a 2009 lineup to satisfy all kinds of appetites. This year’s festival, which runs from April 17 through 19 in Indio, Calif., will be headlined by Paul McCartney (on April 17), the Killers (April 18) and the Cure (April 19). It will also feature Morrissey, Franz Ferdinand, Leonard Cohen, My Bloody Valentine and TV on the Radio. Even Amy Winehouse is on the schedule, so you know it’s a party. Tickets for the festival are now on sale; a layaway program (which allows ticket buyers to pay half now, and the balance on April 1, or one-third now, and the remaining thirds on March 1 and April 1) is available online at Ticketmaster.com through Feb. 28.

The rapper Lil Wayne has pulled the song “Playing with Fire” from his best-selling album “Tha Carter III” in a settlement with the publishing company of the Rolling Stones, which had said the track was an altered version of the Stones’ “Play with Fire.” In July, Abkco Music, which owns the rights to the Rolling Stones catalog, filed suit against Lil Wayne and his Cash Money Records label, saying that “Playing with Fire” was a derivative of “Play with Fire,” and infringed on the Rolling Stones’ copyright. Under the condition of the settlement announced by both parties, Lil Wayne has agreed to pull his song from his album; it will also no longer be offered as a digital download or ringtone. The parties also agreed not to claim that “Playing with Fire” was either an original or derivative work; financial terms were not disclosed.

It’s the pop-music equivalent of the day peanut butter met jelly: the producers behind “American Idol” and the best-selling “Now That’s What I Call Music!” albums say that they will work together on a television series that is planned for this summer, The Associated Press reported. Simon Fuller, the music impresario who created “American Idol” and its British predecessor, “Pop Idol” (and who still has the Spice Girls to account for), will team with the executives of the “Now” records, a pop-music compilation series that has sold more than 73 million copies in the United States and Britain, to create a television show in the vein of “American Bandstand” and “Total Request Live.” No title, host or network for the show was announced.

Despite the economic turmoil, several broadcast television networks still plan to hold their upfronts, the costly annual presentations at which they announce their new programs to advertisers and the press, Variety reported. Fox will lead the week of presentations on May 18, followed by ABC on May 19; CBS will have its upfront event on May 20 at Carnegie Hall, though Variety said the network was unlikely to follow that with its customary party at Tavern on the Green. CW is scheduled to hold its presentation on May 21 at the Madison Square Garden Theater. NBC, which last year opted out of the upfronts with an early April presentation it called an “infront,” will do so again this year.

By now most cultural authorities have weighed in on President Obama … except Lil Wayne, the bawdy New Orleans rapper who is nominated for eight Grammy Awards for his album “Tha Carter III.” In an interview with Katie Couric to be part of her “All Access Grammy Special” on CBS on Wednesday, he tells her: “Music is another form of journalism to me. So I have to cover all the areas with my album. You get Lil Wayne’s take on the new president, Lil Wayne’s take on money, the economy, Lil Wayne’s take on women, Lil Wayne’s take on whatever.” When Ms. Couric asks Lil Wayne, who has rapped about the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, what question he would put to former President Bush about it, he answered: “I’m a gangster, and gangsters don’t ask questions.” But they do answer them, apparently. Watch a preview of the interview here.

Lincoln Center has announced the schedule for its Great Performers 2009-2010 series. Among the highlights of the program is “Beethoven Then and Now: The Complete Symphonies,” scheduled for March 25-27, 2010, at Alice Tully Hall. The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment and the Budapest Festival Orchestra, both conducted by Ivan Fischer, will perform period-instrument and modern-instrument programs of Beethoven’s works. The series will also include the American premiere of Heiner Goebbels’s experimental piece “Stifter’s Dinge,” which will run at the Park Avenue Armory from Dec. 16 through 20, as well as the first New York performances by Gustavo Dudamel with the Los Angeles Philharmonic and Yannick Nézet-Séguin with the Rotterdam Philharmonic. A complete schedule and subscription information can be found at LincolnCenter.org.

A student in one of my English classes recently asked about the endless references to drinking wine in "The Odyssey." The question, which had nothing to do with my lesson, was a good one. Wine has a constant presence in the epic poem, whose most famous image is probably Homer's evocation of the "wine-dark sea" that Odysseus sails in search of his native Ithaka. Sometimes it is mere tonic on an impossibly long journey home from the Trojan War, but on occasion wine is more powerful than the sword, as when Odysseus escapes from the Cyclops by getting him drunk. Homer may have been blind, but his taste buds were alive to wine, and he reserved his richest adjectives for it: heady, mellow, ruddy, shining, glowing, seasoned, hearty, honeyed, glistening, heart-warming, and, of course, irresistible.

As anyone who has had to upgrade to "the latest" iPod can attest, our love affair with technology is often a fleeting one. But the sorrowful response to the news that Polaroid will stop manufacturing its instant film is a testament to the emotional attachments certain gadgets harbor. With the supply of Polaroid film slowly running dry (reportedly extinct as soon as next month), the worlds of art and fashion have offered eulogies as diverse as they are somber: The Whitney Museum of American Art showed a mesmerizing collection of Robert Mapplethorpe's overlooked Polaroids last summer, the Palihouse Holloway hotel in West Hollywood now features a wall of vintage Polaroids encased behind a sheet of glass in their lobby, and Interview magazine has started shooting its front-of-book product editorials using Polaroid film in homage to the its original founder (and Polaroid patron saint), Andy Warhol.

If there was one essential element in the work of John Maynard Keynes, it was the demolition of Say's Law -- the assertion that supply necessarily creates demand. Keynes showed that the fact that spending equals income, or equivalently that saving equals investment, does not imply that there's always enough spending to fully employ the economy's resources, that there's always enough investment to make use of the saving the economy would have had it it were at full employment.

One of the joys of winter work is the wildlife. On a recent trip to the cabin, Kevin and I spotted a flock of wild turkeys at the edge of the gravel road that winds past the cabin path. They walked like an Algonquin war party through the forest. They moved quietly and in single file, stooping forward, stopping often to spot possible trouble and using tree trunks to obscure their presence.

Years ago in a restaurant in Florence (Ristorante Dino it was called, famous for a very flavorful if excessively lean pot roast called Lo Stracotto del Granduca) Jackie and I had a plate of pasta with gorgonzola and arugula: just gorgonzola melted and tossed with short dry pasta (I think it was shells) and raw arugula; they used some butter too, but if anything is gilding the lily, adding butter to gorgonzola is it. This is a perfect dish, with tons of flavor and nearly no work. We've been eating it every now and again ever since.

In a famous 1958 paper my old teacher Jagdish Bhagwati described the conditions for "immiserizing growth" -- a situation in which an expansion in an economy's production, by driving down the price of its exports, actually reduces its real income. It was a classic demonstration that sometimes individually rational actions can make everyone (at least in one national economy) worse off -- although I prefer the terminology of Edgeworth, who noticed the possibility more than a century ago, and talked of nations being "damnified" by their expansion.

People tend to forget this, but we were on the edge of a major banking crisis in the early 90s. it wasn't just the S&Ls; commercial banks were in trouble too, largely because of big losses on commercial real estate. And I remember a conversation I had back then with economists at the New York Fed, one of whom declared that the only reason Citibank (as it then was) had a positive market value was the "FDIC put." That is, part of the Citi's downside was in fact covered by taxpayers, who were guaranteeing deposits whatever happened, while all of the upside belonged to the stockholders.

Buy your Roquefort while you can even dream of affording it. Prices for the genuine import hover between $20 and $40 a pound already. But after March 22, the federal import tariffwill increase from 100 to 300 percent, and the prices are expected to soar. Taylor Cocalis, who works in education at Murray's Cheese, said they will probably stop selling it for a while and recommended a similar French sheep milk blue, Persillé de Malzieu, $24.99 a pound. James Coogan, the manager of Ideal Cheese, also said he probably will not carry Roquefort, and suggested Miti, a Spanish sheep blue, for $17.98. At Fairway, Steve Jenkins, an owner, has an everyday Roquefort, (though not from a top producer like Carles), for $8.39 a pound. Even when that price goes up, it will still be affordable.

[Slate]

I'm a rent-stabilized tenant in a walk-up apartment. All the units have wall-to-wall carpeting throughout. My upstairs neighbor, however, recently removed his. Now, there are loud footsteps all night long. Is he required to carpet the floors?

I am a renter in a condominium. The building is new and just over 50 percent owned at this point. I have a lease with the owner of my unit. My problem is that the heating system has not been working for four or five out of every seven days since October. The conditions are unbearable, especially since I have a 2-year-old who is constantly getting sick. The management says the problem will be fixed soon, but I have lived this way for three months. I have been told that the warranty of habitability does not apply to condominiums. Am I stuck in the cold?

Three of New York's creative fields converge in ABC's hit television show "Ugly Betty" -- fashion, interior design and graphic design. Hypermiling, the art of maximizing gas mileage on the road, is usually associated with owners of the Toyota Prius. A school devoted to cinema will make its debut in the Bronx. A state-of-the-art high school will finally come to Sunset Park, Brooklyn. And the "Little Red School House," Public School 65, will operate under one roof after years of being spread across two campuses.

In a famous episode of "The Simpsons," Homer is sent to an insane asylum for wearing a pink shirt to work. But the color is no longer a sartorial taboo or cultural punch line, as a photo spread in this Sunday's New York Times Magazine and our new home page demonstrate. Designers have come to embrace the once-derided hue for every piece of the male ensemble, from suit jackets to footwear. The photographer Norbert Schoerner took to the streets of Tokyo with a Globe-Trotter suitcase full of Louis Vuitton, Salvatore Ferragamo and Dior Homme, among others, and came back with these arrestingly vivid images and a short film called "Relay" to boot (watch it above). Pass it on: Think pink for men.

The city's current economic implosion is making us all feel like we've time-traveled back to the cash-strapped 1970s, but the era was not all doom and gloom. There was some serious filmmaking going on, and you can see one of the classics, "The Panic in Needle Park" (1971, clip below), at Film Forum through February 5th. The movie, which tells the gritty, emotional story of two heroin addicts played by Al Pacino and Kitty Winn, was directed in cinema verité style by the Bronx-born photographer Jerry Schatzberg, who spent the '60s taking candid portraits of everyone from Bob Dylan to Andy Warhol to the Rolling Stones. His film career has been nearly as prestigious - Faye Dunaway played a mentally unstable former model in "Puzzle of a Downfall Child" (1970) and his 1973 film "Scarecrow," starring Gene Hackman and Al Pacino, won the Golden Palm award at the Cannes Film Festival. Schatzberg, along with Joan Didion (who wrote the screenplay for "The Panic in Needle Park" with her late husband, John Gregory Dunne) and Winn, will be on hand to speak about the film on Friday, Jan. 30, and again on Tuesday, Feb. 3.

MADANS--Marilyn. Beloved wife of the late Melvin Madans, passed away on January 23, 2009 at the age of 92. She is survived by her two devoted children and their spouses, adored grandchildren, cherished sister and many nieces, nephews, grandneices and grandnephews.

SOVAK--Milos, M.D. Inventor, physician-scientist, entrepreneur, poet, artist, author and patron of the arts, Milos Sovak died, after a prolonged illness, in Long Beach, California on Monday, January 26, 2009. Sovak was 67. The holder of 22 biomedical and technical patents, Dr. Sovak's contributions encompassed the discovery of the most widely used non-ionic radiographic contrast media for diagnostic imaging and the groundbreaking synthesis of a novel compound that made possible the production of the first protease inhibitor HIV drug, Nelfinavir. Beyond his medical discoveries, his revolutionary break - resistant chain for power saws is today an industry standard used by firemen around the world and his line of fine crafted etching presses are considered by artists to be the best in class. A citizen of the world, Dr. Sovak was the eldest son of a family of renowned intellectuals and pillars of Prague's cultural community between the wars. Fleeing communist Czechoslovakia in 1963 after receiving M.D. from Charles University in Prague, he undertook radiology training at the University of Copenhagen and later Temple University in Philadelphia, the recipient of a James Picker Foundation Fellowship, finally joining the faculty of the University of California, San Diego. Dr. Sovak published over 170 articles, book chapters, abstracts and monographs, and served as chairman of numerous international symposia. In 1981 he established Biophysica Inc., a developmental laboratory in La Jolla, California where he dedicated himself to research in medical imaging, cytostatics and phytochemicals for cancer therapy. An active member of several professional organizations, he was awarded the Harry Fischer Prize in 1995 in recognition of his substantive contributions to diagnostic radiology. In 1990, Dr. Sovak was summoned to Prague to aid the Czech government (National Council) in the post-communist restructuring of the pharmaceutical industry and formulation of first national health care laws. There, he undertook the revitalization of Interpharma Praha, a then defunct former producer of fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals, and drove it to become an internationally prominent research and manufacturing entity engaged in the development of novel agents for the therapy of resistant Prostate Cancer. A gifted book designer, typographer and publisher of bibliophilic limited editions, Dr. Sovak excelled at matching unusual manuscripts with original art created specifically for the books, designed as art objects, through Ettan Press. A polymath, he drifted deftly from his native Czech to English, German, Danish, Swedish, French, Italian and Spanish with a working knowledge of Japanese. Perhaps nothing better defined this Renaissance man than his receipt of a PEN literary award for his translation of Czech poet Vitezslav Nezvals Antilyric (Sun and Moon Press, Los Angeles) in September 2002, the same month that he authored an internationally acclaimed lead manuscript on prostate cancer in the prestigious US publication, Journal of the National Cancer Institute (JNCI). Throughout his life Sovak strove to recapture and advance the cultural traditions that had formed his early years. The tragic circumstances of his exile, sense of isolation and perception of the disappearance of humanism, so dear to his heart, had a lifelong impact upon him and his work. It was his firm belief that his successes reflected the unique freedoms and opportunities afforded to him by America, his adopted country. He is survived by his brother Mojmir Sovak, his wife Dietlind Antretter and their twin boys, Maximilian and Eliot. The family wishes that donations be made to advance cancer research and the work of Dr. Robert Nagourney through the Nagourney Institute, 750 East 29th Street, Long Beach, CA 90806.

SONET--Jerrold M.,died on January 28 from pulmonary fibrosis, at home, at peace and surrounded by loving family. He was born on September 16, 1928 in Manhattan, the son of Marion and Samuel Sonet. Jerrold attended Farragut Academy and Cornell University, from which he graduated at age 16. After receiving his JD from Harvard Law School, he returned to NYC and joined the law practice of Daniel Levy, which evolved into the firm of Levy, Sonet and Siegel. He was the legal architect for the consolidation which joined the American Institute of Designers and the National Society of Interior Designers into one organization, known since 1975 as the American Society of Interior Designers (ASID). For several decades, he served as General Counsel for ASID. Jerrold represented the late Angelo Donghia, and was selected by him to operate the Foundation he endowed for the benefit of interior design education and AIDS research. Jerrold leaves his beloved wife of 39 years, Ann Pardue Sonet, his brother Richard and wife Toni, and three loving children; Sara, a librarian at the Supreme Court, James, a principal in Electrified Discounters, and Steven, a partner in Levy, Sonet and Siegel; and four grandchildren. Services will be held on Monday, February 2, 2009, at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Martin Luther King Jr. Scholarship Fund at Harvard Law School, 125 Mount Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138. The Sonet family will receive guests on Sunday February 1 at 14 Sutton Place South between 4 and 7pm.

An article on Wednesday about final passage by Congress of pay-discrimination legislation misstated the number of bills signed by President Obama. Until he signed the pay-discrimination measure on Thursday, Mr. Obama had signed no bills -- not one. (The one bill signing attributed to Mr. Obama, a measure affecting the salary of the secretary of the interior, was signed by then-President Bush, days before he left office.) The error was repeated on Thursday in an Op-Ed page column by Gail Collins about the pay-discrimination bill.

LAGRASSA--Carl, 80, of Far Hills, NJ passed away on Tuesday, January 27, 2009 peacefully at his home surrounded by his family. Carl was the Founder and CEO of Automated Securities Clearance Ltd. (ASC). ASC provided back office accounting systems to brokerage Companies. In 1989, ASC developed an online trading system for NASDAQ traders called BRASS. The BRASS system became the standard for the industry and at the time of its sale, over 70% of traders were processed through this system. After selling ASC, he and his wife Gloria built the Pluckemin Inn in Bedminster to pursue his longstanding love of food and passion for fine wine. The ''Inn'' is considered one of the finest restaurants in New Jersey. Carl was a Philanthropist; he was known for his caring and generosity. His favorite charities are those which helped children. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Gloria. His caring children, a daughter Carla L. LaGrassa of New York, NY, a son Carl and his wife Mary Ann of Rumson, NJ, two grandchildren Carl and Cade. A sister Anita Pollack and her husband Jason of Long Island, NY. A niece Andrea. Calling hours will be Friday January 30, 2009 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the Bailey Funeral Home, 176 Main Street, Peapack, New Jersey 07977. Funeral Services: Saturday January 31, 2009, 10:30am. Mass of Christian burial with Most Reverend Paul G. Bootkoski, Bishop of Metuchen officiating, at St. Brigid, 129 Main Street, Peapack, NJ 07977. Entombment will be at Resurrection Cemetery, Piscataway, NJ. Funeral services have been entrusted to the Warren Hills Memorial Home, 234 W. Washington, Ave., Washington, NJ 07882 and the Bailey Funeral Home, 176 Main Street, Peapack, New Jersey 07977. To send an on-line condolence visit www. warrenhillsmemorialhome .com

He is survived by his sister Barbara B. Whittlesey of Chappaqua, NY. Memorial donations can be made to the Paul 1938 and Eleanor C. Baur Scholarship Fund for undergraduate grants at Harvard College.

SMOOT--Katharine (''Kitty'') Smull, M.D.,born 1915 in New York City, died peacefully at her home in Laurel Hollow, NY late last week. Wife of the late William Sydney Smoot, she is survived by her daughter, Sally Smoot Ingraham, and her grandchildren, David Smoot Ingraham and Sarah Jennings Ingraham. After attending The Chapin School, Vassar College and the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, she became a medical researcher whose work at the University of Chicago in the 1950s helped reduce the prevalence of childhood rheumatic fever in America. She was also an avid sailor who, in 1954, braved Hurricane Carol in open ocean while cruising near the Isles of Shoals in a 40 foot cutter. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, January 31st at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Waterfront Center, 1 West End Avenue, Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

He was predeceased by his son Michael. Richard served as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy in Underwater Demolition during WWII. 'GOGOL BORDELLO NON-STOP' Before he started palling around with Madonna and starring in movies with Elijah Wood, Eugene Hutz, the handlebar-mustachioed frontman of the band Gogol Bordello, was just a simple, self-described gypsy punk; before his band started selling out megaclubs and European festivals, he had a weekly D.J. gig in Chinatown. For several years in the early 2000s, the Ukrainian-born, charismatic and propaganda-spouting Mr. Hutz, who moved to New York around 1998, presided over a legendarily raucous, sweaty night of dancing at Mehanata, a dingy Bulgarian bar hidden on a second-floor space above Canal Street. The parties drew a cosmopolitan crowd, a mix of Eastern Europeans, Latin Americans and hipsters, among them Margarita Jimeno, a Colombian-born filmmaker. Intrigued by the scene, Ms. Jimeno, 33, began recording it.

After a contentious search process, N.F.L. players will select a new union chief in six weeks, and that's when the real contentions will begin. The union said here Thursday that a study it commissioned showed that teams made an average profit of at least $24 million last year, even though owners, who have opted out of the existing labor agreement, have claimed that the financial crisis is squeezing their margins, and has caused some teams and the league office to lay off employees.

Dennis Kucinich, one of Congress's most liberal members, and Ted Poe, one of its most conservative, have sent a letter to Treasury officials requesting that they take steps to force Citigroup to give up its $400 million deal to put its name on the Mets' new stadium. In their letter, Kucinich, a Democrat from Ohio, and Poe, a Republican from Texas, noted that Citigroup had received more than $350 billion in taxpayer money from economic stabilization efforts and loans and that it announced in November that it planned to cut more than 50,000 jobs. In the fall, Kucinich, as chairman of the Congressional Domestic Policy subcommittee investigating the tax-exempt financing of the new Yankee Stadium, warned city officials that they could be prosecuted if they lied about the property value.

LOFRUMENTO--Maria. The Hunter College Community mourns with deep sorrow the death of its proud alumna and beloved educator. A strong, indefatigable presence at Hunter College High School, Maria began her tenure at HCHS teaching French and Spanish. She served as chairman of the department and as principal from 1971 until her retirement in 1984. She has enriched the lives of generations of students. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Ave., New York, NY 10065, ATTN: Room E1313. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College

NAGIN--Lawrence M.,died on Wednesday, January 28, 2009, of complications from cancer. Larry, a third-generation Californian, was born on February 14, 1941, in San Francisco; the son of Maurine M. Nagin and David L. Nagin. Within a few months, Larry moved with his family, including his loving sister, Fredericka, and his beloved ''Ria'', Marie E. Jacobs, to Los Angeles. Larry attended public schools in the City of Los Angeles and received a Bachelor of Arts in International Relations from the University of Southern California in 1962. He then attended The University of California, Hastings College of the Law, graduating with a Juris Doctor degree in 1965. He became a Member of the State Bar of California, and remained a member for more than 42 years. From 1966 to 1968, Larry served as a Deputy Public Defender for the County of Los Angeles. From 1968 to 1974, Larry was in private practice in the City of Beverly Hills. From 1974 to 1980, Larry served as Special Counsel to the City Attorney of the City of Los Angeles, and then Senior Assistant City Attorney representing the Los Angeles Department of Airports. In 1980, Larry began his career as an airline industry executive when he joined the Los Angeles-based Flying Tigers as its General Counsel. Flying Tigers was, at that time, the world's largest all-cargo airline. In 1986, Stephen M. Wolf became the airlines Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. In 1988, Larry moved to Chicago, where he joined United Airlines as Executive Vice President and General Counsel, serving again under Stephen M. Wolf, the Chief Executive Officer. Larry helped navigate United through a period of tremendous growth and transformation that ultimately resulted in an employee buyout of the company in 1994. Larry then became of counsel to the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LP, in its Chicago office, until March 1996 when he joined the Virginia-based, US Airways, again under the leadership of Mr. Wolf. Since retirement from US Airways in 2002, Larry had been a Senior Strategic Advisor with the law firm of O'Melveny & Myers LLP, in their New York City office. From the time Larry was a young boy he had a passion for the airline industry--he spent time at Los Angeles International Airport watching airplanes take off and land. He pored over airline schedules and collected airline memorabilia. He always felt fortunate to have transformed a childhood love of airplanes into a lasting and singular career in aviation. Larry leaves his beloved wife of 41 years, Sherrie, his two adored sons, Daniel, a Professor at the University of Virginia School of Law, and Benjamin, a partner in the law firm, Sidley Austin LLP, Daniels wife, Tomiko Brown-Nagin, Ph.D., also a Professor at the University of Virginia School of Law, and Benjamins wife, Melissa Kotlen Nagin, a lactation consultant and writer for About.com; five precious and beloved grandchildren: Zachary Samuel Nagin, Sarah Rose Nagin, Alexander Gabriel Nagin, Julius Brown Nagin, and Avishai Brown Nagin; his adored sister Fredericka and her children, David Miller (Judy Miller M.D.), Deborah Miller and Jennifer Tidstrand (Douglas Tid strand). In addition, he is survived by his loving brother-inlaw, Robert Gandin, DDS, his loving sisters-in-law, Mindy Gandin, Louise Feinberg, Marsha Gandin, and many dear nieces and nephews. Services will be held on Friday, January 30, 2009, at 9:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Street at 81st Street, New York, NY. Interment will follow at Westchester Hills Cemetery, 400 Saw Mill River Road, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. The family requests that memorial contributions be made to The Lawrence M. Nagin Faculty Enrichment Fund; University of California, Hastings College of the Law; 200 McAllister Street, San Francisco, CA 94102. The fund was created by Larry to support faculty research on issues of social justice.

ZELLER--Louise, 48, of Rockaway, on January 26. A great mind. A renaissance heart. Proud Mensa member and graduate of Benjamin Cardozo School of Law. Survived by sister Sarah Zeller and niece Becky. We will miss your loyal friendship, your lyrical writing, your love of horses, dogs, and cats. Toward your Better Days, Walk tall or baby don't walk at all.

HAMBLETON--Mary, 56, died January 9. Loving wife of 20 years to Ken Buhler, devoted mother to Jacob Hambleton Buhler, artist, teacher, Guggenheim Fellow (2007). She lived an inspired life, sweetened by the many friends and family she loved with passion. All who knew her, even briefly, felt embraced, enlivened, and blessed by her radiance, humor, intelligence, generosity, sparkling beauty, and by her magnificent art. Her engaging spirit, warmth, and courage never waned, even after six years of cancer, showing us all how it can be done. Mary, we will miss you forever. Preceded in death by her father, T. Edward Hambleton and sister Anne Hambleton, Mary is also survived by her mother, Merrell Hambleton, sisters Linda Panitz and Susan Hambleton, brothers Edward and Mark Hambleton, and by many adoring in-laws, nieces and nephews. www.maryhambleton.com. Donations in her name can be made to Added Value, www.added - value.org and The Fresh Air Fund, www.freshair.org

The Mets signed outfielder Bobby Kielty, the right-handers Matt DeSalvo and Tony Armas Jr. and the left-hander Valerio de los Santos to minor league deals on Thursday and invited them to spring training. Kielty, a switch-hitter, may have the strongest chance at making the team out of spring training because he provides a right-handed option for a team that leans heavily to the left side. Kielty last played in the majors in 2007, for the Boston Red Sox, when he hit a pinch-hit home run in Game 4 of the World Series in Colorado. In seven major league seasons Kielty has batted .296 with a .379 on-base percentage and a .503 slugging percentage from the right side compared with .228/.329/.348 from the left.

An article on Saturday about the arrest of a dean at Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx on charges of groping a 19-year-old student included a quotation from an unnamed sophomore who said the school's principal had told students that the accuser lied. The reporter had asked the school and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for comment on the case, but did not ask them about the sophomore's statement. After the article was published, school officials contacted The Times to say that the principal, William D. Lessa, had told the students no such thing. Contacted on Thursday, Mr. Lessa said that he had never spoken to students about the dean's case. The Times should have given the principal, or other officials, the opportunity to respond to the sophomore's statement.

SLIDESHOW: HUNTING FISH Mike Holmes waits in his darkhouse, watching for fish through a hole he cut in the ice of Lake Mary in Michigan. Spearing fish is more like hunting than what hook-and-line anglers do. Mr. Holmes carves decoys out of wood, above center, to use as lures. There is no reeling in, and a spear with seven sharpened tines does the catching.
ERIC FERTMAN Susan Inglett

My Sunday column is from Davos but is about the Middle East. Here's to hoping that Obama makes a major push to engage the issue and restores the U.S. role of honest broker. I also argue that with a Palestinian-Israeli deal impossible for the time being, the best strategy is to work for an Israel-Syria deal. The aim would be to peel Syria away from Iran, reducing Iranian influence in the region, moderating Hamas, and lending momentum to a broader initiative (either based on the Arab League's 2002 proposal or a Palestinian deal similar to the Clinton parameters).

Brad DeLong links to Megan McArdle saying something wrong about the effects of a temporary increase in government spending. But he fails to note that it's not just wrong, it's 180 degrees wrong: a temporary increase in government spending should have a larger impact on demand than a permanent increase, not a smaller impact.
