Re "Standing Between Enemies" (Jan. 11): Sorry, your explanation doesn't carry water.Hamas wants to kill every Jew, and its leaders have said so. The Fatah leaders have decided that rather than fight Israel, they will build a country for their citizens, and Israel is helping them toward that end. Hamas should do the same, and The Times should face these hard facts and call a spade a spade.When you hide behind civilians, civilians will get killed. They are terrorists and cowards - no more than that.Richard FentonBoca Raton, Fla., Jan. 12, 2009 Your column about The Times's evenhanded coverage of the Israel-Palestinian conflict is ironic because the column itself is pro-Palestinian.Why doesn't the paragraph that begins "But the readers I am hearing from are not ready to accept that notion" end with something negative about the Palestinians, just like the first sentence does about the Israelis?You could have written: "Supporters of the Palestinians are offended at the mention of the unprovoked killing of at least 18 Israelis since 2001 by Hamas rockets, the thousands of rockets fired into Israeli cities or the misuse of the millions in aid by the Palestinian leadership to buy weapons instead of providing infrastructure and employment."Later, you quote Patrick Witty, a photo editor, as saying, "There's nothing fair in war photography." But you don't mention a significant fact. It's no surprise that the barrage of rockets launched will result in more Palestinian deaths since Israel builds bomb shelters while Hamas launches rockets from sites near United Nations schools.Debbie FeldmanDavid FeldmanScotch Plains, N.J., Jan. 12, 2009 ● You are not correct when you say that Times reporters are doing the best they can counting bodies with counts provided by hospitals, agencies and so on, and choosing the ones the editors and writers think most credible.Nor is The Times fair when it publishes a picture of a person holding a dead child. Pictures influence people, as do statistics about those apparently killed when a bomb went off, not on a house where those people hid, but on a neighboring street (which one has to glean reading other articles)."Hamas militants are fighting in civilian clothes; even the police have been ordered to take off their uniforms," Steven Erlanger reports on Page 1 of the Jan. 11 paper. The article also talks of a "Hamas tactic of asking civilians to stand on the roofs of buildings so Israeli pilots will not bomb."How is a count of so-called civilians killed, no matter who reports it, an accurate account? What kind of a civilization puts its civilians in such jeopardy?Israel is castigated for not having enough casualties. But Israel has built bomb shelters to protect its people, while Hamas has dug tunnels for transmitting weapons and deliberately puts people in harm's way.The Times should send reporters to see how Israel has prepared for assaults and send photographers to show Israeli citizens maimed by Hamas bombing. The Times won't even need to whine that its photographers can't enter the war zone to do so. Have an equal number of civilian atrocities pictured, if you are so bent on equality.Marilyn ShapiroBloomfield Hills, Mich., Jan. 11, 2009 ● While you try eloquently to make the case that the Times coverage of the Gaza conflict is fair and balanced, I believe you fall short. "But most of the destruction is in Gaza, and news photographs are not about blame but about showing what happened," you write, and add that "fear in Israel is more difficult to capture with a camera."You do not, however, address the more fundamental question of why photos of Gaza destruction almost always appear as a front-page banner while any Israeli photos that The Times does manage to get are buried in the middle of the paper.Do you believe that showing what happened, almost always inflammatory to the Arab world, merits front-page placement while Israeli suffering or destruction is less front-page worthy? Or perhaps The Times would rather not offend those in Arab or Muslim countries rather than balance its front-page "damage only" photos.Avram T. GelbBrooklyn, Jan. 11, 2009 ● I don't think that you avoid "bias" by giving "equal" coverage to "both sides" of an issue. Indeed, not all arguments are equally accurate, right and instructive.True, we are trapped in the world of interpretation; for us human beings, there are no ultimate, absolute truths. But there are better arguments than others, otherwise all arguments would be equally devoid of any content - or worse, everything is possible. For example, if someone thinks the Holocaust was right, and I think that it was unacceptable, we would each be entitled to our "opinion." But does fairness work this way?Absolutely not: not all arguments are equal, and there are definitely wrong ones. So how do you distinguish between a better argument? A better argument is the one that is more complex, that instead of passion and simplistic racial, national or hatred overtones, presents clear arguments, a history of the problem at hand, and a detailed context in which the issue discussed has been and is embedded.Maricler MostoSan Diego, Jan. 11, 2009 ● While I agree with you that reporting from a war zone, particularly in the Middle East, will get you blame from all sides, I respectfully disagree that "news photographs are not about blame." They may not be created as such, but for many the visual prompt is the first thing they see and for some helps assign blame before the article is even read.Steven M. ClaytonOcean, N.J., Jan. 11, 2009 ● You write that The Times "has tried its best to do a fair, balanced and complete job" regarding reporting on the situation in Gaza. I believe that in general that is correct. But to report the number of civilian Palestinian deaths without an attempt to determine how many of the civilians were with members of Hamas at the time of an attack by Israel supports an anti-Israeli position.The world needs all the facts when it comes to civilian deaths in this particular situation to understand how Hamas operates in violation of human rights. Phil SandineWashington Crossing, Pa., Jan. 11, 2009● You give a scrupulously honest, detailed and documented analysis of the fairness issue concerning Times coverage of the war in Gaza. It is of utmost importance that this matter be addressed in a manner convincing to anyone who is seeking the truth and is not an unmovable partisan of either side.Israeli and Hamas leaders and their supporters are using every conceivable argument to try to win the battle for public opinion, to "prove" that the other side is wholly to blame for this conflict.The sad, horrible reality is that both sides are to blame for this wretched, unnecessary war. Both sides had long been preparing for it. Each side, by acts committed before and since this all-out bloodletting began, is guilty of terrorism, unspeakable atrocities and war crimes.How can either side believe it can attain a true victory? Both have already lost too much in dead and wounded, in physical resources and in the respect of the rest of the world. They need to get back to the negotiating table.Landrum R. BollingWashington, Jan. 12, 2009The writer is a senior adviser to Mercy Corps on humanitarian assistance programs in the Middle East.●●Re "Leaps of Faith, and the Trouble That Followed" (Jan. 18): I enjoyed your thoughtful piece on the difficulties of establishing the truth for the purposes of journalism. As a former professor of Roman history at the Université de Montréal who has devoted the last couple of decades to studying how civil war came about and brought the Roman Republic to an end, I would slightly alter the advice that you cited from Ronald Reagan: Never trust, and always verify.Another politician, Julius Caesar, wrote an account of his violation of Roman law and ethical standards that has succeeded in misleading generations of readers. Trust in his account is misplaced. No source, however well placed, can be taken on faith.In his "Civil War," Caesar selectively narrates events so as to leave readers with the impression that he invaded Italy crossing the Rubicon in response to an emergency decree passed against him by the Senate of Rome. Logistics, however, demonstrate that his army was already on the march.Even more significantly, Caesar was not above threatening physical violence upon any tribune of the plebs who might choose to oppose him. He omits the threats that he uttered. Instead, he claims that his enemies had left the Treasury of Rome unlocked when they abandoned the city two months earlier.Of course, there was criticism at the time and thereafter. Voices like those of Cicero and Cato the Younger were effectively dragooned into service or silenced. But even in Caesar's camp there were those who recognized that not all was right. Despite his reverence for the master, Asinius Pollio noted that Caesar's narrative of the civil war years was marred by factual "errors."Surprisingly, however, scholars have largely accepted the "great man's" self-portrait as an accurate representation of historical reality. Few are the voices that dissent. Perhaps the desire for figures that are larger than life and mythological in nature may account for this failing.In the wake of the Bush era and its claims of "great men" and "decisive battles," we would do well to be wary of any simplistic vision of reality.Nor should we ever let our guard down and trust someone on the sole basis of his or her own testimony. That is how democracies come to an end.Richard WestallRome, Jan. 18, 2009 ● I have been reading The Times since I was 12 (I'm now 61). I am aghast that seasoned people could make what I think are rookie mistakes.Particularly disturbing is the fake letter to the editor. Wasn't Sarah Palin tricked by a fake phone call from the French president? There were so many warning signs in the letter that I cannot believe your editor did not pick up the phone to verify.Also, the reporters' or editors' excuses for the erroneous stories wouldn't get by a fifth grade teacher. This was shameful and inexcusable for a paper I have revered my entire adult life.Jonathan BrombergFlagstaff, Ariz., Jan. 21, 2009 ● I read your criticism of the Thayer Evans article about the recruitment of Jamarkus McFarland. While I appreciate the effort to correct the obvious mistruths of the "party," the effort does not begin to address the other major problems with the article.The article made damaging accusations of cheating on the part of the University of Texas and painted the University of Oklahoma in a positive light. It referred to an "interest-free loan for a former classmate" if McFarland chose Texas. Was that independently corroborated? Who offered what and when? How much? What were the conditions? The article also indicates that Texas Coach Mack Brown was bragging about the size of his house. Coach Brown is known in the world of college football as a humble, respectful person. This quote seems very out of character for such a classy individual. Why was Coach Brown not contacted to respond to this allegation?You cannot un-ring a bell. The damage is done. Without a full investigation into all of the allegations made in this one-sided article, you still have not done your due diligence. Kent AftergutDallas, Jan. 18, 2009 ● Thayer Evans wrote things that were damaging to the University of Texas without verifying whether they were true. There were contradictions in the article that a junior high student would have questioned. First, McFarland's mother stated that she loved the persistence of the Oklahoma University recruiter but almost canceled the trip to University of Texas because the Longhorns were bugging her too much. That makes no sense.Second, regarding the wild party in Dallas after the Texas-O.U. game: McFarland was a guest of O.U. at that game, so how did he end up at a Texas party? Where was his mother during the party? Where was the party? You say, "The reporter did not ask who invited the young man to the party, who accompanied him or who else might have witnessed the lurid events."Was the phone call regarding the interest-free loan investigated? Was the classmate of McFarland's mother called for verification? And the most unbelievable part was Texas Coach Mack Brown's supposed comment: "Whose house do you like better, Bob Stoops's, Les Miles's or mine?" Are you serious? Do you know anything about Mack Brown? He would never make such a comment. Roger ThompsonAustin, Tex., Jan. 18, 2009 ● Journalism today is at a crossroads, and what has happened at the Times in recent months did not help the situation. Journalism is an important function in a Democratic society, and journalists must do all they can to maintain credibility.The mistakes you describe that were made by Times journalists are troubling, because the reporters and editors did not do their job and check what their sources said.I applaud your column for examining the mistakes that were made and including an explanation of why certain decisions were made.We must remember that what is printed affects people and their lives. Thus, we must verify what is told to us to make sure what is reported is truthful. This lies at the very core of journalism itself.Ryan VivianBaton Rouge, La., Jan. 18, 2009

While Phil Mickelson missed the projected cut by seven strokes, Nick Watney shot an eight-under-par 63 to take the second-round lead in the FBR Open in Scottsdale, Ariz. Play was called because of darkness with three players, all above the cut line, still on the course. At nine under, Watney had a one-stroke lead over Charley Hoffman (68), Matt Kuchar (67) and the first-round co-leader James Nitties (69). Mickelson, the 1996 and 2005 winner, never recovered from a 76 on Thursday in his first round of the year. It was the first time Mickelson missed the cut in his season debut since he turned professional in 1992.

SCHERAGO--Irwin. Farewell, dear friend of 50 years. Our lives were enriched by your presence. Condolences to Marilyn, Nina, Randy and family. Phyllis and Joel Joseph

CHIREAU--Roland Fernand, died January 22, 2009 at his home in Durham, NC at the age of 82 years. He was born in Paris, France, the son of Leonard and Gabrielle Chireau. He received his M. Ch.E. from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute in 1955. Mr. Chireau was married to Dorothy Elaine Smith for 56 years. He worked for various U.S. battery concerns including Yardney Electric Corporation from 1944-1981, then went overseas to start High Energy Batteries in Tiruchirapalli, South India. While in India, Mr. Chireau and his wife engaged in missionary work. He retired in 2000. Mr. Chireau is survived by his wife Dorothy; brother Roger; sister Yolande; stepson Anthony Smith; and daughters Yvonne Chireau Rodriguez and Monique Chireau Wubbenhorst; eight grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren.

BLOOMFIELD--Kathryn Federman, age 100, passed peacefully on January 29th, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Gerard M. Bloomfield, loving mother of Marshall, Ed, and Matthew, proud grandmother of eight grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. Services are scheduled for 11:15am Sunday, at The Riverside Chapel (Amsterdam Ave. and W. 76th St.)

BERRY--Heidi Lehrman, 65, died January 25, 2009 of multiple myeloma. A devoted wife, mother and grandmother; journalist, arts patron and philanthropist, she was deeply loved. She will be remembered for her elegance, kindness, wisdom and beauty. She fought unrelenting cancer with courage, strength and grace. She is survived by husband Max N. Berry, children Elizabeth Berry, Stefanie Stark and David Berry, and grandchildren Jacob and Chloe Stark. A memorial service will be held at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington, DC on February 2 at 3:30pm, followed by three nights shiva. Donations may be made to: the Bryant Fellows, American Wing, Metropolitan Museum of Art; the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee; or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Multiple Myeloma research.

CLATWORTHY--William Paul, passed away peacefully at the St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan on January 29, 2009. He is survived by his mother Sarah, father David, stepmother Diane, brother Conrad, sister Darah, sister-in-law Merrie Beth, brother-in-law Timothy, niece Madeleine and nephew Dane. He will be profoundly missed. A Memorial Mass will take place on February 3rd at 10am in the Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to Catholic Charities and the American Red Cross.

8 P.M. (TCM) TCM PRIME TIME FEATURE: BURT LANCASTER A presentation of four films starring this New York City street kid turned leading man of the 1950s and '60s. The tribute begins with ''Sweet Smell of Success'' (1957), in which a press agent (Tony Curtis) helps a powerful columnist (Lancaster, above left, with Susan Harrison and Mr. Curtis) break up his sister's relationship with a musician. In ''Trapeze'' (1956), at 10, Lancaster and Mr. Curtis play trapeze artists who fall for a trampolinist (Gina Lollobrigida). In ''Elmer Gantry'' (1960), at midnight, Lancaster stars as a ne'er-do-well salesman turned evangelist preacher running from his troubled past; he won a best-actor Oscar for the role. And in ''The Rainmaker'' (1956), at 2:30 a.m., Lancaster plays Bill Starbuck, who tries to coax the rain in a drought-stricken Kansas town. Katharine Hepburn is the spinster whose heart he warms. 11:30 A.M. (13) TO THE CONTRARY WITH BONNIE ERBÉ Ms. Erbé discusses women's health care and whether President Obama has abandoned the issue; Representative Marcia L. Fudge, Democrat of Ohio, talks about the political representation of black women.

Lincoln Center has announced the schedule for its 2009-10 Great Performers series. Among the highlights of the program is ''Beethoven Then and Now: The Complete Symphonies,'' scheduled for March 25-27, 2010, at Alice Tully Hall. The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment and the Budapest Festival Orchestra, both conducted by Ivan Fischer, will perform period-instrument and modern-instrument programs of Beethoven's works. The series will also include the American premiere of Heiner Goebbels's experimental piece ''Stifter's Dinge,'' to be presented at the Park Avenue Armory from Dec. 16 to Dec. 20, as well as the first New York performances by Gustavo Dudamel with the Los Angeles Philharmonic and Yannick Nézet-Séguin with the Rotterdam Philharmonic. A complete schedule can be found at lincolncenter.org.

SONET--Jerrold M. The attorneys and staff of Levy Sonet & Siegel, LLP mourn the loss of its founding partner Jerrold M. Sonet. We will all miss Jerry's wisdom, drive and loyalty. He taught us all there are no shortcuts in serving the interests of our clients. Our love and thoughts go out to his wife Ann, his daughter Sara, his son James and his son Steven, a partner in our firm who continues his legacy. Rest peacefully Jerry. Levy Sonet & Siegel, LLP

DIGGINS--John Patrick. The Graduate Center community mourns the loss of a renowned colleague and extends sincere condolences to his family. An eminent intellectual historian and distinguished member of our doctoral faculty, he will be sorely missed. William P. Kelly, President, The Graduate Center, CUNY

The annual rock smorgasbord known as the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival has announced a 2009 lineup to satisfy all kinds of appetites. This year's festival, which runs from April 17 through 19 in Indio, Calif., will be headlined by Paul McCartney (on April 17), the Killers (April 18) and the Cure (April 19). It will also feature Morrissey, Franz Ferdinand, Leonard Cohen, My Bloody Valentine and TV on the Radio. Even Amy Winehouse is on the schedule, so you know it's a party. Tickets for the festival are now on sale; a layaway program (which allows ticket buyers to pay half now, and the balance on April 1, or one-third now and the remaining thirds on March 1 and April 1) is available online at ticketmaster.com through Feb. 28.

Rachele Fitz scored on a layup 2 minutes 20 seconds into the second half of a 70-44 victory against visiting Manhattan on Friday night to become Marist's career leading scorer. ''It's a good accomplishment,'' said Fitz, a 6-foot junior power forward. ''I think it could also be a team accomplishment, not just an individual one, because of everything they do to get me the ball and make me the player I am.''

The abrupt departure of the State Department's global AIDS coordinator has led to debate over who should run what may be President Bush's most important achievement: his commitment of billions of dollars to fighting AIDS overseas. The position -- global AIDS coordinator and director of the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, known as Pepfar -- is a State Department post with ambassador's rank that had been held by Dr. Mark R. Dybul, a Bush administration appointee.

GILBERT--Rev. Cass, III, died January 22, 2009 in Bennington, husband of Grace Chomeley-Jones Gilbert, son of Cass Gilbert Jr. and Elizabeth Jarvis Wyeth, grandson of Cass Gilbert, Architect, New York City. He was the father of five children and 12 grandchildren. Rev. Gilbert served in the Army during World War II overseas in North Africa, Sicily, Italy, France and Germany also Fort Ord, CA during the Korean War., retiring as Major. He was a graduate of Yale University and Boston School of Theology. Served churches in New York and Vermont, retiring to Bennington. Past master of Holland Lodge #

Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan flew home to Turkey on Friday to a hero's welcome, above, after walking off the stage at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, after an angry exchange over the Gaza war with President Shimon Peres of Israel. Crowds at the Istanbul airport waved Palestinian and Turkish flags while chanting slogans supporting the prime minister. Also on Friday, a report on Thursday that Mr. Peres had called Mr. Erdogan to apologize was disputed by a spokeswoman for Mr. Peres, who confirmed the call but said no apology had been made. SEBNEM ARSU

Casting for the coming Broadway transfer of ''Hair'' has been completed, the Public Theater announced. Among the final cast members announced for the musical revival are Will Swenson, who appeared in the Broadway musicals ''110 in the Shade'' and ''Lestat,'' as Berger, and Megan Lawrence, a Tony Award nominee for ''The Pajama Game,'' as Mother. The show is scheduled to begin previews at the Al Hirschfeld Theater on March 6 and open on March 31. ... Ronald Holgate, who originated the role of Richard Henry Lee in Broadway's ''1776,'' will replace Tony Roberts in the Keen Company's coming production of ''Heroes,'' the company announced. Mr. Roberts withdrew ''due to personal matters,'' the company said. The play, which also stars John Cullum and Jonathan Hogan, is scheduled to begin previews at the Clurman Theater on Feb. 24 and open on March 8; its limited run is to end on April 11. ... Charlotte d'Amboise will return to the Broadway revival of ''Chicago'' at the Ambassador Theater in the role of Roxie Hart on Feb. 13, before joining the show's national tour in Chicago, the producers announced. Another alumnus, Tom Wopat, will rejoin the Broadway show in the role of Billy Flynn on Feb. 16.
DOLCE--Alfred Anthony Aug. 18, 1927-Jan. 31, 2008 Dad, we love you & miss you. Mike, Roxanne, and family

APPELBAUM--Theodore, 91, died peacefully on January 29, 2009. Devoted and adoring husband to the late Leah Kurzer for 63 years. Beloved father of Ann and Alan Obsatz, and Randy Appelbaum. He will be remembered with love by his grandchildren, Joelle Obsatz and Paul Cordasco, Evan and Jennifer Obsatz. He was a loving brother, brother-in-law, uncle, greatuncle and friend. Proud WWII veteran and owner of the Butterfield Market in Manhattan.

About three months after he took office in a major government reshuffle, Georgia's prime minister, Grigol Mgaloblishvili, stepped down on Friday, citing unspecified health problems. The decision, though not unexpected, underscored the sense of instability in President Mikheil Saakashvili's government. Mr. Saakashvili's nominee for the job, Deputy Prime Minister Nika Gilauri, will be the fifth person to serve in that position since Mr. Saakashvili came to power in 2003.

Acklins Island is a tranquil sandbar that sits at the very bottom of the Bahamian chain, 100 miles northeast of Cuba. People come for the bonefish and the solitude -- there isn't much else. At left, Fedel Johnson uses a pole to maneuver the boat quietly onto the sand flats. nytimes.com/travel

SOMLYO--Roy A. The Board of Directors of the American Theatre Wing mourns the passing of Roy Somlyo, longtime champion of the Tony Awards and ATW's President from 1998 to 2003. Roy was there when the Tony's first went on nationwide television and continued as Managing Producer from 1987 to 1998. His unwavering commitment to recognizing theatrical excellence will be missed. We send our condolences to his family. Ted Chapin, Board Chairman Howard Sherman, Executive Director

One of the main story lines of this Super Bowl is the Pittsburgh ties of Arizona Coach Ken Whisenhunt and many members of his staff. But there is one coach who went the other way. Kirby Wilson, the Steelers' running backs coach, held the same position for the Cardinals from 2004 to 2006 under Coach Dennis Green.

HOFFMAN--Adele H.,on January 30, 2009; beloved wife of Gene; devoted mother of Jan Hoffman, Andrew Hoffman and Carol Lee Rainey; dear sister of Marvin Hoberman; also survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral Sunday, February 1, at 1pm in Temple B'Nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, NJ. Contributions may be made to the Israel Cancer Association USA, 525 South Flagler Road, West Palm Beach, FL 33401.

IT may not seem like much of a silver lining, but the bear market has given portfolio managers who focus on smaller companies more stocks to choose from. The values of many medium-size companies have shrunk so much that they can be considered small, and some may offer opportunities for sizable gains. Lori Calvasina, a strategist at Citigroup, points out in a research report that middle-capitalization stocks are trading at their lowest valuations relative to small caps in more than 20 years. That makes many of the ''fallen midcap stars'' attractive, in her view, and she expects managers of funds that focus on smaller companies to agree and to begin buying them.

PERLE--George. The Faculty and Staff of the Aaron Copland School of Music at Queens College mourn the passing of our beloved colleague, Professor Emeritus George Perle. Perle was a great American composer. His music and his pathfinding studies in 20th-century music will enlighten generations to come. He taught at Queens College from 1961 to 1985. A scholarship fund for the study of composition has been established in his honor at the School of Music. Please send contributions to the George Perle Scholarship Fund, c/o Prof. Edward Smaldone, Director, ACSM, Queens College, Kissena Blvd., Flushing, NY 11367.

Standing in for Kurt Warner at a news conference Friday for the finalists for the N.F.L.'s Walter Payton Man of the Year award was a woman many people in the audience did not recognize. It was Warner's wife, Brenda, who has to laugh at the anonymity that a change in hairstyle can provide. The two previous times the Warners were thrust into the Super Bowl spotlight, in the 1999 and 2001 seasons, Brenda had short, spiky hair. Seven years later, her hair has grown out and has blond highlights. For Brenda, who prefers a low-key life to a high-profile existence, it has proved to be a surprisingly effective disguise.

“Slumdog Millionaire,” about a poor young man in the slums of Mumbai who competes on an Indian game show, can add another prize of its own to a growing list that includes recent honors from the Screen Actors Guild, the Golden Globes and the Producers Guild. On Saturday, the film’s director, Danny Boyle, was honored by the Directors Guild of America at the group’s 61st annual awards dinner. The other nominees for best feature film director were David Fincher (“The Curious Case of Benjamin Button”), Ron Howard (“Frost/Nixon”), Christopher Nolan (“The Dark Knight”) and Gus Van Sant (“Milk”). Most years, the guild’s feature film award portends a directing prize at the Academy Awards, set this year for Feb. 22.

The rapper DMX was sentenced on Friday to 90 days in jail and at least 18 months of supervised probation following his conviction on charges of theft, drug possession and animal cruelty, The Associated Press reported. Maricopa County Superior Court Commissioner Phemonia Miller also put DMX, whose real name is Earl Simmons, on supervised probation for at least 18 months. On Dec. 30, Mr. Simmons, 38, pleaded guilty to felony counts of theft, possession or use of marijuana, and possession or use of narcotic drugs, and to a misdemeanor count of animal cruelty. He has been in custody in the Maricopa County Jail since Dec. 9. The time he has already served will not count toward the 90 days, Ms. Miller said on Friday. The animal cruelty and drug charges resulted from a raid of Mr. Simmons’ home in August 2007 that was carried out as part of an investigation of a report of animal abuse. A dozen malnourished pit bulls, three dead dogs, guns and drugs were discovered in the raid.

Primary Stages has announced that Vanessa Aspillaga (“Anna in the Tropics”), Jack Gilpin (“The Elephant Man”), Julie Halston (“Hairspray”), David Margulies (“Wonderful Town”) and Robert Christopher Riley (“Cat on a Hot Tin Roof”) have joined the cast of “Chasing Manet,” a new play by Tina Howe that is the final production of the company’s season. As previously announced, Jane Alexander and Lynn Cohen will star as residents of a nursing home who are plotting to escape for a last hurrah aboard the QE2. Previews begin March 24. …

Paul Blart’s reign at the top of the box office came to an end over the weekend, toppled by the vigilante-father film “Taken,” starring Liam Neeson. That action movie, about a former C.I.A. operative on a mission to rescue his daughter from kidnappers in Paris, earned $24.6 million for 20th Century Fox in its first week in theaters, more than enough to push “Paul Blart: Mall Cop” (Columbia) into second place, according to the box office tracking firm Media by Numbers. “Paul Blart,” a comedy starring Kevin James as a formidable shopping mall security force, earned $13.9 million for a cumulative total of $83.3 million in three weeks. Paramount Pictures took the third and fourth spots: “Uninvited,” a horror movie starring David Strathairn and Elizabeth Banks, made $10.5 million in its first weekend, and “Hotel for Dogs” the adaptation of Lois Duncan’s 1971 story about children who save stray animals, made $8.706 million ($48.2 million to date). “Hotel” barely edged out Clint Eastwood’s “Gran Torino” which earned $8.7 million for Warner Brothers ($110.6 million to date).

TAMPA, Fla. -- There are 4,589 credentialed media members at the Super Bowl, and from Tuesday through Thursday, all the players and coaches from the Super Bowl teams were made available to reporters for at least a hour. The average fan only reads or hears a small fraction of the conversations taking place, but my e-mail inbox has had to contain most of them. The wonderful N.F.L. media operation provides countless transcripts of news conferences and interviews going on during the media availability periods, which concluded with the coaches' and Commissioner Goodell's news conferences Friday. The transcript of Goodell's news conference was the 355th news release, most of which are transcripts of player interviews. To make sure that all that work (and all that paper) doesn't go to waste, here is a sampling of the best quotes of the week.

Kay Yow, the former North Carolina State women’s coach, was buried in her hometown, Gibsonville, N.C., about 70 miles west of Raleigh. Yow, a Hall of Famer, died Jan. 24 after a long fight with cancer. She coached at nearby Elon University for four years before taking over at North Carolina State in 1975 and piling up more than 700 career wins. The Wolfpack players and coaching staff were among about 300 mourners. After the graveside service, the team boarded a bus for Sunday’s game at Virginia Tech.

Tucker Fredricks of the United States edged the World Cup leader Yu Fengtong of China to win the 500-meter race in Erfurt, Germany. Fredricks became the first speedskater to break 35 seconds at the oval, finishing in 34.91 to beat Yu’s course record by 0.12.

A review on Jan. 18 about “Restoring the Balance,” a collection of essays on Middle East policy, misspelled the surname of one of the contributors. As noted in the table of contents, he is Richard N. Haass, not Haas.
A letter last Sunday responding to an article about the evolution of African-American film roles misspelled the surname of a media theorist who was quoted. He was Marshall McLuhan, not McCluhan.

An article on Jan. 11 about African-American filmmakers referred incorrectly to the domestic box-office performance of “The Family That Preys,” directed by Tyler Perry. It had the third-highest earnings ($37.1 million) of any movie directed by an African-American in 2008, not the highest. (“Nights in Rodanthe,” directed by Goerge C. Wolfe, was the top earner with $41.8 million and, as the article noted, “The Secret Life of Bees,” directed by Gina Prince-Bythewood, was second with $37.6 million.).

An article on Jan. 11 about the television show “United States of Tara,” whose protagonist has dissociative identity disorder (once known as multiple personality disorder), misidentified a soap opera character who has the illness and the actress who portrays her. Viki Lord Davidson, a character on ABC’s “One Life to Live” played by Erika Slezak, has the disorder — not Erica Kane, a character on ABC’s “All My Children” portrayed by Susan Lucci.

To the Editor: Regarding the Explorer column A Walk Through New Zealand’s Watery Wild” (Jan. 18): Both Spectator magazine (in 1908) and Sir Edmund Hillary had it right — the Milford Track is “the finest walk in the world.” As Robert D. Hershey Jr. suggests, don’t miss it. We traversed it more than a decade ago, but we had an element Mr. Hershey missed. Pouring rain!.

To the Editor: I’m sorry that James Schembari didn’t see the aurora borealis from his igloo in Finland (“A Bed Under Glass in the Land of the Aurora,” Jan. 18), but he should try again in about three years. The auroras are caused by particles ejected from the sun, and they are linked to the sunspot cycle. Sunspots have been absent on the sun for over a year, with rare exception, to the point where we solar astronomers are beginning to wonder if they will ever start up again. Odds are, though, that in about three years we will be halfway toward the next maximum of the cycle and that auroras will be plentiful.

HALPER DICKSON--Sari. With great sorrow we announce Sari's passing from aggressive cancer on January 30 at Sloan-Kettering Hospital with her husband, sister and mother there. Sari, 39, was an extraordinary, accomplished and caring person who savored life. Much beloved and loving wife of John, adoring mother of Diana (five), Aleksander (three), and Zachary (one). Much loved and loving daughter of Barbara Kaplan Halper, dearest sister and friend of Shauna and brother-in-law Joseph Prudenti, aunt of Matthew, (two and a half) and Tyler (3 weeks), cherished niece of Kenneth Kaplan, loved and loving daughter-in-law of Richard and Maryann, sisterin-law of Kenneth and aunt of Matthew Dickson (14). Funeral Sunday, 11am at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, 718263-7600.

ZINN--Leonard David. Beloved and devoted husband, father, grandfather, nephew, brother-in-law, uncle, cousin and friend. Born June 22, 1933 in Brooklyn, NY. Graduate of Queens College ('55) and Columbia Law School ('60). Served in the U.S. Army, 1955 -1957. Had a long and fulfilling career in real estate management. Avid photographer, lifetime student of history and art, opera lover, Yankees fan, world traveler, lover of fine Italian cuisine, mensch. Survived by his wife, Sandy R. Jamieson, sons Philip and Arthur, stepsons Scott, Francis and Douglas, and grandchildren Kelly, Jack, Henry, Teddy, Andrew, Bridget and Phoebe. Will be sorely missed by countless devoted family and friends, both in the U.S. and abroad. Funeral service will be held Monday, February 2 at 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY, interment immediately following, Woodlawn Cemetery, East 233rd Street, Bronx, NY.

Arizona Cardinals quarterback Kurt Warner is a born-again Christian whose faith informs his every decision, right down to his jersey number. By choosing No. 13, Warner means to send the message that his spirituality allows no room for superstition. He was one of five players on the active rosters of the 32 N.F.L. teams to wear No. 13 in 2008. The others were wide receiver Steve Johnson of Buffalo and quarterbacks Richard Bartel of Cleveland, Brock Berlin of St. Louis and Shaun Hill of San Francisco.

FLEET--Herman, had all the songs --from ''Pig's Foot'' to ''At Last'' --at his fingertips on the piano. He played at '50s Jam Sessions in Houston, Sign of the Dove, Doubles, and POSH NYC charity events from '60s to '08. His favorite was playing for patients at Sloan-Kettering NYC every Wednesday for 21 years. Born and reared in Houston, Rice graduate, WWII Gunner, Pianist, Painter, member of National Board of Review. He slipped away listening to ''Park Ave Sound of H Fleet'' on his 85th Birthday, January 22, 2009. Extraordinary brother, uncle, Friend. We remember him with love.

To the Editor: The article ''For a Chapel on the Park, the Bell May Soon Toll'' (Jan. 18), about the imminent sale and demolition of the Holy Trinity Chapel and the Catholic Center at New York University, may have left the impression that the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is abandoning its New York University campus ministry. SONET--Jerrold M.,died on January 28 from pulmonary fibrosis, at home, at peace and surrounded by loving family. He was born on September 16, 1928 in Manhattan, the son of Marion and Samuel Sonet. Jerrold attended Farragut Academy and Cornell University, from which he graduated at age 16. After receiving his JD from Harvard Law School, he returned to NYC and joined the law practice of Daniel Levy, which evolved into the firm of Levy, Sonet and Siegel. He was the legal architect for the consolidation which joined the American Institute of Designers and the National Society of Interior Designers into one organization, known since 1975 as the American Society of Interior Designers (ASID). For several decades, he served as General Counsel for ASID. Jerrold represented the late Angelo Donghia, and was selected by him to operate the Foundation he endowed for the benefit of interior design education and AIDS research. Jerrold leaves his beloved wife of 39 years, Ann Pardue Sonet, his brother Richard and wife Toni, and three loving children; Sara, a librarian at the Supreme Court, James, a principal in Electrified Discounters, and Steven, a partner in Levy, Sonet and Siegel; and four grandchildren. Services will be held on Monday, February 2, 2009, at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Martin Luther King Jr. Scholarship Fund at Harvard Law School, 125 Mount Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138. The Sonet family will receive guests on Sunday February 1 at 14 Sutton Place South between 4 and 7pm.

NO BARGAINS Ticket prices for the Super Bowl are weathering the economic storm. Late Saturday morning, Jim Holzman, the chief executive of Ace Ticket, said that the average reselling price for an $800 seat, the most common ticket, was $1,700. There had been speculation a couple of days ago that the resale price would drop to face value a day or two before the Super Bowl, but that did not happen. Holzman said the values had fluctuated wildly, spiking at $2,200 last week and dropping as low as $1,400 a few days ago.

GAMSU--Gordon, a world renowned thoracic radiologist, died January 13 at New York Hospital. He was 68. Dr. Gamsu was born in Johannesburg, South Africa. He attended the University of Witwatersrand Medical School and did his residency at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. From 1973 to 1995 he directed the division of thoracic imaging at UC-San Francisco, which under his leadership became the preeminent academic thoracic radiology section in the world. Dr. Gamsu was the author or co-author of 150 original papers, 60 chapters, and edited three major textbooks. In 1996 he became vice-chairman of the Department of Radiology at Weill-Cornell Medical College, taking emeritus status in 2007. He is survived by his wife, Gay Morris Gamsu, and his daughter, Jessica Gamsu Speechly. A memorial service will be held for Dr. Gamsu at 4:30pm, March 5 in the Griffis faculty Club, Weill-Cornell Medical College, 68th St. and York Ave., New York. In Dr. Gamsu's memory, a fund has been established with the Society of Thoracic Radiology that will serve to support academic investigation in the radiologic evaluation of chest disease. Those interested in making contributions can contact Jan Severson at the STR, 507-288-5620 or via email at str@thoracicrad.org.
SHEMIN--Natalie. Born September 19, 1914. Died January 25, 2009. Wife of the late George D. Shemin. Survived by daughter Gail Shemin and brother Dr. Bernard A. Sachs.

LEVINSON--Jacqueline (Gelernter). With deepest sorrow we announce the loss of our beloved Jacqueline on January 16, born September 27, 1930. Wife of the late Jesse Levinson, Jackie will be remembered for her gifts as a teacher, her wonderful contributions to the arts, her individuality, and her passion for life. A graduate of Cooper Union College, she spent over 10 years teaching Art and Theater at Arts High School in Newark, NJ. She was also an accomplished artist, playwright and set designer. She is survived by her loving sons, Adam and David Levinson and her grandchildren, Michael and Hannah Levinson. A memorial service will be held at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ on Sunday, February 8th at 1 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Doctors Without Borders.

MARSHAK--Janet, on January 18th, eight days before her 98th birthday. Wife of the late Benedict. Beloved mother of Alma Whitney (Richard) and Edward (Doris). Devoted grandmother of Benjamin, Sarah, Risa and Kara. Proud great-grandmother of Shannen and Jake. Adored sister and aunt. An activist who sought to right the wrongs of the world. Lover of music who nurtured that same love in her children. Independent and proud, she was a woman ahead of her time who will be missed by all.

FREE-FOR-ALL: In early-childhood education, nothing is underthought. Except, refreshingly, Starfall. The eccentric, cheerful learn-to-read site is loaded with scattershot activities. Some of them are great -- the ''D'' sequence in the opening alphabet is curiously effective -- while some miss the mark. (The Groundhog Day game is plain weird.) All told, though, the site is fun, free and -- see for yourself -- effective. UPSCALE: For a more elegant, more serious and more expensive early-reading experience, try One More Story, the subscription-only online library. For $44 a year, you get a sparkling-clean interface, acclaimed tried-and-true picture books, lovely narration and a glitch-free player.

CHASE--Doris Totten, April 29, 1923-December 13, 2008. Artist, sculptor, filmmaker, died in Seattle. Having a successful career as painter and sculptor, she evolved into filmmaking in the late 1960s. Upon moving to New York in 1972 Doris furthered her filmmaking visions and became recognized as a pioneer of video art. She produced over 70 films. Her ''Dance Series'' integrated modern dance with video effect imaging. Her ''Concept Series'' used a theatrical approach, combining actors and dialogue with visual effects. This lead to the ''By Herself'' series which focused on moments, realizations, and decisions in women's lives. In 1993 she produced a documentary about the Chelsea Hotel which was her home until 2004. Over the years she received many civic honors for her art and lifetime achievement. Her artwork is in numerous public and museum collections worldwide including: Museum of Modern Art, New York, Smithsonian, Washington, DC, British Film Institute, London. Select film festival awards include: Berlin, Cannes, London, New York and San Francisco. Doris was a spiritualist who saw each day as a new opportunity. She is survived by sons Randy (Nancy) of Seattle, and Gary (Pam), grandchildren Tom, James and Jonathan of Melbourne.

CAPOZZA--Cataldo, (65), of Naples, FL and Yarmouth, ME, died at his Naples home on December 28, 2008, following a courageous three year battle with cancer. An original member and shareholder of the New York Mercantile Exchange, Capozza was a strong advocate for modernization and members' rights. In the year 2000, he worked with Chairman Rappaport to establish the Exchange's first electronic trading system. Subsequently, he fought hard to protect members' equity rights as the Exchange made the transition into the era of electronic trading, undertook an IPO, and was ultimately sold to the Chicago Mercantile Ex change. The son of Italian immigrants, Capozza grew up in Tarrytown, NY where his father, Frank, established Frank's Fuel Company, and where his mother, Anna, kept the company books. Young Cataldo drove one of the company's fuel delivery trucks throughout the NY area often having to battle his way down the streets in some of the rougher neighborhoods. He later attended NYU where he earned a degree in economics and business. It was, perhaps, this blend of energies that enabled him to fight for ''a level playing field'' in his dual careers as a real estate entrepreneur and as a commodities trader. When asked by his brother Joe how he wanted to be remembered in this life, Capozza replied: ''As a warrior for all those who in fairness and integrity-pursue the American Dream.'' He is survived by his beloved wife, Suzanne; his sons Seth and Brad; his brother Joe; eight cherished nieces and nephews; and three grandchildren: Christian, Leeann and John. Memorial gifts: The American Cancer Society.

KAPP--Anneliese Gmelch, longtime fashion illustrator, design teacher, and wife of the late record executive and music producer David Kapp, died on January 19th in New York after a brief illness. Born in Germany in 1922 and raised in the countryside near Munich, she came to New York in 1938. Her fashion illustrations in leading New York publications reflected impeccable style and grace, qualities that defined her as well. Anneliese had a grand sense of humor and a wonderful heart. She will be dearly missed.

She will be remembered for her elegance, kindness, wisdom and beauty. She fought unrelenting cancer with courage, strength and grace. She is survived by husband Max N. Berry, children Elizabeth Berry, Stefanie Stark and David Berry, and grandchildren Jacob and Chloe Stark. A memorial service will be held at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington, DC on February 2 at 3:30pm, followed by three nights shiva. Donations may be made to: the Bryant Fellows, American Wing, Metropolitan Museum of Art; the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee; or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Multiple Myeloma research.

The Knickerbocker Ice Festival last week drew the ice sculptors Rob Patalano, above, and Earl Covington, left, to Rockland Lake State Park, where they used their talents to help open the Hudson Valley Quadricentennial, the 400th anniversary of Henry Hudson and Samuel de Champlain's voyages along the river and lake that bear their names. The annual ice festival celebrates Rockland Lake's history as the center of the ice trade in the 19th century.

PROOF It is unlikely that a modern-day Aristotle would ever find himself in a fraternity house playing beer pong to the sounds of Lynyrd Skynyrd. But the historian James Davidson describes the ancient Greek symposium, a ''classic moderate drinking party'' common to the wealthier households of Athens, during which men of stature would engage in lively debate with bowls of wine dispensed under the careful watch of a symposiarch (a sort of strict toastmaster). The most famous of these is recounted in Plato's ''Symposium,'' where Socrates and his friends, still hung over from the night before, decide on an evening of light drinking. The temperance pays off: in the ensuing discussion, they summon an overarching vision of love that has endured in the Western imagination for more than two millennia.

GREENBERG--Murray, earned his doctorate in engineering science at New York University and taught in the management science department at Baruch College of CUNY for 15 plus years. He retired in 1993. In addition to his credentials as an educator, Dr. Greenberg spent many years as a photographer and worked with his wife, Dr. Pearl Greenberg, editing the photographs for her books in the field of art education. He would have turned 83 in May 2009. In recent years, he became Pearl's caretaker after she fractured both hips and took over cooking the most delicious meals which they both enjoyed. Their son Ken and daughterin-law Clara live in California but have recently been back in New York City to visit and celebrate their 30th anniversary. Murray died January 9th doing what he most enjoyed, snorkeling in the beautiful waters of Culebra, Puerto Rico. At his funeral his oldest friend Arthur Klein said it best: ''Murray was smarter than he knew, he will be missed.'' Those interested in a memorial are welcome to make a gift in Murray's memory to Cooper Union (30 Cooper Square, 8th floor, New York, NY 10003), where he met Pearl, his wife of 61 years in 1947.

GOODRICH--Dr. Joyce, passed away on January 2nd, 2009 in New York after suffering a stroke. Born in Chicago on February 21, 1929, the daughter of Grant and Alice Gammeter Goodrich, she received her undergraduate degree from Sarah Lawrence College in 1952 and later a doctorate in Parapsychology. She lived in New York for 40 years. For three decades Joyce was a Director of the Consciousness Research and Training Project teaching the process, use and practice of the LeShan approach to psychic healing across the country. She is survived by her sister, Adele Goodrich (New Jersey), brothers Grant Goodrich (Florida) and Peter Goodrich (California) and their families, cousins and many friends. The Consciousness Research and Training Project team is planning a memorial service in New York. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

HONDA announced last week that the 2009 S2000 roadster would be the last. The decision was not entirely unexpected after the company scrapped plans last month for the next Acura NSX sports car. When it was introduced in 1999, as a 2000 model, the S2000 was really unlike any car of its kind. Its 4-cylinder engine -- Honda enthusiasts referred to it by its engine code: F20C -- was only 2 liters, but made 240 horsepower. It had a redline of 9,000 r.p.m., and the car was most effective the closer you drove to that engine speed, which was a loud proposition.

LOGAN--Harold R. Former President and Chief Executive Officer of Grace Lines Shipping Company and Vice Chairman of W.R. Grace & Co., died on January 23, 2009 in Stuart, Florida from complications of prostate cancer. He was 87. As an accomplished manager in government, business, and charity, Mr. Logan rose to the position of Director of the Budget for the Defense Department during the Eisenhower administration. He left government in 1960 to become Chief Financial Officer of Grace Lines Shipping Company, a subsidiary of W.R. Grace & Co. In 1967, he was appointed President and Chief Executive Officer of Grace Lines. In 1969, he managed the sale of Grace Lines to the Skouras shipping interests in Greece. In 1970, Mr. Logan helped found the Natural Resources Division of W.R. Grace and built it up to be one of the largest landdrilling rig companies in the US, with major interests in oil and gas production and mining. He was elected to the Board of Directors of W.R. Grace in 1976 and elected Vice Chairman in 1981. He retired from W.R. Grace in 1986. Serving on the boards of a wide array of industries and charities, Mr. Logan was Chairman of the Board of Directors of Comstock Resources, Inc.; and a Director of IC Industries, Inc., Whitman Corporation, Chelsea Industries, Abex Corporation, Neuberger Berman Bond Fund Advisory Board, Dome Canada Ltd, Energy Fund Inc., and Voyager Petroleum Ltd. He was a Trustee of the University of New Haven, a Trustee of Norfield Congregational Church of Weston, Connecticut, and a founding member of the Board of Trustees of the South Street Seaport Museum. He was inducted into the Spears Business School Hall of Fame at Oklahoma State University in 1964. Mr. Logan is survived by his wife, Tolita Christensen Logan of Stuart, Florida; his son, Harold R. Logan, Jr. of Denver, Colorado; his daughter, Mary Betts Bohm of New York, NY; grandsons Scott Logan and Matthew Logan; and great-granddaughters, Katherine and Avery Logan. He is also survived by his sisters, Dorothy Guy and Betty Berry of California; LaRue Terry of Texas; and LaNore Hayes of Oklahoma; as well as stepchildren Peter Christensen, Jeff Christensen and Liz Christensen of New York, NY. Mr. Logan was predeceased by his wife of 44 years, Freda Townsend Logan, in 1984. Plans for services will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Treasure Coast Hospices (1201 SE Indian Street; Stuart, Florida 34997) and Peace Presbyterian Church (4881 SE Cove Road; Stuart, Florida 34997).

ISUZU stopped selling passenger vehicles in the United States on Jan. 31. At least officially; it could be argued that Isuzu's been dead since 2004, when it stopped producing its own vehicles and became a purveyor of rebadged trucks from General Motors. But now, even the charade of the Ascender (a Chevy TrailBlazer) and i-Series trucks (a k a, the Chevy Colorado) comes to an end. Isuzu entered the United States in 1981 and enjoyed modest success with vehicles like the Impulse -- a Giorgetto Giugiaro design that featured ''handling by Lotus'' -- and the Trooper S.U.V. Isuzu's famous ad campaign, which featured the actor David Leisure as smarmy pitchman Joe Isuzu, is probably better remembered than the actual cars it was designed to sell. In one spot for the P'up truck -- one of the few nameplates in the truck world to include punctuation -- Mr. Leisure's pathologically lying character offers customers ''3.9 percent financing or 500 pounds of bananas.'' In another spot that now seems horribly inappropriate, an Isuzu Trooper is compared to a Cherokee -- but not a Jeep, an actual Native American on a horse. Which, as Joe Isuzu dutifully points out, does not feature skid plates.

People from Wisconsin and Colorado must think New Yorkers are a bunch of wimps. A dusting of snow and a torrential rain last week led to whining worthy of a full-scale blizzard. But there was reason for dismay: The combination flooded Fifth Avenue curbs and not only soaked feet: if you debated how to cross the street for too long, a passing car would treat you to a body-drenching splash. Men are creatures of habit, generally unwilling to change their dress shoes for boots. Women, with few exceptions, give the weather its due with the proper clothing and boots, although they're not always waterproof. Unsuspecting tourists, unfamiliar with the curbside pools, their eyes trained skyward, walk right into them. And the snobs are so above it all, they think the waters will part for them even as they sink to their ankles.

WALDORF--Geraldine P.,of Suffern, NY, age 67, passed away peacefully January 28 surrounded by family at home after a brave battle with cancer. Cherished daughter of Pauline and the late Marcel Polack, wife of Donald, mother of Heidi, Lawrence and Mel, grandmother of Natasha Waldorf, sister of Lawrence Pollack. Ms. Waldorf had her own law practice in Rockland County, New York. She co-authored, and for 15 years prepared annual supplements for, the two volume New York Practice Guide: Probate and Estate Administration. Ms. Waldorf started her legal career at Kelley Drye & Warren and was also Special Counsel to Davidson, Dawson & Clark, both in New York City. She was a Fellow of The New York Bar Foundation. Ms. Waldorf received her law degree from Columbia University School of Law, where she was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, and a Master of Law in Taxation from New York University School of Law. She earned her undergraduate degree at Vassar College, where she did research on urban renewal under a Ford Foundation grant and graduated with honors in economics. She received a Master's degree in political science from Sarah Lawrence College. Ms. Waldorf gave her time to numerous not-for-profit endeavors. She was Founding Chairman of Friends of Georgetown University Center for Child and Human Development, prior to the founding of which she served on the Center's Advisory Committee. In 2005, she was honored as Georgetown Pediatrics Volunteer of the Year. Ms. Waldorf also served on the Women's Leadership Board and Chaired the Program Committee. Starting in 1999, Ms. Waldorf served on the Advisory Council of the Women Presidents' Organization. Starting in 1971, she served the American Cancer Society, Rockland County Unit, in various capacities including Chair of the Special Gifts Committee, Chair of the Public Information Committee and member of the Executive Committee; she initiated and developed the ''Giving Wall/Living Wall'', the Unit's highest revenue raising project. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: The Geraldine P. Waldorf Fund, Georgetown University Center for Child & Human Development, c/o Donna Deardorff, Center for Child & Human Development, 3300 Whitehaven Street NW, Suite 3300, Box 571485, Washington, DC 20057, to support the work of the Center for vulnerable children having-or at risk for developinglearning, emotional or developmental difficulties.

ANIK--Paul S. June 20, 1954January 27, 2009. Beloved husband of Barbara, father to Vanessa and Ben, brother to Andrew and Arthur, son-inlaw of Selma and Arnold Patent. A family man loved by all. Growing up in New York, Paul came to Southern California and had a highly successful law career. A much loved and respected partner of several major Los Angeles law firms, most recently Dreier Stein & Kahan. He had a business transactional law practice, specializing in the computer industry. Paul was and remained a Brooklyn boy. He collected and reviewed mystery novels, was a wine enthusiast, avid photographer, and had a passion for musical theatre. Served on the board and in many leadership capacities at Temple Aliyah of Woodland Hills, California. Known for his Rice Krispie treats and pancake breakfasts; he had a cousin in every port. Paul lived his life fully, and with passion. His sudden death, at age 54 on January 27, 2009, was a terrible shock, and has rocked the worlds of all lucky enough to have known him.

BACHELDER--Julia Bloodgood, age 93, died of natural causes November 28, 2008 in Canaan, CT. Born February 6, 1915 at 2 Harvard Street in Holyoke Massachusetts to Walter Frederick Bachelder of Palmira, Maine and Julia Selma Bachelder (nee Schniewind) of Whitestone, New York. She attended Wellesley College, Class of 1936. Moving to New York in 1942, she became secretary to the war desk of the New York Times. A member of the 30 Year Club of The New York Times, Julia was picture editor for the Sunday Book Review under Francis Brown and retired as picture editor of the Tuesday Science Section in 1980. She is survived by Susan Parkinson Bachelder of South Egremont, MA; Sally Bloodgood Bachelder Keil, Carl O. Keil and two greatnephews, C. Andrew and Fletcher B. of Woodstock, CT and John Henry Bachelder, his wife Marilyn and two great-nephews Philip C. and Michael F. of Woodbridge, CT. She is preceded in death by her parents and brother, Walter Frederick Bachelder Jr. of Garden City and Fort Salonga, New York. A memorial honoring her life will be held at Wistariahurst Museum in Holyoke, MA, February 7th at 2pm.

A group of unidentified assailants overpowered security guards and vandalized a synagogue here early Saturday morning, the latest in a series of episodes aimed at Jewish institutions since Venezuela's recent expulsion of the Israeli ambassador and the severing of diplomatic ties with Israel to protest the war in Gaza. The vandals broke into Tiferet Israel, a Sephardic synagogue in the Maripérez district of Caracas, strewing Torah scrolls on the floor and spray-painting the walls with messages like ''Death to all,'' according to televised reports.

STANDING in the old wooden lodge of the Mohawk Mountain Ski Area here last month, Carol Lugar gazed at a 60-year-old photograph of her father holding what resembles an oversize garden hose. A mist emanates from the hose, and snow is all around. The picture shows one of the earliest snow-making systems in America, an invention that saved the ski industry in the Eastern United States.

THE NEWSPresident Obama's proposed $819 billion economic stimulus plan passed the House of Representatives on Wednesday. BEHIND THE NEWS Though the president met on Capitol Hill with the entire House G.O.P., led by John A. Boehner, above, and made other overtures, not a single Republican voted for it; 11 Democrats also voted no. The main disagreement was over the balance between tax cuts and spending provisions; Republicans offered a plan that was almost entirely made up of tax cuts. Looming divisions between Senate and House Democrats over Medicaid funding, the alternative minimum tax and other issues threatened to snarl the bill.

STANDING in the old wooden lodge of the Mohawk Mountain Ski Area here last month, Carol Lugar gazed at a 60-year-old photograph of her father holding what resembles an oversize garden hose. A DREAM FULFILLED, WASHINGTON, JAN. 20, 2009: Natosha Sutton, 48, both arms raised, holding a camera, a systems analyst from Charlotte, N.C., rejoicing at the National Mall as Barack Obama was sworn in as president of the United States. ''Several of my co-workers wanted to go, too, but when it came down to it, I guess they saw how cold it was going to be and changed their minds. But I was determined to go, so I drove up by myself from Charlotte the Saturday before. The inauguration meant a lot to me. I got there at 7:30, and I stood on this little brick wall the whole time. For the first couple of hours, I probably could have sat down, but I didn't want to. So many people were there, regardless of their race. Yes, he is the first African-American president. But he also just seems like a really serious person who's willing to try to do the best he can for our country. That picture was taken right after he was sworn in. For me, that was the finishing moment -- that this is real; this is the truth. At that moment, I was just thanking God it had happened.'' As told to Austin Considine

DELVALLE--Hugh M.,of White Plains, NY, died Sunday, January 25, 2009 at home. He was 88 years old. Hugh was born March 9, 1920 in Yonkers, NY, son of the late Kenneth and Eunice Delvalle. Hugh had extensive experience with the international fertilizer markets. Between 1955 and 1980, he served as vice president of Interore, a subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum Corp., where he was instrumental in opening up the Latin American market under the direction of the late Dr. Armand Hammer. After he retired in 1980, he formed his own company Delchem and offered his expertise as a consultant for many years. His beloved wife, June (nee Ackerman), son Bruce and daughter, Margot (George) Delvalle-Pierro survive him as well as grandchildren, Dana Delvalle, Katy Pierro and Jacquelyn Pierro. He was preceded in death by a son Kenneth Delvalle and his family. Contributions in Hugh's memory may be made to the White Plains Hospital Center or the charity of your choice.

WILLINGER--Harding Warren, of Palm Beach, Florida and Bridgehampton, New York died peacefully on Thursday, January 29, 2009, from complications following a fall. Harding was born in 1923 in Bronx, NY, attended New York University and Amherst College, and served in the U.S. Army Air Force during World War II. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Jan Willinger, sister Barbara (Mrs. Hans) Wabeck, three daughters from his first marriage to Maria Ostrow: Karen Leigh (Sanford), Jill Willinger Weiss (George), Kate Manfredi (John), his stepson Joseph Robinson (Jasmine), grandchildren Tara Purasson, Ava and Jesse Robinson, Zachary and Logan Manfredi. Services will be held at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Monday, February 2nd, in West Palm Beach. The family requests that donations in Hardings memory be made to the Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc., 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

WATKINS--John. 1940-2009. It is with great sadness that we inform Colgate people around the world that John Watkins, a long-time and beloved Colgate leader who contributed greatly to the company's strategy and success, passed away on Thursday, January 22. His health and spirits had been good in recent years, more than twenty years after a tragic surf accident that left him physically paralyzed at the height of his career, but undiminished in his wit, wisdom and loyalty to Colgate. A native of Wales, John's illustrious career with Colgate began in 1964 and saw his rapid rise through marketing positions in Europe, the U.S., and Latin America, before he assumed leadership of ColgatePalmolive Italy in 1974. Returning to New York in 1979, he briefly headed Colgate's U.S. Household Products Division and later became the leader of all product management activities for Colgate's U.S. business. With his appointment as Group Vice President for Corporate Strategy and Worldwide Business Planning in 1981, the predecessor group to Global Marketing, he helped develop the strategy that would lead to Colgate's sharp worldwide category focus, financial discipline and subsequent success. Named a Corporate Officer beginning in 1981 and Senior Executive Vice President, Chief Strategic and Business Development Officer in 1984, he expanded his key leadership role on the senior team reporting to the CEO. With his tragic accident in 1987, John and his wife Jo embarked on a new phase in their lives, persevering in a recovery that restored his speech and respiratory functions. With his characteristic Welsh determination, he maintained his Colgate connections and his business interests, sharing his extensive experience as a university lecturer in Florida. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 6 at 4pm, Saint Christopher's by the Sea Episcopal Church, 95 Harbor Drive, Key Biscayne, FL 33149. Colgate people join Jo and the family in fond and grateful remembrance of John, a true friend to Colgate, and extend our deepest condolences. In loving Memory from Colgate People Everywhere

May his memory be for a blessing. AFHU George A. Schieren, President Ira Lee Sorkin, Chairman Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

Two museums in Edinburgh and London said that they have raised enough money to keep a Titian painting that its owner was planning to sell, Reuters reported. The National Galleries of Scotland and the National Gallery in London said that they had jointly raised about $71 million to purchase Titian’s “Diana and Actaeon,” an oil painting from the mid-1500s. In August, the Duke of Sutherland announced that he planned to sell his art collection, which included that painting as well as a second Titian work, “Diana and Callisto,” but gave the museums until the end of 2008 to raise enough money to buy at least one of them; that deadline was later extended. The campaign to save the paintings drew criticism for using public funds to purchase the works. The museums now have until 2012 to buy “Diana and Callisto.”

A producer for the pregame show at Super Bowl XLIII said that Faith Hill and Jennifer Hudson used prerecorded tracks in their appearances on the show, The Associated Press reported. Rickey Minor, the producer and the music director for “American Idol,” said that Ms. Hill, who sang “America the Beautiful,” and Ms. Hudson, who sang “The Star-Spangled Banner,” performed along to recorded tracks that they were required to submit to the National Football League a week before Sunday’s game. “That’s the right way to do it,” Mr. Minor said, according to The A.P. “There’s too many variables to go live. I would never recommend any artist go live because the slightest glitch would devastate the performance.” Ms. Hill previously performed the national anthem at Super Bowl XXXIV in 2000.

A member of the Pasadena, Calif., arts and culture commission has resigned after the City Council voted to reject the commission’s recommendation to install two public artworks near the Pasadena Civic Auditorium, The Los Angeles Times reported. The commission had recommended that the two works, “Light Field” by Hans Peter Kuhn (which uses six-foot-long light tubes on a 570-square foot field) and “Thinking Caps” by Dennis Oppenheim (a sculpture of three large hats that stands 15 feet tall), be installed on the plaza in front of the auditorium. But the City Council voted to seek other options, after complaints by residents and preservationists that the works were too big for the space. In an e-mail message sent to the city council and the commission, Sasha Anawalt, a commission member, said she was resigning over “a poor and cowardly decision for which the citizens ultimately pay,” according to The Times.

A creative dispute has compelled William Friedkin to withdraw from his role as the director of an operatic version of “An Inconvenient Truth” planned for La Scala, Variety reported. In departing the production, adapted from the environmental documentary featuring former Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Friedkin, the director of “The Exorcist” and “The French Connection,” cited “irreconcilable creative differences” with the poet J.D. McClatchy, who is writing the libretto. But Giorgio Battistelli, the composer of the opera, told the Italian newspaper Corriere Della Sera that Mr. Friedkin left for “for personal, not artistic reasons,” and criticized the director for his use of special effects in the production, saying, “Opera isn’t Hollywood.” The opera is scheduled to have its premiere at La Scala on May 11, 2011.

Add Alan Ayckbourn’s “Norman Conquests” to a busy spring season on Broadway. Mr. Ayckbourn’s 1973 comic trilogy of interlocking plays, which was recently revived at the Old Vic Theater in London, is headed to the Circle in the Square Theater with its six-member cast intact, the show’s publicists said in a release. In each of the trilogy’s plays, an assistant librarian named Norman (played by Stephen Mangan) tries to seduce a different woman during a chaotic weekend. The plays, directed by Matthew Warchus (who also directed the recent Broadway revival of “Boeing-Boeing“), will run on a rotating schedule, and all three will be presented consecutively on Saturdays. “The Norman Conquests” is to begin previews on April 7 and open April 23; its limited run is scheduled through July 25.

BOSTON -- If the coaches and analysts needed any more evidence that the Beanpot Tournament exists outside the realm of the rest of the college hockey season, the first game of the 2009 tournament provided it. Boston University entered with the country's No. 1 ranking, but it took a goal in the final two minutes -- and a Harvard goal that came a split-second too late -- for the Terriers to separate themselves from an energetic Harvard squad, 4-3.The Crimson (5-12-4), fueled by the buzz surrounding this year's tournament, did not seem intimidated by the Terriers' aggressive play. Harvard took the lead when Michael Biega slipped a soft shot under goalie Kieran Millan, silencing the B.U. fans. The crowd, dressed mostly in B.U. red and white, grew even quieter after Alex Killorn capitalized on a two-man advantage to open the second and give Harvard a 2-0 lead.

Years ago I worked at Elaine's with a bartender named Tommy who was something of a legend on the East Side of Manhattan. We were behind the bar together one night when an older, well-dressed couple came in for what seemed to me to be a rare night on the town. After some deliberation, the woman brightly asked my bartending partner for a brandy Alexander. Tommy turned to the register took out a $10 bill and handed it to the lady. "Go across the street," he said. "They make that garbage over there."

Two stories about Italy (hat tips to Pete Confalone and Cara De Silva) demonstrate once again that change is inevitable everywhere. But can paranoia and xenophobism - gastronomic racism, as it's called here (what a term!) -- really keep food from changing? Is Italian food so sacred that it must be "preserved" (and therefore die)? As you can tell from my tone, I'd say "no": culture cannot remain static and vibrant at the same time.

On our fifth Tiny Kitchen webisode, which posted this weekend, I cook a dish called uova al purgatorio, or "eggs in purgatory" (hmmmm?), from A-16 in San Francisco. The chef, Nate Appleman, is a fan of the cured meats from La Quercia - the Iowa company profiled in this week's Field Report - and uses both its prosciutto and its lardo in his recipe.The dish starts with some soft chestnut polenta, topped with a few spoonfuls of a four-hour, pork-flavored ragù, topped with an egg that's been poached in the ragù itself, topped with a thin slice of lardo, topped with grated ricotta salata. Fat on fat on fat on fat. Yummmm!

In March 1973, the authorities uncovered a terrorist plot to set off bombs in rented cars next to three Israel institutions in New York City, two on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan and one at Kennedy International Airport in Queens. The bombs were supposed to be detonated at noon on March 4, 1973, upon the arrival of Prime Minister Golda Meir of Israel, but the explosive devices did not go off as intended because of "an error in the circuitry system," the F.B.I. said at the time.
