News that Wall Street workers received bonuses commensurate with their bonuses from the boom year of 2004 inspired an outpouring of vitriol from commentators, politicians and average Joes. But how could something considered so meager on Wall Street inspire so much anger on Main Street? Is a bonus supposed to be a reward for a job well done -- a tip of sorts -- or is it just like any other form of compensation?

On the way to Brooklyn from Manhattan around 7:30 p.m. on Super Bowl Sunday, a disheveled man walked into a No. 2 subway train making a stop at Canal Street. No one paid much attention as the man lay down on a row of seats to take a nap. The complete strangers around him did not realize he would soon force them to come together to make a practical decision.The man, his eyes still closed, sat up a couple of stops later, opened his fly and urinated. From a seated position, he thoroughly soaked his vicinity, and the half-full car emptied out in the middle as his fellow passengers -- including this reporter -- fled in both directions.
Ed has come up with a simpler way to make fondant potatoes. --MB

Behavior | Something to think about if the economy finds you going the D.I.Y. route: people place a disproportionately high value on products they had a hand in making. But being so invested is not always a good thing; the "Ikea effect" may explain why business managers keep failing projects alive. [Harvard Business Review]
Headlines from the world of property:

On Sunday, the Los Angeles Times reported that while Barack Obama has announced significant changes to elements in the Bush terror war -- shutting Guatanamo and C.I.A. black sites, ending the use of torture in interrogations -- he has "left intact an equally controversial counter-terrorism tool."

Today is James Joyce's birthday, and 2009 marks at least two significant Joycean anniversaries: "Finnegans Wake" was published in 1939 - its author was peeved when World War II stole some of his thunder - and Richard Ellmann's great biography came out in 1959.

Is it O.K. to burn someone's belongings after a breakup? About 2 percent of New Yorkers said yes in a new dating survey by Zagat. Some of these, undoubtedly, were among the 9 percent who said they had been dumped via a text message.

Bank of America faces a rising tide of lawsuits over its troubled, shotgun marriage to Merrill Lynch. The latest came late last week, filed in a New York court on behalf of Bank of America shareholders.

Law | Do parents have the right to name their kid Adolf Hitler? Doing so is not just a question of abuse as legally defined, a professor says; it could also run afoul of trademark law, which explicitly forbids registering a name that consists of "immoral or scandalous matter." Still, that hasn't stopped the Washington Redskins. [Forbes]

For the last two years, the T-Redspeed traffic-camera system has been catching drivers in Italy running red lights, speeding and making illegal turns. Now its inventor and more than 100 other people, including 63 police officers, are being investigated for fraud.

The federal court judge overseeing the bankruptcy case of Lehman Brothers was arrested on Saturday after allegedly hitting his wife. James M. Peck, 63, is charged with third-degree attempted assault and second-degree harassment after a fight with his wife, Judith, according to the complaint filed in New York State Supreme Court. Read the complaint [pdf]. Judge Peck was released without bail and is scheduled to appear in court on March 16.
[UPDATE: See bottom of post for the pregame scene from the Garden.]
Opposite NBC's Super Bowl broadcast, the biggest television ratings event of the year, ABC, CBS and Fox barely bothered to court audiences of their own.

Finance | Peter Schiff is now famous across YouTube and cable TV for predicting the collapse of the U.S. financial system. But that's cold comfort to the broker-dealer's clients who took his specific advice: bet that the dollar would weaken significantly and foreign stocks would reap the rewards. In fact, the opposite happened. [Wall Street Journal]

A digital copy of Inauguration Day | Just as millions of Americans saved copies of newspapers on the day after President Obama's election, television executives are hoping that consumers will want digital memories of Inauguration Day. ABC, CBS, CNN and NBC are all selling DVDs of the day's festivities through online stores.
Amtrak’s new campaign for its Acela service between Boston and Washington beckons to air travelers who feel they have lost many of the common comforts and conveniences on their journeys.
The federal court judge overseeing the bankruptcy case of Lehman Brothers was arrested on Saturday afternoon and charged with hitting his wife.
Tinnitus, an annoying hum or ringing in the ears, affects about one in five people, making it one of the most common medical afflictions.
A beautiful salad in which the bitter flavor of the endive is countered by the sweet red peppers and broccoli.

Overnight "metered-market" estimates indicate that NBC's live broadcast of Super Bowl XLIII from Tampa, Fla., attracted fewer viewers than last year's game, which averaged a record 97.4 million viewers for Fox. If the estimates prove correct, the audience should be in line with CBS's broadcast of Super Bowl XLI in 2007, which drew 93.2 million viewers.

Discovery announces underwater discovery | The finding of the wreckage of the H.M.S. Victory, a legendary British warship, will be featured on the Discovery Channel program "Treasure Quest" on Thursday. The cable channel held a press conference about the underwater discovery in London on Monday, reports William J. Broad of The New York Times. The weekly "Treasure Quest" series had its debut last month. (2/2, 1:35 p.m.)

'Leverage' will be back | TNT has renewed "Leverage," the action drama starring Timothy Hutton, right, for a second season. It will return later in the year. The first season has averaged 3.2 million viewers (and 4.1 million when seven days of DVR playback are counted). 2/2, 1:33 p.m.
It was a weekend of firsts in college hockey.

In Monday's New York Times: Claims that Al Qaeda terrorists were not solely responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks have a lively following on the Internet, but a coming episode of the FX drama "Rescue Me" may represent the first fictional presentation of 9/11 conspiracy theories by a mainstream media company.

As Andrew Revkin reports today in The Times, a post on Google Earth's official blog this afternoon announced that, as rumored, the latest version of Google Earth, which was just released, allows users to explore the ocean floor as well as the earth's land masses.

Speaking of logistics, here's the best of the bunch: To get a press seat inside the International Ballroom here at the Beverly Hilton, where the luncheon for the Oscar nominees is being held, you have to turn the crank on a bingo ball bouncer that pops up a seat number. The Academy makes you turn the handle yourself, perhaps so you have no one but yourself to blame for a bad seat. The gambling gods have placed your gallivanting correspondent at a table with Danny Boyle, the director of "Slumdog Millionaire," and John Lasseter, the Disney Animation czar. It's a good table, but I can't help but think that some sort of fix was in. The mandarins at the Academy obviously figured I'd do better with the likes of Mr. Boyle, Mr. Lasseter and Mike Pogorzelski, director of the Academy's film archive, than with somebody like Angelina Jolie.

In continuing to lay the groundwork for his run for mayor this fall, William C. Thompson Jr., the New York City comptroller, has hired a longtime adviser and confidant, Eduardo Castell, to run his campaign. The appointment of Mr. Castell, a deputy in the comptroller's office, will be announced later on Monday. Mr. Castell took a leave of absence from his city job on Friday.Mr. Castell, 44, a New York City native, ran Mr. Thompson's unlikely bid for comptroller in 2001, a bruising and at times nasty Democratic primary that catapulted Mr. Thompson into citywide elected office.

[UPDATE, 2/20: The Bits blog explores reports that someone has found the lost city of Atlantis in Google's oceans.] Google has filled in the vast blue blank in its online version of the home planet , which has been installed on half a billion computers since it was launched in 2005.

What's that popular definition of insanity attributed to Albert Einstein? Doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results? For the second year in a row, Senators G.M. Bryan Murray has axed his first-year coach in February. Craig Hartsburg was dismissed Monday morning after the Caps and Alex Ovechkin dismantled the Sens 7-4 the day before.
A look at the Aral Sea over time, using Google Earth. (Courtesy Google).
The latest version of Google Earth gives a new look at the oceans, which cover 66 percent of the planet. (Courtesy Google)
Amtrak’s Acela campaign seeks to lure passengers away from airlines by promising food and convenience and, perhaps tellingly, urging riders to consider “taking off your shoes.”
Texas regulators last week identified 13 companies that will build transmission lines to aid wind power production in the state, as reported in Texas newspapers.

In a conference call last week to talk about his company's nearly $6 billion fourth-quarter loss, Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive of Ford Motor Company, was very clear on one point: "It's not our plan at all to access the government's money," he said. In doing so, he continued to draw a line between Ford and its rivals, General Motors and Chrysler, both of which have taken government-backed loans to avoid having to file for bankruptcy protection.
Sven-Goran Eriksson, the embattled coach of Mexico's national team, has announced his roster for the World Cup qualifying match against the United States on Feb. 11 in Columbus, Ohio.
div class="thumbnail">Small boutique investment banks are taking advantage of the carnage that has befallen their larger rivals to pick up top talent.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed a 5-cent fee on new plastic bags at the store register last week. While that figure was a penny lower than the 6 cents per bag proposed in November, another figure tucked on Page 34 of the 59-slide presentation [pdf] was a real eye-opener. The projected revenue for this "user fee" was $84 million -- a sharp increase from the last figure floated, just $16 million. Other estimates suggested the revenue would rise to $144 million by 2011 and $124 million in 2012.
Not buying anything new for a while? Your local repairmen (and repairwomen?) thank you.
Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, T's fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

"It gets busy around here," I said, trying to make small talk while the school crossing guard helped me across Wilshire Blvd. "It's Groundhog day," he said. He might have been talking about the daily ferocity of the Beverly Hills rush hour crowd. Or maybe he knew I was going to the Oscar nominees luncheon --at 8:08 in the morning.
Mark Green informs me that be believes that he was the inventor of the term "lemon socialism", 35 years ago.
Keith has been looking for something fast to make after work that is good in single-digit weather. -- MB

A while back Jon Chait wrote a great piece about the peculiar insistence of many people in DC that Social Security is a looming crisis, despite the fact that the numbers say it ain't so. I can't find a link to the original, but there's a good summary here. The key graf:
Q & A with Stuart Elliott.

A couple of months ago I called for the job of Secretary of Agriculture to be renamed "Secretary of Food," as part of a rethinking about what the Ag Department does. As a former Oregon farm boy, I'm convinced that the department mostly serves to undermine some kinds of family farms and support large commercial farming interests -- while also supporting food that is not nutritious and undermines the health of our children. President Obama chose Tom Vilsack as Secretary of Agriculture, which in my view was regrettable; Vilsack is much better than some others on these issues, but he's not a true reformer.

One commenter asks for links on the blog to the columns. Actually, they are there -- over on the right side of the page. I'll try to remember to do a heads-up on the blog that there's a new one, but they do appear every Monday and Friday, like clockwork.

First of all: my piece was NOT an endorsement of protectionism -- it was an explanation that there is an economic case for it, but also that there is a strong political economy case (which I consider dominant) against acting on that economic case. It was, in short, an attempt to be intellectually honest.
President Obama said Monday that he "absolutely" stands by his nomination of Tom Daschle to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.
It is impossible to raise a child all by yourself. It may or may not take a village, but it certainly takes some help. And to get that help, you have to ask.

Updated | 2:03 p.m. After The Lede's post last Friday about the Turkish prime minister's dramatic exit from the panel discussion on Gaza at the World Economc Forum in Davos, Switzerland, a comment posted by a reader using the name Todd S. pointed out that, officially at least, there would be no way for residents of Turkey to legally see the video clip of the event that was burning up YouTube, since access to the site is blocked in Turkey.

It was a quiet Sunday in the junior hockey ranks, with just four games in the Ontario Hockey Leagues while the rest of the circuits were dark.

Updated, 3:30 p.m. | Phil saw his shadow, but Chuck didn't. Then again, Chuck was himself in the shadow of a building "where the sun couldn't get here, even if it tried," as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pointed out. The encounter did not go well, as Chuck bit the mayor's glove-clad left hand, a topic Mr. Bloomberg addressed later in the day.Chuck, a 2-year-old, 10-pound groundhog formally named Chuck G. Hogg, is part of a tradition at the Staten Island Zoo dating to 1981. (The current Chuck is actually a seventh descendant of the original Chuck. Groundhogs, or woodchucks, typically live seven to eight years.)

TAMPA, Fla. -- Do not expect these Pittsburgh Steelers to repeat as Super Bowl champions next season. Never mind the two titles in four years. Sure, quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, with two rings, is on the right side of 30. Coach Mike Tomlin, 36, the youngest to lift the Lombardi trophy, expects his coaching staff to remain intact next season, but he cautions Steelers nation: "We're not attempting to repeat."

Those of us who would not know how to storyboard a four-second cartoon could not be blamed for assuming that "Wall-E", which was credibly mentioned as a best-picture Oscar candidate and will surely win the animated category, would collect a passel of awards at this past weekend's Annies. But the International Animated Film Society, the bestower of such awards, gave its love (10 awards worth) to "Kung Fu Panda." "Wall-E" got skunked. Hard to fathom.

BAGHDAD -- Two days after the local elections in fourteen Iraqi provinces; life seems to be normal and Iraqis have resumed their daily business with hope and an optimistic vision of their future, with conversations and discussions here and there about the elections and the results.

Economy | Thanks to the Internet, "it's a happier global meltdown, a gentler implosion," an unemployed journalist contends. Can you imagine how boring unemployment would be if we only had daytime television? Now the networking jobless brethren of the Facebook age can grouse together online to their hearts' content when not checking out "a fourth-grader with her giant, award-winning cabbage" on YouTube. [Boston Globe]

Pfizer's $68 billion acquisition of rival pharmaceutical maker Wyeth is drawing criticism over the $22.5 billion in loans Pfizer received from major Wall Street banks to help close the deal.

The Prince Edward Island mussels at Vinegar Hill House are drizzled with garlic-chili oil, roasted in a wood-burning oven and served blistering hot. It's a satisfying dish for dreary days like these.

UPDATE 1:45 p.m: This post has confused some readers, in light of a previous report that said Hulu paid NBC Sports for the 60-second ad. To clarify: As part of NBC's and Fox's original investments in Hulu, Hulu received money from the networks that was specifically earmarked to be spent on those networks as advertising, according to a person familiar with details of the 2007 deal. Hulu paid for its Super Bowl spot with those dollars.

Critics of the recent government bailouts often highlight one risk in particular: By saving a firm's skin after it made poor choices, they say, Washington is just encouraging others to take more risks in the future. This was said to be a major consideration last fall, as the government considered whether or not to rescue Lehman Brothers from collapse.

Privacy | Put private DNA labs right up there with computer hackers and identity thieves on the list of threats to your privacy, an article says. "Abandoned DNA" -- cellular material left behind on used napkins, hairbrushes, etc. -- is "a gold mine for information prospectors looking for clues to our health or ancestry" (or who's the real daddy of that baby). There are few laws on the books to stop these people. [Los Angeles Times]

A correspondent raises an important point: there's widespread public confusion between the fiscal stimulus plan -- which should, on its face, be very popular -- and the bank bailouts, which are deeply (and understandably) unpopular. Spending on infrastructure commands broad support; rescuing bankers from the consequences of their own folly, broad revulsion.

As Wal-Mart undergoes a changing of the guard, with a new chief executive in office since Sunday, the company says it has improved fuelfleet efficiency by more than 25 percent since 2005.

As California goes, so goes the nation. That's the expectation of the state's energy commission, which this summer is expected to adopt a ruling that would mandate that all TVs sold in the state meet power consumption requirements, beginning in 2011.

For 30 cents a song, iTunes users can now upgrade their tunes, one at a time, to a format that will allow them to copy the music free of burn limitations and digital rights management (D.R.M.) restrictions.

Tom Daschle, the nominee to become Secretary of Health and Human Services, has released a letter to the leaders of the Senate Finance Committee discussing briefly the three tax-related issues that have held up his nomination. He reiterates that he is "deeply embarrassed" by the problems and that his mistakes were unintentional.
Vizio made a name for itself by selling plasma and LCD TVs at bargain basement prices in big box stores like Costco.
The average car owner is at the mercy of the average car repairman, who is, on the average, merciless.

A new and improved JPEG image format originally created by Microsoft looks like it finally may be available. The Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG) voted to send the JPEG XR format to "final phases of standardization." The JPEG committee expects the standard to be published later this year.

Question: what happens if you lose vast amounts of other people's money? Answer: you get a big gift from the federal government - but the president says some very harsh things about you before forking over the cash.
The clash over how to deal with the economy preoccupies the Senate today while Tom Daschle fights for his Cabinet slot and Eric Holder heads for confirmation as attorney general.
Images from the annual Academy Award nominees luncheon.

Investors who bought products sold by Banco Santander's Optimal unit, which invested in Bernard L. Madoff's alleged Ponzi scheme, have asked a judge in the United States to halt the bank's plan to compensate investors with new shares, El Mundo reported, citing a court writ.

After enjoying rich returns in the boom years that preceded the current economic crisis, the private equity industry now needs to focus on some more humble truths, the chief executive of the British Private Equity and Venture Capital Association argues in an opinion piece in The Financial Times.
Despite being a shadow of its former self, Lehman Brothers has become one of the most sought-after employers on The Street these days, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Deephaven Capital Management, the hedge fund that has begun unwinding its operations, wants to spin off it's London-based Deephaven European Event Fund, The Telegraph reported.

A group of disgruntled Bank of America shareholders plans to demand the ouster of the bank's chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, at the firm's upcoming annual meeting, The New York Post reported.

Icap, the British interdealer broker, along with a consortium investment banks are considering an 800 million pound ($1.14 billion) bid for LCH.Clearnet, Europe's largest clearing house, the Observer reported. Such a move would challenge an agreed deal between LCH and a clearing group in the United States>.
ABN Amro, the nationalized Dutch bank, has held discussions with the Royal Bank of Scotland about buying back some of the bank's former business, The Financial Times reported.
Taking its cue from Pfizer's $68 billion deal for Wyeth, Sanofi-Aventis, the French pharmaceuticals company, is reportedly getting ready to do some dealmaking of its own.

Vision Capital, the private equity firm that targets portfolios of unwanted companies, has raised 680 million euros ($865 million) to snap up assets from large corporate groups, financial institutions and other private equity houses struggling to raise cash, The Financial Times reported.
OpenTable, the online restaurant-reservation service, filed to go public Friday. Have they lost marbles?

Michael Queen, a veteran at the British private equity group 3i, will bring an investor's detail-hungry mind-set to bear as he steers it through a turbulent period as its new chief executive, says Reuters.

The last three months of 2008 may be remembered as the quarter when U.S. venture-capital investing fell off a cliff, raising fears the worsening recession will dampen an entrepreneurial sector that's historically helped to regenerate New England business, The Boston Globe's Robert Weisman reported.

Monday. If New York City -- then New Amsterdam -- had not been formally incorporated 356 years ago today, imagine all the things that couldn't have been. No Empire State Building, no Shea Stadium and no Totonno's Pizza. Beyond those, of course, Arthur Wynne could not have published the first American crossword puzzle in The New York World 1913. The bra might never have been patented (that same year by Mary P. Jacob, a New York socialite). There would no Pyrex (Brooklyn, 1915); no concept of a get-away car (first in 1910, by the fleeing gangster Gyp the Blood); no punk rock (Mercer Arts Center, circa 1970); and, of course, no Mr. Potato Head (George Lerner, New York-born, in 1952). Thank the Dutch.Aid for Orphans

Getting between a broker and his bonus is like getting between a schnauzer and his lunch bowl. He may not bite you, but you are going to smell his breath, The New York Times's Alan Feuer and Karen Zraick write.

There seems to be a growing consensus that Washington has two options if it wants to end the credit freeze and restore confidence in our banking system. One is to, in effect, nationalize the major banks, which would be hugely expensive and would undermine our free-market system. The other is the "bad bank" solution, under which the government would print enormous amounts of money to buy all these banks' "toxic" assets and to put them into a huge new financial institution that would operate under federal control and sell them off over time.

Lindsey Vonn received a big confidence boost by sweeping the final two races before the world championships. Vonn completed a highly successful weekend on Sunday in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, mastering a demanding course for her first super-G win in two years after winning the slalom on Friday. Her focus now turns to the worlds, which start Tuesday in Val d’Isère, France, with another super-G. Vonn, the defending World Cup champion, increased her lead over Maria Riesch of Germany to 179 points in this season’s points race.

Alex Ovechkin scored three goals for his seventh career hat trick, and second of the season, to lead Washington over visiting Ottawa, 7-4. Ovechkin scored his goals in the first two periods with Sergei Fedorov assisting on each.

The French skipper Michel Desjoyeaux won his second Vendée Globe solo around-the-world yacht race in record-setting time after more than 80 days battling rough seas and high winds. Desjoyeaux steered his yacht Foncia into port in Les Sables d’Olonne on the west coast of France to finish in 84 days 3 hours 9 minutes 8 seconds. Roland Jourdain of France was in second place, more than 1,000 nautical miles behind, on Veolia Environnement.

A picture caption on Friday with a music review of the Dave Liebman Group, at Birdland, carried an erroneous credit. The picture, of Mr. Liebman, was taken by Willie Davis, not by Josh Haner of The New York Times.

An article on Wednesday about a support group for women dating or married to men in the banking industry misspelled the surname of a prominent Wall Street investor in referring to the effect that significant financial news has on a partner’s mood. The investor is Warren E. Buffett, not Buffet.

A picture caption with an article on Thursday about the uncertain future of the Really Really Free Market, a monthly gathering at St. Mark’s Church in-the-Bowery in the East Village, misstated the year the picture was taken. It was October 2006, not last October.

An article on Friday about Republican senators who are under political pressure to support President Obama’s economic stimulus program misidentified the committee where one of them, Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, voted on Tuesday against the spending portion of the Democratic legislative package. It was the Senate Appropriations Committee, not the Senate Finance Committee.

An article on Tuesday about a survey showing a 23 percent average decline in college endowments misidentified, in some editions, one of two groups that prepared reports. Besides the Commonfund Institute, the data was analyzed by the financial services company TIAA-CREF — not by the National Association of College and University Business Officers, the group for which the report was prepared.

An article last Monday about efforts by the Nevada brothel industry to pay the state a per-transaction tax attributed an erroneous distinction to the state. While Nevada is the only state that licenses prostitutes and allows for legal brothels, it is not the only state where prostitution is legal. Rhode Island has no law expressly forbidding prostitution from taking place indoors. (The state does criminalize the activities of streetwalkers and customers who solicit them from cars.).

RODGERS AND HAMMERSTEIN'S 'ALLEGRO' (Sony Classics) The first complete recording of ''Allegro,'' the unsuccessful 1947 Rodgers and Hammerstein show, fills a gap in the library of Broadway cast recordings. The show follows the life of Joseph Taylor Jr. (Patrick Wilson), a small-town physician from the Middle West who becomes a wealthy Dr. Feelgood in Chicago, hates himself for it and returns home. Touted by some as a forerunner of the kind of concept musical later refined by Stephen Sondheim, ''Allegro'' might be described as a thematic fusion of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town'' (the show has a supernatural element) and the 1981 Sondheim-George Furth musical ''Merrily We Roll Along'' (a successful man becomes disillusioned with the urban high life).

GORDON--Cynthia Hymanson. On January 30, 2009, Cynthia Hymanson Gordon, wife of the late Dr. Jules D. Gordon, ended a life that began in 1917. After a long illness she succumbed and leaves three sons, James, Andrew and Jeffrey; and three grandchildren, Rebecca, Daniel and Gabriel all of whom she loved and valued as distinct individuals. As well, Cynthia was a loyal and kind presence to her many close friends and family members. With them, she took an interest in their lives and found great pleasure in sharing her love of music, the visual arts, literature and her fondness for reflective conversation. In her mid-forties, long after working as a radio actress, she found it especially gratifying to be employed again in the area of communications, as a Wall Street publicist. Cynthia was spirited and witty, always an engaging and intelligent presence. We will miss her. For those so wishing, contributions to the New York Philharmonic would be a fitting tribute. A memorial gathering will be held at 11am on Saturday, February 7, in the Elliot Library of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

VALUING BAD ASSETS As the government prepares a plan to buy or guarantee banks' troubled assets, the biggest problem is how to value them. Getting this right won't be easy, and hundreds of billions of taxpayer dollars are at stake. The governments of the United States, Germany and Britain are all close to adopting ''bad bank'' solutions to the economic crisis. Such measures must be properly structured. Breaking Views. [B2.]

MELINDA DOOLITTLE ''Coming Back to You'' (Hi Fi) Two seasons ago Melinda Doolittle was the fallen heroine on ''American Idol,'' a contender with the pipes and work ethic but not, evidently, the demographic appeal: she was eliminated before the finale, in an outcome that the judge Simon Cowell protested as unfair. (He wasn't alone in this view.) So Ms. Doolittle's first full-length album, here at last, faces outsized expectations right out of the gate.

TWO TONGUES (Vagrant) The alliance of two emo bandleaders and lyricists -- Chris Conley of Saves the Day and one of his admirers, Max Bemis from Say Anything -- brings at least twice the angst to ''Two Tongues,'' the album they made together. Backed by Save the Day's bassist, Dave Soloway, and Say Anything's drummer, Coby Linder, who collaborated on the music, they share a dozen of their own songs about breakups and reconciliations, betrayals and desperate promises, capped with Ween's snapshot of love despite severe misbehavior, ''Even If You Don't.''

DIERKS BENTLEY ''Feel That Fire'' (Capitol Nashville) There's not a single burr to be found anywhere on the voice of Dierks Bentley, the likably tender rising country star. As a result his best songs have all but snubbed complexity: some are slow and earnest (''My Last Name,'' ''Settle for a Slowdown''), and the others are rollicking, amused chronicles of emotional haplessness (''What Was I Thinkin','' ''How Am I Doin' '').

Lukas Foss, a prolific and versatile composer who was also a respected pianist and conductor, died at his home in Manhattan on Sunday. He was 86, and also had a home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. His wife, Cornelia, announced his death. Although he was a German émigré, Mr. Foss was, from the start of his composing career, considered an important voice in the burgeoning world of American composition, along with Aaron Copland, Samuel Barber, Elliott Carter and Leonard Bernstein. And like Bernstein, he enthusiastically championed the works of his colleagues. But where Bernstein, in his compositions, melded jazz and theater music with a lush symphonic neo-Romanticism -- or wrote theater music outright -- Mr. Foss preferred to explore the byways of the avant-garde, focusing at different times on techniques from serialism and electronic music to Minimalism and improvisation. But as he moved from style to style, his voice remained distinctive, partly because he distrusted rules and never fully adhered to those of the approaches he adopted, and partly because a current of mercurial wit ran through his work.

RATNER--Carol. Our beautiful, colorful light, who brightened our lives for well nigh 40 years, has gone dim, after shimmering for many months beyond reasonable expectations solely because of her unquenchable will to attend Bettina's bat mitzvah and super human tender loving care by her family, doctors and nurses. A perfect match to start with, Carol and Lynn were blessed with Jennifer and Ian, each so rare a gem. That magnificent foursome then set about spinning their magnificent cocoon, bringing into its special and distinctive warmth, Gary and Suzy, and then Bettina, Jonathan, William, Charlie, Natalia and Augie. Together they created the winner of the Family Super Bowl. Carol and Lynn's romance did not need castles rising in Spain, just one another holding hands, either walking down a shop-lined street or through a flea market, or watching a movie. Carol--a great friend with a delightful sense of humor, who did nothing with less than a full heart and always with great taste, had a keen eye for beauty and impeccable quality--both in people and in possessions from A-Z, and was the hostess with the mostest. As a daughter to her adored mother Betty, sister to Blanche and Fran, as a wife, mother, grandmother and aunt, Carol, like Abu Ben Adam, led all the rest. Our hearts are very sad--for the Ratner/Tishelman Family and for so many friends, like ourselves, who had the great privilege of having Carol in our lives. Audrey and Harvey

9 P.M. (13, 49) THE POLIO CRUSADE For decades in the early 20th century the polio epidemic terrified Americans and left thousands of children crippled, paralyzed or condemned to living in an iron lung. Then on April 26, 1954, at the Franklin Sherman Elementary School in McLean, Va., 6-year-old Randy Kerr received the world's first polio vaccine, developed a few years earlier by Jonas Salk. Within weeks nearly two million children in 44 states had received the inoculations. Based on David M. Oshinsky's Pulitzer Prize-winning book, ''Polio: An American Story,'' this ''American Experience'' documentary from Sarah Colt chronicles the bitter battle between Salk and his rival, Albert Sabin, that resulted in the eradication of the virus in the United States. At 10, ''Forgotten Ellis Island'' tells the story of the Ellis Island hospital, whose mission included preventing contagious diseases from entering the general population. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY An interview with President Obama; RuPaul is a guest.

CLATWORTHY--William Paul, passed away peacefully at the St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan on January 29, 2009. He is survived by his mother Sarah, father David, stepmother Diane, brother Conrad, sister Darah, sister-in-law Merrie Beth, brother-in-law Timothy, niece Madeleine and nephew Dane. He will be profoundly missed. A Memorial Mass will take place on February 3rd at 10am in the Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to Catholic Charities and the American Red Cross.

ROSENBERG--Murray. 8/1/ 23-2/2/06. ''Ah, but a man's reach should exceed his grasp, or what's a heaven for?''

RUSSO--Richard. Dearest Richie -you have been a part of our lives for over 50 years we will never forget you. You put on smile on our faces. You are forever in our hearts. Our love to Adele, Jeffrey, Julie, Steven, Jamie and Allison. Barbara and Murray
LEDs, Unready For the Spotlight
What keeps a private equity baron up at night?
Investing in financial firms is not for the faint of heart these days. Just ask TPG and its co-investors in Washington Mutual — they lost a bundle when the bank was seized by regulators.

Oliver Gardey of Adams Street Partners told attendees at a panel focused on the telecommunications and media market that limited partners — the pension funds, college endowments and others who invest in buyout funds — make the “biggest mistake” when they try to time the market in private equity.

There was all kinds of agreement Tuesday on several points of interest to private equity: the macroeconomic environment is lousy, it’s too early to call a bottom and no one knows when the good old days of liquidity will be back.

The business of leveraged buyouts may be flat, but the fizzy beverages were flowing late Tuesday afternoon at the Super Return conference here in Berlin. Above, some unidentified participants at the conference relax during a “Champagne round table.” After Tuesday’s gloomy talk, many attendees could probably use a drink.
Christopher O’Brien, head of direct investment, private equity and real estate at Investcorp, gave a fairly gloomy answer Tuesday to a question about where the private equity industry is headed.
If there’s a light at the end of the economic tunnel, Scott Sperling can’t see it yet.
Leon Black, founding partner of Apollo Management, was called the “king of distressed debt” here at the Super Return conference in Berlin.

He raised some questions and talked about trust — and here are some other major points from what was a fairly wide-ranging keynote address by Henry R. Kravis here at the Super Return conference in Berlin.
Trust. With a capital T.

Henry R. Kravis, a founding partner of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, opened up with a well-structured keynote address that tried to draw on the positive. The economy may have gone to pot, and the days of big deals are over for now, but private equity is not dead, he said — “absolutely” not.

Protesters with locust signs and megaphones were conspicuously missing Tuesday morning in front of Berlin’s InterContinental hotel as deal-makers met for the annual Super Return conference. Last year in Munich, Germany’s heart of cozy capitalism, a few had lined up to complain to the buyout bosses about lost jobs and failed, debt-ridden companies.

How much is a Tony Award worth to an artist’s a career? An online auction may soon provide a precise answer to the question. The estate of the costume designer Florence Klotz has placed her Tony Award, received in 1985 for her work on the short-lived Broadway musical “Grind,” for sale on eBay. Describing the award in her eBay listing as “a rare, once in a lifetime, opportunity for the true theater buff,” the estate has set the starting bid for the trophy at $10,000 (with an option for a lucky collector to buy it outright for $20,000); they have also thrown in sketches of the costumes she created for Ben Vereen and Stubby Kaye. “Grind,” a musical set in a 1933 Chicago burlesque house, with a book by Fay Kanin, lyrics by Ellen Fitzhugh and music by Larry Grossman, ran for just over two months at the Mark Hellinger Theater in 1985; in his review of the show, Frank Rich wrote that “when ‘Grind’ grinds to its halt just before intermission, ignorance at this show is bliss.”

Didn’t get enough Bruce Springsteen at the Super Bowl halftime show, when he slid down the television screen and almost into your lap? You’ll have another opportunity to catch him and the E Street Band at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, the four-day music shindig in Manchester, Tenn., which announced its 2009 lineup. Among more than 120 other acts performing at the festival, which this year runs June 11 through 14, are the Beastie Boys, Nine Inch Nails, TV on the Radio and the newly reunited Phish; they’ll also be joined by
At the Carpetbagger, Michael Cieply reports:

The New York Pops has announced the lineup for its 2009-2010 season, the first in which it will be led by its recently appointed music director, Steven Reineke. The five-concert schedule begins Oct. 9 at Stern Auditorium in Carnegie Hall with a tribute to Sammy Davis Jr. and Sam Cooke, performed by Wayne Brady, the comedian and television host. The season also includes a show on Nov. 20 in celebration of the 100th birthday of Johnny Mercer, featuring performances by the singer and pianist Ann Hampton Callaway and the opera singer N’Kenge, and a concert called “The Best of Lerner and Loewe,” featuring Kelli O’Hara, Paulo Szot and the Clurman Singers. More information can be found online at newyorkpops.org.

The Broadway revival of “Guys and Dolls” has delayed the date of its first preview, the show’s publicists said. In a release, they said, the postponement was needed “to allow for an extra day of needed technical rehearsal.” The first preview, originally scheduled for Wednesday, will now take place on Thursday. Ticket holders for Wednesday’s show will be contacted and accommodated for a later performance. The musical, which stars Oliver Platt, Lauren Graham, Craig Bierko and Kate Jennings Grant, is scheduled to open on March 1 at the Nederlander Theater.

The coming 2009-2010 season of Primary Stages, the nonprofit theater company, will feature works by three women playwrights, the company announced. The new season will open on July 28 with “A Lifetime Burning,” a new comedy by Cusi Cram, about a wealthy trust-fund recipient who writes a memoir claiming to come from a less-privileged background; its limited run ends on Sept. 5. That will be followed by the New York premiere of “Night Watcher,” Charlayne Woodard‘s one-woman play about the roles she has played in children’s lives; it runs from Sept. 22 through Oct. 31. The season concludes with Lucinda Coxon’s comedy-drama “Happy Now?”, about intertwining, unsatisfied professional and personal lives, which runs from Jan. 26, 2010, through March 6, 2010. The performances will take place at 59E59 Theaters; more information can be found at primarystages.org.

To help struggling nonprofit arts organizations around the country, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Tuesday announced that it will offer free emergency planning assistance through a Web site, artsincrisis.org.

As personal blogs go, this one is a pretty interesting read: Jane Fonda has begun her first-ever web journal to chronicle her return to Broadway, after a four-and-a-half-decade absence, as the star of Moises Kaufman’s new play, “33 Variations.”

It’s not “Bernie Madoff: The Musical,” but Jean Doumanian Productions, a producer of “August: Osage County” and several Woody Allen films, is developing the non-fiction book “Ponzi’s Scheme” into a musical.

The Metropolitan Opera has announced that Giuseppe Filianoti will sing the role of Edgardo Tuesday night in Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor,” replacing Rolando Villazón. Mr. Villazón is ill, the Met said in a statement, but is still scheduled to sing the role at Saturday’s matinee.

The recession has claimed its first major pop festival: The Langerado Music Festival, in Miami, canceled its seventh annual outing because of “sluggish ticket sales,” the organizers announced on Tuesday. The festival, with Death Cab for Cutie, Snoop Dogg, Ryan Adams, Dashboard Confessional, Girl Talk, Broken Social Scene, Matisyahu and others, had been scheduled for March 6 to 8 at Bicentennial Park. “Unfortunately, during these difficult economic times, and facing a first year in a new venue, it’s become apparent that we cannot execute a production that lives up to the high standards of our past events,” Ethan Schwartz, one of the promoters, said in a statement. While the concert business has remained relatively healthy, many big festivals have begun making concessions to the economy. Coachella and Bonnaroo, two of the biggest events, announced their new lineups recently and will offer layaway plans for tickets.

The Senate has been rushing to adopt the roughly $900 billion economic stimulus package with an eye toward President Obama's goal of finishing the bill by the end of next week. And debate in the Senate, including votes on amendments, is expected to carry through this weekend.

The last night of games in Europe before a weeklong break for international play that includes the Sweden Hockey Games (part of the exceedingly bogus yet popular Euro Hockey Tour) and the infinitely more important qualifying tournament for the last three men's berths at the 2010 Olympics. When domestic play resumes next week, the European regular season will enter the home stretch.
By Aaron E. Hirsh
Paula Gamache is back with a puzzle that worked exactly right for me.

If some of the readers of my last post have their way, suburbia could eventually evolve into something straight out of Cormac McCarthy's post-apocalyptic novel "The Road," where a desolate, polluted land is dotted with abandoned homes and buildings that have been stripped of all valuable parts, and lawlessness (and cannibalism) rules the streets.
“The Exterminators,” which begins Wednesday on A&E, follows the often creepy adventures of the family that operates a real-life pest-control company in Benton, La.

Carlos Beltrán is about to enter his fifth season in New York -- has it been that long already? -- but he just as easily could have been doing so for the Yankees and not for the Mets.

Citigroup is considering backing out of a $400 million marketing deal with the New York Mets, according to The Wall Street Journal. (Citigroup disputes this report, though.) If the beleaguered company does pull out, it would lose the naming rights to the Mets' new stadium.

So far three of President Obama's high-profile nominees have acknowledged that they failed to pay some income taxes they owed, and two have already pulled out of contention as a result. Does this high hit rate in the pool of Obama picks likely mean that tax evasion is widespread?
TPG has ended talks with several investors over the potential sale of a stake in the private equity firm, a person with knowledge of the talks told DealBook on Tuesday.
Wells Fargo mortgage brokers are going to party like it is 2006 -- or maybe they won't.

Notably, he'll be making a late-night appearance on CBS's "The Late Show with David Letterman" (11:35 p.m.). The Los Angeles Times has highlights. He'll also appear on CNN's "Larry King Live" (9 p.m.) and Fox News Channel's "On The Record" (10 p.m.). 2/3, 7:21 p.m.

A three-judge panel considering Norm Coleman's election challenge in Minnesota handed the former Republican senator a partial victory on Tuesday, allowing the inclusion of roughly 4,800 rejected absentee ballots during the recount trial.

Representative Carolyn B. Maloney represents an East Side district that includes two of the biggest federally financed transit projects in the nation: the $16 billion Second Avenue Subway project and the $6.3 billion East Side Access project.

A former investment manager is prepared to tell a House hearing on Wednesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission ignored his repeated warnings about the dealings of the disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff.

In mid-March I will be leading a group of 30 ten year olds to Munich for a week to visit their pen pals. Can you recommend interesting activities and a few day trips? Also, can you recommend night time hot spots for the chaperones, mainly young men and women in their 20s? What weather can we expect?
The octuplets born to an enigmatic California woman have all been alive for one week today, making them the longest surviving set of octuplets known to have been born in the United States.

Valentine's Day vacation packages follow a standard script: a few nights in a far-flung resort, a cozy country inn or a luxurious urban hotel tower; chilled champagne and chocolate-covered strawberries; a couple's spa treatment; and a romantic dinner. And something quirky: a rose-petal bubble bath (as offered at the Garden Gables Inn of Lenox, Mass.), free Twister in your room (at the Gansevoort Hotel in New York), or something called the "Aura Soma Relationship" (at the Enchantment Resort in Sedona, Ariz.).

Under the leadership of Carol Bartz, Yahoo's new chief executive, the company is still trying to forge a new path forward. Meanwhile, a string of former Yahoo executives are landing important jobs at rival companies, in something of a game of musical chairs of the Internet and online advertising industry.
Update | 7:20 p.m. The Times' Ellen Barry and Michael Schwirtz have more on this story from Moscow in this article for Wednesday's newspaper.

For those of you keeping tabs, and unable to watch C-Span, Senate Democrats' first efforts failed in amending the stimulus bill with a bigger infrastructure package to build roads, bridges and water projects.

"Declining ratings at ABC (combined with the economy) have blown a hole in Disney's broadcast television business," Brooks Barnes notes in a report on the company's fiscal first quarter earnings. Income at ABC fell 60 percent, the company said:

Customers at John's Deli on Stillwell Avenue in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, (there is also one in Bay Ridge) had lunch as part of the "Godfather" trilogy played on television. At the Museum of Modern Art, visitors moved between floors as a video by the Swiss artist Pipilotti Rist was being installed in the Marron Atrium on the second floor.
From our colleagues at the Caucus.

Is New York City's health commissioner, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden -- who has achieved something of a national profile pushing antismoking, anti-trans fat, calorie-counting, and most recently, anti-salt agendas -- on the way to bigger things?

Yesterday, Green Inc. wrote that Tim Gregori, the chief executive of the Southern Montana Electric Generation and Transmission Cooperative, had said that his energy cooperative was ending its pursuit of the Highwood coal-fired power plant near Great Falls, Mont., due to an "aura of uncertainty" surrounding the regulation of coal.

As an enthusiastic fan of the emerging fashion week circuit, I was looking forward to Mercedes-Benz Berlin Fashion Week -- it's always interesting to see how different locales attempt to create a sartorial identity. But a funny thing happened on the way to the Bebelplatz, the historic square that houses B.F.W.'s tented venue. After attending 17 days straight of fashion shows, first at Fashion Rio, then at São Paulo Fashion Week and finally at the couture in Paris, I was no longer in the mood to be giving any designer the benefit of the doubt.Holding Berlin Fashion Week to the same standards as the couture shows clearly makes no sense, but the show audiences seemed to be confused, acting as if they were guests at an exclusive soiree in the Paris Ritz. Perhaps they've watched too many syndicated episodes of "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous." Instead of distilling a powerful German aesthetic and developing the public relations and commercial infrastructure necessary for real success, people are more focused on blowing Champagne kisses and indulging their caviar dreams.
A 15-year-old stone house, on the island of Kea, is an hourlong ferry ride from Lavrio, a town on the mainland about 30 minutes from Athens.

Most American airport lounges are about as welcoming as the lobby of a La Quinta Inn. Which is why Lufthansa's new $10 million lounge at Kennedy Airport's Terminal 1 is pretty interesting news. Bringing a taste of its specTACular first-class terminal in Frankfurt stateside, the triple-decker glass-walled space has three buffets, showers, a bar with actual bartenders and wi-fi everywhere. And it's just one in a huge rollout of lounges happening over the next several months from Washington Dulles to Bombay. At a time when most carriers are cutting back, this is also a bit of encouraging news for the dismal business of aviation. (Of course, airlines never mind spending on the premium classes - they know which side their bread is buttered on.) And sure, not a lot of people are flying first right now, but before anyone starts hating on the forward cabins, keep in mind that you can get into the new lounge if you're a Frequent Traveler (35,000 miles a year) on any Star Alliance carrier. And for those of us hopelessly stuck in the back of the plane, Lufthansa is also bringing back on-board broadband Internet access in every class. So, anyone been in any other great airport lounges lately?
While his press secretary fielded volleys of questions about the withdrawal of his health and human services nominee, Tom Daschle, President Barack Obama went to school.
The senior news executive at CNBC said Tuesday that he would leave the job next month, in the midst of what is arguably the biggest story in the business channel's history.
I.B.M. remains intent on producing the biggest and baddest supercomputers on the planet.
UPDATE: The International Herald Tribune has published a report on the hearing today.

Child custody and balance of parenting power post-divorce have been in the news around the world lately. Everywhere it is messy, and everywhere parents seem certain that the other gender is getting the better deal.

Bloomberg cancels 'Night Talk' | "Night Talk," the prime time program on Bloomberg Television, is coming to an end. Mike Schneider, the anchor of the 10 p.m. program, is departing the channel, a spokeswoman confirmed Tuesday. In addition to "Night Talk," which specialized in long-form conversations with newsmakers, Mr. Schneider had hosted the 6 p.m. hour on the business news channel.

For most of the fashion world, couture week offers a relatively relaxed schedule, without all the rushing around of the ready-to-wear shows. (Moreover, each season a master couturier seems to fall to illness, the economy or the well-earned idleness of retirement, leaving only a handful of shows for editors to attend.) But in case you haven't checked the Mode A Paris Web site recently, the Chambre Syndicale de la Haute Couture is veritably bursting at the hand-finished seams with a long list of names you've probably never heard of, unless you happen to be a Saudi princess shopping for your wedding trousseau, or a Parisian grande dame with a taste for old-school sartorial drama.
Despite all the odds, Marcel Heijnen and his girlfriend Dawn, now his wife, found a 19th century shop house they could afford on their first day of looking.
The Times's Motoko Rich recently reported on the boom in self-publishing. In the Boston Globe, Alex Beam blows the lid off BookReview.com and other book reviewers for hire.

Sabine Chalmers, the chief legal officer of Anheuser-Busch InBev, and Frank Aquila, a partner in the mergers and acquisitions group of Sullivan & Crowmell, were InBev's lead internal and external lawyers, respectively, on the company's successful bid to acquire Anheuser-Busch last year. Below, Mr. Aquila and Ms. Chalmers offer their views on what other unsolicited buyers can learn from this takeover battle.

Tom Daschle withdrew his name from consideration to be the Secretary of Health and Human Services earlier today. First takes on the failed nomination began moving over the Internet shortly thereafter.
Hoping to buy a pair of those Sasha and Malia dolls? You're out of luck. And the White House couldn't be happier.

Capping a week of intense recruitment, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's re-election campaign has hired Andrea Batista Schlesinger, the executive director of the Drum Major Institute, a public policy group with deep ties to the civil rights movement.

Politics | Americans say they like to live in diverse communities, but in reality they are increasingly clustering together in "landslide counties" among people of the same political party, a columnist writes. And it appears that behind the geographic separation and political polarization are lifestyle preferences. "The yoga people simply can't stand what the lawn-chemical people represent, and vice versa." [Washington Post]
I was out of town late last week when the Bacon Explosion detonated, but when I got back to the office yesterday the fallout was waiting for me.
From the Department of Irony comes this early campaign ad once televised by Tom Daschle in his 1986 election to the Senate as a Democrat in South Dakota.

The three deadliest buildings in New York for bird collisions in New York City are the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and Bellevue Hospital Center, according to the New York City Audubon Society, which keeps track of the deaths as part of Project Safe Flight in an online database.

Tom Daschle's failure to report income from use of a car and driver provided by a client have brought light upon a disturbing trend. No, not tax evasion. Something worse -- politicians getting into car trouble without being drunk behind the wheel.
Doubledown Media, which chronicled the lavish life of bankers in magazines like Trader Monthly and Dealmaker, has suspended operations, The New York Times's Stephanie Clifford reports.
Frank Bruni reviews the restored Oak Room of the Plaza, while Oliver Schwaner-Albright sorts through the 125-item menu at the Indian restaurant Dhaba.

As I postulated, Dow Chemical's answer on Tuesday to Rohm & Haas's lawsuit was not filled with many surprises. Its response can be characterized as a "global force majeure," "woe is me" or "mercy please" argument.
The preliminary ratings for the Super Bowl were just that -- preliminary.

Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat, promised today to draft cap-and-trade legislation for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in as a little as a few weeks -- and definitely "before the end of the year."
The 100th episode of "House" gave Fox a boost in the ratings on Monday as 14.7 million viewers tuned in to the medical drama at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates.

Updated, 4:12 p.m. | The Oscar Wilde Bookshop in Greenwich Village, which is believed to be the oldest gay and lesbian bookstore in the country, will close on March 29, its owner announced on Tuesday, citing "the current economic crisis." The announcement came nearly six years after the store was about to close, only to be given a last-minute reprieve when a new owner bought it.

Updated, 4 p.m. | It seems as if Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg can't catch a break these days. On Monday, he was bitten by a groundhog at the Staten Island Zoo. On Tuesday, his keynote speech at a business summit (called the Future of New York City) was interrupted by a boisterous and angry group of protesters.Mr. Bloomberg was about five minutes into his remarks when at least 100 people barged into the main ballroom at the Grand Hyatt New York hotel in Midtown, holding signs that read, "Mayor Bloomberg, Talk to All New Yorkers," and chanting, "This is what democracy looks like."
Here is a postscript to our daily Blogtalk feature: We have added some new links to the City Room Blogroll. The listings may be found at the bottom of the column at right on most of our pages.
The Swiss bank UBS offered big bonuses to hire more than 200 brokers in the United States in the fourth quarter as it sought to counter client defections.
A crunchy, garlicky snack that puts the stems of broccoli to good use.
The Wall Street Journal is reporting today that Citigroup is exploring the possibility of backing out of its $400 million deal with the New York Mets to name the new Mets baseball stadium Citi Field.
"Grab on here," Joe Ades instructed me a couple of years ago in front of a small crowd in Union Square, "and pull it toward you."

Judging by the response from some Chinese readers of The Lede, who have posted a number of comments that were highly supportive of China's prime minister, Wen Jiabao -- or "grandpa Wen" as a reader using the screen name Qiu referred to him -- after we reported that a shoe was thrown at him in England on Monday, it is not a surprise to read, on the Web site of The Times of London, that "China's blogs were abuzz" with conversation about the incident.

I needed some watermelon radishes to put out for a little Super Bowl party I was hosting Sunday. A watermelon radish looks like a cross between a turnip and rutabaga. It's kind of ugly on the outside. Inside, the flesh is a sexy, bright fuchsia. Sliced into circles and put on a plate with a good squeeze of lime, they make for a mild, refreshing and completely brainless little party snack.
SanDisk's founder and chief executive, Eli Harari, could be kicking himself for not taking Samsung's $5.85 billion takeover offer last year.
Ed suggests a simple way to collect fat to make burgers juicier. --MB

Of the 13 countries who submitted 11 bids to host the 2018 World Cup, only one has a rock-star head of state, an advantage that Sunil Gulati says will help the United States win the right to host the tournament for a second time.
It was just about a year ago that I attended an extraordinary dinner centered around an unbelievable lineup of well-aged Barolos.

Media | The right-wing commentator Ann Coulter and the late lefty "gonzo" journalist Hunter S. Thompson have a lot in common, an essay argues. But few can appreciate this because their audiences are almost entirely mutually exclusive. "There was a certain high-wire performance-artist ethos to Thompson's outsized persona, just as it often seems that the entire purpose of booking Coulter on TV is the producers' hope that she'll finally utter the outrage that ends her career." More important, the work of both, however derided, is substantive, the writer says -- and funny. [Splice Today]
Bloggers weigh in on the California octuplets.

Tom Daschle withdrew his nomination on Tuesday as President Obama's nominee to lead the Health and Human Services Department, a decision that came one day after Mr. Obama declared that he would stand behind Mr. Daschle as problems over unpaid taxes were scrutinized on Capitol Hill.
Photos from “The Third Story,” the new play by Charles Busch.

Dow Chemical argued Tuesday that it had no legal obligation to carry out its deal to buy Rohm & Haas because current economic conditions had made it impossible to close "without jeopardizing the very existence of both companies."

Updated, 4:29 p.m. | After two deadly crane collapses in 2008 -- one on East 51st Street and one on East 91st Street -- the Buildings Department went through a substantial overhaul. Two crane inspectors, including the chief of the unit, faced criminal charges. The commissioner was ousted. The new commissioner, Robert D. LiMandri [pdf], promised substantial reforms.

In addition to some of the expert round tables set up to brainstorm solutions to the financial crisis, some Web sites are soliciting stimulus ideas more broadly, from academics and nonacademics alike.

It's not been quite a month since Sony, with some heavy-duty fanfare at the Consumer Electronics Show, unwrapped its $900 "Lifestyle" P series Vaio portable. Bulletproof it wasn't, in terms of performance and features, and I carped about its display, but the P held promise.

Nikon today launched eight new Coolpix cameras that include new technologies to make photography easier for the point-and-shoot crowd. Enhancements include increased zooms, faster touch-screen navigation, and new features like motion detection and smart portrait.

In the middle of what may be the worst recession since the Great Depression, at a time when it seems as if every consumer is trying to rein in spending, DirecTV has decided to make its customers spend more.
Ed Witt has left Bloomingdale Road but the restaurant will remain open with a limited menu while Jeremy Wladis, the owner, tries to renegotiate the lease, according to Mr. Wladis's publicist.

Several Blogs have published accounts saying that an Android application called MemoryUp, which is supposed to boost memory, is wiping out personal data from G1 Google phones, spamming people from the phone's contact list and corrupting memory.

The Kings' best defensive effort of the season must have taken place at the N.H.L. office yesterday during the hearing on Denis Gauthier's head shot that left Montreal's Josh Georges with a concussion. Helene Elliott reports in today's L.A. Times that "Jeff Solomon, the Kings' vice president of hockey operations and legal affairs, argued that Gauthier's elbow was down when he hit Gorges and that Gauthier's feet didn't leave the ice until after the hit."
The Bagger discusses the "Slumdog Millionaire" backlash.
Anheuser-Busch InBev is looking to sell its South Korean unit, Oriental Brewery, for as much as $2.5 billion, Bloomberg News reported, citing two unnamed sources.

Eataly, a giant market for artisanal Italian food products that opened in Turin two years ago, is in the final stages of negotiating a lease for a Manhattan location. Originally Eataly was supposed to have opened near Rockefeller Center, but that deal was never completed.

Tough times make for tough fashion choices, but none more difficult than what to wear on the day you get the chop. Sometimes it can be an excuse for a fashion moment - like Marie Antoinette, who famously wore all white to the guillotine. (Contemporaries noted her ramrod bearing and hair turned snowy white from stress, like a stately Carmen del'Orifice on a one-way trip off the end of the catwalk.) Others, like the recently terminated Village Voice fashion writer Lynn Yaeger, feel that they missed their chance to make a sartorial exit statement. "With advanced warning, I could have done an outfit," she told a reporter from the New York Observer after parting from her employer of 30 years. "For me, a shredded Comme des Garçons look or a more sober gothic nun sort of thing would have been more appropriate."

Plantains, a staple of Latino cuisines, are usually bought when they're green, and then, like common bunch bananas, just get riper and sweeter until they rot. Before that happens, they're black: the flesh is soft, delicate and pink-tinged. At this stage, they are sweet enough to make into dessert, though most often they're used to produce one of the easiest and most delicious weeknight side dishes a home cook can have in his or her repertory: plátanos maduros.

Rome's Quadraro isn't exactly a trendy neighborhood, notwithstanding the proximity of the Cinecitta film studios and nostalgic reminiscences of a long-gone Dolce Vita. But Condotto C, a new art space that recently opened in the working class district, has sent its coolness quota soaring.

You've seen it too often on the news - a child is found (sometimes too late) in an abusive home. A baby dies in a hot car. A teen shoots up a school, and it turns out he was ignored or mistreated by his parents. You wonder - didn't anyone notice? And why didn't they say anything?
It was the worst January ever for the stock markets -- but it turned out pretty well for Och-Ziff Capital Management.

Danny Cepero burst on the scene during the 2008 Major League Soccer season when he found himself starting in goal for the New York Red Bulls late in the season. And it was quite a professional debut when the native of Baldwin, N.Y., became the first goalkeeper in league history to score a goal. Cepero went on to backstop the Red Bulls through two rounds of the playoffs before losing to Columbus in M.L.S. Cup '08.

Richard Sandomir reports: "Pittsburgh's 27-23 win over Arizona in the Super Bowl on NBC attracted average viewership of 95.4 million, the second most for the game after last year's 97.5 million for the Giants' upset over New England."

The White House this morning released a letter from 19 governors, including a few Republicans, in support of the stimulus bill now wending its way through debates on the Senate floor. But within a few hours, Republicans on the Senate floor sought to sway votes through complaints that the bill offered far too much spending and not enough tax relief.
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

Depending on whom you talk to, Christopher E. Bangle, head of BMW Group design, is either a forward thinker or a reckless design agitator. BMW announced his resignation on Tuesday, saying that the reason he quit was to pursue other interests in design outside the automotive field.

The "Saturday Night Live" sketches that endorsed Pepsi using the MacGruber character were "the first in a collaboration between PepsiCo and Lorne Michaels," the executive producer of the NBC series, Stuart Elliott reports.

Josh Marshall gives us David Broder talking about stimulus -- which he says failed to achieve the predicted results the first time. It's not clear whether he was referring to the TARP or the early 2008 stimulus package, but either way it's a poor comparison. The TARP isn't stimulus; the early 2008 package was 1/5 the size of the Obama proposal, and contained nothing but tax cuts.

Tony Hayward, BP's chief executive, played down talk of consolidation between Western oil majors Tuesday, as his company announced its first quarterly loss in seven years. But he did say that the crash in oil prices might cause another kind of energy transaction: deals with state-owned oil companies.

CBS enters the 'Arranged Marriage' business | CBS has ordered a series "that puts lovelorn singles into arranged marriages," according to The Hollywood Reporter. Under the working title "Arranged Marriage," four people will have their spouses selected for them by family and friends. "The series follows their marriages." Read more... 2/3, 11:22 a.m.

Speaking of Super Bowl-related economics, on Monday, The Times posted a breakdown of all the TV commercials that ran during the Super Bowl from 1984 to 2009. It shows how many spots each year advertised products like drugs, food or vehicles, as well as what percentage of the commercials featured humor, animals and celebrities. Some of the archived commercials are embedded in the graphic, and there are also some interesting data trends showing which products were promoted when and how -- for example, the percentage of commercials that used humor rose almost continuously, starting with 36 percent in 1984 and ending with 80 percent in 2009.

Yesterday's report on consumer incomes, spending, and saving showed a sharp rise in the personal savings rate; it also showed a decline in nominal personal incomes, the third in a row, reflecting the weakening economy.

Christopher Campbell writes in SpoutBlog that it isn't just "Milk" or "Button" that could interrupt "Slumdog's" walk to the podium. He suggests that "The Reader" actually has a shot, because the Academy is always crushing on director Stephen Daldry and that the power of the Holocaust as a subject never diminishes. He envisions a scenario where the advocates of the other films take each other out in cross-fire and "The Reader," assisted by a "whole hog" Harvey Weinstein, could sneak in. Not feeling it, but worth reading.
The Rangers will retire Adam Graves's No. 9 in a ceremony before Tuesday night's game against Atlanta.

Updated President Obama's choice for the position of chief White House performance officer has withdrawn from consideration for the post, an administration official said Tuesday, after coming forward with concerns about her tax returns.
Beastie Boys, Nine Inch Nails, TV on the Radio and the newly reunited Phish are some of the bands in the 2009 lineup for the four-day music shindig in Manchester, Tenn.
I was sure before the election that people would move away from their old sectarian political loyalties.
Every week, Times editor Dana Jennings writes about coping with the treatment and side effects of prostate cancer.
After Deadline examines questions of grammar, usage and style encountered by writers and editors of The Times.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: Very exciting Super Bowl on Sunday, and they said every seat at Raymond James Stadium was a good seat. Unless, of course, you were sitting behind Aretha Franklin. "Hey, lady, the hat. Take the hat off, lady."
Health news from around the Web.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: Right after Sunday's Super Bowl, President Barack Obama placed a congratulatory phone call to the Steelers from his BlackBerry. Meanwhile, John McCain called the Cardinals from his ham radio.

In this week's issue of The New Yorker, the critic David Denby argues that although this year's nominees have their charms, except for "Milk" they are not the "best picture" type. Is this a weak year for movies as reflected in the five nominees for picture? The Bagger thinks not. The Bagger is (understatement alert) a bit of a homer when it comes to movies - he generally likes what he sees - but he thought it might be useful to put this year's bunch up against those that made the cut in the past few years and see if they suffer by comparison. These comparisons are necessarily rough and highly subjective, but then that's why the overlords of the Interweb invented comments, no?
Sometimes marketing devices work perfectly.

Update | Wednesday, 9:44 a.m. For more interesting details on this story, including word that "Amateur observers have already spotted the bright craft in the night sky," and a more nuanced view on how the launch of a small satellite might relate to Iran's capability to launch weapons, please see the updated version of this article, which appeared in today's print edition of The New York Times, by Nazila Fathi and William Broad. Readers who have been making mental calculations adding news of this advance in the Iranian space program to what's known of Iran's nuclear program, should be aware of this part of the latest report from Ms. Fathi and Mr. Broad:
This morning President Barack Obama is to announce the addition of another Republican to his cabinet: New Hampshire senator Judd Gregg, who is the president's pick for commerce secretary.

The Polanski case gets going again: An appeals court here on Monday rejected Roman Polanski's request that the Los Angeles Superior Court be disqualified from deciding whether his prosecution be dismissed because of alleged wrong-doing in the justice system. In the ruling, division seven of the second appellate district of the court of appeal of the state of California said the superior court is free to consider the dismissal request. Judge Peter Espinoza had planned a hearing for Jan. 21, but the appeals court had stopped it at the last minute. Presumably, Judge Espinoza will set a new date and start to get the matter untangled.
A new trend in energy savings has much in common with the fantasies of political conservatives: shutting down the government (for a day, at least).
In the 10 days since becoming New York State's new junior senator, Kirsten E. Gillibrand has had a sleep-deprived crash course in representing an entire state.

Corey Tropp will not be playing in the United States Hockey League this season. According to a U.S.H.L. release, fears that Tropp would be jeopardizing his N.C.A.A. status led to the decision that Tropp should return to East Lansing, Mich., to continue his studies and serve his suspension for his actions in an on-ice incident in a game last month against Michigan.

Mixpo, an online video advertising company, has raised $4 million to help it do so, in a second round led by Madrona Venture Group.

Politics | Movement conservatism is "quite possibly dead," Sam Tanenhaus, editor of the Times Week in Review, argues in the New Republic. But for the right, that could be a good thing -- the opportunity to embrace the original conservatism of the 18th century philosopher Edmund Burke. "Burke's conservatism was based not on a particular set of ideological principles but rather on distrust of all ideologies." And who today is "more thoroughly steeped in the principles of Burkean conservatism"? Obama. [New Republic]
Tiscali has agreed to sell its international network arm to Italy's BS Private Equity and BS Investimenti, the Italian Internet company announced Tuesday.

Mark Cuban has lined up a roster of Ivy League professors to take his part in his battle against the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has accused the investor of trading on insider information.
Greetings from Berlin, where many of the world's private equity titans -- or, at least, they used to be called titans -- have come together to talk about the many headwinds facing their industry.
Ben Roethlisberger told David Letterman on Monday night that his first thought after releasing the winning touchdown pass in the Super Bowl was that he had just lost the game.

Citigroup plans to start auctioning off its Japanese brokerage unit, Nikko Cordial Securities, as early as this month, and the country's top three banks are expected to place bids in a deal likely to be worth up to $3.4 billion, Reuters reported, citing people with the knowledge of the matter.
As businesses recalibrate their environmental impact, breweries, of all places, seem to be struggling to outdo one another with efforts to turn amber ales green.

History | Lincoln "remains the only U.S. president to have a patent in his name," a Smithsonian magazine retrospective notes. Before becoming President, "Lincoln, who had a long fascination with how things worked, invented a flotation system for lifting riverboats stuck on sandbars." There must be an economic metaphor in there somewhere. [Smithsonian]

SAS, the troubled Scandinavian airline, said Tuesday that it would cut 3,000 jobs and ask shareholders for more cash as it seeks to ride out the global economic crisis, The New York Times's David Jolly reported.

Economy | Don't fixate on past downturns in fighting this one, an article warns. This may be our "first epistemologically driven depression" -- epistemology being the study of the nature and limits of knowledge. "That is, a large role was played by the failure of the private and corporate actors to understand what they were doing." And if they couldn't, how could we expect regulators to be on top of things either? [The American]

Citigroup, under pressure to increase its lending, says it will spend $36.5 billion to issue mortgages, make credit card loans and buy distressed assets in the tight credit markets in the coming months.

Citigroup is exploring the possibility of backing out of a nearly $400 million marketing deal with the New York Mets amid concerns over how lenders are using government bailout money, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.
SanDisk, which on Monday posted a larger-than-expected fourth-quarter loss, said it may seek to raise cash through a dilutive stock sale.
Taking a page out of Citigroup's book, UBS is reportedly mulling a deal to merge its wealth-management business with that of Wachovia.
A big debate has erupted over Wall Street's bonuses and the culture that surrounds them. But amid all the outrage and rhetoric, there could be a valuable lesson that many people are missing.
The doom-laden comparison between London and the capital of Iceland.

New York City Transit is trying to make it easier for subway and bus riders to retrieve lost items, by creating a Web page where they can fill out an online claim form describing their missing property.The descriptions will be compared with a database of items recovered on buses or in the subway system, and riders will be notified, either immediately or by e-mail, if there is a possible match.
Men and women who act as gym weights.
The Swiss bank UBS held talks with Morgan Stanley late last year over the sale of its United States brokerage unit, UBS Financial Services, news reports said, citing unnamed sources.

UBS, which agreed to change its compensation practices when it received a Swiss government bailout last fall, on Thursday confirmed it is slashing bonuses for its investment bank by more than 80 percent.

Morgan Stanley plans to cut about 3 percent to 4 percent of its work force, or up to 1,880 people, as it battles with spiraling costs and slowing business, Reuters reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.
