The last two times Chrysler was sold - to Daimler-Benz in 1998 and to Cerberus Capital Management in 2007 - its new owners promised nothing less than a remarkable renaissance for the smallest of Detroit's Big Three, The New York Times's Bill Vlasic writes.

The Internal Revenue Service, which is participating in a broad federal investigation into UBS and its offshore private banking services, is widening its scrutiny to include ordinary accounts owned by Americans who work overseas, according to a person briefed on the issue, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.

World stocks hit a one-week low and the euro set a two-month trough against the dollar on Monday as nervousness grew about poor economic data and falling corporate profits in a rapidly slowing global economy.

Shaking up the tight world of banking in Kazakhstan, the government announced on Monday that it would take controlling stakes in two private banks as a condition of keeping them from a possible bankruptcy filing, The New York Times's Andrew E. Kramer reports.

Afghanistan | NATO commanders are soliciting proposals to create a virtual version of Afghanistan, to test battle plans and forecast unrest, a blog post says. This "Sim Afghanistan" would complement a strategy of embedding social scientists with combat units in a harsh tribal land that has resisted conquest for centuries. "They are smoking something they shouldn't be," says one skeptical military hand. [Wired]
Spanish portal Kyero.com has come up with an interesting comparison chart of pricing trends in coastal areas, which might help buyers determine the costas offering more "realistic" prices.
My digital camera can take short video clips, but the files are huge. Is there a way to slim these movies down so I can send them around to friends and family by e-mail?

Qassem H.J. is a newspaper cartoonist working in Iraq. He abbreviates his name to protect his identity.

Russians’ complaints about their government increasingly focus on economic problems rather than crime or foreign affairs, according to a poll of 1,600 citizens released Monday by the Moscow-based Levada Center. Twenty-eight percent of respondents said their biggest grievance was that leaders “can’t deal with the economic problems in the country,” and 17 percent faulted the Kremlin for not having a “well-considered plan of action.” Only 4 percent blamed leaders for “not being able to solve problems in the Caucasus,” compared with 18 percent in 2003.

Hamas’s leader-in-exile, Khaled Meshal, spoke Monday at Tehran University, where he thanked Iran for its support during the recent Israeli offensive in Gaza. “I thank Iran for its official, unofficial and public support,” Mr. Meshal said. “You are our partner in this victory.” Iran is a major supporter of Hamas, and its Parliament has pledged to rebuild the Palestinian Parliament building in Gaza.

Schools turned pupils away, civil servants stayed home and banks shut their doors after President Hugo Chávez, taking Venezuela by surprise, declared Monday a national holiday. He announced the holiday on Sunday to commemorate his rise to power 10 years ago and the start of his Bolivarian Revolution. “Be alert, for the sword of Bolívar strides through Latin America,” he said at a ceremony on Monday, at the tomb of the liberation hero Simón Bolívar. .

Palestinian militants fired two mortar shells from southern Gaza at Israel on Monday and Israel carried out an airstrike against what the military said were members of the launching squad. One militant was killed and three were wounded, according to news reports from Gaza. The shelling caused no casualties in Israel. Officials of Hamas are in Cairo talking with Egyptian mediators who are trying to extend a tenuous truce with Israel. Also on Monday, Israeli soldiers in the southern West Bank killed a Palestinian who the military said was armed with an AK-47 assault rifle and opened fire on the soldiers.

President Raúl Castro of Cuba said Monday that the results of his visit to Moscow were “very positive.” It was the first visit to the Russian capital by a Cuban leader since the cold war. Mr. Castro, who won pledges of $354 million in aid, said, “I think we are leaving very satisfied.” He held talks with Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin during his eight-day trip to help revive ties that weakened after the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.

Just two weeks after introducing trillion-dollar notes, the central bank on Monday chopped 12 zeros off the Zimbabwe dollar, which grows more worthless by the hour. New Zimbabwean dollar bills will be equal in value to the old trillion-dollar notes. Six months ago the government dropped 10 zeros from the dollar.

Sudanese forces bombed the outskirts of a rebel-held town in southern Darfur on Monday, forcing 5,000 residents to take refuge around the compound of the joint United Nations-African Union peacekeeping force. Sudan had asked the peacekeepers to leave so that the government forces could retake the town, Muhajeria, but the peacekeepers remained. .

At least 20 people were killed and dozens wounded after a roadside bomb exploded on Monday in Mogadishu, the capital, and African Union forces fired in response, Somali officials said. The blast hit a truck for African Union peacekeepers near one of the union’s bases. Abdifitah Ibrahim Shaweye, deputy mayor of Mogadishu, said the peacekeepers then fired into a crowd of civilians, killing 39. A spokesman for the peacekeepers denied that account, saying the soldiers were responding to small-arms fire after the blast.

Rory McIlroy, a Northern Ireland teenager, jumped to No. 16 in the world rankings after his first tour victory in the Dubai Desert Classic. McIlroy shot a two-under 70 for a one-shot victory over Justin Rose. He is three spots behind Ernie Els in the world rankings. McIlroy, the top amateur at the 2007 British Open at Carnoustie, also tied for fifth in Abu Dhabi two weeks ago, lost a playoff in Hong Kong in November and tied for third at the South African Open in December.

A federal judge in San Francisco said she planned to unseal evidence that Barry Bonds’s lawyers are trying to have excluded from his perjury trial. Bonds’s lawyers filed a motion two weeks ago asking United States District Judge Susan Illston to throw out several pieces of evidence, including drug tests, doping calendars and handwritten notes. As part of that motion, the defense lawyers filed the evidence under seal. Illston said in the filing that members of the news media had asked her to make the documents public and that she would do so on Wednesday if Bonds’s lawyers did not file another motion. A hearing is scheduled for Thursday for Illston to hear arguments about whether the evidence should be admitted at trial.

A former athletic compliance officer who claims Marshall University used him as a scapegoat said he has settled a lawsuit against the university and several officials for an undisclosed amount. The lawsuit filed by David Ridpath was scheduled to go to trial this week before United States District Judge Chuck Chambers in Huntington, W.Va. But lawyers notified the court of the pending settlement.

Michael Phelps does not seem to be in much trouble with his sponsors despite being photographed inhaling from a marijuana pipe. From the apparel company Speedo to the luxury Swiss watchmaker Omega, several sponsors were standing by the 23-year-old Phelps — at least for now — and have accepted his public apology. Other companies, like Visa Inc., Subway and Kellogg Co., were not talking.

This season, The New York Times Magazine worked behind the scenes at the Paris Haute Couture with the photographer Ellen von Unwerth. We traveled from show to show with a mini-studio -- a seamless backdrop and a couple of lights -- to create quick and dirty tableaux vivants amid the chaos of the backstage. Look for von Unwerth's photos in the Sunday Magazine in the weeks to come. In the meantime, here's how it all went down. The three-day week started out at Dior, in a tent pitched in the gardens at the Musée Rodin (where Tom Ford used to stage his collections for Yves Saint Laurent). The collection, we were informed, was inspired in part by Dutch portraiture and also by a visit to the Dior archive where John Galliano had been so struck by the construction of some of the dresses he saw that he decided to "turn them inside out." All was surprisingly calm backstage. As the models had their hair laced into corset-like up dos, the voluminous dresses trickled in from the atelier one by one -- each more enormous and more elaborate than the next. (They are heavy, too. When one poor woman tripped through our makeshift studio, the dress she was carrying landed right on me. I still have a huge yellow bruise.) Pat McGrath's makeup was more subdued this year -- some seasons you can hardly tell one model from the next under all the glitter and false eyelashes -- but as the show was about to begin, calm gave way to chaos. "I'm not Olga, I'm Myf!" a model, apparently named Myf and not Olga, exclaimed after being scolded for not getting into her proper place in the lineup.
“Artifacts” from Leanne Shapton’s novel in the form of an auction catalog, chronicling a failed relationship.

A picture caption with an article on Jan. 17 about Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III, the US Airways pilot who safely landed a jet in the Hudson River, said he was an Air Force Academy cadet at the time the picture was taken. Several readers pointed out that he was wearing an officer’s uniform. According to a spokesman for the academy, Captain Sullenberger was indeed a cadet at the time. However, as was standard practice in the academy in the 1970s, for his official photo, he wore the uniform of the office he was to be promoted to — second lieutenant in the Air Force.
Suspected militants blew up a bridge in Pakistan’s Khyber Pass on Tuesday, cutting the main route for supplies bound for Western forces in Afghanistan.
A San Diego man has been sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for killing the professional surfer Emery Kauanui.
A Cleveland woman found not guilty by reason of insanity in the bathtub drowning deaths of her two young children is being sent to a mental health hospital.
The state’s top judge has temporarily disqualified himself from appeals that involve the Massey Energy Corporation, the coal mining giant.
Brazil is reporting its first monthly trade deficit since 2001 as the global economic crisis cuts exports.
A convicted sex offender has pleaded guilty to raping a 6-year-old boy at a public library last year.
South Korean exports tumbled a record 32.8 percent in January as shipments of products as varied as cars and wireless communication equipment fell, a report said.
Luxury home prices in London fell 3.7 percent in a month as would-be buyers struggled in January to secure mortgages from banks hurt by the financial crisis.
Rio Tinto said it had held talks to sell some assets to Chinalco, its biggest shareholder, reportedly to cut debt by up to $8 billion.
Barclays stock fell in trading in London after Moody’s Investors Service cut the bank’s long-term debt rating by two levels.
Almost half of the world’s lithium, the mineral used in electric-car batteries, is found in Bolivia — a country that may not be willing to surrender it easily.
The earthquake, with a preliminary magnitude of 3.0, struck just after 10:30 p.m.; the epicenter was reported at Victory Gardens.
A protester threw an athletic shoe at the Chinese prime minister, Wen Jiabao, during his speech at Cambridge University’s concert hall on Monday.
Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader who is under house arrest, criticized the United Nations for failing to help achieve political reform in her country.
Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III, who has mostly stayed out of the spotlight since last month’s crash landing, described the experience to a reporter on Saturday.

BOSTON -- An unrelenting attack and a stellar performance from Brad Thiessen in the Northeastern nets turned what had seemed like the tournament's marquee matchup into a 6-1 laugher, as the No. 3 Huskies crushed No. 12 Boston College and reached their first Beanpot final since 2005.
The teachers’ union wants the mayor to only appoint five of the 13 members on the city’s Panel for Educational Policy, which could limit the mayor’s control over policy.

Sales fell 23 percent to $10.9 billion. Read the press release here. Dow has also filed its response; read it here.

Pat Summitt’s 1,000th victory will have to wait at least another game. No. 2 Oklahoma beat 12th-ranked Tennessee, 80-70, for the Sooners’ 15th consecutive win.
Jeff Adrien scored 18 points and Hasheem Thabeet added 14 points, 11 rebounds and 4 blocks for the Huskies (21-1, 10-1 Big East), who rolled to their 10th straight victory.

LaMarcus Aldridge scored 22 points as the visiting Portland Trailblazers won their fifth in a row, 97-89, against the New Orleans Hornets.

Bank bonuses have a deservedly bad name when taxpayers’ dollars are being used to bail out the industry, but bonuses are central to the merit-based capitalist system.

Pittsburgh’s 27-23 win over Arizona in the Super Bowl on NBC attracted average viewership of 95.4 million, the second most for the game after last year’s 97.5 million for the Giants’ upset over New England.
Craig Hartsburg lasted only 48 games as the coach of the unraveling Ottawa Senators. He was fired Monday.

Like rival presidential candidates visiting the same city on the same day, Joe Torre and Brian Cashman will make separate public appearances in the metropolitan area Tuesday, and no doubt each will be asked about a long relationship that now appears strained.
The United States was among 12 candidates on four continents to submit bids to FIFA in the hope of hosting the 2018 or the 2022 World Cup.
Margaret Kirkland, 78, had always kept ahead of her bills with disciplined spending — until fall of 2007, when her heating bill started creeping steadily upward.
Federal health officials needed the Peanut Corporation of America’s permission before announcing a recall of its products, which may have delayed contamination warnings.
The optimistic financiers who give entrepreneurs their first cash infusion are cutting back, threatening the technology economy.
The Rutgers team that Epiphanny Prince helped reach the national championship in her freshman year is losing a lot more games than she is used to.
Monday’s warm weather had meteorologists struggling to explain how, even with the help of sophisticated computer models, their predictions were so wrong.
Australia’s prime minister promised the equivalent of $26 billion in spending that will send the national budget into the red for the first time in nearly a decade.
Iraqis went to the polls for the fourth time, with elections in 14 of the country’s 18 provinces. Three Iraqi bloggers share their impressions of the day.
Adam Graves’ impressive statistics are not the only reason the Rangers decided to retire his jersey along with those of three fellow ’94 teammates.
The Lakers faced the Knicks less whole after learning that Andrew Bynum, their fourth-year center, would miss 8 to 12 weeks.
Kobe Bryant made 19 of 31 field-goal attempts and all 20 of his foul shots for a total of 61 points as he broke scoring records for Madison Square Garden.

An article on Monday about foreign criticism of the United States’ economic stimulus plans misspelled the surname of the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, who commented on the level of global anxiety. He is Richard N. Haass — not Haas.

An article on Monday about efforts to expand Internet availability in rural Africa misspelled the name of a nonprofit organization that supports social development in Africa. It is Acumen Fund, not Funds.
After vowing to usher in a new era of responsibility, President Obama has shown a willingness to compromise between campaign rhetoric and Washington’s realities.
An art review on Friday about Kit Rank’s new paintings, at the McKee Gallery in Manhattan, misstated the gallery’s address. It is 745 Fifth Avenue (at 57th Street).

An illustration last Tuesday with the Personal Health column, about the positive effect that consuming organisms in dirt has on the immune system, misstated the given name of the illustrator. He is Gary Neill, not Greg.
The nominee for secretary of health and human services ought to withdraw his name and let the president choose a less-blemished successor.
On her maiden voyage as senator, Kirsten Gillibrand has an occasional stranger-in-a-strange-land quality.

An article on Thursday about parental resistance to efforts by allies of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to rally support for the renewal of a state law that gives the mayor control of the city’s public schools misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a spokeswoman for the mayor’s supporters and misstated, in some editions, part of the name of the consulting group for which she works. She is Julie Wood, not Woods, and the group is the Global Strategy Group, not Strategies.

An article on Monday about the anticipated broad shift in policies at the Justice Department under the Obama administration referred incorrectly to the status of Ali al-Marri, whose detention in a military brig as an uncharged terrorism suspect is under review. Mr. Marri is a legal resident of the United States, not a citizen.

An article on Monday about the risks involved in determining the value of tainted assets on the books of banks misstated the name of a government agency that issued a report on Friday about the effectiveness of the bank bailout program. It is the Government Accountability Office, not the General Accountability Office.
FRONT PAGE.
James M. Peck, a federal judge overseeing the Lehman bankruptcy, was arrested after his wife complained that he struck her in the face in their Manhattan home.
The sight of fresh tracks in the snow elates me. Perhaps it’s just the reminder that, minus the human footprint, this is still a world of animal trails.
Joe Ades got people’s attention at the Union Square Greenmarket: the British man with expensive suits and a radio announcer’s voice — the man selling the $5 peeler.
Ads designed by health unions and hospitals to frighten citizens don’t help as officials work to make sense of health care spending and try to balance the state budget.
An item in the proposed stimulus package would spend billions to expand broadband Internet service to rural areas.
Financiers have a big incentive to outsmart the financial police. It is called a bonus. How can federal agencies compete?
For the good of the city, Mayor Eddie Perez, who was arrested on bribery and other charges, should step aside while his case unfolds.
Mike Tomlin was confident in victory, humbled but not awed by the magnitude of the moment.
Rich people no longer get to set their own rules. Now they are set by people who live in Ward Three, a section of Northwest Washington, D.C.
An Internal Revenue Service effort to flush out wealthy investors in abusive tax shelters has fallen short, according to a government watchdog report.
Seventy years after Lou Gehrig’s “luckiest man” speech, Major League Baseball will help fight the disease that bears his name.
Tom Daschle said his failure to pay taxes on use of a car was inadvertent, while Senate Democrats said they intended to win his confirmation as secretary of health and human services.
Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of the Fiat Group, is blunt in assessing a prospective alliance with Chrysler.
The commercials that NBC broadcast during the fourth quarter of the Super Bowl fared well in many postgame polls and surveys.
The Democratic-led Assembly passed legislation designed to re-regulate tens of thousands of units that were converted to market rate in recent years.
The trustees of the State University of New York are poised to select Nancy L. Zimpher to be the system’s next chancellor, filling a position vacant for nearly two years.
The oldest sailor in the Vendée Globe, the solo around-the-world sailing race, is focused simply on finishing the course.
We do not seem to learn much from history. Time and again an economic boom has followed a period of sustained infrastructure investment.
The report came days after supporters of the ballot measure to outlaw same-sex marriage lost a suit that sought to prevent the names of donors from being revealed.
Cynthia Manning, 55, has been a life model at the Art Students League of New York, where she poses for painters, sketchers and sculptors.
No one in their right mind would want to have their eyebrows plucked midflight. Except for one passenger.
If the landmark restaurant changes owners when the restaurant’s operating license expires Dec. 31, it may also change names.
An unusual number of journalists started new government jobs in January, stoking the debate over whether President Obama is receiving favorable treatment in the media.
Scientists said that the series of tiny earthquakes, known as swarms, were felt by almost no one and probably not a sign of geological volatility.
An 18-year-old man from Staten Island pleaded guilty to assault as a hate crime after leading a series of assaults against presumed supporters of Barack Obama.

WIDES--Melvin, 89 years. Passed away on February 1, 2009. Adored husband of the late Ruth Wides of Boca Raton for 60 marvelous years. Brother of the late Albert and of Doris Satler (Lenny). Sharp-witted and smartly-dressed, well-travelled and cultured, he owned Wides Motor Sales, a new car dealership for 40 years. Devoted to his family and friends, he inspired admiration in everyone who knew him. Service will be held at Gutterman's of Rockville Centre on Wednesday, February 4, 2009 at noon.

STONE--Robert L.,born in New York City on December 12, 1921 died in Boca Grande, Florida on Wednesday, January 28th of heart failure. He will always be a cherished husband, supportive and loving father, devoted grandfather, brother, uncle, mentor, a member of a wonderful family, and an equally wonderful extended family. He graduated from Deerfield Academy, and left Williams College to serve his country in World War II flying 40 combat missions over the Pacific and earning the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with 8 Oak Leaf Clusters. His career spanned work at Cresap, McCormick, and Paget, ABC, NBC, The Hertz Corporation and Columbia Pictures, and he served on the Board of the John Blair Company. In each of his jobs he made a difference, and he valued every friendship in his life. He treasured his family and his friends, and took special pleasure in Williams College athletics, always wearing his '92 hat, and cheering young players on from the sidelines. He always supported women's sports, most particularly Field Hockey and Lacrosse, and he was an ardent fly fisherman, tennis player and golfer. He loved Williamstown, the place where he chose to retire and live the rest of his life, and was always the happiest when he was there. Throughout his life he encouraged, loved, and mentored young friends and his spirit will continue by gifts in his memory going to The Williamstown Youth Center on Cole Avenue in Williamstown, Massachusetts. A Celebration of his life will be held in Williamstown in the Spring.

SHEMIN--Emanuel ''Manny'', 78, of Greenwich, CT and Boca Raton, FL died of leukemia at Johns Hopkins Hospital on January 28. He died peacefully surrounded by his family. Manny was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Air Force in the Korean War and also served as a Major in the Reserves for 18 years. He received his B.S. from Syracuse University, where he also met wife Rhoda. In 1968, he moved the small Bronx family business begun by his father, to Greenwich, CT, and founded Shemin Nurseries, creating the nation's first ''one stop'' wholesale nursery distribution center, expanding it worldwide to over 30 distribution centers in the U.S. and Holland. Manny remained on its Board of Directors and as special consultant to the president until his death. Manny took a strong interest in encouraging development of Israel's agricultural industry to focus on high-value products competitive on world markets. With partner Dr. Issac Nir, he co-founded Genesis Seeds in the Negev, pioneering one of the largest organic seed producers in the world, literally making the desert bloom. He established an agribusiness course at The Hebrew University in Jerusalem, and in April 2006 was awarded the Certificate of Honor by its Agricultural Science faculty, for long-term contributions to agricultural research, and education of generations of scientists. Manny also served as an advisor to Israel's Ministry of Agriculture, including consulting with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. He also endowed a scholarship fund in Israel to train agriculturalists in the latest business and scientific techniques. Manny served on the Board of Trustees of Syracuse University for 16 years and on its Executive Committee for nine years. He established an entrepreneurship program for veterans at Syracuse's Whitman School of Management. He also served on the Board of Temple Sholom in Greenwich. In Florida, he and Rhoda sponsored annual Shemin Trialogue forums at Florida Atlantic University to foster communication between Christians, Muslims and Jews. He was a Trustee of the Boca Raton Museum of Art. Manny is survived by Rhoda, his wife of 57 years; his four daughters Sara Cass, Suzanne Katz, Grace Goldstein, and Leslie Lester; 10 grandchildren; and sisters Elsie Roth and Ina Bass. Donations in his memory can be made to Johns Hopkins, Kimmel Cancer Center Leukemia Program, Attn: Ellen Stifler, 100 North Charles St., Suite 234, Baltimore, MD 21201

POULOS--Ruth G. November 13, 1913 - January 31, 2009. Widow of John G. Poulos, daughter of Russian immigrants Anna Maslow and Samuel Ageloff and the last of the Ageloff siblings. B.A., NYU and later M.A., Columbia, graduate of the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis. In 1936 and 37 she lived in Mexico City as secretary to Leon Trotsky and to the John Dewey Commission. In her 50s, she became a psychoterapist and maintained a practice into her 80s. She leaves behind her son Eric G., New York and Steven M. and wife Nancy Johnson of El Cerrito, CA; two grandchildren, Carla and Joseph Poulos and nieces and nephews Ann Tufel, Boca Raton; Andrew Ageloff, Freeport, NY; Bette Rosen, Northbrook, IL; Alan Lupka, Florida; Bernard Mohr, New York; Diane Bardos, Potomac, MD; George Laios, Venice, FL and John Christian Poulos. Ruth is also survived by her brother-in-law Peter Karagianis, Laconia, NH. Ruth was predeceased by her siblings Allen Ageloff, Monte Ageloff, Monte Ageloff, Lillian Lupka, Sylvia Mohr and Hilda Mason and nieces Joelle Shankman, Naomi Lupka and Anthi Karagianis Jones. You can visit with the family on Wednesday, 4 February, 7-9pm at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 2nd Avenue, New York, NY 10010, (212)477-6334. Burial will be private. Messages may be sent to er999@aol.com or smpoulos@comcast.net. Contributions may be sent in Ruth's name to VISIONS, 500 Greenwich St., New York 10013.

DUBIN--Dorothy Bernstein. Dotty died peacefully on Sunday, February 1st, after suffering two strokes in close succession. She was beautiful, gracious, loving, charmingly quirky, and caring. She grew up in Portland, Maine and came to New York after graduating from Mt. Holyoke. After her first graduate degree, from Teachers College, she taught school in New York, and New Jersey. Later, because she loved design, she completed a second graduate degree at the Columbia School of Architecture in historic preservation before beginning a long career in real estate brokerage with leading New York firms. Dotty was an ardent Democrat and met her husband, Seth, at the Lexington Democratic Club. They were married in 1961. She was the beloved joy of her husband, her sister Brenda Shapiro of Miami, her children Tom Dubin and Pam Klem, Ellen Dubin and Matt Shapiro, and Andy and Nancy Dubin, and her grandchildren Emma, Harry, Jonah, Shira, Sam, Liron, Noa, Stella, and Ari. Her funeral will be at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd Street, at 9:45am on Wednesday, February 4th. Contributions may be made in her memory to the American Jewish Committee on whose national Board of Governors she served for many years.

Our condolences go to her children Lenora (and Matthew), Jesse, and Kyle (and Tali), and to her grandchildren. GORDON--Cynthia Hymanson. On January 30, 2009, Cynthia Hymanson Gordon, wife of the late Dr. Jules D. Gordon, ended a life that began in 1917. After a long illness she succumbed and leaves three sons, James, Andrew and Jeffrey; and three grandchildren, Rebecca, Daniel and Gabriel all of whom she loved and valued as distinct individuals. As well, Cynthia was a loyal and kind presence to her many close friends and family members. With them, she took an interest in their lives and found great pleasure in sharing her love of music, the visual arts, literature and her fondness for reflective conversation. In her mid-forties, long after working as a radio actress, she found it especially gratifying to be employed again in the area of communications, as a Wall Street publicist. Cynthia was spirited and witty, always an engaging and intelligent presence. We will miss her. For those so wishing, contributions to the New York Philharmonic would be a fitting tribute. A memorial gathering will be held at 11am on Saturday, February 7, in the Elliot Library of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

RUSSO--Richard, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Alpine, NJ passed away January 30, 2009 after a seven year courageous battle with unrelenting prostate cancer. Adored husband of Adele, beloved father of Jeffrey, Julie and Steven, Jamie and Allison, proud poppy of Samantha, Jessica, Lauren, Allie, Lexi, and Zachary, dearest brother of Howard and loving stepson of Pearl. Deeply loved for his kindness, love of family and generosity.

She is survived by brother Raziel Abelson, sister Carmel Friedman, niece Maris Abelson, and nephews Gabe and Ben Abelson. Funeral service Tuesday 2pm at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam.

A creative dispute has compelled William Friedkin to withdraw from his role as the director of an operatic version of ''An Inconvenient Truth'' planned for La Scala, Variety reported. In departing the production, adapted from the environmental documentary featuring former Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Friedkin, the director of ''The Exorcist'' and ''The French Connection,'' cited ''irreconcilable creative differences'' with the poet J. D. McClatchy, who is writing the libretto. But Giorgio Battistelli, the composer of the opera, told the Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera that Mr. Friedkin left ''for personal, not artistic reasons,'' and criticized the director for his use of special effects in the production, saying, ''Opera isn't Hollywood.'' The opera is scheduled to have its premiere at La Scala on May 11, 2011.

DIAMOND--Bruce David, died suddenly in Seattle, Washington on February 1. He was a caring son, and brother to his sister, Diane, and his brothers, Peter and Michael. He was a good and loving person and will be missed. At his request, no services will be held.

GLADSTONE--Bernard, age 87, husband, father, grandfather passed away on January 29, 2009. He worked for the New York Times for almost 30 years as the Home Improvement and then Leisure editor. He was a resident of Sarasota, formerly of Long Island, NY and is survived by his wife, Sandra and daughter, Robin and was predeceased by his first wife, Olga and daughter, Carol Arava.

STONE--Robert L.,born in New York City on December 12, 1921 died in Boca Grande, Florida on Wednesday, January 28th of heart failure. He will always be a cherished husband, supportive and loving father, devoted grandfather, brother, uncle, mentor, a member of a wonderful family, and an equally wonderful extended family. He graduated from Deerfield Academy, and left Williams College to serve his country in World War II flying 40 combat missions over the Pacific and earning the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with 8 Oak Leaf Clusters. His career spanned work at Cresap, McCormick, and Paget, ABC, NBC, The Hertz Corporation and Columbia Pictures, and he served on the Board of the John Blair Company. In each of his jobs he made a difference, and he valued every friendship in his life. He treasured his family and his friends, and took special pleasure in Williams College athletics, always wearing his '92 hat, and cheering young players on from the sidelines. He always supported women's sports, most particularly Field Hockey and Lacrosse, and he was an ardent fly fisherman, tennis player and golfer. He loved Williamstown, the place where he chose to retire and live the rest of his life, and was always the happiest when he was there. Throughout his life he encouraged, loved, and mentored young friends and his spirit will continue by gifts in his memory going to The Williamstown Youth Center on Cole Avenue in Williamstown, Massachusetts. A Celebration of his life will be held in Williamstown in the Spring.

The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Monday evening to confirm Eric H. Holder Jr. as attorney general. The vote was 75 to 21, with only Republicans opposing the nomination. Mr. Holder, who will be the nation's first black attorney general, is expected to be sworn in on Tuesday.

After holding runway shows under a big tent in Bryant Park for 15 years, organizers of New York's Fashion Week are expected to announce on Tuesday that they will move the event to Lincoln Center, beginning in 2010. The twice-annual event, which is estimated to draw more than 100,000 visiting store buyers and fashion editors, has been under increasing pressure to find a new home after complaints from the park management that the invitation-only shows had grown too large and were restricting public access to the park.

DUBIN--Dorothy Bernstein. Dotty died peacefully on Sunday, February 1st, after suffering two strokes in close succession. She was beautiful, gracious, loving, charmingly quirky, and caring. She grew up in Portland, Maine and came to New York after graduating from Mt. Holyoke. After her first graduate degree, from Teachers College, she taught school in New York, and New Jersey. Later, because she loved design, she completed a second graduate degree at the Columbia School of Architecture in historic preservation before beginning a long career in real estate brokerage with leading New York firms. Dotty was an ardent Democrat and met her husband, Seth, at the Lexington Democratic Club. They were married in 1961. She was the beloved joy of her husband, her sister Brenda Shapiro of Miami, her children Tom Dubin and Pam Klem, Ellen Dubin and Matt Shapiro, and Andy and Nancy Dubin, and her grandchildren Emma, Harry, Jonah, Shira, Sam, Liron, Noa, Stella, and Ari. Her funeral will be at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd Street, at 9:45am on Wednesday, February 4th. Contributions may be made in her memory to the American Jewish Committee on whose national Board of Governors she served for many years.

DAVIDOW--Sanford L. Beloved husband; cherished father, grandfather and uncle; dear friend and confidante, died on Saturday, January 31, 2009 at the age of 89. Sandy, as he was known to everyone, was born the first of two children to Harry and Rae Davidow on November 11, 1919 in Patchogue, Long Island, NY. In the winter of 1947, he married Saundra Newman of Brooklyn, and they had three loving children, Arline, Michele and Harry. In the forties, Sandy answered his country's call to arms with the Army's 45th Regiment Thunderbirds for four years of honorable service. The war took him through four invasions and across two continents. He pushed off from North Africa, battled his way into Anzio and marched up to Munich, where he was a part of the force that liberated Dachau. Sandy was awarded the Bronze Star and two Purple Hearts for his meritorious service in combat, and he received a rosary from Pope Pius XII as one of the first soldiers to enter Vatican City. He later bestowed this gift to a Catholic army brother, to whom the item held greater meaning. These actions came to define Sandy's character for friends and family. Following the war, Sandy went to St. John's Law School on the G.I. Bill and became a juris doctor in Suffolk County. Subsequently, he joined his father's law firm, founded in 1913, and it was known thereafter as Davidow & Davidow. Later in life, Sandy traveled the world, exploring far-off cultures, making new friends and connecting with distant family. He and his wife also took a winter residence in Palm Beach, FL and shared decades of fond memories with the friends they made there. When Sandy wasn't in Florida, he was at his Manhattan residence with his wife and family, enjoying the cultural offerings of Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall and the city's fine art museums. Sanford L. Davidow was among the last members of the Greatest Generation. He will be missed by all. Services will be held at noon on Tuesday February 3 at Temple Beth- El, 45 Oak St., in Patchogue, NY (631-475-1882) and will be followed by internment at Wellwood Cemetery on Wellwood Ave. in Pinelawn, NY (718-920-0500). Shiva will be observed at the Davidow residence at 44 W. 62nd St. in Manhattan from Tuesday February 3 until Thursday February 5 from 6pm-8:30pm each day and on Friday February 6 from 3pm-5:30pm.

When Laura P. Russell took a snapshot of her parents, Gene and Cindy, kissing in front of Rodin’s sculpture “Eternal Spring” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art one Saturday night, she had no idea that the image, which she later posted on the photo-sharing Web site Flickr.com, would end up on the side of a New York City bus and a billboard on Times Square some 3,000 miles from her home in San Francisco. But starting Friday, that image, along with about a dozen others taken at the museum and posted on Flickr, will be the centerpiece of a new marketing campaign. Each one carries the tag line “It’s Time We Met,” and will emphasize the museum’s collections and programs. “In the 19th century people would make a sketch in the galleries,” said Thomas P. Campbell, director of the Met. “Now they take pictures and upload them.”

Members of the Russian National Ballet Theater were assaulted at a Minnesota hotel by a local resident while in Minneapolis to perform “Sleeping Beauty,” The Star Tribune reported. When a group of about 20 people, including dancers from the ballet troupe, returned to their hotel in downtown Minneapolis on Sunday morning, they were attacked by a man who was punching and slapping people. The 28-year-old man, whose name was not given, made remarks to the dancers that “led them to believe he was upset because they were speaking Russian and not English,” said Sgt. William Palmer, a police spokesman, according to The Star Tribune. Sgt. Palmer added that the man “made some racially based remarks” when he hit a black security guard. None of the dancers sought medical treatment; the incident is being investigated as a bias-related fourth-degree assault.

Oscars officials, take note – here’s one way to make an awards show more inclusive: the board of governors for the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences will increase the number of nominees permitted in 10 major categories for the primetime Emmy Awards, the board announced. The academy will choose six nominees each in the categories of outstanding comedy and drama programs, lead actor and actress in a comedy and drama series, and supporting actor and actress in a comedy and drama series; traditionally, five nominees were named in each group. The governors also voted to streamline the nomination process, phasing out the blue-ribbon committees that weighed in on nominees in the performance and series categories. Emmy nominees for the 2008-09 season will be announced on July 16.

After performing as the halftime entertainment at the Super Bowl, Bruce Springsteen is No. 1 on the Billboard chart. His new album, “Working on a Dream” (Columbia), sold 224,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping Taylor Swift after her run of seven consecutive weeks in the top spot. Ms. Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) was a distant second, with 55,000 sales. The “2009 Grammy Nominees” (Rhino) compilation moved 33,000 to open at No. 6, and Franz Ferdinand’s new album, “Tonight: Franz Ferdinand” (Domino/Epic) reached No. 9 with 31,000. The remainder of this week’s Top 5 is a slightly shuffled version of last week’s. Beyoncé’s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) fell one spot to No. 3, Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) dropped one to No. 4, and Kanye West’s “808s & Heartbreak” (Def Jam) fell one to No. 5.

With several Broadway musicals and plays struggling to fill seats in the dead of this recessionary winter, one popular guessing game among producers and press agents is how much life is left in the longest-running play now along the street, “August: Osage County.”

A part of Universal Studios that was damaged when an all-too-real blaze swept through the Southern California backlot will reopen this summer, the studio said in a news release. In the early morning of June 1, a fire at the studio in Los Angeles burned through four acres of the 230-acre lot, destroying a video library and the King Kong attraction on the studio tour. Street scenes used in films and television shows were also damaged, including a New York streetscape seen on “Seinfeld” and the courthouse square from the “Back to the Future” movies. Universal said that many of those locations would reopen along with new sets like a gas station and a London street.

Goodbye, Elton John, though we never knew you at all: the pop pianist will blow out the candle on his long-running Las Vegas show, “The Red Piano,” The Associated Press reported. In traditionally unsubtle Vegas style, “The Red Piano” mixed Mr. John’s performances of his most popular songs, including “Candle in the Wind” and “Rocket Man,” with lavish sets and short films created by the photographer and director David LaChapelle. The show made its debut in February 2004 at the Colosseum Theater at Caesars Palace, where it was originally booked for 75 performances but repeatedly extended. The final performance of “The Red Piano,” scheduled for April 22, will be its 241st. The theater, originally built for Celine Dion, continues to hold shows starring Cher and Bette Midler; no replacement for Mr. John’s show was announced.

It was announced on Tuesday that Christopher E. Bangle, who has headed BMW design for 16 years, would leave his post. He supervised design for BMW, Mini and Rolls-Royce, and administered Designworks, BMW's studio, known for shaping everything from yachts to coffee makers. Mr. Bangle's approach to design also helped make BMW an aesthetically progressive company, one that became known for hiring the architect Zaha Hadid to design a factory in Leipzig, Germany, and the Danish conceptual artist Olafur Eliasson to create an art car, coated with ice.

I am refinancing my house in Putnam County. Yesterday an appraiser hired by the bank visited my house. In the course of conversation, I learned from her that nearly all of the appraisals she and her company have done in recent weeks have been for refinancings and that there have been almost no appraisals associated with purchases. If this is the case, and the volume of home sales is very low, on what basis are houses being appraised?

For years my son suffered with migraines. He came to know the warning signs, and if intervention was swift - two Tylenol, two Advil, taken at once ASAP - he could sometimes avoid the more powerful, sleep-inducing prescription drugs and the three-day-long headache that was his particular MO. (Everyone's headaches, as I have learned firsthand, are different, so please talk to a doctor rather than treating yours based on what worked for my boy.)

Finance | Despite outrage over its bailout status, Citi might actually be smart to pay $400 million to put its name on the Mets' stadium, a columnist says. As a consumer business, Citi needs a high profile and a long-term strategy to survive. The naming deal is high-profile and long-term too. And, if paid for in installments as inflation rises, it may be a bargain. [Slate]

"It's really just one story about how to make it as an artist," explains Chiara Clemente of her new film, "Our City Dreams," which opens today at Film Forum. And although she follows the careers of five different female artists, their stories are strikingly similar, most significantly in that they all moved to New York City to pursue their passion for art. Focusing on several generations of artists -- from Nancy Spero, who arrived here from Europe during the turbulent '60s, to Swoon, a Daytona Beach street artist who came to study at Pratt University in 1998 -- Clemente, an occasional contributor to T Magazine, tells their rich stories as well as that of the city's. Whether it's Marina Abramovic (who came by way of Yugoslavia and Amsterdam) performing in the Guggenheim's iconic rotunda or Swoon tagging the subway walls with her signature works, the city is both a muse and a canvas. Watch an exclusive clip above.

Today we are finally hearing from Harry Markopolos, the man who repeatedly attempted to inform the Securities and Exchange Commission of the Bernie Madoff fraud. Mr. Markopolos is appearing before the House Financial Services Committee, and his testimony highlights the commission's failure to heed his warnings.

This is a post to briefly take account of some new developments in stories we discussed on Tuesday, but first a word about how this blog relates to the rest of the Times Web site. Since news articles on NYTimes.com are now updated throughout the day (and night), as breaking news events unfold, and as our correspondents have a chance to report on them in greater and greater detail, it is a good idea, in general, for readers interested in the subjects we cover here on The Lede to check back during the day (and night), and read the news articles by our colleagues we link to, for new information we might not always be able to flag.

I have long enjoyed stir-fried tofu creations like ma-po tofu, a classic dish from Sichuan. But I found making them difficult -- tofu is as delicate as cream cheese and no easier to sauté. Unless you pour half an inch or so of oil in the skillet or wok, the tofu sticks and falls apart. After a little further thought, I figured out that these dishes are not correctly described as stir-fries; they are really simmered dishes, with the tofu introduced at the last minute, after just enough liquid has been added to keep the dish moist and the tofu from sticking.

After surveying 220 adults in the United Kingdom who were tending to relatives with dementia, British researchers recently concluded that elder abuse should be viewed as a "spectrum of behaviors rather than an all-or-nothing phenomenon." Among other things, their findings expose an old myth - that abuse of elders happens at the hands of paid caregivers, rarely family members.

Over at the Film Experience, Nathaniel R. has all due regard for the president and everything, but he sort of lost it when both Entertainment Weekly and Vanity Fair traded out the movie stars on their Oscar covers for some guy who lives at 1600 Pennsylvania. Last Friday, Haaretz broke the news that for the last four years, the Israeli government has been compiling a database on Jewish settlements on the West Bank. The paper reports that the information - known as the Spiegel report, after the name of the Israeli general who led the effort - was gathered to enable the government "to contend with legal actions brought by Palestinian residents, human rights organizations and leftist movements challenging the legality of construction in the settlements and the use of private lands to establish or expand them."

Cinematical has watched all the frantic to-and-fro-ing on the part of the Oscar planners and suggests that they calm down and "embrace the length" of the annual rump-tester. While the producers and speech makers might be willing to do so, it's doubtful that the audience wants to do any more length embracing. Peter Martin says that with a little pregame work and a great half-time show, folks might decide to make that second bowl of guacamole and stick around for the better end. His suggestion for half-time entertainment? Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, our colleagues here at the House of Many Fallen Trees. The Bagger knows that Ms. Dargis has a long-time allergy to television, but he would kill, just kill, to see her diagramming the proceedings on a telestrator.

Tuesday was a relatively quiet night for junior hockey, with a handful of games in the Western Hockey League, one game and two suspensions in the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League, and another day of waiting before all-star games in the Ontario Hockey League and United States Hockey League.

This morning I woke up around 4:30 and switched on the tube and saw that "Designing Woman," the MGM-Helen Rose fashion spectacular, was playing on TCM. I felt for a second that I was watching the Dior show all over again. So many bateau-necklines and puffed sleeves Lauren Bacall was in the role of the chic designer; Gregory Peck was her sports-writer husband, and Vincent Minnelli directed. Rose conceived the idea of a film about a sparkling New York designer, partly as a vehicle for Grace Kelly, but Kelly got married and Bacall got the role and ran with it. As tailored a personality as she is, Bacall could always pull off the big romantic blouse with full sleeves that element of surprise and pure fashion madness.
Participants in the zany Idiotarod -- like the Iditarod, but where the carts are pulled by goofy humans -- slash and burn through the city, in costume.

Youth may be fleeting, but Urban Outfitters is intent on keeping its customers. Long a teenage and college wallet mainstay, Urban Outfitters has been keeping up with the H&M's, Targets and Uniqlos with a series of innovative collaborations, Steven Alan, Grey Ant, Paul & Joe and Neal Sperling among them. The latest is with the artist-musician-designer Kim Gordon, best known as a member of Sonic Youth, and her friends Melinda Wansbrough (a Mayle and Sari Gueron alum) and Jeffrey Monteiro (formerly at Derek Lam). Called Mirror/Dash, it hits stores Feb. 16. The Moment caught up with Kim Gordon between rehearsal sessions in Berlin.

Sasha Stone, sort of a North Star for Oscar bloggers at Awards Daily, is working on her picks. The Bagger would make big-time fun of her - Ms. Stone tends to lead with her heart when it comes to picks - but the thought of actually setting his own picks in stone gives him a kind of typing Tourette's, so we'll keep the snark to a minimum. She picks "Slumdog Millionaire" for the big prize, natch, saying it "has thing in the bag." For best actor, she likes both Sean Penn and Mickey Rourke, but says any of the others (Frank Langella, Richard Jenkins and Brad Pitt) could sneak in. Best actress is still balanced between Kate Winslet and Meryl Streep. She puts her nickel on Viola Davis in supporting female, but says that Heath Ledger is not a lock for best supporting (!?!?!??!):

Unless you have headphones for your computer at the office, you'll want to wait till you get home before you tune in some of Christian Bale's on-set banter from "Terminator Salvation." What is remarkable about Mr. Bale's serial invective directed at the director of photography for walking through a scene is its ability to carry both whiny menace and remarkable privilege at the same time. This is a man who likes the sound of his own, mostly profane, voice and seems to take pleasure in tearing apart one of his colleagues on the set. (He's also someone who's been on the receiving end of allegations of assault, allegations that he has denied.)

Fact checking is usually a pretty straightforward process, but as I called restaurants over recent days to make sure I'd accurately reported certain of the details in today's story about restaurants reacting to the recession, fact checking was more complicated than usual.

The Bagger was taking a rare F train in from Brooklyn last night. As a PONJ - Person Of New Jersey - he is generally not allowed to go there. But last night, the cool police were on Code Snooze and he snuck over there for a pal's birthday. When it was time to go, he went down to take the train back to Manhattan when he spotted a young man trying to get a new card in time to grab the incoming train. The Bagger was feeling flush with civic spirit - Brooklyn air will do that to you - and swiped the guy through on his card. Turned out the guy knew that the Bagger was far afield from his basement in New Jersey and we fell into conversation about, what else, the movies that are up for the best picture Oscar.

When two guards were accused last month of encouraging inmates in one Rikers Island jail to police themselves, leading to beatings and in one case the killing of an inmate, correction officials called the situation "an aberration" and said they had not seen such a case in other units involving other guards.

By far the most poignant moment of the Adam Graves jersey retirement ceremony on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden was Graves finally letting his emotions go as he watched his No. 9 raised. Poetry | All inaugural poets have succumbed to platitudes, and Elizabeth Alexander was no exception, a critic agrees. Lazard, the independent investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter profit fell about 50 percent as its mainstay businesses of advising on deals and managing money suffered from the market turmoil.

The Obama administration is expected to impose a cap of $500,000 for top executives at companies that receive large amounts of bailout money, the New York Times' Edmund L. Andrews and Vikas Bajaj wrote, citing people familiar with the plan. Executives would also be prohibited from receiving any bonuses above their base pay, except for normal stock dividends.
Edscha, a German auto parts manufacturer owned by Carlyle Group, sought bankruptcy protection this week, causing Carlyle to lose its $180 million investment.

Transportation | Ants "never get stuck in traffic," says an entomologist; look at how opposing streams of ants on a narrow path efficiently alternate their flows. So, scientists are studying the insects to come up with "a system of driverless cars running on ant-traffic algorithms." At which point, presumably, traffic will become a picnic. [Wired Science]

ING Groep plans to raise as much as 2.1 billion Canadian dollars by selling its 70 percent stake in a Canadian insurance unit. Bloomberg reported that shares of ING Canada, the country's largest property and casualty insurer, will be sold at a discount to institutional investors and other buyers in separate transactions.

Baugur has applied for the Icelandic equivalent of administration, The Financial Times reported Wednesday. The investment group has stakes in some of Britain's best-known retail names, and the move cast into doubt the future ownership of such chains as House of Fraser and Hamleys.

Deutsche Bank has recruited a dozen dealmakers from Merrill Lynch, The Daily Deal reported. The group of twelve bankers have gone to Deutche's financial institutions group in the global banking division.

Forget Sturgis, the annual South Dakota bikers' rally. Harley-Davidson riders may want to shift gears and head toward Omaha, Breakingviews says. The maker of Chinese herbal shampoo is planning to raise up to $300 million in an initial public offering in Hong Kong during the first half of this year, according to media reports.

Martin Lipton, founding partner of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and inventor of the "poison pill" takeover defense, gave activist hedge funds a different kind of medicine Tuesday as he lashed out at what he believes is a short-term and potentially short-sighted investment style, The Daily Deal reported.

Health | Could the sensory experience of architecture play a role in healing - affecting psychology and ultimately physiology? People thought so back when modernist sanitoriums were designed with tubercular patients in mind, with flat roofs for sunning and wide verandas. And researchers haven't given up on the idea -- "the megastructure as medical cocoon, architecture designed to stimulate the human nervous system." [Bldg Blog]

Good earnings reports from two pharmaceutical companies and an unexpected bit of positive news from the housing market lifted stock markets higher on Tuesday, though financial companies continued to lag, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.

Wind and solar power have been growing at a blistering pace in recent years, and that growth seemed likely to accelerate under the green-minded Obama administration. But because of the credit crisis and the broader economic downturn, the opposite is happening: installation of wind and solar power is plummeting, according to The New York Times's Kate Galbraith.

I am just beginning to pay attention to the bad comments thrown at Vista. I do not know much about it but last week I bought a new HP 4-in-1 printer for my current PC. I am afraid that it might be incompatible with Vista when the time comes to buy a new computer.

The free-agent slugger Manny Ramírez rejected a third offer from the Los Angeles Dodgers. The Seattle Storm waived Sheryl Swoopes, a three-time W.N.B.A. most valuable player and three-time Olympic gold medalist, a day before her 2009 contract would have become guaranteed. Coach Brian Agler said the weekend move was made to clear space under the $803,000 salary cap. Since having back surgery in October 2007, Swoopes, 37, is averaging less than half her career scoring average of 15.8 points.

Derrick Fujikawa, the father of the teenage professional golfer Tadd Fujikawa, pleaded guilty to two counts of second-degree methamphetamine trafficking in a Honolulu courtroom. He faces at least one year and as many as 10 years for each count.

The United States will play its World Cup qualifier against Trinidad and Tobago in Nashville on April 1. The Americans, trying to qualify for their sixth straight World Cup, open the final round of the North and Central American and Caribbean region on Feb. 11 against Mexico in Columbus, Ohio. They play at El Salvador on March 28. Sites have not been picked for games against Honduras (June 6), El Salvador (Sept. 5) and Costa Rica (Oct. 14).

Thomas Dold of Germany and Suzy Walsham of Singapore repeated as winners of the Empire State Building Run-Up. In his fourth consecutive victory, Dold, 24, finished in 10 minutes 7 seconds. Walsham, 35, a native of Australia, earned her third consecutive victory in 13 minutes 27 seconds.

After a preliminary calculation Monday that the Super Bowl on NBC attracted average viewership of 95.4 million, the second-most ever, Nielsen Media Research on Tuesday changed the estimate of those watching Pittsburgh beat Arizona to 98.7 million, beating last year’s previous high of 97.5 million on Fox.

The Raiders made Tom Cable their official head coach, removing the interim designation from his title more than five weeks after their season ended. Cable went 4-8 after replacing Lane Kiffin with the Raiders (5-11), who have lost at least 11 games in six consecutive years.

Just a few weeks after Google announced that it was terminating its Dodgeball service, which allowed cellphone users to share their current locations with their friends, the company is coming out Wednesday with a new service, Latitude, that, well, lets cellphone users share their locations with their friends.
When the White House scheduled five television interviews, it intended to push forward the economic stimulus bill. It didn't quite work out that way.

An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about “buy American” requirements for government spending, included outdated information about the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. While California officials reported in 2004 that a “buy American” provision would force taxpayers to spend $400 million more for domestic steel for the bridge, the state later restructured the project and was able to use cheaper imported steel.

Sara Holladay leads a dual life blogging as the Fantasy Football Librarian and working as a university librarian in Colorado. She's a devoted fan of the Denver Broncos and the Northwestern Wildcats and has a soft spot for the Redskins as a Washington native.

A subheading on Monday with an article about the government’s efforts to determine the value of tainted assets on the books of banks misstated the risk involved. An unreasonably low price could hurt banks, while an excessively high price could be costly to taxpayers — not the other way around.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Bernard Gladstone, the longtime home repair columnist for The Times, erroneously described the premise of “To Tell the Truth,” the television game show on which he appeared and fooled a panel of celebrities about the nature of his work. The game involved three contestants who would claim to have a specific job or other distinction; only one actually did. It did not involve celebrity panelists’ guessing a contestant’s line of work, the premise of another game show, “What’s My Line?”.

A capsule summary on Saturday for a Business Day article about France’s development of a next-generation nuclear reactor referred incorrectly to evidence that has emerged about the ability of industry and governments to handle the increasingly toxic waste that would result. New reports show that they will be unprepared — not prepared — to deal with the waste.
An article on Tuesday about a newly discovered form of boron misstated the number of pure forms of the element. It is four, including the new one, not three.

To help struggling nonprofit arts organizations around the country, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced on Tuesday that it would offer free emergency planning assistance through a Web site, artsincrisis.org. The program, called Arts in Crisis: A Kennedy Center Initiative, will provide counsel from the Kennedy Center’s president, Michael M. Kaiser, and members of its executive staff. Organizations can seek advice on fund-raising, budgeting, marketing and other areas. Companies that submit online requests for assistance will receive responses through e-mail, phone calls, live Web chats or in-person visits. “Everyone’s in trouble,” Mr. Kaiser said in an interview. “Every day you hear about companies cutting their seasons, closing doors, cutting budgets.” He added, “We’re in a crisis point, and I believe it’s going to get worse.”.

How much is a Tony Award worth to an artist’s career? An online auction may soon provide a precise answer to the question. The estate of the costume designer Florence Klotz has placed her Tony Award, received in 1985 for her work on the short-lived Broadway musical “Grind,” for sale on eBay. Describing the award in the eBay listing as “a rare, once in a lifetime opportunity for the true theater buff,” the estate has set the starting bid at $10,000 (with an option for a lucky collector to buy it outright for $20,000); it has also thrown in sketches of the costumes she created for Ben Vereen and Stubby Kaye. A rule instituted in 1997 requires that Tony recipients first offer their statuettes back to the Tony Awards at a minimal price before they are offered for public sale; Ms. Klotz’s statuette is not covered by this restriction.

President Nicolas Sarkozy of France bestowed the title of knight in the Legion of Honor on J. K. Rowling (above with Mr. Sarkozy) at the Élysée Palace in Paris, The Associated Press reported. ... Randy Gener, the senior editor of American Theater magazine, has won the Nathan Award for Dramatic Criticism for the theater year 2007-8, the award’s committee announced. Endowed by the theater critic George Jean Nathan, the award is determined by a majority vote of the heads of the English departments of Cornell, Princeton and Yale. It comes with a prize of $10,000 and will be presented to Mr. Gener next month. ... The Off Broadway revival of Martin McDonagh’s comedy “The Cripple of Inishmaan” has extended its run by two weeks. The show, a joint production of the Atlantic and Druid Theater Companies, will now play through March 15 at the Linda Gross Theater.

The 2009-10 season of Primary Stages, the nonprofit theater company, will feature works by three female playwrights, the company announced. The new season will open on July 28 with “A Lifetime Burning,” a new comedy by Cusi Cram, about a wealthy trust-fund recipient who writes a memoir claiming that she came from a less privileged background. Its limited run, which ends on Sept. 5, will be followed by the New York premiere of “Night Watcher,” Charlayne Woodard’s one-woman play about the roles she has played in children’s lives, from Sept. 22 through Oct. 31. The season concludes with Lucinda Coxon’s comedy-drama “Happy Now?,” about intertwining, unsatisfied professional and personal lives, which runs from Jan. 26 through March 6, 2010. The performances will take place at 59E59 Theaters; more information can be found at primarystages.org.

The New York Pops has announced the lineup for its 2009-10 season, the first in which it will be led by its recently appointed music director, Steven Reineke. The five-concert schedule begins Oct. 9 at Stern Auditorium in Carnegie Hall with a tribute to Sammy Davis Jr. and Sam Cooke, performed by Wayne Brady, the comedian and television host. The season also includes a show on Nov. 20 in celebration of the 100th birthday of Johnny Mercer, featuring performances by the singer and pianist Ann Hampton Callaway and the opera singer N’Kenge, and a concert called “The Best of Lerner and Loewe,” featuring Kelli O’Hara, Paulo Szot and the Clurman Singers. More information can be found online at newyorkpops.org.

The Broadway revival of “Guys and Dolls” has delayed its first preview, the show’s publicists said. They added that the postponement was needed “to allow for an extra day of needed technical rehearsal.” The first preview, originally scheduled for Wednesday, will now take place on Thursday. Ticket holders for Wednesday’s show will be contacted and accommodated for a later performance. The musical, which stars Oliver Platt, Lauren Graham, Craig Bierko and Kate Jennings Grant, is scheduled to open on March 1 at the Nederlander Theater.

SHEMIN--Emanuel ''Manny'', 78, of Greenwich, CT and Boca Raton, FL died of leukemia at Johns Hopkins Hospital on January 28. He died peacefully surrounded by his family. Manny was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Air Force in the Korean War and also served as a Major in the Reserves for 18 years. He received his B.S. from Syracuse University, where he also met wife Rhoda. In 1968, he moved the small Bronx family business begun by his father, to Greenwich, CT, and founded Shemin Nurseries, creating the nation's first ''one stop'' wholesale nursery distribution center, expanding it worldwide to over 30 distribution centers in the U.S. and Holland. Manny remained on its Board of Directors and as special consultant to the president until his death. Manny took a strong interest in encouraging development of Israel's agricultural industry to focus on high-value products competitive on world markets. With partner Dr. Issac Nir, he co-founded Genesis Seeds in the Negev, pioneering one of the largest organic seed producers in the world, literally making the desert bloom. He established an agribusiness course at The Hebrew University in Jerusalem, and in April 2006 was awarded the Certificate of Honor by its Agricultural Science faculty, for long-term contributions to agricultural research, and education of generations of scientists. Manny also served as an advisor to Israel's Ministry of Agriculture, including consulting with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. He also endowed a scholarship fund in Israel to train agriculturalists in the latest business and scientific techniques. Manny served on the Board of Trustees of Syracuse University for 16 years and on its Executive Committee for nine years. He established an entrepreneurship program for veterans at Syracuse's Whitman School of Management. He also served on the Board of Temple Sholom in Greenwich. In Florida, he and Rhoda sponsored annual Shemin Trialogue forums at Florida Atlantic University to foster communication between Christians, Muslims and Jews. He was a Trustee of the Boca Raton Museum of Art. Manny is survived by Rhoda, his wife of 57 years; his four daughters Sara Cass, Suzanne Katz, Grace Goldstein, and Leslie Lester; 10 grandchildren; and sisters Elsie Roth and Ina Bass. Donations in his memory can be made to Johns Hopkins, Kimmel Cancer Center Leukemia Program, Attn: Ellen Stifler, 100 North Charles St., Suite 234, Baltimore, MD 21201

POULOS--Ruth G. November 13, 1913 - January 31, 2009. Widow of John G. Poulos, daughter of Russian immigrants Anna Maslow and Samuel Ageloff and the last of the Ageloff siblings. B.A., NYU and later M.A., Columbia, graduate of the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis. In 1936 and 37 she lived in Mexico City as secretary to Leon Trotsky and to the John Dewey Commission. In her 50s, she became a psychotherapist and maintained a practice into her 80s. She leaves behind her sons Eric G., New York and Steven M. and wife Nancy Johnson of El Cerrito, CA; two grandchildren, Carla and Joseph Poulos and nieces and nephews Ann Tufel, Boca Raton; Andrew Ageloff, Freeport, NY; Bette Rosen, Northbrook, IL; Alan Lupka, Florida; Bernard Mohr, New York; Diane Bardos, Potomac, MD; George Laios, Venice, FL and John Christian Poulos. Ruth is also survived by her brother-in-law Peter Karagianis, Laconia, NH. Ruth was predeceased by her siblings Allen Ageloff, Monte Ageloff, Lillian Lupka, Sylvia Mohr and Hilda Mason and nieces Joelle Shankman, Naomi Lupka and Anthi Karagianis Jones. You can visit with the family on Wednesday, 4 February, 7-9pm at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 2nd Avenue, New York, NY 10010, (212)477-6334. Burial will be private. Messages may be sent to er999@aol.com or smpoulos@comcast.net. Contributions may be sent in Ruth's name to VISIONS, 500 Greenwich St., New York 10013.

BURNS-->Daniel M. Our extraordinary father, grandfather, great-grandfather, and friend died January 31 at Winthrop Hospital in Mineola, NY, at 90. Youngest son of Isaac and Mary Burns of Brooklyn; devoted husband for 63 years of Adele V. Burns; loving father of nine, grandfather of 19, great-grandfather of four; dedicated parishioner of St. Anne's Church of Garden City and Third Degree Knight of Columbus ("Monsignor John's Knights"). Writer, editor, consummate ad man, Daniel joined the William Esty Advertising Company in 1953 as account executive, becoming Senior Vice President and Director of Promotions; his clients included Colgate, Nabisco, General Mills, Seagram's, Ballantine Ale, Coca-Cola, Nissan, among many others. A graduate of St. Francis College in Brooklyn, he held positions as Chairman of the college's Council of Regents and president of the College Alumni Fund. He served as an infantry intelligence officer in Europe during WWII, saw action as a first lieutenant in the Battle of the Hurtgen Forest. "Pop" leaves behind hundreds who cherished his wisdom, his enthusiasm for hard work, and most of all, his wry and contagious humor. Besides his wife Adele, he is survived by all of his children: Daniel, Jr., of Ann Arbor, Michigan (Smilka Zdravkovska); Eugene Burns of Rhinebeck, NY (Dorothy); Clare Burns of Garden City, NY; Margaret Burns, M.D., of Manhattan; Christopher Burns, M.D., of Lyme, NH (Tien); Adele Schroeter of Brooklyn (Richard); Theresa Burns of South Orange, NJ (Gregory Fagan); Stephen Burns of Charlottesville, VA (Mary); and Barbara Wright of Montclair, NJ (Glenn). Funeral mass to be held Wednesday, Febuary 4, 10am, at St. Anne's Church in Garden City, NY.

The Obama administration is expected to impose a cap of $500,000 on the compensation of top executives at companies that receive large amounts of federal bailout money, according to people familiar with the plan. Under new rules to be announced by the Treasury Department as early as Wednesday, executives would also be prohibited from receiving any bonuses above their base pay, except for normal stock dividends.

HANDELMAN--Walter. The Jay Heritage Center extends its deepest sympathies to the Handelman family at this time. Walter was a beloved member of our board since 1992. He was our legal champion and good humored advisor, lending the gravitas of his voice and stature in the community to our efforts. His advocacy and constancy were integral in securing landmark recognition for John Jay's childhood home in Rye, which he fondly called ''a jewel in the crown of Long Island Sound.'' As a leader in historic preservation in Westchester County and New York State, for our organization and countless others, he was peerless. He leaves us saddened yet enriched for having known him. Suzanne Clary, President Jay Heritage Center 210 Boston Post Road Rye, NY 10580

Back around the time the earth cooled, there was a restaurant, Giordano's, on West 39th Street near the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel. Craig Claiborne gave it three stars in his 1968 ''New York Times Guide to Dining Out in New York.'' Among the specialties was sautéed beef tenderloin, unusual because its sauce depended on white wine, not red. When I asked the chef about it, he said it was lighter that way.

HERSHCOPF--Elaine Yeckes, 80. Adored wife, beloved mother and grandmother. She was an elegant, gracious and caring woman, a generous hostess and superb cook, who devoted herself tirelessly to her family, yet still found time to work as a volunteer for organizations such as Hadassah, the United Nations Hospitality Committee and Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. Known for her great beauty, creativity, and extraordinary sense of style, she brought these skills and a great deal of kindness and compassion to her work with cancer patients in the Look Good Feel Better program at Sloan Kettering. A graduate of Mount Ida College, she attended NYU and the Tobe Coburn School of Fashion. She will be remembered and mourned by her husband of over 58 years, Gerald T. GRIFFIN--Dr. Helen Joanne King, of New York City. Born April 19, 1931, in Brooklyn to Helen and John King. Later moved to Merrick, Long Island. Survived by brother Thomas H. King. Attended St. Agnes School in Rockville Center then studied nursing at The College of Mount St. Vincent. Practiced nursing in Hempstead and San Francisco, then returned to NYC to complete her M.A and Ph.D in nursing at New York University. Member of the NYU Nursing faculty for 40 years, until retirement in 2006. Member Society of Rogerian Scholars and Sigma Theta Tau. Founding faculty member of CUNY's Bronx Community College Nursing Dept, where she met her husband, Gerald Joseph Griffin They built rich personal and professional lives together until Gerry's death in March 1989. They had four daughters, Mary Hope, Jerilyn "Cinder", Maura, and Jennie. Survived by her daughters; sons and daughters-in-law, Clayton Thomason, Erich Miller, and Sarah Trehearn; grandchildren, Helen, Julia, Bennett, Eleanor, Abigail, and Griffin; brother, Tom, his wife Teena; nephews John, Michael, and Paul King; and five greatnieces and nephews. Residents in the Khyber Pass region, a lawless northwestern tribal area straddling Pakistan's border with Afghanistan, crossed a river after Taliban militants blew up a highway bridge on Tuesday. The trucking of supplies for NATO forces in Afghanistan was suspended after the blast. Pakistani officials said teams had been sent to repair the bridge. It was not immediately clear how soon the supply trucks would be able to resume travel through the pass to Afghanistan.

Infatuated husband of the late Judith for 49 years, nurturing sage to David, Dan, and Matthew, blissful grandfather of Helen, Isaac, Nancy, Shea, and Megan, beloved big brother of Alice Model. Born September 8, 1931 to Edward and Blanche, the Eagle Scout graduated from New Rochelle High, Harvard College and Harvard Law, served as Navy Lieutenant on USS Curtiss. Inherited his father's law practice, moving it to White Plains. Passionate community volunteer, serving on a gamut of Scarsdale boards: Appeals, Architectural Review, Ethics, Historical Preservation, Library, Senior Housing. Former Trustee, Mayor, President of Scarsdale Foundation and Town Club, Scarsdale Bowl recipient. Worked for countless charitable, religious, and not-for-profit entities (Lyndhurst, Jay Heritage Center, Boy Scouts of America, Hudson Link, Preservation League, Friends of the Westchester Band, Westchester Reform Temple, Partners for Sacred Places, Education Through Music, Emmanuel Day Care, National Maritime Historical Society, Scarsdale Historical Society, Bronx River Parkway Restoration Conservancy), providing cheerful, thoughtful counsel to all. Randy Gener, the senior editor of American Theater magazine, has won the Nathan Award for Dramatic Criticism for the theater year 2007-8, the award's committee announced.
