STONE--Robert L.,born in New York City on December 12, 1921 died in Boca Grande, Florida on Wednesday, January 28th of heart failure. He will always be a cherished husband, supportive and loving father, devoted grandfather, brother, uncle, mentor, a member of a wonderful family, and an equally wonderful extended family. He graduated from Deerfield Academy, and left Williams College to serve his country in World War II flying 40 combat missions over the Pacific and earning the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with 8 Oak Leaf Clusters. His career spanned work at Cresap, McCormick, and Paget, ABC, NBC, The Hertz Corporation and Columbia Pictures, and he served on the Board of the John Blair Company. In each of his jobs he made a difference, and he valued every friendship in his life. He treasured his family and his friends, and took special pleasure in Williams College athletics, always wearing his '92 hat, and cheering young players on from the sidelines. He always supported women's sports, most particularly Field Hockey and Lacrosse, and he was an ardent fly fisherman, tennis player and golfer. He loved Williamstown, the place where he chose to retire and live the rest of his life, and was always the happiest when he was there. Throughout his life he encouraged, loved, and mentored young friends and his spirit will continue by gifts in his memory going to The Williamstown Youth Center on Cole Avenue in Williamstown, Massachusetts. A Celebration of his life will be held in Williamstown in the Spring.

CLEARY--John P. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's Board of Trustees, faculty and administration mourn the passing of John P. Cleary. John was a cherished friend of CSHL and actively participated in the growth of this institution. Elected a trustee in 1994, he served as president of the CSHL Association from 1995-1997, and was named honorary trustee in 2004. John promoted the research and education mission of the Laboratory, providing excellent judgment and counsel on a range of critical issues. We are thankful for his support of the recent expansion of the Laboratory's research infrastructure and the creation of the Broad Hollow Bioscience Park to facilitate biotechnology ventures on Long Island. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife Rita and their children Mark, Sharon and Jimmy. John will be profoundly missed. Eduardo G. Mestre, Board Chairman Bruce Stillman, President James D. Watson, Chancellor Emeritus W. Dillaway Ayres, Chief Operating Officer

Tom Daschle withdrew his name on Tuesday as President Obama's nominee to lead the Health and Human Services Department, a startling decision that came only hours after the withdrawal of another candidate for a high White House office. Mr. Daschle withdrew a day after Mr. Obama unequivocally declared that he would stand behind him as his problems over income tax arrears were scrutinized on Capitol Hill. The nominee's tax issues had developed into a troublesome distraction for the president, who entered the White House pledging to hold his people to the highest ethical standards.

BRUCE--Gerald H.,91, passed away peacefully February 2 with family at his side in Westchester, New York. He leaves a loving and devoted wife of 61 years Anne, his beloved children Mark, Steven and Gina, their spouses Nancy, Monica and Mike and cherished granddaughters Sharon, Elizabeth, Rebecca and Polly. Jerry, as he was known, graduated from the University of Minnesota and was a decorated World War II and Korean War veteran. A true New Yorker who lived in Boca Raton the past 13 years, he spent his entire career in advertising and communications working for Madison Advertising, Bliss Gruenwald, and Battistone & Bruce, before launching GHB Advertising in 1965, one of the first high technology advertising agencies. During his more than 50-year career he represented Adam Hats, Arrow Shirts, Burberry, Florsheim, Freedom Land Amusement Park, Kinney Rent-A-Car, Litton Industries, London Fog, Panafax, Ricoh, and Sony of America. Jerry was involved in many civic organizations and had a passion for sports, dancing, cooking and writing. A true optimist, he always offered a helping hand to those in need, a warm smile for everyone and humored all with his long tales. He was a frequent lecturer and authored numerous articles and was profiled in "Who's Who in Advertising." Private services are being held and in lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

Kyrgyzstan's president said Tuesday that he would order the closing of a base used by the United States to supply its forces in Afghanistan, a decision that could seriously hamper American efforts there. The president, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, said at a news conference in Moscow that the United States had not paid Kyrgyzstan enough for use of the base in Manas. He also expressed anger over a 2006 case in which an American serviceman killed a Kyrgyz truck driver on the base.

To help struggling nonprofit arts organizations around the country, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced on Tuesday that it would offer free emergency planning assistance through a Web site, artsincrisis.org. The program, called Arts in Crisis: A Kennedy Center Initiative, will provide counsel from the Kennedy Center's president, Michael M. Kaiser, and members of its executive staff. Organizations can seek advice on fund-raising, budgeting, marketing and other areas. Companies that submit online requests for assistance will receive responses through e-mail, phone calls, live Web chats or in-person visits. ''Everyone's in trouble,'' Mr. Kaiser said in an interview. ''Every day you hear about companies cutting their seasons, closing doors, cutting budgets.'' He added, ''We're in a crisis point, and I believe it's going to get worse.''

DAVIDOW--Sanford Leo. Beloved husband; cherished father, grandfather and uncle; dear friend and confidante, died on Saturday, January 31, 2009 at the age of 89. Sandy, as he was known to everyone, was born the first of two children to Harry and Rae Davidow on November 11, 1919 in Patchogue, Long Island, NY. In the winter of 1947, he married Saundra Newman of Brooklyn, and they had three loving children, Arline, Michele and Harry. In the forties, Sandy answered his country's call to arms with the Army's 45th Regiment Thunderbirds for four years of honorable service. The war took him through four invasions and across two continents. He pushed off from North Africa, battled his way into Anzio and marched up to Munich, where he was a part of the force that liberated Dachau. Sandy was awarded the Bronze Star and two Purple Hearts for his meritorious service in combat, and he received a rosary from Pope Pius XII as one of the first soldiers to enter Vatican City. He later bestowed this gift to a Catholic army brother, to whom the item held greater meaning. These actions came to define Sandy's character for friends and family. Following the war, Sandy went to St. John's Law School on the G.I. Bill and became a juris doctor in Suffolk County. Subsequently, he joined his father's law firm, founded in 1913, and it was known thereafter as Davidow & Davidow. Later in life, Sandy traveled the world, exploring far-off cultures, making new friends and connecting with distant family. He and his wife also took a winter residence in Palm Beach, FL and shared decades of fond memories with the friends they made there. When Sandy wasn't in Florida, he was at his Manhattan residence with his wife and family, enjoying the cultural offerings of Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall and the city's fine art museums. Sanford L. Davidow was among the last members of the Greatest Generation. He will be missed by all. Services will be held at noon on Tuesday February 3 at Temple Beth- El, 45 Oak St., in Patchogue, NY (631-475-1882) and will be followed by internment at Wellwood Cemetery on Wellwood Ave. in Pinelawn, NY (718-920-0500). Shiva will be observed at the Davidow residence at 44 W. 62nd St. in Manhattan from Tuesday February 3 until Thursday February 5 from 6pm-8:30pm each day and on Friday February 6 from 3pm-5:30pm.

One of the founders of the New York Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, he remained an active supporter the rest of his life. For many years until his passing, he was a talented investment manager and trusted advisor. He loved travel, golf, a good meal and, mostly, the friends and family with whom he shared those experiences. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, February 4, 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, New York City.

A California state judge denied a request on Thursday by the president of the Screen Actors Guild to block the resumption of contract talks between the union and the major Hollywood studios. The union president, Alan Rosenberg, and three other board members had filed a lawsuit against the union seeking to block the talks and to invalidate the firing last month of the union’s executive director and chief negotiator, Doug Allen, by a majority of its board of directors. A Los Angeles Superior Court judge denied the request, saying the plaintiffs had little probability of success on the merits of their claim. The actors’ union contract expired at the end of June, and no talks have been undertaken since the union ended a federally mediated bargaining session in November.

Days after Lionsgate announced that it had acquired the independent film “Push: Based on the Novel by Sapphire,” the studio is both suing and being sued by the Weinstein Company over the rights to the movie, the Hollywood Reporter said. On Monday, Lionsgate announced that it had purchased “Push,” the Grand Jury Prize-winning film at this year’s Sundance festival, for about $5.5 million; the movie is adapted from a Sapphire novel about an African-American teenager from an abusive family in 1980s Harlem. On Wednesday, Lionsgate filed a suit in Los Angeles County Superior Court which said that the Weinstein Company does not possess “any right, title or interest” in the film; hours later, the Hollywood Reporter said, the Weinstein Company filed its own suit against Lionsgate and the film sales company Cinetic Media, saying it had already struck a deal to purchase “Push.” No release date for “Push” has been announced.

In this week’s Popcast, Ben Sisario previews the Grammy Awards and Jon Pareles explores the self-titled debut from Two Tongues, a collaborative effort from the emo bands Say Anything and Saves the Day.

The image of Barack Obama made ubiquitous by Shepard Fairey‘s “Hope” poster looked especially familiar to The Associated Press, which says the artwork infringes on its copyright to a photograph of the president, The A.P. reported. Mr. Fairey has previously acknowledged that his poster, a mixed-media stenciled collage depicting Mr. Obama on a red, white and blue field, is based on an A.P. photograph taken by Mannie Garcia in April 2006. The A.P. said in a statement that any use of the image requires itspermission, and it is seeking credit and compensation for its use in Mr. Fairey’s works; a lawyer for Mr. Fairey told The A.P. that the artist was protected by fair-use standards. In January, The National Portrait Gallery in Washington added Mr. Fairey’s poster to its collection.

As befits a man who made it (semi-)cool to appreciate horror and science-fiction literature and movies, the memorabilia collection of Forrest J Ackerman will live on long after him, The Associated Press reported. Thousands of items owned by Mr. Ackerman, the pulp magazine editor, literary agent and vocal genre-entertainment advocate who died in December, will be auctioned at a sale planned for the end of April by Profiles in History, a California-based memorabilia company. Among the items up for bids: the ring worn by Bela Lugosi in the 1931 film version of “Dracula” and the costume he sported Ed Wood’s sci-fi train wreck “Plan 9 From Outer Space,” as well as first-edition copies of Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein” and Bram Stoker’s “Dracula,” the latter signed by Stoker, Lugosi and Boris Karloff (who portrayed Frankenstein’s monster and the Mummy).

The Smithsonian Institution said it has appointed Richard Kurin under secretary for history, art, and culture, confirming a report on the Museum Anthropology blog. The appointment was made by G. Wayne Clough, the Smithsonian secretary. Dr. Kurin, who received his Ph.D. in cultural anthropology from the University of Chicago, has been serving as acting under secretary, and was also director of the Smithsonian Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage, where he oversaw its Folklife Festival and Folkways Recordings label, as well as the director of the Smithsonian’s national programs.

New works and classic favorites like “Cinderella” and “The Nutcracker” are among the productions featured in the Joffrey Ballet‘s 2009-2010 season, the Chicago company announced. Its new season begins on Oct. 14, with the Chicago premiere of Lar Lubovitch’s “Othello,” which runs through Oct. 25. Other highlights include Robert Joffrey’s “The Nutcracker,” which will run from Dec. 11 through 27; Frederick Ashton’s “Cinderella,” which will be presented from Feb. 17, 2010, through Feb. 28, 2010; and a mixed repertory program, “Eclectica,” running from April 28, 2010, through May 9, 2010, which will include Gerald Arpino‘s “Reflections” well as the premieres of new works, currently untitled, by the choreographers James Kudelka and Jessica Lang. More information can be found online at joffrey.org.

[UPDATE: 2:50 p.m. Vote taken. Closure voted.] The North Pacific Fishery Management Council today decided to close a vast stretch of American waters to fishing that has never been fished actively. Catholics in Rome and the United States who track movements in the hierarchy say the Vatican is close to announcing a successor to Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the archbishop of New York, who occupies what may be the most high-profile bishop's seat in the American church. Cardinal Egan has rarely used that bully pulpit, focusing more on closing a huge budget deficit and, in the process, closing parishes and schools. His successor is expected to be far more eager to engage the public and the news media.

Despite a report that Bank of America's board is backing the bank's management and its strategy, BofA shares fell below $5 for the first time since 1990 on speculation that spiraling losses at newly acquired Merrill Lynch might lead to government control of the largest United States bank, wiping out shareholders.

If Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation agree to merge, it would become a powerhouse in the music industry and an early test of the Obama administration's views on concentrated corporate power, particularly in an area with potentially stark implications for consumers, The New York Times's Tim Arango writes.

When it comes to Wall Street pay, how much is too little? That's the question Andrew Ross Sorkin tackles in an interview with The New York Times's Backstory. Mr. Sorkin discusses the balancing act that regulators have to achieve to keep executives performing without overcompensating them.
Chrysler apparently has three potential bidders for its Dodge Viper brand, which the struggling automaker put on the block last summer.
A battle between two activist investors over the board of Gaylord Entertainment appears to be in the offing.
To most people, a salary cap of $500,000 would be anything but punishment.
It seems that the private equity executive Dave Krasne is not too keen on President Obama's plan to cap Wall Street's executive pay at $500,000.

In announcing executive pay limits on Wednesday, President Obama is trying to hold the financial industry accountable to taxpayers while aiming to change an entrenched corporate culture that endorses outsize bonuses and perks that often bear little relationship to corporate performance.

Securities regulators could not cool the white-hot Congressional fury on Wednesday over their failure to act on tips that might have exposed the Madoff scandal almost a decade ago, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques writes.
Is EchoStar considering making a run at Sirius XM Satellite Radio?

Warren E. Buffett shored up the weakened world No. 2 insurer Swiss Re with a 3 billion Swiss franc ($2.6 billion) investment on Thursday, as the Swiss group wrote down twice that amount in toxic assets.
Federal officials pushed Bank of America hard to complete its acquisition of Merrill Lynch even as credit losses mounted at the troubled investment bank, The Wall Street Journal reported.

When BlackRock teamed up with the real-estate developer Tishman-Speyer in 2006 to purchase Peter Cooper Village and Stuyvesant Town, the largest apartment complex in New York City, some considered the $5.4 billion price tag to be a bargain. Other real-estate moguls even said that BlackRock got a sweetheart deal because of its relationship with the former owner, MetLife.

Steve Wozniak, the co-founder of Apple, could ignore the call of the motherboard no longer. He is going back to work - this time at Fusion-io, a start-up company that tweaks computers to let them tap vast amounts of storage at very quick rates.

The American International Group 's AIG Investments unit, which managed money for A.I.G.'s own insurance companies and outside investors, took on additional risks in its securities lending business, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing current and former employees.
To the list of things Bernard L. Madoff has been blamed for ruining - retirements, lives, reputations - add another: a clean breakup, The New York Times's John Eligon writes.
The unique characteristics of Maori culture - which may have particular relevance during the economic downturn.
Nickname for South Africa's electronic voter scanners.
Deutsche Bank predicted a bleak future for the global economy and its industry as the onetime engine of its business, debt trading, broke down and the bank plunged to a loss in 2008.

With governments focused on shoring up domestic lending, the world's major financial businesses are pushing to help the flow of financing to subsidiaries in emerging markets like Eastern Europe, The New York Times's Matthew Saltmarsh writes.

Baugur, an Icelandic holding company with stakes in a wide range of British retailers, filed for creditor protection on Wednesday after talks with its biggest lender broke down, The New York Times's Julia Werdigier reported.
The Canadian chip firm Wavesat said it raised 11.7 million Canadian dollars ($9.5 million) in a round of new financing for its business of making chips for 4G cellular phones.

Losses in consumer stocks dragged Wall Street lower on Wednesday, while Bank of America stock fell below $5 a share, signaling more rough months ahead for the country's largest financial institutions.

It must seem like yet another crazy day on Wall Street when an investment bank reports that its quarterly profits fell by half - and its stock jumps 10 percent. But that is what happened to Lazard on Wednesday.

On Wednesday, the price of a ton of carbon dioxide in Europe fell below 10 euros, or a little less than $13 and a record low for the current trading period - before closing the trading day at 10.45 euros.

Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, said Tuesday night that it had reached a settlement with the Ontario Securities Commission after an investigation into backdating of its stock options.
Auto parts suppliers are in discussions with the Treasury Department about ways to address their financial troubles, industry trade groups said Wednesday.

Michael J. Homer, a Silicon Valley executive who played important roles in the development of three waves of technology - the personal computer, the hand-held device and the Internet - died on Sunday in Atherton, Calif. He was 50.

Business | Obama's move to limit executive pay in bailouts could be a corporate game-changer much like Reagan's firing of striking air-traffic controllers in 1981, a columnist says. Just as Reagan's move encouraged companies to follow suit in confronting unions, Obama's move could prompt a wider shift in corporate attitudes toward executive pay. [Business Week]

Somebeachsomewhere — who set an earnings record, equaled the fastest time for a mile and won 14 of 15 races — was named Horse of the Year at harness racing’s Night of Champions awards dinner.

The Olympic champion Michael Phelps said he hoped to learn from the fallout of a photograph that showed him smoking from a marijuana pipe. Phelps, outside the pool where he trains in Baltimore, made his first public comments since the photo surfaced in a British tabloid over the weekend.
Derek Jeter, the Yankees’ captain, said Alex Rodriguez has the support of his teammates and defended his former manager, Joe Torre, for controversial statements in his new book, “The Yankee Years.”.

Lisa Leslie, a three-time W.N.B.A. most valuable player and a four-time Olympic gold medalist, will retire after her 12th season with the Los Angeles Sparks. Leslie, 36, announced her decision while accompanied by her 19-month-old daughter and husband, Michael Lockwood. A cornerstone of the league since its start in 1997, Leslie guided the Sparks to W.N.B.A. championships in 2001 and 2002.

Dre' Kirkpatrick, a top high school defensive back, made it a signing day to remember for his hometown of Gadsden, Ala., as he chose the Alabama Crimson Tide over the Texas Longhorns after months of wavering.
Mr. Kimbro, who shot and killed a suspected police informer in New Haven in 1969, later earned a Harvard degree and became a respected community leader.

An Italian woman who has spent 17 years in a persistent vegetative state was moved this week to a private clinic where she will be allowed to die.
A judge postponed a hearing on the corruption case against Jacob Zuma until several months after he is expected to become the next president.
The United Nations agency that provides assistance to Palestinian refugees said Hamas police confiscated about 3,500 blankets and more than 400 food parcels.
Even in its brutal cold, there’s something comforting in a February that feels like February, a regression toward some semblance of the old normal: meteorological and financial.

Despite Congressional rules, Representative Charles B. Rangel accumulated more than $239,000 in assets that were not disclosed, according to a private government-ethics group.
Leon E. Panetta earned more than $1 million last year serving on corporate boards, consulting and delivering speeches, including some given to imploding banks at the height of the financial crisis.
The Nets won their third straight game by beating up on a bad team that had only eight players in uniform and fans chanting for a former coach.

An Op-Ed article on Wednesday, about the Heimlich maneuver, incorrectly described the technique. The person administering the maneuver pushes under the choking victim’s diaphragm, not above it. The article also misidentified the part of the body food travels through to the stomach. It is the esophagus, not the trachea.

An article on Wednesday about the Walt Disney Company’s quarterly earnings referred incorrectly to its investment in video game development in 2009. Disney plans to increase its investment by — not to — $50 million.

An article on Tuesday about a growing reluctance of angel investors to finance technology start-ups misstated the status of TwoSmartDogs, a company that was unable to raise money for its online hub for adult education classes. While the company’s Web site is not being updated, it is still operating; it has not been shut down.
One last phone call and the words of a stranger prompted Dre’ Kirkpatrick, a top high school defensive back, to say “Roll Tide” on national signing day.

A brief article on Wednesday about the condemnation by the archbishop of Chicago of remarks by a Holocaust-denying English bishop carried an erroneous credit. It was by Religion News Service, not by The Associated Press.

An article on Tuesday about New York’s Groundhog Day ceremony — at which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was bitten by Staten Island Chuck as he tried to coax the groundhog out of his shelter — erroneously included one dignitary among those who attended. Senator Charles E. Schumer was not there.

An article on Friday about an evacuation by the United Nations of wounded civilians who had been trapped between government and rebel forces in Sri Lanka misstated the formal name of the group that confirmed the evacuation. It is the International Committee of the Red Cross, not the International Committee for the Red Cross. The error also appeared in a brief article on Jan. 17 about international laws governing warfare and in an article on April 9, 2008, about an attack by militants on road construction workers in Afghanistan.

A headline on Saturday with an article about a meeting between President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and the editor of Novaya Gazeta, a newspaper that has been sharply critical of the government and recently lost a reporter in what appeared to be a contract killing, misidentified the site of the meeting. The men met in a government building, not at the offices of the newspaper.
Experts from both countries say political leaders recognize that a new international climate treaty is impossible without agreements between the two nations.

A part of Universal Studios in Southern California that was damaged when an all-too-real blaze swept through its back lot will reopen this summer.

After performing at the Super Bowl, above, Bruce Springsteen is No. 1 on the Billboard chart. His new album, “Working on a Dream” (Columbia), sold 224,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping Taylor Swift after her run of seven consecutive weeks in the top spot. Ms. Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) was a distant second, with 55,000 sales. The “2009 Grammy Nominees” (Rhino) compilation moved 33,000 to open at No. 6, and Franz Ferdinand’s new album, “Tonight: Franz Ferdinand” (Domino/Epic), reached No. 9 with 31,000. The remainder of the week’s Top 5 is a slightly shuffled version of last week’s. Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) fell one spot to No. 3, Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) dropped one to No. 4, and Kanye West’s “808s & Heartbreak” (Def Jam) fell one to No. 5.

A judge has set Feb. 17 as the new date for a hearing on Roman Polanski’s efforts to have charges against him dismissed in a longstanding sex case, The Associated Press reported. A state appeals court in Los Angeles on Monday rejected claims by Mr. Polanski’s lawyer that the Los Angeles County Superior Court was biased against his client and could not rule fairly on dismissing charges against the director. Mr. Polanski pleaded guilty in 1978 to having sex with a 13-year-old girl but fled to France before his sentencing. ... Giuseppe Filianoti sang the role of Edgardo at Tuesday night’s performance of Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor” at the Metropolitan Opera, replacing Rolando Villazón. Mr. Villazón, who is ill, the Met said in a statement, will be replaced at Saturday’s matinee by Piotr Beczala. That performance will be broadcast as part of “The Met: Live in HD” series. ... Roy Clark, Barbara Mandrell and the harmonica player Charlie McCoy were named to the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville, Reuters reported. They will be inducted this spring.
In its first Hollywood episode of the season, “American Idol” soared past its competitors on Tuesday night with 26.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

Goodbye, Elton John: the pop pianist, below, will blow out the candle on his long-running Las Vegas show, “The Red Piano,” The Associated Press reported. In traditionally unsubtle Vegas style, “The Red Piano” mixed Mr. John’s performances of his most popular songs, including “Candle in the Wind” and “Rocket Man,” with lavish sets and short films by the photographer and director David LaChapelle. The show made its debut in February 2004 at the Colosseum Theater at Caesars Palace, where it was originally booked for 75 performances but repeatedly extended. The final performance, scheduled for April 22, will be its 241st. The theater, originally built for Celine Dion, continues to hold shows starring Cher and Bette Midler; no replacement for Mr. John’s show was announced.

Members of the Russian National Ballet Theater were assaulted at a hotel by a local resident while in Minneapolis to perform “The Sleeping Beauty,” The Star Tribune reported. When a group of about 20 people, including dancers from the ballet troupe, returned to their downtown hotel on Sunday morning, they were attacked by a man who was punching and slapping people. The 28-year-old man, whose name was not given, made remarks to the dancers that “led them to believe he was upset because they were speaking Russian and not English,” said Sgt. William Palmer, a police spokesman, according to The Star Tribune. Sgt. Palmer added that the man “made some racially based remarks” when he hit a black security guard. None of the dancers sought medical treatment; the incident is being investigated as a bias-related fourth-degree assault.

When Laura P. Russell took a snapshot of her parents, Gene and Cindy Russell, kissing in front of Rodin’s sculpture “Eternal Spring” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art one Saturday night, she had no idea that the image, which she posted on the photo-sharing Web site Flickr.com, would end up on the side of a New York City bus and a billboard in Times Square, some 3,000 miles from her home in San Francisco. But starting Friday that image, along with about a dozen others (like the one above) taken at the museum and posted on Flickr, will be the centerpiece of a new marketing campaign. Each image carries the tag line “It’s Time We Met” and will emphasize the museum’s collections and programs. “In the 19th century people would make a sketch in the galleries,” said Thomas P. Campbell, director of the Met. “Now they take pictures and upload them.”.

The recession has claimed its first major pop festival: the Langerado Music Festival, in Miami, canceled its seventh annual event because of “sluggish ticket sales,” the organizers announced. The festival, which had scheduled Death Cab for Cutie, Snoop Dogg, Ryan Adams, Dashboard Confessional, Girl Talk, Broken Social Scene, Matisyahu and others, had been scheduled for March 6 to 8 at Bicentennial Park. “Unfortunately, during these difficult economic times and facing a first year in a new venue, it’s become apparent that we cannot execute a production that lives up to the high standards of our past events,” Ethan Schwartz, one of the promoters, said in a statement. Other big festivals have begun making concessions to the economy; Coachella and Bonnaroo, two of the biggest, announced their new lineups recently and will offer layaway plans for tickets.

It’s not “Bernie Madoff: The Musical,” but Jean Doumanian Productions, a producer of “August: Osage County” and several Woody Allen films, is developing the nonfiction book “Ponzi’s Scheme” into a musical. Ms. Doumanian said in an interview that her production company had acquired the stage and film rights to the book, written by Mitchell Zuckoff and published in 2005 by Random House. “Ponzi’s Scheme” tells the story of Charles Ponzi, a charismatic charlatan who came to Boston and fleeced investors out of millions of dollars in the early 1900s. Ms. Doumanian said she had begun talks with several book writers and composers — including Marshall Brickman, a book writer for “Jersey Boys” — about joining the project.

The $5.1 billion write-down, its biggest ever, was an admission by its new chief executive of the company’s shrunken value.
In announcing executive pay limits, President Obama is trying to hold the financial industry accountable to taxpayers while aiming to change an entrenched corporate culture.
In the 12 seasons since Shaquille O’Neal left Orlando for the Los Angeles Lakers, only a few superstars have left their teams as free agents.
After global outrage, the church called on a rehabilitated bishop to take back his statements denying the Holocaust.
Wall Street veered into the red as investors cashed their profits from a day earlier and waited for a highly anticipated report on January unemployment.
President Obama hopes to change the shrill tone of Washington by opening his doors to the Republicans.
The U.S. service sector, which represents about 80 percent of the nation’s economic activity, shrank in January, but less severely than expected, a new report shows.
The media company reported a fourth-quarter loss, hurt by a $24.2 billion write-down for its cable, publishing and AOL assets.

NO, they weren't scouring the heavens for vagrant U.F.O.'s. Patrons at the Daryl Roth Theater in Manhattan were experiencing close encounters of a more conventional kind as they bumped in the night, dodging showers of confetti that rained intermittently onto their heads. The crowd, mostly college age, was drawn by the clublike spectacle that is ''Fuerza Bruta'' (''Brute Force''), the long-running show from the Argentine creators of ''De La Guarda.'' On a recent Saturday, the event, which invites a kind of hectic participation, had audience members pogo-ing to a techno beat or staring unabashedly at the demiclad performers splashing overhead.

HANDELMAN-->Walter J.,age 77, died suddenly and peacefully February 2, 2009. Infatuated husband of the late Judith for 49 years, nurturing sage to David, Dan, and Matthew, blissful grandfather of Helen, Isaac, Nancy, Shea, and Megan, beloved big brother of Alice Model. Born September 8, 1931 to Edward and Blanche, the Eagle Scout graduated from New Rochelle High, Harvard College and Harvard Law, served as Navy Lieutenant on USS Curtiss. Inherited his father's law practice, moving it to White Plains. Passionate community volunteer, serving on a gamut of Scarsdale boards: Appeals, Architectural Review, Ethics, Historical Preservation, Library, Senior Housing. Former Trustee, Mayor, President of Scarsdale Foundation and Town Club, Scarsdale Bowl recipient. Worked for countless charitable, religious, and not-for-profit entities (Lyndhurst, Jay Heritage Center, Boy Scouts of America, Hudson Link, Preservation League, Friends of the Westchester Band, Westchester Reform Temple, Partners for Sacred Places, Education Through Music, Emmanuel Day Care, National Maritime Historical Society, Scarsdale Historical Society, Bronx River Parkway Restoration Conservancy), providing cheerful, thoughtful counsel to all. Lifelong swimmer, clarinetist, operagoer, Mets fan. Services Thursday, February 5, 1pm at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale, NY. Shiva at 260 Mamaroneck Rd., Thursday 5-7pm, Friday 11-5, Saturday 6-8pm, and Sunday 2-6pm. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the above causes or your own.

VOGEL-->Irene, 104. Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She, her husband Walter Vogel and their daughter Renate left Germany for NYC in 1937. They founded the Breezy Hill Hotel with two friends. The hotel was a summer idyll for their fellow German Jewish refugees, home to summers of song, laughter and community. She was a wonderful storyteller and her peaceful, optimistic approach to life is a trait we all aspire to. She will be missed and loved always by Renate, son-in-law Stafford, her three grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Funeral Thursday, February 5, 12:45pm, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.
LIEBENTHAL--Lester. Goodbye to our dear friend, may you rest in peace and our sincerest condolences to the Liebenthal Family. Love Marilyn and Alvin Rush

LARSEN--Ingeborg Skrobek "Inge." September 24, 1920 - January 21, 2009. Ingeborg Skrobek Larsen "Inge", 88, of San Jose, California, beloved mother, died on January 21, 2009. Ingeborg died peacefully at Kaiser Santa Clara Hospital after a long illness and was surrounded by family and close friends. Ingeborg was born on September 24, 1920 in Leobschutz, Upper Silesia, Germany to Edith Kornblum and Gunther Skrobek. Ingeborg grew up in Berlin, Germany and graduated from The Reimann Institute in 1938. Ingeborg immigrated to the United States in 1948, continued her education and graduated from New England School of Art in 1951. She had a distinguished and enjoyable career with the Lockheed Missiles & Space where she worked as an Artist/Illustrator from 1978-1989. Ingeborg cherished many long-lasting friendships throughout her career with Lockheed Missiles & Space. Ingeborg was also a member of the Cupertino Fine Arts League for many years. Ingeborg also enjoyed spending time Drawing and Painting, and was well known in the area for her fine art and she enjoyed Traveling. Ingeborg is survived by her loving husband of 50 years years, James (Jim) Larsen, Son, Victor Larsen of Hayden, ID, Son, Chris Larsen of San Francisco, Daughter, Nanette Larsen of San Jose and many other dear friends and family members. Ingeborg was preceded in death by her mother, Edith Skrobek and father, Gunther Skrobek. The family would like to give special thanks to Leticia Victorio and Kaiser Hospital Staff for the extraordinary care given to Ingeborg. Memorial services will be held at St. Francis of Assisi, 5111 San Felipe Road, San Jose on February 7, 2009 at 4:30pm.

WEIN--Herbert. Predeceased by Charlotte, his beloved wife for over 50 years. Uncle to Ingrid, Ron, Robert and Deborah; most valued and lifelong friend to many. Goodbye, Elton John: the pop pianist, below, will blow out the candle on his long-running Las Vegas show, ''The Red Piano,'' The Associated Press reported. In traditionally unsubtle Vegas style, ''The Red Piano'' mixed Mr. John's performances of his most popular songs, including ''Candle in the Wind'' and ''Rocket Man,'' with lavish sets and short films by the photographer and director David LaChapelle. The show made its debut in February 2004 at the Colosseum Theater at Caesars Palace, where it was originally booked for 75 performances but repeatedly extended. The final performance, scheduled for April 22, will be its 241st. The theater, originally built for Celine Dion, continues to hold shows starring Cher and Bette Midler; no replacement for Mr. John's show was announced.

There may be only one thing that the political rivals Marc Ravalomanana and Andry Rajoelina agree on -- and that is that Mr. Rajoelina is no longer the mayor of the capital, Antananarivo. On Wednesday, Mr. Rajoelina appointed someone else to that job, a day after Mr. Ravalomanana, the country's elected president, used an unusual law to fire him as mayor and appoint a caretaker. Mr. Rajoelina felt entitled to appoint his own replacement instead because he has declared himself to be the nation's new leader. Hence, after a month's long political showdown, this island nation has two people claiming to be the president, two others claiming to be the capital's mayor and a population that is divided, confused and anxious.

The recession has claimed its first major pop festival: the Langerado Music Festival, in Miami, canceled its seventh annual event because of ''sluggish ticket sales,'' the organizers announced. The festival, which had scheduled Death Cab for Cutie, Snoop Dogg, Ryan Adams, Dashboard Confessional, Girl Talk, Broken Social Scene, Matisyahu and others, had been scheduled for March 6 to 8 at Bicentennial Park. ''Unfortunately, during these difficult economic times and facing a first year in a new venue, it's become apparent that we cannot execute a production that lives up to the high standards of our past events,'' Ethan Schwartz, one of the promoters, said in a statement. Other big festivals have begun making concessions to the economy; Coachella and Bonnaroo, two of the biggest, announced their new lineups recently and will offer layaway plans for tickets.
ROSS--Alan Gordon. Dear Alan, so many unanswered questions. We think about them every day. We miss you. Love, Mom, Dad & Chris

A judge has set Feb. 17 as the new date for a hearing on Roman Polanski's efforts to have charges against him dismissed in a longstanding sex case, The Associated Press reported. A state appeals court in Los Angeles on Monday rejected claims by Mr. Polanski's lawyer that the Los Angeles County Superior Court was biased against his client and could not rule fairly on dismissing charges against the director. Mr. Polanski pleaded guilty in 1978 to having sex with a 13-year-old girl but fled to France before his sentencing. ... Giuseppe Filianoti sang the role of Edgardo at Tuesday night's performance of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' at the Metropolitan Opera, replacing Rolando Villazón. Mr. Villazón, who is ill, the Met said in a statement, will be replaced at Saturday's matinee by Piotr Beczala. That performance will be broadcast as part of ''The Met: Live in HD'' series. ... Roy Clark, Barbara Mandrell and the harmonica player Charlie McCoy were named to the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville, Reuters reported. They will be inducted this spring.

In announcing executive pay limits on Wednesday, President Obama is trying to hold the financial industry accountable to taxpayers while aiming to change an entrenched corporate culture that endorses outsize bonuses and perks that often bear little relationship to corporate performance. Mr. Obama also needs to deflect a growing populist outrage over sky-high pay among the banks and other companies now on the public dole. His announcement comes just days before the administration is expected to unveil a new strategy -- and possibly request more money from Congress -- to guarantee or buy outright hundreds of billions of dollars in bad assets held by banks.

TUCKER-->Richard F.,of Fairfield, CT, and Nantucket, MA. Cornell University mourns the loss of a dedicated alumnus and loyal friend, Richard F. "Dick" Tucker. Dick's devotion and service to Cornell University will provide enduring inspiration to his peers on the Board of Trustees, his fellow alumni, and to the entire Cornell community. We express our sincere condolences to his wife, Genevieve M. "Gen" Tucker, and to their children, Jocelyn R. Tucker Charney and Jeffrey P. Tucker. Peter C. After performing at the Super Bowl, above, Bruce Springsteen is No. 1 on the Billboard chart. His new album, ''Working on a Dream'' (Columbia), sold 224,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping Taylor Swift after her run of seven consecutive weeks in the top spot. Ms. Swift's ''Fearless'' (Big Machine) was a distant second, with 55,000 sales. The ''2009 Grammy Nominees'' (Rhino) compilation moved 33,000 to open at No. 6, and Franz Ferdinand's new album, ''Tonight: Franz Ferdinand'' (Domino/Epic), reached No. 9 with 31,000. The remainder of the week's Top 5 is a slightly shuffled version of last week's. Beyoncé's ''I Am ... Sasha Fierce'' (Columbia) fell one spot to No. 3, Nickelback's ''Dark Horse'' (Roadrunner) dropped one to No. 4, and Kanye West's ''808s & Heartbreak'' (Def Jam) fell one to No. 5.

SHAR--Rose Podolsky (almost 93 years young), died February 3, peacefully in her sleep with her loving sons and daughters-in-law by her side. Predeceased by her beloved husband Hillard (Hilly) on February 3, 1979. Rose leaves her sister Alice (and her children and grandchildren), her sons, Albert (Cynthia), Larry (Tracy) and five grandchildren, Jonathan (Marla), Daniel (Wendy), Brad (Angela), Tracy and Hilary, and six great-grandchildren, Noah, Jessica, Emma, Brady, Benjamin and Olivia. Rose's kindness, caring, wisdom and selfless love for her family and friends is the legacy and gift she leaves to all who had the privilege of being part of her life. We love you mom and will miss you dearly. Memorial service Friday, February 6th at 1:15pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a charity of your choice.

STONE--Robert L.,born in New York City on December 12, 1921 died in Boca Grande, Florida on Wednesday, January 28th of heart failure. He will always be a cherished husband, supportive and loving father, devoted grandfather, brother, uncle, mentor, a member of a wonderful family, and an equally wonderful extended family. He graduated from Deerfield Academy, and left Williams College to serve his country in World War II flying 40 combat missions over the Pacific and earning the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with 8 Oak Leaf Clusters. His career spanned work at Cresap, McCormick, and Paget, ABC, NBC, The Hertz Corporation and Columbia Pictures, and he served on the Board of the John Blair Company. In each of his jobs he made a difference, and he valued every friendship in his life. He treasured his family and his friends, and took special pleasure in Williams College athletics, always wearing his '92 hat, and cheering young players on from the sidelines. He always supported women's sports, most particularly Field Hockey and Lacrosse, and he was an ardent fly fisherman, tennis player and golfer. He loved Williamstown, the place where he chose to retire and live the rest of his life, and was always the happiest when he was there. Throughout his life he encouraged, loved, and mentored young friends and his spirit will continue by gifts in his memory going to The Williamstown Youth Center on Cole Avenue in Williamstown, Massachusetts. A Celebration of his life will be held in Williamstown in the Spring.

SILBER--Theresa, nee Kohn, (87), passed on Tuesday, February 3rd. Beloved mother of Deborah Friedman and Daniel Silber. She will be missed by her five grandchildren, her sister Rebekah Mosenkis and her brother Aaron Kohn. She was a Jewish Educator, an author of the classic Hebrew Primer, Shalom Yeladim and other great texts. She taught Hebrew for many years at Temple Beth<--El of Great Neck, originating a method for teaching the language in the afternoon School setting, and mentored other teachers as a consultant for the Board of Jewish Education. Services at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ on Friday, February 6th at 11:30am.

It's not ''Bernie Madoff: The Musical,'' but Jean Doumanian Productions, a producer of ''August: Osage County'' and several Woody Allen films, is developing the nonfiction book ''Ponzi's Scheme'' into a musical. Ms. Doumanian said in an interview that her production company had acquired the stage and film rights to the book, written by Mitchell Zuckoff and published in 2005 by Random House. ''Ponzi's Scheme'' tells the story of Charles Ponzi, a charismatic charlatan who came to Boston and fleeced investors out of millions of dollars in the early 1900s. Ms. Doumanian said she had begun talks with several book writers and composers -- including Marshall Brickman, a book writer for ''Jersey Boys'' -- about joining the project.

As President Obama met with centrist lawmakers to address concerns over the $900 billion economic stimulus plan, the Senate on Wednesday voted to expand the package with a tax credit for homebuyers of up to $15,000, a provision championed by Republicans as addressing a root cause of the recession. The vote to add the tax credit, at a cost of about $18.5 billion, came as Senate leaders seemed to be nearing completion of negotiations. The majority leader, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, suggested that a final vote on the stimulus plan could come on Thursday.

In a White House ceremony, President Obama signed legislation on Wednesday that extends health coverage to four million uninsured children, a move he called a first step toward fulfilling a campaign pledge to provide insurance for all Americans.

SELIGMAN--Dan, a noted writer probably best known for the popular "Keeping Up" column he wrote in Fortune magazine between 1976 and 1997, passed away January 31st at age 84 in Lenox Hill Hospital after a four-year battle with multiple myeloma. His humor, consideration, and integrity will be sorely missed by family and friends. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Mary "Meg" Seligman, whom he met when they were both working at Time, Inc., a brother, Paul, of Morristown, NJ and sister, Susan Cohn, of Maplewood, NJ, two children, Nora Favorov, a North Carolina based translator, and William Seligman, Vice President for Operations at BillMeLater, Inc., and four grandchildren. A lifelong native of Manhattan, he graduated Townsend Harris in 1941 and attended Rutgers University before enlisting in the army in 1943. His military career was short-lived due to severe asthma. He eventually graduated from New York University, where he studied under the philosopher Sidney Hook, a major influence in his life. In the late 1940s he worked for the American Mercury. He also wrote for The Commonweal and the New Leader, where he had a feature entitled "Squinting at Labor" that focused on Communist influence within organized labor. During this period he was an outspoken anti-communist and engaged in open polemics with the American Communist Party's mouthpiece, The Daily Worker. In 1950 he joined Fortune magazine and held a number of senior editorial positions at the magazine and its parent company, Time, Inc. In 1976 he began writing "Keeping Up." In 1988, when Seligman stepped down as associate managing editor of Fortune but continued contributing "Keeping Up," then managing editor Marshall Loeb wrote in the magazine, "Dan Seligman is an urbane, soft-voiced, unfailingly courteous colleague who transforms himself in these pages fortnightly into the curmudgeonly Dr. Keeping Up, an acerbic slayer of (mostly liberal) prig-headedness. In both personae, Super-Dan uses elegance and trenchant wit to wage his never-ending battle against fustian thinking, be it from overbearing bureaucrats, loony activists, or insufficiently rigorous colleagues." In March of 1997 he left Fortune for Forbes magazine, where he was a contributing editor until 2006. He continued to write for the New York Post, Wall Street Journal and Commentary Magazine through 2007. He also contributed to City Journal, which published a memoir about the poker game he founded with two Fortune colleagues in 1953. He hosted and organized the game until shortly before his death. The game was high stakes and in a single 1958 session he himself lost 10 percent of his $16,000 salary. Among the players over the years were Irving Kristol, co-founder of The Public Interest, Chester Davis, Howard Hughes's chief trial attorney, and Victor Mitchell, the Grand Life Master bridge player. Mitchell left the game shortly after joining it, when his four-of-a-kind was beaten by a straight flush in seven card stud. Seligman, a whiz at calculating probabilities, determined that the chance of this happening was about 2.5 million to 1. He had a life-long interest in questions surrounding intelligence, genetics, and the taboos imposed on open discussion of their interplay. In 1992 he published A Question of Intelligence: The IQ Debate in America, an overview of intelligence testing that argues its usefulness. Donations may be sent to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation.
EXECUTIVE PAY LIMITS President Obama announced new executive pay limits on companies seeking government assistance, an attempt to change an entrenched corporate culture.
FOSS-Lukas. The American Academy in Rome mourns the loss of a dear friend and brilliant Fellow Lukas Foss. May his music last forever.

BARRING the compulsion to sniff everything in sight, dogs usually love going hiking for the same reasons that humans do. There's the mental stimulation of traversing a complicated trail, the physical benefits of brisk exercise at changing inclines and, of course, the plain old fun of being in the great outdoors. To facilitate canine hiking expeditions, a vast array of gear has been introduced in recent years, including backpacks, leashes, harnesses, coats, boots, bowls, beds and tents designed especially for dogs, for their paws and their comfort, on the trails. ''There was a time when it was difficult to get dog hiking gear,'' said Linda B. Mullally, the author of ''Hiking With Dogs: Becoming a Wilderness-Wise Dog Owner,'' and an especially firm advocate of dog hiking boots, among other products. ''Now it's become a bit of a snazzy fashion industry, and you have to be careful to select things that are actually comfortable and functional for the dog.'' Samantha Lewis, the owner of the dog walking and hiking service Lewis & Bark in Los Angeles, takes her canine clients trekking in the Santa Monica Mountains every weekday afternoon. With the help of Spotty, her 11-year-old Dalmatian, and a couple of friends -- Honey, a 6-year-old Australian shepherd and Auggie, a 2-year-old Rhodesian Ridgeback -- she tested five kinds of outdoor dog gear on the Sullivan Canyon Trail near Brentwood, evaluating them for construction, practicality, ease of use and comfort. She liked elements of each item, even if Spotty sometimes seemed less sure. JENNIFER BLEYER

Just in time for the worst economic downturn since the Depression, those brand-conscious, free-spending ladies of “Sex and the City” will be back for a movie sequel, Reuters reported. Sarah Jessica Parker, Cynthia Nixon, Kim Cattrall and Kristin Davis have all signed contracts with New Line Cinema for a second film based on the HBO series and the book by Candace Bushnell; Michael Patrick King, who wrote and directed the first film, has signed on to write a script for the sequel. The first “Sex and the City” movie, a 142-minute frolic in which Carrie wed Mr. Big and bought lots and lots of things, grossed more than $415 million worldwide after its release in May. The sequel is planned for a 2010 release.

Having variously portrayed God, Moses and Philip II of Macedon in his unpredictable career, Val Kilmer may be contemplating a role that would carry more real-world authority. In an interview with The Associated Press, Mr. Kilmer said he may consider running for governor of New Mexico in 2010, when a term-limit law would prevent Gov. Bill Richardson from seeking a third stay in office (although that’s what opponents of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg thought, too). “I’m just looking for ways to be contributive,” Mr. Kilmer said, according to The A.P. “And if that ends up being where I can make a substantial contribution, then I’ll run.” Though born and raised in Los Angeles, Mr. Kilmer, a star of films including “The Doors” and “Batman Forever,” has resided for two decades in New Mexico, where he keeps a 6,000-acre ranch outside of Santa Fe. He said he had not conclusively decided to seek office, but told The A.P., “If I run, I’m going to be the next governor.”

A final collection of poetry by John Updike, composed over the last eight years of his life and assembled weeks before his death, will be released by Alfred A. Knopf on April 5, the publisher said in an e-mail message. Though arguably better known for his literary prose, Mr. Updike, the Pulitzer Prize- and National Book Award-winning author who died on Jan. 27, was also a prolific writer of poetry; his first collection of verse, “Ex-Basketball Player,” was published in 1957. The new collection, “Endpoint and Other Poems,” will include his recently published work “Requiem,” in which Mr. Updike playfully wrote that “a shrug and tearless eyes” would greet his passing, adding: “The wide response will be, I know, / ‘I thought he died a while ago.'” Another posthumous work by Mr. Updike, “My Father’s Tears and Other Stories,” is scheduled for publication in June.

It’s the most action a production of “Waiting for Godot” has ever seen: a few weeks before the start of rehearsals for Roundabout Theater Company‘s production of the Beckett play, David Strathairn, who was scheduled to play Lucky, has withdrawn from the show; the role will now be played by John Glover. The announcement was made by the show’s publicists, who said only that Mr. Strathairn “had to regretfully leave the production prior to rehearsals beginning.” The “Godot” revival, which stars Nathan Lane as Estragon, Bill Irwin as Vladimir and John Goodman as Pozzo, is scheduled to begin previews at Studio 54 on April 3 and open on April 30.

After a week of rumor and speculation, the National Gallery of Art in Washington confirmed that it was the buyer of “Bagpipe Player in Profile,” a 1624 painting by the Dutch master Hendrick ter Brugghen. Johnny Van Haeften, a London dealer, purchased the painting at Sotheby’s New York sale on Jan. 29 for $10.2 million, a record price for the artist at auction. The National Gallery purchased it from him. “Bagpipe Player in Profile” was recently returned to the heirs of Herbert von Klemperer, a German industrialist who was forced to surrender it in 1938. Purchased by the Wallraf-Richartz Museum in Cologne in a public sale, the painting remained in the museum’s collection until July when it was returned to von Klemperer’s heirs, who were the sellers last week.

More than 10,000 works in Yiddish – perhaps more than half of all that was ever published in the language – are now accessible online as part of a joint project between the National Yiddish Book Center, based in Amherst, Mass., and the Internet Archive in San Francisco, the two institutions announced on Friday. The scanning began more than 10 years ago as part of a $5 million effort to create the Steven Spielberg Digital Library, said Aaron Lansky, founder and president of the book center. The books will be available for downloading in a variety of formats at www.archive.org/details/nationalyiddishbookcenter.

Lux Interior, 62, who died on Wednesday from heart failure, was more than just the singer of the campy punk-a-billy band the Cramps. He was a style beacon of head-to-toe PVC and spike-heeled pumps. With the Cramps, Interior, né Erick Lee Purkhiser, gave a camp horror twist to the androgyny of the New York Dolls and sexed up the silly spookiness of their English compatriots, the Damned. The resulting cocktail would fuel eight albums and almost-constant touring until 2006, when Interior and his guitarist wife, Poison Ivy Rorschach (born Kristy Wallace), hung up their traveling catsuits. Designers like Gareth Pugh have recently dusted them off, as have latex-legging lovers like Mary-Kate Olsen, Kate Moss and Rihanna. For his style and music contributions over the years, we know Interior is receiving his well-earned 21-machine-gun salute from heaven's baddest bikini girls.

I know the fashion shows are just around the corner when I start receiving model cards in the mail. They come as a sort of "for your consideration" for the new round of magazine stories that are always shot directly after the shows. For a while now, the model companies (Elite, DNA, IMG, Ford) have vamped up the images, trying to make them more arty and less commercial. Out of them all, Supreme Model Management has always been the most creative. When the purple box arrived, I tore into it immediately as I assumed that it contained chocolates. But after unthreading the flaps, I was greeted by a confection of another kind altogether. While it's a little difficult to actually see the girls in the photographs, the overall effect is mysterious and beautiful -- qualities you often look for in a model.

Last Thursday, I rode five hours to Rhode Island to spend 10 minutes at the wake of my great-uncle, whom I adored. Afterward I was hungry, so I followed my dad's cousins to Twin Oaks in Cranston. "Is this that place we go to after every wake?" I asked my father. It sure wasn't, 'cause I would have remembered Twin Oaks.Located in a residential neighborhood, the DeAngelus family's vast restaurant is a cross between a country club and a Lion's club, Italian-American-style. Once seated in the red-carpeted banquet room, with heaps of red-sauced pasta and veal Parmesan around us, my brother whispered, "When did we leave Providence and enter 'The Sopranos?'" The food was surprisingly good, but my favorite was this sign on the entrance door, which says it all. Definitely worth the trip.

The Bagger would be deeply embarrassed to admit how much time he spent staring at the Times Magazine's portfolio of great performers last night. It's not that the feature wasn't worthy. The photographs by Paolo Pelligrin are stone-cold amazing and Lynn Hirschberg's audio analytics on the photos themselves are illuminating in way that work about celebrities almost never is. In fact, the pair managed to render some of the most famous people in the world - Brad Pitt, Kate Winslet, Penelope Cruz - visible as human beings. By setting aside the general approach to these things, which goes something like "we will stage these photos and art direct them within an inch of their lives, so that you, the reader, will see directly into the souls of the subjects," the magazine shot the famed while they were at home, or working, or getting ready to go to work. They look like normal people, only better, which is sort of what an actor is at bottom.

Finance | Last year we watched 401(k)'s deflate. This year looks like the year of pension fund implosions, an article says. Federal law requires funds to have enough money to pay all their retirees. Yet with markets way down, more than two-fifths of big-company plans "are nowhere close to meeting that standard, and those dire numbers are increasing." The politically driven "social investing" of public pensions makes matters worse. [Reason]

Environment | All those reusable, designer tote bags look like a bad deal for the environment "when there are closets and drawers full of them in every home," an article says. Producing one tote is roughly equivalent to making 400 plastic bags. "Once the emphasis shifts from reusing a bag to having a bag that reflects your status or personality, the environmental goal starts drifting out of sight." [Design Observer]

The iPhone's Safari browser doesn't limit to stripped-down mobile versions of Web sites. But while Safari can bring the full versions of most sites right to the palm of your hand (well, except those that feature Adobe Flash and other incompatible browser plug-ins), it can be a pain to pinch and spread your fingers all over the screen to make the tiny text legible. There is a way to zoom in more efficiently, however: just tap twice on a column or section of text to zoom in - and tap twice again to zoom back out.

The N.F.L. Players Association is appealing a federal court decision ordering the union to pay $28.1 million to retired players for allegedly cutting them out of lucrative marketing deals. A jury found in November that the union failed to include the retired players in deals with Electronic Arts, the maker of the “Madden NFL” video game, and other companies. Lawyers for the retired players assert that the union excluded them from licensing deals so active players could receive bigger royalty payments. The union argued that companies paid licensing fees exclusively for active players. The players association filed its appeal Tuesday in United States District Court in San Francisco. ¶The former Dallas Cowboys receiver Terry Glenn was arrested on public intoxication and marijuana possession charges after appearing disoriented at a hotel, the police said. The announcer Joe Buck will host a new HBO show starting in May, helping to fill the void left by Bob Costas, who joined the new MLB Network on Tuesday. Buck, who has covered two Super Bowls and 10 World Series, called it a “dream” job. He will keep his play-by-play duties for Fox, where he has covered baseball and the N.F.L. The 90-minute show may involve a studio audience, HBO said, and will not impose on his play-by-play schedule.

The Belgian cyclist Frederiek Nolf was found dead in his Doha hotel room hours before the start of the fifth stage of the Tour of Qatar. Nolf, 21, was found in his bed by his roommate Kristof Gooddaert, the Belgian team Topsport Vlaanderen Mercator said. The cause of death was not immediately known. The team quit the Qatar tour and planned to return to Belgium.

Lane Kiffin’s first game against Florida as the coach of Tennessee got much more interesting Thursday. Kiffin, the Volunteers’ new coach, was reprimanded by the Southeastern Conference, and he issued an apology after he falsely accused Florida Coach Urban Meyer of a recruiting violation. Earlier in the day, Kiffin told fans at a breakfast celebrating the Volunteers’ recruiting class that Meyer violated rules by calling a prospect who was on an official visit at Tennessee.

A report in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about the unusual criticism of Pope Benedict XVI by German Chancellor Angela Merkel over his rehabilitation of a bishop who denied the Holocaust referred incorrectly to her position in the German leadership hierarchy. An article on Saturday about the signing of a strategic partnership by the presidents of Russia and Cuba, part of an effort to rekindle their countries’ cold war alliance, referred incorrectly to Russians’ use of the term “Great Patriotic War.” That is their description of the Soviet Union’s struggle with Germany from 1941 to 1945, for Russians the overwhelmingly significant part of World War II; it is not the Russian name for the whole war.

An article on Monday about the activities of former Senator Tom Daschle after he left office referred incorrectly to a business decision by Leo Hindery, who provided a car and driver for Mr. Daschle. The article also misstated part of the name of the company involved in that decision. Mr. Hindery was chief executive of the YES Network (not Networks) and he sold his stake in the company while other partners retained their interest. Mr. Hindery did not sell the YES Network. The article also misstated the year that the federal government killed a loan supporting a railroad operation near the Mayo Clinic, where Mr. Daschle was a director. It was in 2007, not last year.

WOODBURY--Nathalie Ferris Sampson, of Shutesbury, died December 22 at home after a long illness. She leaves her husband, Richard B. Woodbury and loving friends. Nathalie was born in Humboldt, Arizona in 1918, where she began formal schooling in the sixth grade, and grew into a widely respected scholar and writer. A woman of strong opinions and wit, she delighted in dogs and other animals, which surrounded her at her Shutesbury home. She was an honorary life member of the Nature Conservancy, honorary dog officer of Shutesbury; and a valued supporter of the Dakin Animal Shelter. Her home on the edge of an extensive woodland provided many opportunities to observe wildlife. She attended Barnard College in New York, received her BA degree there in 1939, and pursued graduate studies in Anthropology at Columbia University. She devoted her adult life to the study of human society, languages, and culture in various manifestations, and was the co-author and editor of several volumes in various anthropological sub-disciplines. She married archaeologist Richard Benjamin Woodbury in 1948, and shared field work with him in Mexico, Arizona and New Mexico. The two held museum posts, together and severally in Arizona, New York, and the Smithsonian Institution. In her long career, Nathalie taught at Barnard College, Brooklyn College, Eastern New Mexico College, and the Universities of Arizona and Kentucky. At Barnard she also held administrative positions. In the course of her career she became widely acquainted within the professional ranks of Anthropology and Archaeology, and was universally respected. She was very skillful at editing and authoring, leading to various professional positions. She was editor of several newsletters, contributed a regular column for the Anthropology Newsletter, entitled "Past is Present," and organized and sometimes wrote obituaries for the Newsletter. She was a regular contributor to professional programs, annual reports, and guides. The renown that followed her services led to positions on the Board of the American Anthropological Association, the Society for American Archaeology, and the American Ethnological Society. She edited the internationally respected professional journals for the Society for American Archaeology and the American Anthropological Association. With this background, it is not surprising that she chose anthropologists as 'her people' to study and report. She easily recognized that the familiar was not always well understood, and the exotic was not necessarily foreign. She delighted in 'problem solving' in real world situations, and was able to contribute significantly by applying those skills. Equally adept close to home, she served in town government in Shutesbury as a Selectperson and on the board of the Dakin Animal Shelter. Her skills and vision led her into advocating for a strong executive for the American Anthropological Association. She was instrumental in hiring a business specialist, and watched with deep satisfaction as he drew the Association into fiscal soundness and executive order. Nat was a natural networker. She cared about and maintained close mentoring relationships with former students she had taught at Barnard, Eastern New Mexico, Arizona, and Kentucky. The profession was enriched by their training and skills. At annual professional meetings, she conferred with colleagues and students at luncheons; these relationships frequently blossomed into lifelong friendships. Nathalie and Richard Woodbury were recognized jointly and severally for their significant services for the town and their professional societies. Awards for Distinguished Service were presented by the American Anthropological Association and the Society for American Archaeology. The town of Shutesbury recognized their joint services with a plaque. Close to retirement, Nathalie asked a rhetorical question that sums up a significant career remarkably well: "Am I an archaeologist or a sociocultural anthropologist?...., an educator, an administrator, or a small town politician?" She was all of those, and everyone who knew her recognized her gifts and was grateful. Donations in her memory may be made to the Dakin Pioneer Valley Humane Society, P.O. Box 319, South Deerfield, MA 01303. Obituary and register at www.douglassfuneral.com.

IT'S not difficult to stay entertained on Maui. View the sunrise from the top of the 10,000-foot volcano Haleakala and then take an exhilarating 38-mile bicycle ride down the mountain with no pedaling. Drive the winding, cliff-hugging, hairpin-turn Road to Hana along Maui's tropical northeast shoreline, where each bend yields a view from the car windows more breathtaking than the last. Take a sailboat ride out to the half-sunken crater island of Molokini and do some scuba diving in its crescent-shaped bay. My wife, teenage daughter and son, and I did all of the above on a family trip to Maui last year, and enjoyed each experience, but the activity we loved best was simple, required no reservations and came free of cost: snorkeling. We found a succession of spectacular beaches in the south Maui towns of Wailea and Makena where snorkelers can see dozens of species of fish and coral in relatively protected waters. Without our really intending it, our vacation became a snorkeling adventure.

The Smithsonian Institution said that it had appointed Richard Kurin its under secretary for history, art and culture, confirming a report on museumanthropology.blogspot.com. The appointment was made by G. Wayne Clough, the Smithsonian secretary. Dr. Kurin, who received his Ph.D. in cultural anthropology from the University of Chicago, has been serving as acting under secretary, and was also director of the Smithsonian Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage, where he oversaw its Folklife Festival and Folkways Recordings label, as well as the director of the Smithsonian's national programs.

'''' My grandfather, who came from Italy, who had farms, he showed me the quality of milk. And when he saw my mother making cheese, he showed her, and my mother showed me. The most important thing is to keep the quality of the cheese together. But that has to be all from your head, just when you handle it, you know what you're doing. Cheese matures differently, it gets either hard or soft. It's a very wonderful cheese, it's a very healthy cheese, because our cheese comes from cow's milk, and cow's milk is nearest to mother's milk.

President Obama's economic stimulus plan includes about $1 billion to help local governments hire more police officers, which would resurrect a Clinton administration program that had been largely shelved by President George W. Bush. The so-called COPS Program, for Community Oriented Policing Services, aimed to add 100,000 police officers to local departments in eight years. Whether it met that goal is the subject of heated debate in law enforcement and public policy circles.

Anybody who has paid for theater tickets recently in New York City knows what a big hole they can leave in the family budget. Gov. David Paterson of New York wants to make that hole even deeper with a new theater ticket tax. The proposal could increase ticket prices by about 8 percent, which could dim Broadway's lights as tourists start thinking twice about that vacation in Manhattan. If tourism slumps in the city, the state's budget problems would surely worsen along with it. Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, summarizes his latest pleas to lawmakers this way: ''Please, don't kill your golden goose.''

She is also survived by her other daughter, Katherine Gross, her son-in-law Leonard, her sister Judy Leff and her grand- and great-grandchildren. Mary Kamens was the widow of the advertising Art Director, Irvine Kamens, and upon his death in 1955 she became the Village Clerk of Ardsley, NY, a position she held for 40 years. THE New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, a leader in promoting public health, has embarked on a campaign to persuade the makers of processed food to reduce its salt content by more than 40 percent over the next 10 years. The goal is commendable: to prevent strokes and heart attacks. And the premise is logical: if people eat less salt, they'll have lower blood pressure, and this could translate into better cardiovascular health. If such a large reduction were actually to be achieved, however, New Yorkers would consume less sodium than people in most other developed countries do. And there is a possibility that such a big change in one element of their diet might have unintended harmful consequences. Prudence requires that logic and good intentions also be supported by strong evidence that such an action would be safe.

THAW--Jack Alvin. Beloved father and friend Jack Alvin Thaw, of White Plains NY, died at home on January 29th 2009. He was 78 years old. Father to Janesse Bruce, Robert Thaw and Jacqueline Thaw and sons-in-law Richard Bruce and Raphael Ben-Yehuda; grandfather to Jessica, Oliver and Julian. Born Brooklyn NY on February 9th 1930, only son of Henry Thaw and Jesse Thaw (Cantor). Graduated Midwood High School in 1948, played varsity basketball; attended Syracuse University. Married Beverly Wolkoff in 1954, divorced in 1971. Worked with father in the family business, The Washington Arms Restaurant, Mamaroneck, NY; in commercial real estate at Julien J Studley, NYC; and served as a teachers' aide in Bronxville schools. His children and grandchildren were his greatest pride. Loved tennis, avid sports fan and chronicler, lover of music and literature. Jack, you will be missed. A memorial will be held Monday February 9, 10am to 1pm, remarks and prayer at 12pm noon at the Harrison Funeral Home, 329 Halstead Avenue, Harrison NY. Friends and family are welcome. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the New York Junior Tennis League, a charity founded by Arthur Ashe.

GREEN--Paul, Esq.,passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his loved ones on February 4, at the age of 86. Dearly beloved husband to Alice for 57 years, loving father to Vivien, Linda, and Richard, devoted father-in-law to Harvey and Judi, and proud grandfather of Daniel, Carly, and James. Born in Vienna, Austria, he came to New York City when he was fourteen, and excelled in his academic pursuits at New York University and New York Law School. In 1947, a few years after graduating law school he became a single practitioner and in 1951 started his own law firm, Green & Ettinger, with his friend Joseph Ettinger. He was a practicing attorney for nearly 65 years and loved his work. The New York County Lawyers Association honored him recently as the second longest-standing member since he joined in 1944. In addition to his law practice, Paul owned and managed real estate throughout the United States. He was a superb dealmaker, negotiator and advisor, and many of his clients and partners became his closest friends. All his life, Paul had an intense interest in history, politics and geography. He was an avid learner and a gifted teacher. He was also a member of NYCLA's Real Property Section for over 20 years and Secretary of NYCLA's Committee on Professional Discipline since 1991. In addition to his many legal committees, Paul was a longtime Trustee at Beth Israel Hospital. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, February 8, 2009 at 11:30am at Frank Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY 10028. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Beth Israel Hospital or American Jewish Committee. He will be forever loved and missed by all his family and countless friends.

The chief Pentagon official for the military commission system, Susan J. Crawford, dropped all charges Thursday night against the leading suspect in the 2000 bombing of the Navy destroyer Cole. The move, first reported by ABC News and confirmed by administration and Pentagon officials, pertains to the death penalty case of Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, a Saudi charged as the leading architect of the attack, which killed 17 American sailors. A Pentagon spokesman, J. D. Gordon, said Mr. Nashiri could face new charges later. President Obama plans to meet Friday at the White House with victims and families of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and the Cole bombing. to explain his decision to close the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

When the South Dakota State women's basketball team moved to Division I four seasons ago, it brought along a devoted following that had kept it among the national leaders in Division II attendance for almost a decade. Still, it was hard to imagine the Jackrabbits becoming the biggest show in town. It took only one season of Division I play for the Jackrabbits to start outdrawing the men's team. Now, the 21-2 Jackrabbits are no longer a regional secret. They keep knocking off bigger-name colleges and have been bobbing in and out of the top 25 in the Associated Press poll, rarefied air for a team from the Summit League. On Saturday, the Jackrabbits defeated Oakland University, 88-75, before a crowd of 5,637, the ninth largest in Frost Arena history and the most for any basketball game on campus this season. A week earlier, 4,491 walked through snow and braved below-zero wind chills to watch a 64-48 victory against archrival North Dakota State, about 800 more than the men's game with the same opponent the night before.

Amenities include a medical center, aquatics programs, a domed yoga room, six gyms, spa treatments, squash and tennis courts, and golf facilities. There are two full bathrooms.
