IT is a subtle realization on the final five minutes of the drive to the venerable Wildcat Mountain in New Hampshire: Something is missing. Actually, lots of things are missing. There are no houses, hotels, restaurants, gas stations, banks, shops, traffic lights or billboards. Just miles of tree-lined hills. Finally, there is a sign for the ski area, a parking lot and a lodge.

I enjoyed reading ''Florida Glide'' but was a bit curious as to the lack of life jackets. How and why would a guide take people out without requiring them to wear a life jacket? Even the best of swimmers can get into a difficult and dangerous situation. Jenni Ankarström Brunswick, Me.

THE woman approaching the hot spring was wearing nothing except for my missing gray ski hat. I had been shivering in my sleeping bag all night without it. The dawn still hadn't lifted the chill from the valley, which is encased like a tomb by snow-topped mountains. I didn't have to look too closely to see that she was freezing. ''What are you doing with my hat?'' I said, in a tone probably too aggressive, given that we were about to share a steaming hot tub in a desolate California desert valley about three times the size of Manhattan. The woman took off my hat, and her long blond locks rolled down to places you don't politely look at when speaking to a naked stranger.

The Olympic swimming sensation Michael Phelps, who was photographed inhaling from a marijuana pipe, has lost a major sponsorship deal and has been suspended from competition for three months. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg underwent surgery at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York on Thursday for what was apparently early-stage pancreatic cancer, according to a statement released by the Supreme Court. The surgery followed the discovery of a lesion during an annual check-up in late January at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. A CAT scan revealed a small tumor, approximately one centimeter across, in the center of the pancreas, the court's statement said.

He also criticized the leadership of Hamas for letting its police force run wild, attacking a distribution center for the needy to cart off supplies.

CLEARY--John P.,76, attorney, of Locust Valley, who dedicated the last decade of his life to development of science on Long Island, died February 1st in Loveland, Colorado. A graduate of Yale University, an expert in tax certiori and real estate law, he was a founding partner of Farrell Fritz law firm of Uniondale. He was former Director and honorary Director of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Association, former trustee and honorary trustee of said Laboratory. He helped develop the Broad Hollow Bioscience Park at SUNY, Farmingdale and in an effort to find a cure for muscular dystrophy, was angel investor in Mirus Bio, of Madison, WI. He was former trustee, board chair and Chairman Emeritus of Molloy College in Rockville Centre and served as trustee of the Village of Oyster Bay Cove. Dear husband of his wife, Rita, loving father to two sons, Mark and James, and daughter, Sharon, he will be sorely missed. Viewing: Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home, Inc. Oyster Bay, Friday, February 6, 1-3 and 6-9pm. Funeral Saturday, February 7, 10am, St. Dominic's Church, Oyster Bay. Interment: Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury following the service. Contributions in lieu of flowers: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Development Dept., 1 Bungtown Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724 or Molloy College Office of Advancement, 1000 Hempstead Ave. Rockville Centre, NY 11571. For further information www.fpdevinefuneralhome.com

This New England ski area offers an unadorned, rugged experience. Carved into a peak in the White Mountain National Forest 76 years ago, Wildcat is a ski area in a preserve. Long known for its steep and expert trails, the mountain doesn't offer amenities like Wi-Fi, but packs a thrilling and thorough alpine adventure and is full of not-so-secret backcountry stashes when you tire of the sanctioned trails. nytimes.com/escapes

CLEARY--John P. Farrell Fritz deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend, founder and partner, John P. Cleary. John was a respected colleague and an invaluable mentor. We celebrate his zest for life and his myriad professional accomplishments, and we admire his benevolence to the many charities he helped. We mourn John's all-too-soon passing and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, whom he loved above all else -- his wife Rita, and his children, Mark, Sharon and Jimmy. He will be sorely missed.

President Obama signed an executive order Thursday to create a revamped White House office for religion-based and neighborhood programs, expanding an initiative started by the Bush administration that provides government support -- and financing -- to religious and charitable organizations that deliver social services. ''No matter how much money we invest or how sensibly we design our policies, the change that Americans are looking for will not come from government alone,'' Mr. Obama said. ''There is a force for good greater than government.''

GREEN--Paul. The Board of Directors of 885 Park Avenue Corp. mourns the loss of Chairman Paul Green. He was a devoted member of the Board and cherished neighbor for over forty years. The Board depended on his wise counsel, extensive knowledge of the real estate industry, and intimate history of the building. We also appreciated his dry humor, sophistication, insightful assessment of current events, and his sincere concern for his neighbors. We and the tenant shareholders will miss him profoundly. Our most sincere condolences to Alice, Vivian, Linda, Richard and the family. The Board of Directors 885 Park Avenue Corp.

The Obama administration is facing its first big international test this weekend as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. heads to a conference in Europe in the face of a confrontational stance from an old cold war adversary. Administration officials have concluded that Russia pressed Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet republic, to close the American base in that country, which they interpret as a shot across the bow. The base is crucial to the American-led fight in Afghanistan that Mr. Obama has identified as his central national security objective. Mr. Obama plans to deploy as many as 30,000 additional troops to Afghanistan over the next two years; shaky overland supply routes through Pakistan would make it difficult for the United States to adjust to the loss of the base, in Manas, Kyrgyzstan.

FOSS--Lukas. The Board of Directors of the Aaron Copland Fund for Music acknowledges with deep regret and sorrow the passing of one of our charter members. His direct connection to Copland and his great stature as a composer-pianist-conductor added so much to the work of the Fund. We grieve with his family as we honor our friend and colleague for his extraordinary musical talents and his steadfast devotion to American music. The Aaron Copland Fund for Music, Inc. John Harbison, President James M. Kendrick, Secretary

Thompson," "Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story," and "Fuel."

Wearing a ski hat and pacing for an hour before he finally ascened the stage to give John Patrick Shanley the Ian McLellan Hunter Award for Lifetime Achievement in Writing, Philip Seymour Hoffman said he was going to be a little more serious than those who had come before. But that didn't stop him having a little fun critiquing writers' sartorial habits. He also pointed out that "this is an unruly event. Lots of empty seats." And, he was right, the auditorium was half empty. Mr. Hoffman quoted Eugene O'Neill, and then watched movie clips from "Moonstruck" and "Doubt" along with everybody else before bringing up Mr. Shanley.

An Iraqi journalist working for The New York Times in Falluja was one of the first people to meet Luca Marchio, the Italian tourist who turned up unexpectedly in a public bus at the entrance to the city on Friday on the third - and soon to be abruptly-truncated - leg of his tourist trail around Iraq. (Read the story here.) We asked our correspondent to describe his reaction, and that of his fellow Fallujans, to the arrival of the first holidaymaker in a city that has seen two major battles, countless explosions and foreigners killed, mutilated and hanged from a bridge. Falluja was once the heart of the Sunni insurgency, and still lives under a heavy security cordon.

Books | What's up with all these books with the "Grim Reaper as life coach"? With boomers sensing their date with the hereafter, James Wolcott says, the publishing industry is cashing in. Books tell them to experience all manner of things before they die -- "as if life were a race through the supermarket aisle to grab as many experiences off the shelves as possible before collapsing at the checkout line." And when they do, a la "Tuesdays With Morrie," they must set a "gallant example at the exit ramp." It all "seems an awful lot to ask of a sick, dying person-admirable conduct plus a lifetime's treasury of pithy lessons handed out like Wheat Thins." [Vanity Fair]

Meryl Davis and Charlie White won the ice dancing title at the I.S.U. Four Continents competition in Vancouver, British Columbia. Davis and White, from suburban Detroit, scored a 192.39 to beat Canada’s Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir in the test event for the 2010 Olympics — the final one before next month’s world championships. Virtue and Moir, who led after Thursday’s original dance program, thrilled the fans with their innovative free dance program to Pink Floyd’s “The Great Gig in the Sky” and “Money,” scoring 191.81. The Americans Emily Samuelson and Evan Bates, from Ann Arbor, Mich., won the bronze with 180.69.

The American Lindsey Vonn led the downhill portion of the super-combi at Val d’Isère, France, but was disqualified from the slalom for splitting a gate. Kathrin Zettel of Austria was the surprise winner, posting the fifth-fastest downhill and the third-fastest slalom. Zettel had a combined time of 2 minutes 20.13 seconds. The Swiss teenager Lara Gut, 17, finished second, 0.56 seconds behind. Elisabeth Görgl of Austria was third, 0.88 back.

The teenager Melanie Oudin has been chosen as the No. 2 player for the United States in the first round of its Fed Cup competition against Argentina this weekend in suburban Phoenix. Mary Joe Fernandez, the captain, picked Oudin, 17, of Marietta, Ga., over the U.S.T.A. pro tour veteran Julie Ditty. Oudin will make her Fed Cup debut against the No. 1 Argentine player, Gisela Dulko, on Saturday. The top American, Jill Craybas, will play Betina Jozami in the opening match in the best-of-five competition.

Randy Wolf, who went 9-6 in 2007 for the Dodgers before shoulder trouble sidelined him midseason, agreed to a one-year, $5 million deal with the team Friday. The left-handed Wolf, 32, went a combined 12-12 with a 4.30 earned run average with San Diego and Houston last year.

A Mexican newspaper began encouraging fans to cast a voodoo hex on the United States ahead of Wednesday’s World Cup qualifier in Columbus, Ohio. Readers of The Record could trade in coupons for voodoo-doll likenesses of American players at Blockbuster video stores in Mexico City on Friday. Fans were instructed to use the doll to wish for a Mexico goal.

High School, erased Alan Webb’s national indoor record in the 1,000 meters when he won the event in 2 minutes 22.28 seconds at the Collegiate Invitational at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. A blistering final 400 meters in 54.8 seconds eclipsed Webb’s scholastic record of 2:23.68 set in 2001.

More than 10,000 works in Yiddish are now accessible online as part of a joint project between the National Yiddish Book Center, based in Amherst, Mass., and the Internet Archive in San Francisco, the two institutions announced on Friday. The scanning began more than 10 years ago as part of a $5 million effort to create the Steven Spielberg Digital Library, said Aaron Lansky, founder and president of the book center. The books will be available for downloading in a variety of formats at archive.org/details/nationalyiddishbookcenter.

After a week of rumor and speculation, the National Gallery of Art in Washington confirmed that it was the buyer of “Bagpipe Player in Profile,” below, a 1624 painting by the Dutch master Hendrick ter Brugghen. Johnny Van Haeften, the London dealer, purchased the painting at Sotheby’s New York sale on Jan. 29 for $10.2 million, a record price for the artist at auction. The National Gallery purchased the work from Mr. Van Haeften. “Bagpipe Player in Profile” was recently returned to the heirs of Herbert von Klemperer, a German industrialist who was forced to surrender it in 1938. Purchased by the Wallraf-Richartz Museum in Cologne in a public sale, the painting remained in the museum’s collection until July, when it was returned to Mr. von Klemperer’s heirs, who were the sellers last week.

With CBS in reruns on Thursday night, ABC soared to No. 1 in the ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC earned the night’s largest audience, 15.2 million viewers, with “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 p.m., and retained many of those viewers at 10 with “Private Practice” (13 million), which outperformed its competitors, NBC’s “ER” (7.3 million) and CBS’s repeat of “Eleventh Hour” (8.2 million). But at 8, ABC’s “Ugly Betty” (7.3 million) struggled opposite Fox’s “Bones” (10.8 million), which led the hour and helped Fox place second on the night. CBS ranked third for the night over all. NBC lagged behind in total viewers with its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, but delivered its best ratings in the 18-to-49 age group during the 9 p.m. hour with “The Office” (8.4 million total viewers) and “30 Rock” (6.3 million).

It’s the most action a production of “Waiting for Godot” has ever seen: a few weeks before the start of rehearsals for the Roundabout Theater Company’s Broadway production of this Beckett play, David Strathairn, who was scheduled to play Lucky, has withdrawn from the show; the role will now be played by John Glover. The announcement was made by the show’s publicists, who said only that Mr. Strathairn “had to regretfully leave the production prior to rehearsals beginning.” The “Godot” revival, which stars Nathan Lane as Estragon, Bill Irwin as Vladimir and John Goodman as Pozzo, is to begin previews at Studio 54 on April 3 and open on April 30.

Having variously portrayed God, Moses and Philip II of Macedon in his unpredictable career, Val Kilmer, below, may be contemplating a role that would carry more real-world authority. In an interview with The Associated Press, Mr. Kilmer said he may consider running for governor of New Mexico in 2010, when term-limit laws would prevent Gov. Bill Richardson from seeking a third stay in office (although opponents of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York thought the same thing). “I’m just looking for ways to be contributive,” Mr. Kilmer said, according to The A.P. “And if that ends up being where I can make a substantial contribution, then I’ll run.” Though born and raised in Los Angeles, Mr. Kilmer, a star of films including “The Doors” and “Batman Forever,” has lived for two decades in New Mexico, where he has a 6,000-acre ranch outside Santa Fe. He said he had not conclusively decided to seek office but told The A.P., “If I run, I’m going to be the next governor.”.

A final collection of poetry by John Updike, composed over the last eight years of his life and assembled weeks before his death, will be released by Alfred A. Knopf on April 5, the publisher said in an e-mail message. Though better known for his prose, Mr. Updike, the Pulitzer Prize- and National Book Award-winning author who died on Jan. 27, was also a prolific writer of poetry; his first collection of verse, “Ex-Basketball Player,” was published in 1957. The new collection, “Endpoint and Other Poems,” will include his recently published work “Requiem,” in which he playfully wrote that “a shrug and tearless eyes” would greet his passing, adding: “The wide response will be, I know,/‘I thought he died a while ago.’ ” Another posthumous work by Mr. Updike, “My Father’s Tears and Other Stories,” is scheduled for publication in June.

After weeks of internal debate, the Obama administration has settled on a plan to inject billions of dollars in fresh capital into banks and entice investors to purchase their most troubled assets. The new financial industry rescue plan, to be outlined in broad terms on Monday in a speech by the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, will not require banks to increase their lending. That is despite criticism that institutions that already received money from the Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP, either hoarded it or used the funds to acquire other banks.

With the Senate on track to pass its version of the economic stimulus legislation, President Obama is widely expected to win final Congressional approval of the plan soon, and thus make good on an assortment of his campaign promises. But in the process, he is confronting the impediments to his most ambitious pledge: to end the capital's partisan warfare. Mr. Obama has been frustrated by an array of forces, from an often bitter and personal history of partisanship on Capitol Hill to the near-extinction of Republican moderates in the House to the deep ideological gulf between the parties on economic policy. And as his aspiration of putting aside petty politics has met the necessity of winning legislative votes -- no more than two or three Senate Republicans are expected to support him, which is two or three more than did so in the House -- he has gone through a public evolution that has left him showing sharper edges when it comes to the ways of Washington.

Donations in his memory can be made to the UJA/Federation. A memorial service will be held in his memory on February 21st .

GREEN--Paul, Esq.,passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his loved ones on February 4, at the age of 86. Dearly beloved husband to Alice for 57 years, loving father to Vivien, Linda, and Richard, devoted father-in-law to Harvey and Judi, and proud grandfather of Daniel, Carly, and James. Born in Vienna, Austria, he came to New York City when he was fourteen, and excelled in his academic pursuits at New York University and New York Law School. In 1947, a few years after graduating law school he became a single practitioner and in 1951 started his own law firm, Green & Ettinger, with his friend Joseph Ettinger. He was a practicing attorney for nearly 65 years and loved his work. The New York County Lawyers Association honored him recently as the second longest-standing member since he joined in 1944. In addition to his law practice, Paul owned and managed real estate throughout the United States. He was a superb dealmaker, negotiator and advisor, and many of his clients and partners became his closest friends. All his life, Paul had an intense interest in history, politics and geography. He was an avid learner and a gifted teacher. He was also a member of NYCLA's Real Property Section for over 20 years and Secretary of NYCLA's Committee on Professional Discipline since 1991. In addition to his many legal committees, Paul was a longtime Trustee at Beth Israel Hospital. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, February 8, 2009 at 11:30am at Frank Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY 10028. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Beth Israel Hospital or American Jewish Committee. He will be forever loved and missed by all his family and countless friends.

Opening the barn door to a new era in farming and pharmaceuticals, the Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first drug produced by livestock that have been given a human gene. The drug, meant to prevent fatal blood clots in people with a rare condition, is a human protein extracted from the milk of genetically engineered goats.

In his first weeks in office, President Obama has dismantled many environmental policies set by the Bush administration. But in some areas, he will be building on the work of his predecessor, rather than taking it apart. Mr. Bush was not known for his concern over the environment. In the eight years of his tenure, he opened vast tracts of public lands to drilling, mining and timbering, earning the enmity of many environmentalists. His critics accused him of easing restrictions on polluters, subverting science and dragging his feet on global warming.

Environmentalists dream of a bigger and ''smarter'' electric grid that could move vast amounts of clean electricity from windswept plains and sunny deserts to distant cities. Such a grid, they argue, could help utilities match demand with supply on the hottest afternoons, allow customers to decide when to run their appliances and decrease the risk of blackouts, like the one that paralyzed much of the East in 2003.

SPYER--Thea C.,an extraordinary woman, died peacefully Thursday, February 5 at age 77 from aortic stenosis. Dr. Spyer earned her Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from Adelphi University. She interned at St. Vincent's Hospital, NYC and Veterans Administration, NYC and she later became Director of the Psychiatric Clinic at the International Center for the Disabled and was Clinical Consultant in Rehabilitation at St. Vincent's Hospital, Westchester before concentrating exclusively on her private practice. She was born to Elisabeth Ketellapper and Willem Spyer in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, and immigrated to the US States during World War II. Thea was an avid violinist, and golfer and dancer before she was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis. She reinvented herself every year of advancing physical disability to stay active and working and joyous in her life. Told of her death, friends offered the following adjectives: vibrant, witty, courageous, compassionate, insightful, resolute, and beautiful; the epitome of intrepid brilliance. She is survived by her spouse Edie Windsor, whom she married in Toronto Canada in 2007 after 41 years of living together, by her Netherlands cousins, and by her loving friends and former and current patients. A memorial service will be held May 10, location to be announced.
WATER A Change in Tone

TUCKER-->Richard F.,of Fairfield, CT, and Nantucket, MA. Cornell University mourns the loss of a dedicated alumnus and loyal friend, Richard F. "Dick" Tucker. Dick was a tireless volunteer who served as a member of the Board of Trustees, a Presidential Councillor, and a longtime member of both the Weill Cornell Medical College's Board of Overseers and the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art Advisory Council. A member of the Class of 1950, Dick was a loyal supporter and benefactor of his alma mater, the College of Engineering, but he extended his interest and leadership as well to the university's museum, medical school, and business school. Dick's devotion and service to Cornell University will provide enduring inspiration to his peers on the Board of Trustees, his fellow alumni, and to the entire Cornell community. We express our sincere condolences to his wife, Genevieve M. "Gen" Tucker, and to their children, Jocelyn R. Tucker Pearson and Jeffrey P. Tucker. Peter C. The drivers pulled into the lot of the Department of Motor Vehicles office here, momentarily stymied by the empty parking spaces, then sprinted through the drizzle toward the door, only to be met with one dispiriting word: Closed. In the starkest example of the intensifying budget crisis befalling most states, more than 200,000 California state workers were ordered to stay home Friday, the first of the semimonthly work furloughs across state agencies intended to trim $1.3 billion from California's $143 billion budget.

SIEGELBAUM--Ruth D.,on Thursday, February 5, 2009, Ruth D. Siegelbaum of New York and Arlington, VA. Beloved Wife of the Late Jack Siegelbaum; Devoted mother of Dee and Lewis Lord; Loving Grandmother of Charlie and Dinah Lord. Interment services will be held on Sunday, February 8 at 2pm at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY. Memorial Contributions may be made to the Arthritis Foundation. Services by Edward Sagel Funeral Direction.

Dewey Martin, the drummer for Buffalo Springfield, the short-lived but influential 1960s California rock band that spawned the careers of Neil Young and Stephen Stills, was found dead on Feb. 1 in his apartment in Van Nuys, Calif. He was 68. A roommate found his body , a friend, Lisa Lenes, told The Los Angeles Times. The cause has not been determined, the newspaper said; Ms. Lenes said he had had health problems in recent years.

GREEN--Paul. The Board of Directors of 885 Park Avenue Corp. mourns the loss of Chairman Paul Green. He was a devoted member of the Board and cherished neighbor for over forty years. The Board depended on his wise counsel, extensive knowledge of the real estate industry, and intimate history of the building. We also appreciated his dry humor, sophistication, insightful assessment of current events, and his sincere concern for his neighbors. We and the tenant shareholders will miss him profoundly. Our most sincere condolences to Alice, Vivian, Linda, Richard and the family. The Board of Directors 885 Park Avenue Corp.

Mitsubishi UFJ Financial, Japan's biggest bank, cut its full-year earnings outlook, saying it expected net income of 50 billion yen ($555.5 million), for the year ending March 31, rather than the 220 billion yen that it had previously forecast. The revision, it said, was mainly the result of write-down of equity securities caused by a drop in stock prices. The company lost 134.1 billion yen (about $1.49 billion) last quarter, in contrast to a net profit of 57.9 billion yen a year earlier. Write-downs were about 400 billion yen, it said.

A final collection of poetry by John Updike, composed over the last eight years of his life and assembled weeks before his death, will be released by Alfred A. Knopf on April 5, the publisher said in an e-mail message. Though better known for his prose, Mr. Updike, the Pulitzer Prize- and National Book Award-winning author who died on Jan. 27, was also a prolific writer of poetry; his first collection of verse, ''Ex-Basketball Player,'' was published in 1957. The new collection, ''Endpoint and Other Poems,'' will include his recently published work ''Requiem,'' in which he playfully wrote that ''a shrug and tearless eyes'' would greet his passing, adding: ''The wide response will be, I know,/'I thought he died a while ago.' '' Another posthumous work by Mr. Updike, ''My Father's Tears and Other Stories,'' is scheduled for publication in June.

HERSHCOPF--Elaine, nee Yeckes, 80. Adored wife, beloved mother and grandmother, she was an elegant, gracious and caring woman, a generous hostess and superb cook, who devoted herself tirelessly to her family, yet still found time to work as a volunteer for organizations such as Hadassah, the United Nations Hospitality Committee and Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. Known for her great beauty, creativity, and extraordinary sense of style, she brought these skills and a great deal of kindness and compassion to her work with cancer patients in the "Look Good Feel Better" program at Sloan Kettering. A graduate of Mount Ida College, she attended NYU and the Tobe Coburn School of Fashion. She will be remembered and mourned by her husband of over 58 years, Gerald T. Hershcopf, her daughter and son-in-law, Jane and Donald Schreck, her grandson, Sam Schreck and her sister-in-law, Judith Banki. Contributions can be made in Elaine's memory to Memorial Sloan Kettering.

“Coraline” the movie opened on Friday; “Coraline” the musical is in the works. MCC Theater has just announced a bit of unconventional casting news for its stage adaptation of the graphic novel by Neil Gaiman. Jayne Houdyshell, 55, who was nominated for a Tony award for her performance in “Well,” will play the 9 year-old Coraline, who wishes for a better a life and finds a parallel universe that holds great promise (until she gets to know her new parents.) David Greenspan wrote the book and will also play the creepy Other Mother. The music and lyrics are by Stephin Merritt, of the Magnetic Fields, and Leigh Silverman is the director. Previews begin May 7 at the Lucille Lortel Theater (www.mcctheater.org). MCC has also announced that its current production, “The Third Story” by Charles Busch, starring Mr. Busch and Kathleen Turner, has been extended a week and will now close on March 6. … The Irish Repertory Theater’s revival of “Aristocrats,” Brian Friel’s play about the decline of a formerly patrician Irish family, has been extended for three weeks. The production, directed by Charlotte Moore, will run through March 29 at the Chelsea theater (irishrep.org). … John Leguizamo is in the midst of a new work in progress called, well, “Work in Progress,” that will be presented at the Barrow Street Theater Feb. 27 through March 11. Mr. Leguizamo, the creator of solo shows including “Freak” and “Sexaholix,” will try out new material in front of an audience and seek help coming up with a title, too. “Watch me trip up and mess up and you can twitter it to your friends,” reads a message from the performer on the theater’s Web site, barrowstreettheatre.com.

Moviegoers were into seeing the new romantic comedy “He’s Not That Into You” over the weekend. The Warner Brothers movie, starring an ensemble cast including Bradley Cooper, Ginnifer Goodwin and Scarlett Johansson, took the top spot at the weekend box office, earning $27.5 million in its first week in theaters, according to figures released by the box-office tracking firm Media by Numbers. The first-place film last week, the action movie “Taken” (20th Century Fox), starring Liam Neeson, fell to second place, earning $20.3 million (and a total of $53.4 million to date). New movies took the third and fourth spots, starting with “Coraline” (Focus) the animated feature based on a novel by Neil Gaiman. The tale of a young girl who wishes for a better life and learns to be careful what she wishes for earned $16.3 million. In fourth place was the sequel comedy “Pink Panther 2” (Columbia) starring Steve Martin, which earned $11.8 million. “Paul Blart: Mall Cop” (Columbia) continued a four-week run in the top five but fell from second place to fifth, making $11 million over the weekend, for a $97 million cumulative total.

Last week we came to the section on academic freedom in my course on the law of higher education and I posed this hypothetical to the students: Suppose you were a member of a law firm or a mid-level executive in a corporation and you skipped meetings or came late, blew off assignments or altered them according to your whims, abused your colleagues and were habitually rude to clients. What would happen to you?
Cheryl Ziegler, an 18-year-old single mother from the Lower Brule Sioux Reservation in South Dakota, travels with her trainer to an amateur boxing match and dreams of going pro.
The trainer Ray Hawk formed a professional boxing network to give American Indians a chance to rise above lives of hardship.

Salmonella-laced peanut butter from a plant in Georgia has sickened an estimated 19,000 people in 43 states, killing eight. The owner of the plant, the Peanut Corporation of America, is under federal criminal investigation for knowingly selling contaminated products. More than 1,000 products have been pulled from store shelves, making this one of the largest food recalls in the nation's history.

The best part of the evening was Mickey Rourke's acceptance of the Leading Actor award for "The Wrestler." His hair looked as if it had been brushed with a pitchfork, while his clothes appeared as if they had spent several days bunched up on the floor among discarded pizza crusts and half-smoked Cuban cigars, only to be randomly excavated at the last minute when it became clear that their owner could not advance naked into the rain. Complementing his "Pirates of the Caribbean" aesthetic, Mr. Rourke wore sunglasses even though it was dark outside and not that bright inside. His shoes were shiny and black; so was his shirt. Several chains emerged from beneath his jacket and then looped down one pants leg, possibly for decorative reasons.

In the end, Kate Winslet kept it together when she collected the Leading Actress award for "The Reader" this evening at the BAFTA awards. She did have to bang her hand on the lectern several times in order to compose herself, but she pulled it off without collapsing, and showed that has a sense of humor by making a little joke at her own expense.

Collender says that in the months ahead there will be several opportunities to introduce new spending in a way that isn't subject to a filibuster.

"Slumdog Millionaire" continued its steady accumulation of movie awards, chalking up another seven prizes including best film at the Orange British Academy Film Awards, held at London's Royal Opera House in Covent Garden on Sunday. The film, adapted by Simon Beaufoy from the novel "Q & A," by Vikas Swarup, also won BAFTAs for best director (Danny Boyle), best adapted screenplay, best music, best cinematography, best editing and best sound. While "Slumdog" - about a poor young man in Mumbai who competes on a lucrative television game show - was the big winner of the night, "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" took three BAFTAs (for production design, makeup and hair, and special visual effects). Kate Winslet was the winner for leading actress for her performance in "The Reader" and Mickey Rourke won best actor for "The Wrestler." In the supporting actor categories, Penélope Cruz won for "Vicky Cristina Barcelona" and Heath Ledger won another posthumous prize for his eerie turn as the Joker in "The Dark Knight."

There are few things so humbling as arriving at a fancy party in which the paparazzi guarding the entrance like ravening pitbulls greet you with angry admonitions to hurry up and move away from the celebrities (especially when they do it in tough British accents). But that is what it was like at a party at the luxury store Asprey's in London on Saturday, held for the people nominated for the BAFTA film awards.

Norway became the 12th and last nation to qualify for the 2010 Olympics by overcoming a stubborn Denmark, 5-3, in the final Group G qualifier in Oslo on Sunday. Former N.H.L.'er and current HC Lugano star Patrick Thoresen had a hat trick as the hosts fought back from 0-1 and 1-2 deficits. In the second period Thoresen's second goal tied the score, and his third later in the period gave Norway a lead they never relinquished. His third goal, at 56:36, made it 5-3 and shut the door on courageous Denmark's Olympic dreams.

John Tavares missed Saturday night's game against Barrie and will not play Sunday when London visits Owen Sound in Ontario Hockey League action. According to TSN.ca, Tavares sprained an acromioclavicular joint in a shoulder when he was hit by Windsor's Taylor Hall on Friday night.

President Obama and his economic team will present their multibillion plan to bailout some of the nation's troubled banks on Tuesday, delaying the announcement by one day to avoid a collision with the administration's economic stimulus plan in Congress.

History | Bush may be remembered with "the same tincture of admiration and regret" as Woodrow Wilson is, an article says. "After all, Wilson is the only other American president who had a faith-based foreign policy, who asserted the president's absolute primacy over Congress in foreign affairs, who initiated a crusade 'to make the world safe for democracy.' " Wilson, like Bush, dramatically expanded government. And Wilson presided over a campaign against domestic radicals, "left his party in a shambles, and the country in a virulent 18-month recession." [Economic Principals]

Terror | A psychologist who helped design an interrogation model for terrorist suspects at Guantánamo says there's a better way than torture to get information out of Muslim radicals, who expect to die anyway: "put them in some type of conflict consistent with their culture and their commitment to Islam ... If you develop a rapport with a member of a socially reflected shame-based society, they will talk and communicate." [Foreign Policy]

Lexicon | "Porkulus" is opponents' word for the economic stimulus bill now before Congress, a conflation of "pork" and "stimulus." A Nexis database search finds nearly 70 citations in major news sources since Jan. 28 and none before (with this legislative meaning). Google News shows a similar spike, especially this weekend. The word's currency is attributed to Rush Limbaugh: "On his show Wednesday [Jan. 28], Limbaugh called it the 'porkulus' package, for all the pork-barrel projects he saw in it." [San Francisco Chronicle, Jan. 29; Google]

Haynesfield moved closer to a Triple Crown race, easily winning the $107,600 Whirlaway Stakes for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. The victory was the fourth in a row for Haynesfield, a New York-bred colt trained by Steve Asmussen. Haynesfield ran 1 minute 44.48 seconds for the mile-and-a-sixteenth race. ¶Pioneerof the Nile rallied to win the $200,000 Robert B. Lewis Stakes and give trainer Bob Baffert a Kentucky Derby candidate. The colt won his 3-year-old debut by a half-length over Papa Clem at Santa Anita. pioneerof (AP).

Germany’s ice hockey team qualified for the Vancouver Olympics by edging Austria, 2-1, in Frankfurt. The victory guaranteed that Germany would top the four-team qualifying tournament in Hannover, where only the winner advances.
Reliever Shawn Camp, who had filed for salary arbitration, and the Toronto Blue Jays agreed Saturday on a one-year, $750,000 contract.

Reliever George Sherrill and the Baltimore Orioles agreed to terms on a one-year, $2.75 million contract Saturday, avoiding arbitration. Sherrill made the American League All-Star team in 2008, going 3-5 with a 4.73 earned run average and 31 saves. He threw two and a third scoreless innings in the All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium. He had sought $3.4 million after earning $1 million last season.
Nationals pitcher Shawn Hill won his salary arbitration case Saturday when a panel awarded him the $775,000 contract he sought instead of the $500,000 the team offered.
Jenn Stuczynski, the Olympic silver medalist in the women’s pole vault, cleared 15 feet 9 ¾ inches to break a six-year-old American mark and win the Boston Indoor Games for the third straight year.

Three Houston police officers who were accused of beating the father of Green Bay Packers wide receiver Donald Driver have filed a defamation lawsuit, saying Marvin Driver Jr. and activist Quanell X made false statements about Driver’s November arrest.
Top-seeded Jo-Wilfried Tsonga will face Jérémy Chardy in an all-French final at the South African Tennis Open in Johannesburg.

Walt Henning, a native of South Huntington, N.Y., and a sophomore at Louisiana State, set a meet record of 72 feet 8 ½ inches in winning the 35-pound weight throw at the Collegiate Invitational at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Manhattan. Renaud Lavillenie, a college student in France, set a meet record in the pole vault at 18-8 1/4.

Dante Cunningham matched a career high with 31 points and No. 17 Villanova rolled to its fifth straight win, 102-85 at home over No. 20 Syracuse on Saturday. The Wildcats (19-4, 7-3 Big East) got off to a sizzling start from the floor and led by 20 late in the first half. The Wildcats reached their highest point total ever in a game against Syracuse and hit the 100-point mark for the second time this season. In the first half, the Orange (18-6, 6-5) went nearly 10 minutes without a field goal and committed 13 turnovers that led to 21 Villanova points. ¶Jessica Morrow scored 17 points, Jhasmin Player added 16 points and No. 8 Baylor pulled away late to beat No. 18 Kansas State, 59-50, on Saturday. Baylor (19-3, 7-2 Big 12) snapped a two-game home losing streak in which it lost to No. 2 Oklahoma and No. 16 Texas.

The Charlotte Bobcats’ starting shooting guard Raja Bell will miss at least two games with a groin injury. Bell strained his right groin late in the third quarter of Charlotte’s loss to Atlanta on Friday. Bell, who missed five games just over a month go with a similar injury, said Saturday that he would not play Sunday at Miami or Monday against the Los Angeles Clippers.

An article on Jan. 25 about Pope Benedict XVI’s revoking the excommunication of four schismatic bishops referred incorrectly to the use of a Good Friday prayer that calls for the conversion of Jews. The prayer is part of a service — not a Mass — on Good Friday, according to a traditional version of the Latin Mass, known as the Tridentine rite. (No Mass is said on Good Friday.).

Because of an editing error, excerpts of an interview last Sunday with the artist Emily Jacir erroneously attributed part of a quotation to her when she was asked about Wael Zuaiter, a Palestinian intellectual whose killing in 1972 inspired one of Ms. Jacir’s works. She was quoting the Italian novelist Alberto Moravia when she said in the interview, conducted by e-mail, that Mr. Zuaiter’s “dominant characteristic was his sheer benevolence towards everyone and everything. This seemed to me a rare and precious quality, especially when I remembered that he was Palestinian and therefore had many reasons for allowing himself to resort to violence. But he rejected violence, absolutely.” The words beginning with the phrase “This seemed to me” were not Ms. Jacir’s.

Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 25 about the forthcoming film adaptation of “Sherlock Holmes” misidentified the character that Susan Downey, a producer on the film and the wife of its star, Robert Downey Jr., described as “a bit of a ladies man, a bit of a brawler” and as having “a gambling problem.” Ms. Downey was referring to Dr. John Watson, not Sherlock Holmes.

In the various lines of research described by Daniel Bergner in his account of investigations into female desire (Jan. 25), it is interesting that almost all of the stimuli presented to female subjects come in the form of photographs or film and video. Theorists of art and visual culture have long recognized that vision is not simply a neutral, physiological act, and that the act of filming or photographing encodes gendered forms of looking.

As someone who worked for many years in the insurance industry and who suffered a total loss on a car, I can say that comparing the stained clothes paid for by the company of the worker who caused the damage with a damaged car is not apt (The Ethicist, Jan. 25). If the clothes were not repairable, the proper comparison is a car that is considered a total loss. In that case, the insurance company is indeed entitled to the salvage. After you receive payment for your loss, you cannot then sell the salvage to the local junkyard. The insurance company will most certainly take what remains of the car.

To the Editor: I was disappointed by the description of Tobago in your article “Affordable Caribbean” (Jan. 25) as a “dusty little island.” On the contrary, tiny Tobago is well-known as a nature lover’s paradise. It is home to all major ecosystems, including lowland forests, wetlands and coral reefs, as well as a 10,000-hectare (24,710 acres) tropical rain forest, which has been legally protected since 1765. There are also more than 200 species of “precious birds,” some found only in Tobago.

To the Editor: In his article “Cathedrals of the Iron Horse” (Jan. 18), Simon Winchester cites Oakland’s 16th Street Station as the best example of train station abandonment. He has apparently never visited the Michigan Central Station in Detroit (below). It’s a grand Beaux-Arts, neo-Classical palace designed in 1913 by Warren & Wetmore and Reed & Stem, the same architectural firms that designed Grand Central Terminal. Since it closed over 20 years ago, the station has sat abandoned and in ruins. If Oakland’s new station is a “shed,” Detroit’s is a shack. In Detroit, the contrast between the old and the new as an illustration of the demise of rail travel in this country is truly breathtaking.

HOW annoying. It took a man to realize there was something missing from women's lingerie. ''High-end lingerie isn't really suitable for every day,'' said Matthias Jaschke, the creator of the Wundervoll line, based in Berlin. ''It's too elaborate. I saw the need for underwear that is both high-quality and comfortable, and still very sexy.'' The year-old label, which just became available in the United States, includes modern, clean-lined pieces with intelligent hints of sex appeal: high-waist briefs that arch into a thong in back, balconette bras with slinky straps, and delicately structured camisoles -- all cut from superfine organic cotton and silk jersey, produced by Mr. Jaschke's family business. Had Helmut Lang, the master of minimalist cool, designed lingerie, it might look like this.

GREEN--Paul, Esq.,passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his loved ones on February 4, at the age of 86. Dearly beloved husband to Alice for 57 years, loving father to Vivien, Linda, and Richard, devoted father-in-law to Harvey and Judi, and proud grandfather of Daniel, Carly, and James. Born in Vienna, Austria, he came to New York City when he was fourteen, and excelled in his academic pursuits at New York University and New York Law School. In 1947, a few years after graduating law school he became a single practitioner and in 1951 started his own law firm, Green & Ettinger, with his friend Joseph Ettinger. He was a practicing attorney for nearly 65 years and loved his work. The New York County Lawyers Association honored him recently as the second longest-standing member since he joined in 1944. In addition to his law practice, Paul owned and managed real estate throughout the United States. He was a superb dealmaker, negotiator and advisor, and many of his clients and partners became his closest friends. All his life, Paul had an intense interest in history, politics and geography. He was an avid learner and a gifted teacher. He was also a member of NYCLA's Real Property Section for over 20 years and Secretary of NYCLA's Committee on Professional Discipline since 1991. In addition to his many legal committees, Paul was a longtime Trustee at Beth Israel Hospital. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, February 8, 2009 at 11:30am at Frank Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY 10028. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Beth Israel Hospital or American Jewish Committee. He will be forever loved and missed by all his family and countless friends.

I find it really funny when I hear people say, ''You get anything you want because you are an athlete.'' The best, though, is: ''Everything is much easier for you because you are an athlete.'' Those ideas have to be put to rest. I'm sure many athletes would say they would love to be just a student -- to sleep in, go to class, work for a few hours, and then spend time with their peers at school functions and activities. Regular students don't appreciate that freedom. In fact, the majority probably would struggle with an athlete's schedule.

THE NEWS As he urged a gathering of House Democrats to pass his proposed stimulus bill, President Obama warned them, ''If we do not move swiftly, an economy that is in crisis will be faced with catastrophe.'' BEHIND THE NEWS He sketched the kind of calamity he had in mind: ''Millions more Americans will lose their jobs. Homes will be lost. Families will go without health care. Our crippling dependence on foreign oil will continue.'' His impatience grew as the Senate dickered over the plan before reaching an accord Friday night: ''It is inexcusable and irresponsible to get bogged down in distraction and delay while millions of Americans are being put out of work.''

FULFORD--David. Leading Summer Stock Director and Producer David Fulford, a leading force in Summer Theater in its heyday from the mid 1950s to the mid 1980s died in New York City on January 20, 2009. He was 83 year old. In 1954, Mr. Fulford started a small summer stock company in an old barn in Canal Fulton, Ohio. Hiring young New York actors in his first season, he soon discovered that one needed name actors to attract audiences, so, working through Hollywood agents, he began hiring an older generation of film and television stars such as Van Johnson, Betty Grable, Nanette Fabray, George Hamilton and Mickey Rooney. As opposed to the 'star package' policy of other summer theaters, he engaged stars on an individual basis, produced a play of their choice and cast the secondary roles with members of his company. So successful was this plan, he soon abandoned his barn and built, also in Canal Fulton, a state of the art theater, complete with swimming pool. He also opened the Carousel Dinner Theater in 1976 in Ravenna, Ohio, where he produced popular musicals of the day. Mr. Fulford produced and directed three major Off-Broadway productions <-- "Moon in the Yellow River", "Colombe" and "Fashion", starring Will Greer and Enid Markey, which won the Vernon Rice Award in 1959. He ventured into the film industry directing and writing the screen plays "Excuse Me For Living", "The Prince of Terror" and "The Haunted Mansion". Charles David Fulford was born in Newport News, Virginia, on August 31, 1925, and grew up in Barberton, Ohio. He served as a Navy Ensign in WWII and as a Naval Lieutenant in the Korean War. He attended the Yale Drama School, Carnegie-Mellon University and graduated from the New School for Social Research where he subsequently taught "Introduction to Voice Over" from 1989 to the end of 2008. After retiring from his summer stock career, he returned to his first profession of acting, studying with Uta Hagen and appearing in several Off-Off- Broadway plays. Mr. Fulford is survived by long time companions Everett Susco of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio and Patricia O'Grady of New York City; niece Nancy Thrams of Cleveland, Ohio; and nephews Guy Thrams of Lexington, Ohio and Benjamin Thrams of Mansfield, Ohio.

GALLAGHER--William J.,age 80, of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida passed away February 3, 2009. He was born on November 17, 1928 in Middle Village, New York. He proudly served in the United States Army. William started his business career in advertising at the Chain Store Age and then as a Senior Representative for Pollack Printing, Buffalo, NY. He later founded his own successful printing company, The Production Group Inc. William was Vice President of the New York Advertising Club. He was a member of Plandome Country Club, Mid Ocean Club, Old Marsh Golf Club and the Old Guard Society in West Palm Beach for over 25 years. William was preceded in death by his son William. He leaves behind to cherish his memory: his loving wife of 59 years, Susan; daughters Barbara (Mark) Boisi, Stacey (Jonathan) Clark, Kim (Michael) Walsh; daughter-in-law Barbara Gallagher; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

OUTPOSTS When home-office hobbyists could flip a tract house every six months and walk away with a sweat-free windfall, no one would have minded if, say, Countrywide Financial was paying exotic dancers to sort M&Ms on the corporate jet of its chief executive, Angelo Mozilo. But after Countrywide collapsed, and more than 12,000 people lost their jobs and many more lost their life savings, Mr. Mozilo was a pariah. How could he stand to make $110 million in total severance (later reduced) after driving the nation's largest home lender into the ground? Class resentment, like race, is always there in American life, though often smothered by the surface calm of good times. It was considered unfashionable, or worse, to point out that by 2006 total compensation for chief executives of the largest companies was 364 times that of the pay of the average worker, a nearly tenfold increase in the salary gap over 30 years.

One man died Saturday after more than 100 ice fishermen who had ventured a mile out from the western shores of Lake Erie were rescued from an eight-mile-long portion of ice that had broken away amid warming conditions and starting drifting north. The man, whom the authorities identified as Leslie Love, 65, of New Albany, Ohio, fell into the water as he rode his snowmobile while looking for a path to the shore. He died, apparently of a heart attack, when he was being airlifted to the hospital, the sheriff in Ottawa County, Ohio, said.

PARKER--Milton, of the world famous Carnegie Deli passed away January 30th. He was 90 years old. Milton took over the deli operations in 1976. He was well-known for his wonderful personality, beautiful smile, gargantuan sandwiches and "that the customer was always right". The business is still being run today by his son-in-law Sanford Levine. Milton was well loved by his Carnegie Deli family and people throughout the United States and the world and he will be greatly missed. He wrote the book How to Feed Friends and Influence People. Devoted husband to his wife Mildred of 62 years, loving father to his children Marian Levine, his son Jeffrey Parker, his brother Irving and loving grandfather to granddaughter Sarri. Donations in his name can be made to the City of Hope, Nob Hill Chapter.

CONVINCED that seasonal dressing is a thing of the past, the Bottega Veneta designer Tomas Maier opened his spring collection with a series of leather pieces: a pinafore, a T-shirt, a paper-bag-waist skirt in warm saffrons and chestnut. This was his idea of investment dressing (that skirt? $5,700); and from the looks of the spring runways, he was not alone. Leather, in its many incarnations, showed up at Marc Jacobs, Proenza Schouler, Rodarte and Givenchy. And though it all looked cool, the skirts in particular seemed the most practical. Wear them with tights and a fitted sweater now; bare legs and a T-shirt in spring. ''There are so many things you can do with leather,'' said Camilla Staerk, who incorporates it into each of her collections. ''That's the reason why I love it. It's something you can easily make hard, and something that can have a soft, feminine feel as well.''

Donations can be made in his memory to either the Cancer Research Institute or to the Nature Conservancy.

THAW--Jack Alvin. Beloved father and friend Jack Alvin Thaw, of White Plains NY, died at home on January 29th 2009. He was 78 years old. Born Brooklyn NY on February 9th 1930, only son of Henry Thaw and Jesse Thaw (Cantor). Graduated Midwood High School in 1948, played varsity basketball; attended Syracuse University. Married Beverly Wolkoff in 1954, divorced in 1971. Worked with father in the family business, The Washington Arms Restaurant, Mamaroneck, NY; in commercial real estate at Julien J Studley, NYC; and served as a teachers' aide in Bronxville schools. His children and grandchildren were his greatest pride. Loved tennis, avid sports fan and chronicler, lover of music and literature. Jack, you will be missed. A memorial will be held Monday February 9, 10am to 1pm, remarks and prayer at 12pm noon at the Harrison Funeral Home, 329 Halstead Avenue, Harrison NY. Friends and family are welcome. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the New York Junior Tennis League, a charity founded by Arthur Ashe.

WITH her elegant, almost ecclesiastical creations, Valentina was one of the seminal designers of the 20th century, pioneering a chic American aesthetic that rivaled Parisian haute couture. Though in her day the exquisite Russian émigré shared the spotlight with clients like Katharine Hepburn and Greta Garbo (with whom she also shared her husband), Valentina has been largely overlooked in the half-century since she closed her doors. Shame, really. Not only are her designs strikingly relevant in their simplicity, but the woman was a character. ''You want bows?'' she once chastised her client Kitty Carlisle Hart. ''Go to Macy's!'' This week, Rizzoli will release the first book dedicated to her life and career, and her first retrospective will open at the Museum of the City of New York. Among the items on view: clothing from her personal couture collection; a taped interview with Edward R. Murrow, in which she flirtingly transforms the dress she's wearing; and an old passport with an impeccably polished photo of her shot by Horst P. Horst.

BEING DOUSED AT TI KWEN GLO CHO HOT SPRINGS, WOTTON WAVEN, DOMINICA, DEC. 27 John-Francis Bourke, left, a photographer from Brooklyn. ''My mom passed away last March, and since I usually go home to Ireland to spend Christmas with her, I needed to do something totally different. So I Googled 'remote undeveloped Caribbean island,' and this is what I came up with -- honestly, true story. I've always traveled with friends or girlfriends who need to see everything, who really need to digest the destination. I found it all too tiring, because New York is so exhausting every day. I always fantasized about going somewhere where I could sit alone. So I did a lot of sitting in Dominica. At the springs, bamboo pipes channel the hot water from the side of the mountain into the cast-iron tubs. All the bathtubs are vintage -- probably not a word they use in Dominica -- but they're really ancient, I would imagine from old plantation homes or other old-style homes. The water has a bit of a metallic taste. I don't know if it's from the mineral salts or from the tub, I have really no clue.'' As told to Seth Kugel
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

FELDMAN--Ernest, of Great Neck, NY and Florida died peacefully on January 31, 2009. He was the devoted husband for 64 years of Ray who died on May 31, 2008. He was a liquor industry executive with an extraordinary ability for marketing. After graduating from New York University in 1943, he went to work for Schenley Distillers Company where he worked his way up to President. In 1968 he joined Somerset Importers and remained there until he retired in 1986. He was a justly renowned liquor industry spokesperson and a national keynote speaker frequently on "the importance of new products for the growth of the economy". Ernie was a man of vision and integrity. He was a veteran of WWII, a member of the economic round table of Boca Raton, and volunteered at SCORE counseling individuals on opening new businesses. He is the beloved father of Elyse Feldman and Susan Greene (Richard), grandfather of Victoria Greene and Emily Nussbaum (Scott) and great-grandfather of Annabel Nussbaum.

IT was announced last week that Christopher E. Bangle, the head of BMW design for 16 years, would leave his post. He supervised design for BMW, Mini and Rolls-Royce, and administered DesignworksUSA, BMW's subsidiary design agency. In an interview on Thursday, Mr. Bangle said his departure did not stem from differences with BMW. ''It has nothing to do with how the company works inside or with me,'' he said, adding that he intended to form his own company or studio. ''It was a moment I have been planning for a long time.''

SHEMIN--Emanuel ''Manny'', 78, of Greenwich, CT and Boca Raton, FL died of leukemia at Johns Hopkins Hospital on January 28. He died peacefully surrounded by his family. Manny was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Air Force in the Korean War and also served as a Major in the Reserves for 18 years. He received his B.S. from Syracuse University, where he also met wife Rhoda. In 1968, he moved the small Bronx family business begun by his father, to Greenwich, CT, and founded Shemin Nurseries, creating the nation's first ''one stop'' wholesale nursery distribution center, expanding it worldwide to over 30 distribution centers in the U.S. and Holland. Manny remained on its Board of Directors and as special consultant to the president until his death. Manny took a strong interest in encouraging development of Israel's agricultural industry to focus on high-value products competitive on world markets. With partner Dr. Issac Nir, he co-founded Genesis Seeds in the Negev, pioneering one of the largest organic seed producers in the world, literally making the desert bloom. He established an agribusiness course at The Hebrew University in Jerusalem, and in April 2006 was awarded the Certificate of Honor by its Agricultural Science faculty, for long-term contributions to agricultural research, and education of generations of scientists. Manny also served as an advisor to Israel's Ministry of Agriculture, including consulting with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. He also endowed a scholarship fund in Israel to train agriculturalists in the latest business and scientific techniques. Manny served on the Board of Trustees of Syracuse University for 16 years and on its Executive Committee for nine years. He established an entrepreneurship program for veterans at Syracuse's Whitman School of Management. He also served on the Board of Temple Sholom in Greenwich. In Florida, he and Rhoda sponsored annual Shemin Trialogue forums at Florida Atlantic University to foster communication between Christians, Muslims and Jews. He was a Trustee of the Boca Raton Museum of Art. Manny is survived by Rhoda, his wife of 57 years; his four daughters Sara Cass, Suzanne Katz, Grace Goldstein, and Leslie Lester; 10 grandchildren; and sisters Elsie Roth and Ina Bass. Donations in his memory can be made to Johns Hopkins, Kimmel Cancer Center Leukemia Program, Attn: Ellen Stifler, 100 North Charles St., Suite 234, Baltimore, MD 21201

CERTAIN things are simply recession-proof. Isabel Marant's taupe suede boots with chains wrapped around the ankle are among them. The French designer, whose bohemian-cool clothing has a cult following, showed them with every look on her spring runway; they've since become a sensation of sorts, selling out before they even hit stores. ''They're insanely out of control,'' said Nevena Borissova of the SoHo boutique Curve. Her shipment doesn't arrive until later this month, but already she has sold half of it. ''Tan boots are a big trend for spring,'' Ms. Borissova said. ''And these are the best of them.'' Isabel Marant boots, about $1,050 at Curve, 83 Mercer Street; (212) 966-3626.

SPYER--Thea C.,an extraordinary woman, died peacefully Thursday, February 5 at age 77 from aortic stenosis. Dr. Spyer earned her Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from Adelphi University. She interned at St. Vincent's Hospital, NYC and Veterans Administration, NYC and she later became Director of the Psychiatric Clinic at the International Center for the Disabled and was Clinical Consultant in Rehabilitation at St. Vincent's Hospital, Westchester before concentrating exclusively on her private practice. She was born to Elisabeth Ketellapper and Willem Spyer in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, and immigrated to the US States during World War II. Thea was an avid violinist, and golfer and dancer before she was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis. She reinvented herself every year of advancing physical disability to stay active and working and joyous in her life. Told of her death, friends offered the following adjectives: vibrant, witty, courageous, compassionate, insightful, resolute, and beautiful; the epitome of intrepid brilliance. She is survived by her spouse Edie Windsor, whom she married in Toronto Canada in 2007 after 41 years of living together, by her Netherlands cousins, and by her loving friends and former and current patients. A memorial service will be held May 10, location to be announced.

HERSHCOPF--Elaine, nee Yeckes, 80. Adored wife, beloved mother and grandmother, she was an elegant, gracious and caring woman, a generous hostess and superb cook, who devoted herself tirelessly to her family, yet still found time to work as a volunteer for organizations such as Hadassah, the United Nations Hospitality Committee and Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. Known for her great beauty, creativity, and extraordinary sense of style, she brought these skills and a great deal of kindness and compassion to her work with cancer patients in the "Look Good Feel Better" program at Sloan Kettering. A graduate of Mount Ida College, she attended NYU and the Tobe Coburn School of Fashion. She will be remembered and mourned by her husband of over 58 years, Gerald T. Hershcopf, her daughter and son-in-law, Jane and Donald Schreck, her grandson, Sam Schreck and her sister-in-law, Judith Banki. Contributions can be made in Elaine's memory to Memorial Sloan Kettering.

Amid all the dancing pregnant women and duets with Disney stars at the Grammy Awards, some actual news occurred, too: the punk rock band Blink-182 announced that it would reunite. On stage to present the award for best rock album, the band members Mark Hoppus, Tom DeLonge and Travis Barker said they would be getting back together; a statement on the band’s Web site, blink182.com, said: “To put it simply, we’re back. We mean, really back.” The trio, which recorded hit songs like “All the Small Things” and “What’s My Age Again?”, played its last live show together in 2004; Mr. Barker and Mr. Hoppus formed a new band called +44 while Mr. DeLonge started his own group, Angels & Airwaves. No tour dates or recording plans for the reunited group were announced.

Cahiers du Cinéma, the singularly influential French film journal, has found a new home: the magazine has been acquired by the book publisher Phaidon Press, the publisher said in a news release. Founded in 1951 by André Bazin, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze and Joseph-Marie Lo Duca and edited by Eric Rohmer, Cahiers du Cinéma was a crucible for writers-turned-New Wave directors like Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard, and a vocal advocate of filmmakers including Alfred Hitchcock, Howard Hawks, Jean Renoir and Jean Cocteau. In 1988 its parent company was acquired by the newspaper Le Monde, leading to a much-criticized makeover of the magazine in 1999; in April, Le Monde said it would seek a new owner for Cahiers du Cinéma as part of a corporate reorganization. In addition to acquiring the monthly magazine, Phaidon Press said it would also take over the book publishing division of Cahiers du Cinéma.

At the Grammy Awards on Sunday night, all eyes were on the duo of Robert Plant and Alison Krauss, who took five prizes for their album, “Raising Sand.” But it was also a big night for Ms. Krauss in particular, whose winnings took her to a career total of 26 Grammys.

Every now and then someone suggests they may have uncovered the oldest known photograph of New York City. The latest example is a 4-by-5 1/4 inch daguerreotype image of a rural estate on what Sotheby’s conjectures is the old Bloomingdale Road (a site that would fall today within the Upper West Side of Manhattan). The auction house, which is to sell the photograph on March 30, has invited experts to take a look in the meantime.

The board of the Screen Actors Guild voted on Sunday to formally fire its former executive director and chief negotiator, Doug Allen, who had already been removed by petition by a majority of board members. In doing so, the board hoped to eliminate questions concerning the legality of its earlier move to oust Mr. Allen, which resulted in a lawsuit against the union by its president, Alan Rosenberg, and three other board members. Last week, a California state judge refused to issue an injunction or restraining order preventing a new executive director and chief negotiator from taking office or negotiating on the union’s behalf with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents the major Hollywood studios. The two sides are expected to meet this month to restart contract negotiations, which have been dormant since November.

The Broadway musical “Shrek” made a substantial gain in box-office ticket sales last week, after a steady decline in its weekly grosses through the month of January. The production grossed $636,329 during the week of Feb. 2, an increase of $133,851 over its take in the previous week. That dollar gain was the largest for all Broadway shows last week. A producer of the show, Bill Damaschke, had predicted in a statement last week that “Shrek” grosses would improve, in part due to increased advance sales of tickets.

Officials from prominent museums in China and Taiwan are scheduled to have their first meetings in 60 years as part of an effort to improve tourism and increase cooperation between the institutions, Agence France-Presse reported. On Saturday, Chou Kung-shin, the director of Taipei National Palace Museum, will lead a delegation to Beijing, and on March 1 her counterpart at the Forbidden City’s Palace Museum will visit Taiwan. Much of the Taipei museum’s collection — more than 655,000 artifacts spanning 7,000 years — originally came from the Forbidden City, and was taken to Taiwan after the island split from China in 1949 following the Chinese civil war. But relations between the museums have improved since the election of the Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou; the Beijing museum has since agreed to lend 17 artifacts to the Taipei institution for a coming exhibition.

In late 2007, E. Stanley O'Neal stepped down as Merrill Lynch's chief executive, and a successor was named for Richard D. Parsons, Time Warner's chief at the time. The departures of two prominent African-American chief executives rekindled a debate about what barriers still exist for black executives seeking a corner office.

Gary Bettman has made his long-anticipated appearance on CBC's "The Hour With George Stroumboulopoulos," part of his ongoing media blitz, and CBC.ca has posted Bettman's entire unedited interview. In an emotional meeting on Monday morning with classmates of a Brooklyn high school student killed by gunfire, Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand vowed to go after illegal gun trafficking. Ms. Gillibrand had been invited to the school, Nazareth Regional High School in East Flatbush, by the principal, Barbara Gil, who had been sharply critical of the senator's past opposition to gun control as a member of the House of Representatives from upstate New York.The meeting lasted less than an hour. She told the student she would name legislation targeting illegal gun traffickers for Nyasia Pryear, 17, who was killed in a gang-related shooting at a student gathering in Bedford-Stuyvesant on Jan. 17.

The further we get from the Yankees' bizarre winter after the 2007 season, the more damaging that period becomes. The Yankees had a chance to take Alex Rodriguez up on his idea to opt out of his contract and explore free agency. They could have let him go and moved away from the constant drama around him. Instead they tied their fate to Rodriguez for another decade, for the declining years of his career and the expected bonanza of his chasing the career home run record.

The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday reached a partial settlement in its civil case against Bernard L. Madoff, the financier accused of masterminding a vast Ponzi scheme. The agreement, submitted to the federal judge overseeing the case, could eventually force him to pay a civil fine and return money raised from investors.

At General Motors he is known as the "product czar." His nickname is "Maximum Bob." His personal jet is an L-39 Albatross fighter plane. At the end of the year, Robert A. Lutz, one of the most visible automotive executives in Detroit -- and possibly the world -- will retire.
Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, T's fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.

"The Nation Guide to the Nation," by Richard Lingeman, was published last month, just in time for the inauguration of Barack Obama. According to the introduction, by the estimable Victor Navasky and the estimable Katrina vanden Heuvel, the book is intended for "people of the left-liberal-radical persuasion (the kind of people who read The Nation) who find themselves in some red state backwater hungering for kindred spirits, for community, for folks who'll help them organize an antiwar rally or a fund-raiser or a peace march or a discussion group or a food co-op." Or for folks who'll help them hook up: in the back of the book, under the heading "Sex ... Romance ... Love?," we learn about Act for Love, "an online matchmaking site for progressives. Its motto is: 'Activist? Leftist? Take action, get action!'"
Chelsea announced that Manager Luiz Felipe Scolari, after seven months in the job, is out at Stamford Bridge.

While some hedge fund managers have been left apologizing for their performance last year, those who lost less than 10 percent are breathing a sigh of relief.

Apple adds some pretty clever tricks to its updated iPhoto application, available on new Macs as a part of the iLife '09 suite, which also includes iMovie, GarageBand and iWeb. You can also purchase iLife for $79.

I never quite know what to do with tofu, and am always at risk of being deeply bored by it. But at $1.99 per pound, it's just too good a bargain too pass up. So on a recent night I threw caution -- and all respect for culinary traditions - out the window, and made a broiled tofu recipe that was a jigsaw puzzle of culinary influences -- broiled teriyaki-marinated tofu (Japanese) over chili-accented broccoli rabe (Italian) surrounded by a broth of soy-sauce-and-ginger-spiked chicken stock (Chinese), that I'd flavored with scallion oil (who knows?) -- the result was startlingly refreshing, and the farthest thing from boring. Not bad for $1.99 plus the cost of the broccoli rabe.

In the past week, we have had two excellent, though disturbing, must-read stories about the Merrill Lynch/Bank of America deal. One, in this Sunday's New York Times, was headlined "Love Was Blind" and written by Louise Story and Julie Creswell; the other, with the headline "In Merrill Deal, U.S. Played Hardball," was written by Dan Fitzpatrick, Susanne Craig and Deborah Solomon of The Wall Street Journal. The stories are bombshells.

Poetry | Natural adaptation, indeed. The British poet Ruth Padel, a great-great-granddaughter of Charles Darwin (born 200 years ago Thursday), renders his biography in a sequence of often brief poems -- "a difficult act of literary ventriloquism" that "embeds many of Darwin's own words." The technique works, though, a review says, since Darwin, throughout his life, "was in the grip of ... a terrible, destabilizing sense of wonder" and the best lyric poems, likewise, are "moments of epiphany." [Economist]

PARIS -- There's a scene in the movie "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade" where Harrison Ford as Indiana Jones is tied to a chair when the turncoat femme fatale plants a kiss on his lips and says "that's how we say goodbye in Austria." A thug then walks up to him and socks him in the nose, saying, "und zat's how vee zay goodbye in Germany!" Dr. Jones shakes off the punch and remarks: "I like the Austrian way better."

General Motors is in talks to reacquire parts of Delphi, the auto parts supplier it spun off a decade ago that is now in bankruptcy, a person with knowledge of the talks told DealBook.

It's been a cold winter this year -- and that's the way we like it. Cold, so you can go outside and skate and ski and play hockey and feel the snow on your face and hear the faint jingling of tiny crystals against the lake's bright frozen surface, wafted by the breeze.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg presented keys to the city on Monday to the five crew members of US Airways Flight 1549 who help guide a plane to a successful emergency landing on Jan. 15, with all 155 people on board surviving.In presenting the key to the pilot, Chesley B. Sullenberger III, Mr. Bloomberg called him "Captain Cool," as the pilot seemed calm in advance of the landing despite admitting to be terrified. He also lauded the captain by saying, "I wonder how many parents this month have named their newborns 'Sully,' " referring to the pilot's nickname.

Politics | "Obama's rise to power has, to many people's surprise, once again made patriotism a liberal faith." a columnist says. First, Bush policies jolted liberals to "take our country back." Then Obama blended "two of the most powerful and uplifting narratives in U.S. history" -- the immigrant and black ones -- to cast "Americanism with a tolerant, energetically populist hue," much as F.D.R. did. And so we heard the New Deal-ish "This Land Is Your Land" sung by Seeger and Springsteen for the inaugural. [Washington Post]

Technology | Why phone voice recognition gives you Beatrice instead of Pete Smith: You and everybody else are really hard to understand. With some 30 ways of saying "of," and nearly infinite spoken variants for more complex words, even the largest sound database is easy to fool. "There's not a speech recognizer today that you can't break by stretching out certain syllables." Then there's the problem of the context of speech. So, progress in vocal tech is kind of on hold. But we can put you through to Beatrice. [Wired]

Trisha Haas, who runs the blog MomDot.com, would love to have a second child. The plan, in last year's economy, was to have four. If times were better she would "be pregnant, or at least trying" by now, she says.

Weekend sweeps brought two contenders toward the top of their respective conferences. First, in the East, No. 10 Princeton took a swing through upstate New York and snuck past Colgate, 3-2, in overtime Friday, then scored twice in the final 36 seconds to knock off No. 5 Cornell, 2-1, at Lynah Rink on Saturday. Princeton is now just one point behind the Big Red for second place in the E.C.A.C.
Calgary defenseman Paul Postma set a team record for goals by a defenseman on Sunday as the Hitmen defeated the Kootenay Ice, 4-2, to clinch the Central Division of the Western Hockey League.

Updated | 12:20 p.m. In a new interview with the German news magazine Der Spiegel, Bishop Richard Williamson, the recently rehabilitated Catholic priest who told Swedish television that "not one" Jew had died in a Nazi gas chamber during World War II, says that he will "now review the historical evidence once again." But he will do so by reading a book about Auschwitz by a French pharmacist, not by visiting the death camp himself, he said. (Der Spiegel has posted an English translation of the interview online.)

"Slumdog Millionaire" had a very good night at the BAFTAs, winning picture, director, adapted screenplay, music, cinematography, editing and sound, while "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" settled for awards for production design, make-up and special visual effects. ("Slumdog" picked up hardware at the Writers Guild of America awards on Saturday as well.) As Sasha Stone and others have suggested, it is a narrative that will likely hold into the Oscars, with the emotional momentum behind "Slumdog" continuing to carry the day and the technical brilliance of "Button" delivering only a few of the smaller categories.
