Still, they behaved like poster children for enlightened capitalism. My supervisor reminded me unfailingly to take my mandatory two (paid) quarter-hour breaks during each eight hours of working time. I was cautioned never to abbreviate my lunch hour ..." [New York Post]

In his first in-depth interview since landing US Airways Flight 1549 into the Hudson River on Jan. 15., Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III said he was terrified. On Sunday night's broadcast of "60 Minutes" on CBS, Captain Sullenberger said, "I had this expectation that my career would be one in which I didn't crash an airplane."

Newspaper companies face "antiquated" antitrust rules that are preventing much-needed consolidation in a perilous time for the industry, John Chachas, a managing director of Lazard, wrote in an opinion piece in The Dallas Morning News.

Goldman Sachs Chief Executive Lloyd Blankfein, writing Monday in an opinion piece in The Financial Times, faulted his industry for what he considers to be widespread failures of risk management in the period before the current financial crisis.

UBS, the largest Swiss bank, doesn't plan to abandon investment banking or jettison the head of the securities unit, despite looming job cuts, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the situation.
Activist investor Carl C. Icahn made another power play for Biogen Idec Friday, as the company said its fourth-quarter profit edged up 3 percent and 2009 results could top expectations.

American Eagle Outfitters sued Citigroup Global Markets, accusing it of fraudulently inducing American Eagle to buy $258 million worth of auction rate securities that it now can sell only at a significant loss, if at all.
Rohm & Haas has rejected a possible meeting with top Dow Chemical executives to talk about a way forward for their stalled merger, but suggested that the companies' financial advisers should meet.
General Motors is in talks to take back large portions of Delphi, the auto parts supplier it spun off a decade ago, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people involved in the negotiations.

Hailed as the path forward for a Wall Street in disarray, the merger between Bank of America and Merrill Lynch offered Merrill a chance to rebound from billions of dollars in mortgage-related mistakes and gave Bank of America access to Merrill's well-known brand and its vast network of brokers, known as the thundering herd.

The founders of Fairfield Greenwich Group, a New York hedge fund that invested heavily with the disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff, are paring down their luxurious lifestyles amid huge losses and a spate of lawsuits against their firm, The New York Post reported.
The company that manages the endowment for Harvard will cut about 25 percent of its staff, or 50 positions, over the next several months, the school said on Friday.
Regulators closed FirstBank Financial Services in Georgia, and County Bank and Alliance Bank, both of California, bringing to nine the number of failures this year by federally insured banks.
The British bank Barclays said bonus payments across the bank would be cut almost in half for 2008 as it reported a 14 percent drop in annual profit and said it faces a tough year ahead.
Swizterland's top two banks, UBS and Credit Suisse Group, are expected to announce record losses for 2008 this week and UBS may unveil thousands of job cuts, according to Swiss news reports.

President Obama has named the venture capital veteran John Doerr to his new 16-member Economic Recovery Advisory Board, which will "provide advice directly to the president on the programs to jump-start economic growth and facilitate economic stability," the White House said Friday.

Xavier Rolet, an equities trading veteran who ran Lehman Brothers in France, is the front-runner to take the helm at the London Stock Exchange, Reuters reported, citing two people with direct knowledge of the matter.
Dubai government investment agency Istithmar World is not in talks to sell luxury retailer Barneys New York, its parent firm said.
Ho Ching will step down as chief executive of the Singaporean state investor Temasek Holdings at a time when turmoil in global markets is ravaging the value of its investments.

In a move that could force similar changes at other money-losing hedge funds, the well-known fund manager William A. Ackman is cutting his fees and allowing investors to take what is left of their money from one of the funds he manages, The New York Times's Zachery Kouwe reported.

Wall Street helped produce the global financial and economic crisis. Now, as the Obama administration prepares to unveil a revised bailout plan for the banking system, policy makers hope Wall Street can be part of the solution, The New York Times's Floyd Norris reports.

Just a couple of weeks ago, Marten Mickos was telling me how great Sun Microsystems' MySQL database business was performing during the economic downturn. Now, he's left the company, adding to a string of departures that threaten one of Sun's fastest-growing businesses.

Just in case you missed it: The Congressional Oversight Panel monitoring the Treasury Department's bailout of broken banks - the Troubled Asset Relief Program - reported last week that Henry M. Paulson Jr.'s team at Treasury paid significantly more for the assets it bought from banks than they were worth when the deal was announced in the fall, The New York Times's Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest "Fair Game" column.

Monday, 8 a.m. There are three good reasons to attend the 133rd annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. 1) You are an animal lover. 2) You are satirist. 3) You are a snob. After all, the Kennel Club permits only pure breeds to compete in the show, a "sports event" that predates the Model T. While one could argue that a shorthaired pointer with a long bloodline is an interesting thing, it is probably true that the dog closest to the spirit of New York is actually the mutt. A new Sherlock Holmes is coming soon, and he looks like a brute. Scheduled for release next fall and featuring Robert Downey Jr. as the great detective, Guy Ritchie's "Sherlock Holmes" will possess abs as rigid as his logic. So it's a good time to remember a slightly different style of Holmes, as portrayed by the brilliant Jeremy Brett. In over 40 episodes of the 1980s and '90s Granada Television Sherlock series, Brett's moody characterization was as complex as the master detective himself. For many fans, this one included, Brett became the modern Holmes, and Downey should hope to be half as bewitching, with or without an Inverness cape.
Headlines from the world of property:

An obituary by The Associated Press on Friday about Herbert Hamrol, one of the last survivors of the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, gave an incorrect date for the anniversary of the disaster. It is April 18, not April 17.

A picture caption with an article on Wednesday about the arrest of a man the police say is Poster Boy, who cuts up and rearranges images on advertisements in the New York City subway system, carried an erroneous credit. The picture, of a man identified as Poster Boy in a subway station, was by Daniel Carrus; it was not from YouTube.

A report in the Goal soccer roundup on Tuesday about competitive bidding to host the 2018 and the 2022 World Cup tournaments referred incorrectly to a past business affiliation of David Downs, a member of the United States organizing committee. He is a former president of Univision Sports, a division of the Spanish-language media company Univision. He is not a former chief executive of Univision.

An article last Monday about Rafael Nadal’s victory over Roger Federer to win the Australian Open men’s singles tennis title omitted part of a quotation by Nadal. He said of Federer after their match: “Remember, you’re a great champion. You’re one of the best in history.” He did not say, “You are the best in history.”.
A graphic video delivered to reporters appeared to show the execution of a Polish engineer by Pakistani militants who had held him captive for more than four months.

Facebook, now five years old, is capturing more users. Although it still trails MySpace, the site had a twofold increase from January 2008 to January 2009 in a custom category of social networking sites as measured by Hitwise. Share among Facebook users was fairly equally divided in January among 18- to 24-year-olds (23 percent), 25- to 34-year-olds (28 percent) and 35- to 44-year-olds (24 percent). That represents a 46 percent drop for the youngest group, and a 54 percent increase in the oldest group. Of course, the criteria for cool is set by younger users.

8 P.M. (USA) 133RD WESTMINSTER KENNEL CLUB DOG SHOWSome 2,500 dogs, representing 170 breeds and varieties, compete for top honors in the country's second-longest continuously held sporting event. Labrador retrievers (47) and French bulldogs (42) are the largest categories, with German shorthaired pointers, golden retrievers, Australian shepherds and Bernese mountain dogs close on their heels. THE VON BONDIES ''Love Hate and Then There's You'' (Majordomo) The Von Bondies last released an album five years ago, around the time that this decade's garage-rock revival was petering out. And while the album, ''Pawn Shoppe Heart,'' made an urgent case -- its standout single, ''C'mon, C'mon,'' had the force of a defibrillator jolt -- it also felt like something destined for dismantlement. Jason Stollsteimer, a whippetlike lead singer and guitarist, howled his compact choruses as if on borrowed time.

INDIA.ARIE ''Testimony: Vol. 2, Love & Politics'' (Soulbird Music/Universal Republic) Love is both bliss and panacea, while politics is a test of fortitude, on India.Arie's fourth studio album, ''Testimony: Vol. 2, Love & Politics.'' One of the most determinedly virtuous songwriters in R&B or pop, India.Arie strives to make faith, goodness and positive thinking seductive, and on this album, working as her own co-producer (with Dru Castro), she's endearing even when she's preachy.

LONELY ISLAND ''Incredibad'' (Universal Republic) With apologies to Debbie Harry, Tairrie B, Invincible and Amanda Blank, the most significant white female rapper of all time is Natalie Portman. (To Northern State and Uffie, no apology is necessary.) Based on Eazy-E's ''No More ?'s,'' ''Natalie's Rap,'' which originated in 2006 as a ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch written by Lonely Island -- and appears on this comedy team's first musical album, ''Incredibad'' -- is savagely funny, a reputation changer for a young actress and, most surprisingly, an utterly convincing revisiting of late-1980s Los Angeles gangster rap. It isn't parody; it is a love letter.

NELS CLINE ''Coward'' (Cryptogramophone) If the guitarist Nels Cline had joined the revered and more than semi-popular rock band Wilco in his early 20s, rather than in his late 40s, he might never be making solo-guitar albums on the side like ''Coward.'' This record reflects a far-and-wide aesthetic imagination, one that's been broadening for a long time.

Maybe he should have been a lawyer instead: The performer Victor Willis, better known as the original police officer in the campy band the Village People, has filed suit against a resuscitated version of the group, saying it is using his likeness and voice in its performances, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Willis was among the first members of the wink-wink disco-era band, famous for songs like “Y.M.C.A.” and “Macho Man;” he departed the group before its flop 1980 movie, “Can’t Stop the Music,” but rejoined them for a Las Vegas performance in 2007. He is also suing Sixuvus Ltd., a New York company that promotes the new Village People band, as well as the William Morris Agency and Can’t Stop Productions, which owns the trademark to the band’s name.

The pop singer Rihanna has postponed a concert in Malaysia after she and her companion, the R&B performer Chris Brown, canceled their scheduled appearances at the Grammy Awards, The Associated Press reported. In a statement to The A.P., the Malaysian promoter Pineapple Concerts said that it had been informed by Rihanna’s representatives that a show planned for Friday would be rescheduled “in light of recent events involving Rihanna.” On Sunday, Mr. Brown was arrested and charged with making criminal threats after an incident in which he got into an altercation with a woman in his car; the name of the woman was not released. Mr. Brown was later set free on $50,000 bail. On Monday, Wrigley said it had suspended an advertising campaign for Doublemint gum that features Mr. Brown as its spokesman.

A German court has ruled that a rare poster seized by the Gestapo in 1938 from a Jewish collector must be returned to his son, The Associated Press reported. Peter Sachs, a retired airline pilot living in Sarasota, Fla., had sued Deutsches Historisches Museum in Berlin, saying that posters in the museum’s collection were originally property of his father, Hans, a dentist who was put in a concentration camp but later escaped with his family to Boston. In a test case, a Berlin administrative court ruled that a poster for the German satirical magazine Simplicissimus was part of Hans Sachs’s collection and must be returned to Peter Sachs. In January, a German court ruled that some 4,250 posters in the museum’s possession, including prewar advertisements for movies and cabaret shows as well as political propaganda, belonged to Peter Sachs, but held off ruling on whether the museum had to hand over the collection to him.

The $700 million renovation of the Bolshoi Theater continues to be beset by delays, and will now not be completed until 2011, The Guardian newspaper reported. The 185-year-old Moscow theater, home to both the Bolshoi Ballet and Bolshoi Opera, closed in July 2005 to undergo massive restorations to its structure, its orchestra and backstage facilities; at the time, the Bolshoi anticipated that work would be completed by 2008. But Russia’s culture minister, Aleksandr Avdeyev, said the renovations now would not be finished until the middle of 2011, after contractors were hired “because they were inexpensive rather than high quality,” according to The Guardian. Mr. Avdeyev also said that the installation of a stage hydraulics system would take longer than originally expected. But Nikita Shangin, the former chief architect of the renovation, said that previously announced completion dates were “all bluff and politics,” according to The Guardian, adding: “I always believed it would take a lot longer.”

Having famously played roles in the lives of Alvy Singer and the Corleone clan, Diane Keaton is about to shine a spotlight on her own family. The actress, of “Annie Hall” and “The Godfather” fame, will write a memoir for Random House about her mother’s 15-year battle with Alzheimer’s disease, the publisher said in a news release. Ms. Keaton’s mother, Dorothy Keaton Hall, kept some 90 notebooks during her life, chronicling the upbringing of her children and her frustrating marriage; Ms. Keaton read those journals back to her mother during her final years, and began writing her memoir soon after her mother’s death from Alzheimer’s in 2008. The book, as yet untitled, is planned for publication in 2012. Financial terms of the deal were not announced.VIDEO: A.O. Scott reviews “Annie Hall” in this Critics’ Picks segment.

Three prominent museum-world figures who are Brandeis University graduates spoke out vigorously on Tuesday against the school’s plans to close its Rose Art Museum and sell off artworks to raise money. In an open letter posted at the Rose’s Web site, Adam D. Weinberg, director of the Whitney Museum of American Art; Gary Tinterow, chairman of the department of 19th-century, modern and contemporary art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; and Kimerly Rorschach, director of Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University, wrote that Brandeis had “shaken confidence in its educational mission, threatened a covenant established with thousands of donors, and set a sad and troubling example to other institutions.’’ They said of the Rose: “This was where an extraordinary collection kindled our passion for art and art history. This was where we decided to devote our professional lives to studying art, and to helping others feel the excitement we had discovered in these galleries.’’ The three added: “We can only hope that Brandeis will now revisit its decision. If not, we all stand to lose.’’

I'd like to thank Aaron Hirsh for a fascinating series of articles in the last month. He now passes the baton to Steve Quake, the second guest columnist for The Wild Side during my sabbatical. Steve is a professor of bioengineering at Stanford University and an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute; he uses his background in physics to develop technologies to solve problems in biology and human health. He has, for example, pioneered a new way to sequence DNA, and developed a new, noninvasive test for Down syndrome that can give results much earlier in pregnancy. He is currently studying the human immune system.

I missed out being born on Friday the 13th by a mere 28 minutes. I say "missed out" because the Saturday the 14th that followed was Valentine's Day -- an annual event that comes with its own special heart-shaped box of horrors. (Don't even get me started on single red roses.) In fact, one theory as to the origins of what is now widely regarded as a Hallmark marketing executive's wet dream is that Valentine's Day was conceived to pay tribute to Saint Valentine, who, having been rejected by his mistress, carved out his still-beating heart and presented it to her as a token of his undying love. (That's gotta be worth an NC-17 rating at least.) While I have never received a still-beating human heart for my birthday, I have, over the years, amassed an impressive collection of heart-shaped paraphernalia mostly thanks to a dear grandmother who has never met a heart-shaped paperweight, candy dish, pendant, pin or pair of earrings that she didn't wrap up and send to me special delivery.

Jackie and I are in damp, chilly Paris for four days of eating and museum-going and, most important, visiting our friend Richard. On our first night the three of us went to l'Ami Louis, where we hadn't been for probably 15 or 20 years. A chef friend in New York had had a terrific meal there last year (which he characterized as "medieval" but delicious), and we were looking forward to it. Well, while we had great fun, the cooking was inconsistent -- fabulous old-fashioned snails in herb/garlic butter; some other things a little underseasoned and a little overcooked. Gigantic portions, hence the "medieval" description.

Morality | "What happens when, for the first time in history - at least in theory, and at least in the advanced nations - adult human beings are more or less free to have all the sex and food they want?" an essay asks. We get a "transvaluation" of values in which food is freighted with taboos, but sex much less so. "In the end, it is hard to avoid the conclusion that the rules being drawn around food receive some force from the fact that people are uncomfortable with how far the sexual revolution has gone - and not knowing what to do about it, they turn for increasing consolation to mining morality out of what they eat." [Hoover Institution]

It's been two years since I was last in Venice. But I found myself thinking about the city again today, after looking at a lovely slide show produced by my colleagues on the Travel desk about the Venetian Carnevale, the 10-day masked extravaganza that starts this Saturday. I have something of a love-hate relationship with Venice. There are few places on the planet where I have been quite so thrilled by art, and of course the sheer unlikelihood of the place, the gorgeous fantastical quality of it, cannot but mesmerize, no matter how many times you've seen it. Then again, I wish it were easier to have a great meal there (don't get me wrong, I've eaten very well in Venice, but I do find this more of a challenge than in other Italian cities), and I always find the place a bit creepy at night, when the sudden and near-total emptiness of the streets can give the feeling of being locked in a museum after closing. As amusing as I'm sure Carnevale is - and I suppose the streets are plenty lively after dark then - my aversion to crowds means I'd never dream of going for the festival. No, I prefer Venice as it was on my first visit, one gray, cold and misty November. My companion and I ditched our guidebook, and we simply wandered the quiet, fog-shrouded streets. And in that atmosphere the city felt not like some commercialized tourist trap but rather a place of romance and mystery, of unexpected beauty down obscure lanes and great possibilities for discovery every time we stopped studying the map and just allowed ourselves to get lost.

The Soviets sent woefully inadequate forces to impose a Communist model "that had nothing to do with the nature and traditions of the Afghan people." By contrast, if the Americans commit resources sufficient to win hearts and minds and defeat Taliban forces -- many of whom hold simply "local grievances" and can be won over -- Afghanistan is "indeed winnable." Philosophy | Why ideology persists: It flourishes, an essay says, where "the number of educated people has risen far faster than the capacity of economies to reward them with positions they believe commensurate with their attainments. Even in the most advanced economies, one will always find unhappy educated people searching for the reason that they are not as important as they should be." And so Islamism and environmentalism are all the rage today. [City Journal]

Oral arguments are scheduled for Tuesday before the New York State Court of Appeals in Albany in the bitter case between San Francisco’s Golden Gate Yacht Club, which backs Larry Ellison’s BMW Oracle Racing, and Société Nautique de Genève, the Swiss club that backs Ernesto Bertarelli’s two-time defending America’s Cup champion Alinghi. In its last-chance appeal, the San Francisco club is asking New York state’s highest court to reverse the New York Supreme Court’s Appellate Division ruling last summer that Spain’s Club Náutico Español de Vela, not Golden Gate, is the Challenger of Record for the 33rd America’s Cup. Cavanaugh, who spent 14 seasons in the N.F.L., was the offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach at the University of Pittsburgh the past four years. Cavanaugh has 11 years of N.F.L. coaching experience, serving as the offensive coordinator for Baltimore (1999-2004) and Chicago (1997-98) and as the quarterbacks coach for San Francisco (1996) and Arizona (1994-95). jets (AP).

It was the New York Legislature, not Congress. A reader pointed out the error in a recent letter.

An article on Saturday about the environmental issues facing President Obama misspelled the surname of the president of the Marine Conservation Biology Institute, who praised former President George W. Bush’s decision to designate as national monuments 400,000 square miles of ocean, reefs, atolls, seamounts and surrounding waters. He is Elliott Norse, not Nourse.

The On Religion column on Saturday, about Zoroastrianism, attributed an erroneous distinction to the religion. Zoroastrianism is considered to be among the first religions to worship a single god; research has not established that it was the first.

The announcement in church bulletins and on Web sites has been greeted with enthusiasm by some and wariness by others. But mainly, it has gone over the heads of a vast generation of Roman Catholics who have no idea what it means: ''Bishop Announces Plenary Indulgences.'' In recent months, dioceses around the world have been offering Catholics a spiritual benefit that fell out of favor decades ago -- the indulgence, a sort of amnesty from punishment in the afterlife -- and reminding them of the church's clout in mitigating the wages of sin.

How sweet it is! The American diet, that is. While the current recommendation is a maximum intake of eight teaspoons of sugars a day, one 12-ounce can of regular soda (or a 20-ounce bottle of VitaminWater) delivers eight or nine teaspoons. That means you are at or over the limit before you've eaten a single cookie or container of fruit-flavored yogurt, or even some commercial tomato soups or salad dressings with added sugars. The result is an average daily intake of more than 20 teaspoons of sweet calories. Although much fuss has been raised about high-fructose corn syrup, when it comes to calories and weight gain, it makes no difference if the sweetener was derived from corn, sugar cane, beets or fruit juice concentrate. All contain a combination of fructose and glucose and, gram for gram, supply the same number of calories. All contribute to the excessive caloric intake that has resulted in an epidemic of obesity among Americans in the last 25 years.

The announcement in church bulletins and on Web sites has been greeted with enthusiasm by some and wariness by others. But mainly, it has gone over the heads of a vast generation of Roman Catholics who have no idea what it means: ''Bishop Announces Plenary Indulgences.'' In recent months, dioceses around the world have been offering Catholics a spiritual benefit that fell out of favor decades ago -- the indulgence, a sort of amnesty from punishment in the afterlife -- and reminding them of the church's clout in mitigating the wages of sin.

In addition to being the 200th anniversary of Darwin's birth, 2009 is the 150th anniversary of the publication of his fundamental work, ''On the Origin of Species.'' As with many original sources, it is known mostly by reputation. Few people who are not biologists read Darwin in the original. But his writing can still offer surprises, insights and pleasures, and it can be sampled at nytimes.com/evolution, where the text is available, with selections by prominent scientists of their favorite passages and discussions of why these passages are important. At right, for example, is a favorite passage and comment from Neil Shubin, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Chicago and author of ''Your Inner Fish.'' This quote captures my interest in biology in a nutshell: How can an understanding of evolutionary history explain the diverse body structures we see in the natural world?

Darwin's theory of evolution has become the bedrock of modern biology. But for most of the theory's existence since 1859, even biologists have ignored or vigorously opposed it, in whole or in part. ARTON--Dolores M.,of Greenwich, CT died suddenly on February 6, 2009, surrounded by her loving family at Greenwich Hospital. Dolores moved to Greenwich in 2002 from New York City. Dolores and her identical twin sister Katherine were born on July 31, 1957 in Lansdale, Pennsylvania to the late Catherine (Cummings) and Harry Arton. She is survived by her sisters Katherine Arton and Elizabeth Dyevich of Princeton, New Jersey, Mary Cooper of Greenwich, CT, and Patricia Arton of Stamford, CT. She is also survived by her brothers- in-law James Cooper of Greenwich, CT, Thomas Dyevich of Princeton, NJ and her six adored nieces and nephews, Henry, Michael, and Kate Cooper of Greenwich, CT, and Jack, Harry, and Catherine Dyevich of Princeton, NJ. Dolores was Principal and Chief Financial Officer of Founder's Equity, a private equity firm in Manhattan. Prior to joining Founders, Dolores served as a Director in Citibank's Investment Banking Division, and PaineWebber's Investment Banking Group. She began her career at Grant Thornton, where she received her C.P.A., and subsequently joined First Pennsylvania National Bank. She received her M.B.A. from Columbia University and a B.A. from Temple University. Dolores was the guiding compass to her entire family. Her nieces and nephews were the shining light of her life; she loved them with the most beautiful unconditional love imaginable. Dolores stepped in and became a mother to her two youngest sisters after their mother's death. She was a cherished sister, aunt, cousin, niece, friend and colleague. She touched many lives, working as a mentor to countless young students and business professionals. Dolores was never too busy to help anyone who crossed her path. Dolores's modesty about her many accomplishments impressed all who knew her. She inherited her boundless energy and passion for adventure and world travel from her beloved father. Dolores held dearly her beloved mother's belief that all people, regardless of their status, deserved respect and dignity. She inherited both parents' adoration for animals, and continued their tradition of supporting animal welfare. She was a pet therapy volunteer with her cocker spaniel, Dudley. Dolores had recently returned from Russia, where she met the beautiful girl who was soon to become her adopted daughter. We miss her terribly, but take great comfort and solace in knowing that her indomitable spirit will live on forever in all of us. Her final act of love was to be an organ donor. Many people will be able to live normal lives as a result of her. Visitation will be held from 8:30 to 9:30am, on Wednesday February 11th at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. The funeral services will be at 10am, at Saint Mary Church, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be contributed in Dolores' name to The Fresh Air Fund 633 Third Avenue, 14th Floor New York, NY 10017 (212)-681-0146 http://www.freshair.org/ Adopt-A-Dog, Inc. 849 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06831 203-629-9494 http://adopt-a-dog.org/

The line to enter the Majestic Theater is always long -- ''The Phantom of the Opera'' plays there, after all -- but Monday the line stretched much farther than usual, as more than 1,500 people arrived for a memorial tribute to Gerald Schoenfeld, the influential theater owner and producer who died at 84 in November. It was an unusual Broadway moment, as famous friends of the famous Mr. Schoenfeld -- like Henry A. Kissinger and Barbara Walters -- mixed with the less-famous people who were also close to Mr. Schoenfeld: the ushers and cashiers and box-office clerks whom he checked in with nightly to see how business was doing at the 17 Broadway theaters owned by the Shubert Organization, which he ran.

According to the sages who issued the Biblical edicts of Deuteronomy, if you come upon a bird's nest, you may take eggs and nestlings, but you must leave the mother bird behind. ''Let the dam go,'' the King James version says. Some consider this advice as odd as many of Deuteronomy's other injunctions, like its ban on clothing made of blends of linen and wool. It runs counter to the fishing tradition of throwing the small fry back so they can grow up, aiming for the largest males in trophy hunting.

GRANTTHAM--Dr. Caryl. Reeve. Bloomfield, CT. 92, previously of Sound Avenue, Riverhead, NY, passed away after a brief illness Saturday, January 24 at Seabury Home in Bloomfield, CT. She was the wife of the late Olen Earl "Earl" Granttham of Riverhead. Dr. Granttham was born on January 29, 1916 in Riverhead, the daughter of Myrtle Wehl Reeve and Norman Frank Reeve. Caryl earned her B.A. in History from Barnard College at Columbia University in 1940, and her Ph.D. in History from New York University in 1963. Dr. Granttham held a variety of roles in political science and government, including editor for Prentice-Hall, staff member during World War II for the Office of War Information under Edward R. Murrow, and government research associate for John D. Rockefeller's personal staff. She later became Assistant Professor of History and Director for Development and Public Relations at Southampton College, Long Island University. Dr. Granttham was deeply committed to her beloved Riverhead, serving on the Suffolk County Historical Society, the Long Island Archeological Society, the Woman's Club of Riverhead, and the Advisory Committee to the Riverhead School Board. She was also founder and President of the Riverhead Preservation Landmark Society, where she oversaw the Fresh Pond 1822 School House program. Concerned about the loss of historic farmland in Eastern Long Island, Dr. Granttham donated a 20-acre preserve with frontage on Long Island Sound to the Peconic Land Trust, and remained an active supporter of the Land Trust. In addition to her long-standing interests in political activism and local history, Dr. Granttham was a talented cook, gracious hostess, and an accomplished gardener and bonsai culturalist. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Peconic Land Trust, P.O. Box 1776, Southampton, NY 11969 or Hallockville Museum Farm, 6038 Sound Avenue, Riverhead, NY 11901.

''You care for nothing but shooting, dogs and rat-catching,'' Robert Darwin told his son, ''and you will be a disgrace to yourself and all your family.'' Yet the feckless boy is everywhere. Charles Darwin gets so much credit, we can't distinguish evolution from him. Equating evolution with Charles Darwin ignores 150 years of discoveries, including most of what scientists understand about evolution. Such as: Gregor Mendel's patterns of heredity (which gave Darwin's idea of natural selection a mechanism -- genetics -- by which it could work); the discovery of DNA (which gave genetics a mechanism and lets us see evolutionary lineages); developmental biology (which gives DNA a mechanism); studies documenting evolution in nature (which converted the hypothetical to observable fact); evolution's role in medicine and disease (bringing immediate relevance to the topic); and more.

Two books about the military prowess of Abraham Lincoln will share the 2009 Lincoln Prize, bestowed by Gettysburg College for scholarship on the 16th president, the award’s administrators announced. The two winning works are “Tried by War: Abraham Lincoln as Commander in Chief” by James M. McPherson, and “Lincoln and His Admirals: Abraham Lincoln, the U.S. Navy and the Civil War” by Craig L. Symonds. Mr. McPherson, a Pulitzer Prize-winner and a professor emeritus of American history at Princeton University, won the Lincoln Prize in 1998 for his book “For Cause and Comrades: Why Men Fought in the Civil War.” Mr. Symonds, a professor emeritus of American history at the United States Naval Academy, was a finalist in 1993. Each author will receive $25,000 and a bronze cast of Lincoln at a ceremony on April 7. Honorable mentions were given to “Saving Savannah: The City and the Civil War,” by Jacqueline Jones; “Lincoln: The Biography of a Writer,” by Fred Kaplan; and “President Lincoln: The Duty of a Statesman,” by William Lee Miller.

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously to give landmark status to 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza and the Consolidated Edison Building in Manhattan, the Web site TheRealDeal.com reported. One Chase Manhattan Plaza, an aluminum-and-glass-skinned skyscraper between Nassau Street and William Street, was designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and was the sixth-tallest building in the world at the time of its completion in 1961. The construction of the Consolidated Edison Building, at 4 Irving Place between East 14th Street and East 15th Street, began in 1911 (when its principal tenant was still known as the Consolidated Gas Company) and was designed by Henry J. Hardenbergh, who also designed the Dakota and the Plaza Hotel.

In a sales week that ended on Sunday before the Grammy Awards could drive consumers to record stores, The Fray, a Denver band, made its debut at the top of the Billboard chart with its second, self-titled album, on Epic Records. It sold 179,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping last week’s best seller, Bruce Springsteen’s “Working on a Dream” (Columbia) to No. 2, with 102,000. The country singer Dierks Bentley opened at No. 3 with his new release, “Feel That Fire” (Capitol Nashville), which sold 71,000 units, and Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine), fell two spots to No. 4, with 64,000. Beyoncé’s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Columbia), also dropped two, to No. 5, as did Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner). “Kidz Bop 15” opened at No. 7, the ninth consecutive Top 10 opening for the series.

Nearly 50 years after the San Diego school district demanded that Pete Seeger sign an anti-Communism oath before performing at a high school auditorium, the school board has turn, turn, turned around and apologized to Mr. Seeger, The Associated Press reported. In May 1960, Mr. Seeger was scheduled to perform at Hoover High School when the board demanded he sign a pledge that the concert would not promote Communism or the overthrow of the government; he refused, but a judge allowed the concert to be performed. On Tuesday, the school board passed a resolution declaring that it “deeply regrets its predecessors’ actions” and apologizing to Mr. Seeger, The A.P. said. In an interview with The A.P., Mr. Seeger said the board’s resolution was a “measure of justice that our right to freedom of expression has been vindicated.”

The Los Angeles County District Attorney’s office has asked the police there to collect more evidence before it determines what if any charges to file against the R&B singer Chris Brown, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown was arrested Sunday night after an altercation early that morning with an unidentified woman in his car; the police initially said they were investigating a battery on a injured woman, but Mr. Brown was instead booked on suspicion of making a criminal threat and released on bail. Mr. Brown and his companion, the singer Rihanna, canceled their appearances at the Grammy Awards; Rihanna has also postponed a concert in Malaysia and one in Indonesia, and Mr. Brown has been dropped from advertisements with Wrigley and Body By Milk. He has also withdrawn from a planned appearance in Phoenix in advance of the N.B.A. All-Star game.

City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn plans to propose on Thursday that Albany raise the income tax on people making more than $300,000 a year as a way to generate $1 billion. But they also suggest that there could be tough negotiations with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over how to plug a $4 billion budget deficit.

Shiny heart-shaped things aside, isn't Valentine's Day just the worst? What really drives me nuts as a travel editor are all the cheese-ball hotel packages that show up this time of year. They're just so utterly devoid of any real style or romance, not to mention value. There's a hotel in Santa Fe, N.M., with a package that includes "passionate fruit cocktail" and "red incense to burn." Canned pineapple and patchouli ... yeah, that's hot. Another hotel, in Austin, Tex., provides a classical violinist to ruin - I mean accompany - your dinner for two. And I've lost count of the number of times I've seen some variation on the theme of champagne and strawberries. That tired old couple can't possibly feel sexy any more, can they? Of course some "deals" really are deals, but please, hotel execs, don't try to convince us that "two terry-cloth bathrobes" is something to get excited about. And pretty please with a strawberry on top, don't try to sell us a weekend of chocolate massages (yuck) for $14,000, as in the case of one major Hawaiian resort. Upgrade me to a suite - now that's a turn-on. Our friend The Frugal Traveler over at The New York Times travel section has a keener eye on Valentine's Day specials than I do; he did a good post the other day listing some of the better offers. But he didn't include my favorite, the Fairmont San Francisco's Break-Up package for the newly single. Among the usual cookies and bubbly is a chance to buy jewelry wholesale - plus a $100 gift certificate - at Padis Gems. It's $250 a night, which is actually a few bucks cheaper than a regular night, and San Francisco is a great city to be single in. If I were, I'd be there.

Any parent with more than one child can feel like a lab scientist, unraveling the questions of nature vs. nurture. On the other hand we spent nearly two decades aware that we are shaping who they become, wondering (worrying) if we are doing it right or screwing it up.

Credit Suisse posted a worse-than-expected fourth-quarter net loss of 6 billion Swiss francs ($5.2 billion), taking it to its biggest-ever annual loss, due to poor trading and restructuring charges.
The founding family of Mervyn's agreed to purchase the defunct retailer's name and all its Internet-related intellectual properties, The Wall Street Journal reported.

American International Group is in advanced talks to sell its U.S. auto insurance unit to Swiss insurer Zurich Financial Services, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the matter.

European banks that receive government help to get toxic assets off their balance sheets may have to report each week to their national authorities on the value of their portfolios under plans being discussed by the European Union.

Interesting: the Obama-linked Center for American Progress trails two European think tanks as top newcomer. Also noted: "phantom" think tanks like the China Development Institute that "are in fact arms of the government." [Foreign Policy]

YUSUFIYA--I looked out of my car and there were Iranians everywhere.

The Department of Defense has identified 4,233 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 639 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.

A marijuana advocacy group is urging a boycott of the Kellogg Company for deciding to cut ties with the Olympic hero Michael Phelps after he was photographed with a marijuana pipe. The leader of one of the biggest legalize-pot organizations, the Marijuana Policy Project, called Kellogg’s action “hypocritical and disgusting,” and said he had never seen his membership so angry, with more than 2,300 of them signing an online petition.

The American Society for Reproductive Medicine says it is investigating whether fertility treatment guidelines were broken in the case of a Southern California woman who gave birth to octuplets last month. The society said in a statement that it had asked the woman, Nadya Suleman, and the doctor for more details about her latest pregnancy. Ms. Suleman’s six other children were also conceived through in vitro procedures. The voluntary, nonprofit group has guidelines for the number of embryos that should be implanted to prevent multiple births, but it cannot stop doctors from practicing.
Troy Aikman, the former Dallas Cowboys Hall of Fame quarterback, said he had passed his final two college courses and would graduate in June from U.C.L.A. — 20 years after he left for the N.F.L.

Attorney General Talis J. Colberg, a major figure in the abuse-of-power investigation of Gov. Sarah Palin, has resigned, the governor’s office said. Mr. Colberg, left, who was appointed to the post in 2006 after Ms. Palin was elected, represented seven of nine state employees who initially refused to testify before a legislative panel investigating Ms. Palin’s firing of her public safety commissioner. Mr. Colberg said he advised the seven of their options, and he unsuccessfully challenged the subpoenas in court. Ms. Palin’s spokesman, Bill McAllister, said that the resignation was a personal decision for Mr. Colberg, and that the governor had neither fired him nor pressured him to quit.

Bill Parcells’s escape clause with the Miami Dolphins was expanded before the sale of the team last month, and he can leave at any time and collect the balance of the $12 million due to him under a four-year contract. The contract Parcells signed a year ago gave him a 30-day window to depart with full pay if the team was sold.

While celebrating her downhill victory at the world championships in Val d’Isère, France, on Monday, Lindsey Vonn grabbed a broken Champagne bottle and cut a tendon in her right thumb. She underwent surgery Tuesday. Vonn already has won two gold medals at the worlds. The United States team anticipated her competing in the slalom Saturday and possibly the giant slalom Thursday. She probably will skip the team event Wednesday.

Two students at Yulee High School sued their school board because they were not allowed to form a club that promotes gay tolerance. The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida filed the suit in federal court on behalf of the students. The lawsuit claims violations of the First Amendment and the Federal Equal Access Act. The A.C.L.U. said the act requires schools to grant access and recognition to the Gay-Straight Alliance and other groups if the school allows any extracurricular group to meet.

A doctor accused but never charged with giving four patients lethal doses of drugs in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina is asking the state to pay her legal fees. A lawyer for Dr. Anna Pou said that because she was a state employee, she is entitled by law to be reimbursed for her legal fees. About 2,000 people had to be evacuated from the hospital where Dr. Pou worked when the 2005 hurricane hit New Orleans. An investigation led to the arrest of Dr. Pou and two nurses. None of the women were indicted.

The price of a first-class stamp will rise to 44 cents on May 11, the Postal Service announced. Until then, people can buy “forever” stamps for 42 cents and use them no matter how much prices go up in the future. When the price for the first ounce of first-class mail goes up to 44 cents, the price for each additional ounce will remain unchanged at 17 cents.
Midfielder Bobby Convey, who spent the last four seasons with the English team Reading, has signed with the San Jose Earthquakes of Major League Soccer.

The judges in the Senate trial in Minnesota have identified the first of what could be many wrongly rejected absentee ballots that they say must be included in the final count. The judges’ order means that 24 supporters of Al Franken, the Democrat, whose absentee ballots were rejected will see their votes counted. The incumbent, Norm Coleman, a Republican, wants the judges to count about 4,700 other rejected absentee ballots, and his lawyer says their decision means they are more likely to take that step. Mr. Franken has a 225-vote lead over Mr. Coleman, not including the 24 votes at issue.
The period for public comment on a plan to give oil companies the right to resume oil and gas extraction off the coasts of the United States is now six months longer.

Fifteen members of the executive board of Unite Here, a union representing apparel, hotel and restaurant workers, said they had filed a federal lawsuit in Manhattan seeking to undo the merger that created the union. Those board members come from Unite, which represents apparel workers and merged in 2004 with Here, the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union. Arguing that the merger has failed, the plaintiffs are seeking to seize the union’s financial assets. On Monday, the union’s board voted 39 to 24 against undoing the merger. Here called the lawsuit frivolous.
The Committee to Protect Journalists called on the Obama administration Tuesday to end the indefinite detention of journalists by the United States military overseas.

A Russian safety commission blamed pilot error and poor training for the crash of a plane that killed 88 people last year.

Soldiers in the state of Chihuahua chased and killed 14 armed men who had kidnapped nine people and killed six of them on Tuesday. One soldier was killed by the kidnappers, believed to be drug traffickers, bringing the death toll to 21. The gunmen took the hostages from the ranching town of Villa Ahumada and drove them to an isolated farm where six were killed, said Enrique Torres, a spokesman for the federal government’s antidrug operation in the state. A military convoy caught up with the kidnappers about 80 miles south of El Paso, killed seven of them and freed the remaining three hostages. Soldiers then pursued the other seven gunmen through heavy snow and killed them in a shootout.

BRUNNER--Norman, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Norman Brunner. Dr. Brunner was at Maimonides Medical Center for 30 years. He was Vice-Chairman of the Department of Medicine. He was a brilliant physician who trained thousands of residents and was voted by the house staff as teacher of the year many times. He was a pioneer and researcher in the field of Myasthenia Gravis. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. Warren Wexelman MD, Pres Herbert Wasserman MD, Sec Edward Fitzpatrick MD, Tres

BENDINER--Robert, died peacefully at 99. Magazine writer, author. Managing Editor, The Nation, member Editorial Board, NY Times. We will miss his warmth, whimsy, and wisdom. Leaves son, David, daughter, Peggy Margoshes, grandson, Elliot Margoshes, and many others who loved him. Memorial planned.
$210/SQ. FT. approximate annual rent $2.4 million

BABBIN--Belle, New York City, 102, loving wife of Abraham, loving mother of Malcolm, Chester (Kathleen) and Norma Horowitz. Loving grandmother to Jennifer, James, Elizabeth, Douglas, Barbara, Steven, Fran and Stan and 15 great-grandchildren. She will always be our guardian angel. Services are private.

d'AMBOISE--Carolyn George. Peter Martins and the entire New York City Ballet family mourn the passing of Carolyn George, a soloist with the Company during the 1950s. In addition to performing a broad range of ballets, she was also known for her memorable photographs of George Balanchine and NYCB. Carrie will be deeply missed by all who knew her, and our deepest sympathies are extended to her beloved husband, former NYCB Principal Dancer Jacques d'Amboise, and their children, George, Christopher, also a former Principal Dancer, Charlotte and Catherine.

RODRIGUEZ KEEPS A DATE Alex Rodriguez, who acknowledged Monday that he had used performance-enhancing drugs during his three years with the Texas Rangers, is still scheduled to appear at a fund-raiser at the University of Miami on Friday, according to his publicist, Richard Rubinstein, and a spokesman for the Miami athletic department. Rodriguez donated $3.9 million to Miami's baseball program for major renovations to its facilities. At a dedication ceremony Friday, the university will rename its freshly upgraded stadium Alex Rodriguez Park.

HANKOFF--George, born 1926. Native New Yorker, WWII veteran, sales executive in television broadcasting. Lifelong Democrat, dedicated fisherman and consultant until his final days. Survived by four children, Peter, Palmer, Alexander and Damon, and two grandchildren. Memorial service details to be determined.

Houston Astros shortstop Miguel Tejada is expected to plead guilty Wednesday to misdemeanor charges that he made false statements to Congressional investigators who were looking into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball. Federal prosecutors from the United States attorney's office for the District of Columbia charged Tejada on Tuesday with making false statements to investigators when he told them that when he played for the Oakland Athletics, he never talked to teammates about their use of steroids or human growth hormone. Tejada was scheduled to appear Wednesday before a judge at the United States District Courthouse in Washington to plead guilty.

JONES--Glory. Media wordsmith for the arts world, sterling mentor and poet, died February 7 at 57. Press and public relations voice for the Guggenheim, the Morgan Library, and the Hirshhorn Museum, Glory last joined Resnicow Schroeder Associates as consultant to the arts and culture. She served for years as the media contact of the Venice Biennale for both the US and Italian offices. Later, Glory wrote poetry now accepted by journals for posthumous publication. Glory is survived by her husband Kenneth Flowers, her sisters, Beverly Reid of Prescott Valley, AZ, Janice Newman of Perris, CA, Susan Smith of San Diego, Cynthia DeLanty of Riverside, CA, and a brother Gerard Jones of Seattle, eleven nieces and nephews, and eleven grandnieces and nephews. Visitation at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St., on Tuesday, February 17, 2009 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A memorial service will be held at Symphony Space Thalia at a time to be determined. Burial in Cornwall, CT will be private. Donations may be made to the Oncology Department, Herbert Irving Pavilion, Columbia University Medical Center.

ANDERSON--Robert. The playwrights, board, and staff of New Dramatists mourn the death of Robert Anderson. A writer of the highest caliber and dedication, a generous mentor to younger writers, and a devoted member of our board of directors, Bob never wavered in his belief that playwrights are each other's greatest resources. He helped Michaela O'Harra imagine New Dramatists into being and, in 1949, became part of its first class of writers. He famously said, "You can't make a living as a playwright, but you can make a life," and then showed, by example of service and kindness, how rich that life could be. We will miss his leadership, dedication, and friendship. He was a playwright's playwright, and that is how we shall remember him.

ROSENBERG--Marion Ruth (nee Stessman), 76, of Saddle River, NJ passed away peacefully surrounded by her loving family on Tuesday, February 10th 2009. A survivor of Nazi Germany along with her father Max Stessman and mother Rosa Stessman, she held a Masters Degree from Hunter College and had been an educator in the New York City School system. She loved children and touched the lives of countless grateful and precious students. She married the love of her life, Kurt Rosenberg in 1953 and they spent 56 extraordinary years together during which they were blessed with four children and twelve grandchildren all of whom adored her. She valiantly battled and survived ovarian cancer for 11 years under the care of her beloved doctor, Franco Muggia, M.D. and his extraordinary, dedicated and compassionate staff at NYU Medical Center, together with the relentless efforts of her son Dr. Paul H. Rosenberg. She is survived by her loving husband Kurt, sons Michael (Staci) Rosenberg of Woodcliff Lake, Dr.'s Paul (Ilana) Rosenberg of Saddle River, daughters Donna (Dan) Levine of Brookville, NY and Dorette (Peter) Forman of Sands Point, NY, and beloved grandchildren Jason, Zachary and Brandon Levine, Alexandra, Jessica and Nicole Forman, Marc, Lauren, Jonathan, Alexander, Julian and Karina Rosenberg. The family requests contributions be made in her name to: NYU Fund for Education and Training in Oncological Medicine c/o Dr. Franco Muggia, 160 E 34th St., New York, NY 10016. Grave- side service tomorrow at Cedar Park/Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ at 11:30 am.

MACKINTOSH--Elisabeth Plankinton, who passed peacefully on February 5, 2009 was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin on November 8, 1910, the daughter of William Woods Plankinton and Alexandra Stuart Plankinton. Mrs. Mackintosh received her education in New York and Paris. She was a business woman, managing the Plankinton Arcade in Milwaukee, a part of the Plankinton family businesses originally established by her great-great-grandfather, John Plankinton. Mrs. Mackintosh was a member of The Everglades Club, The Bath and Tennis Club, The Garden Club of Palm Beach, The Four Arts Society and past member of the Town of Palm Beach Landmark Commission, all of Palm Beach, Florida; a member of the Ladies Village Improvement Society of East Hampton Long Island; a member of the University Club of Milwaukee; a member of the Colony Club of New York; a past member of the Junior League in New York; a former member of Club de Saint Cloud, Paris, France; and was a congregant of the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach. Mrs. Mackintosh is survived by her sons, Williams Woods Mackintosh (Magdalena), New York, New York, and Michael T. Mackintosh (Rebecca), Milwaukee, Wisconsin. A visitation will be held at the Calvary Presbyterian Church, Milwaukee, Wisconsin at 12 Noon, Thursday, February 12, 2009, with a service immediately following at 1pm.

ANDERSON--Robert. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the passing of former Guild President Robert Woodruff Anderson, who died at the age of 91 on February 9, 2009. An acclaimed playwright, novelist and screenwriter, his credits include the Broadway play "Tea and Sympathy" (1953), which he adapted for the screen in 1956, and his Oscar-nominated screenplays for "The Nun's Story" (1959) and "I Never Sang for My Father" (1970), which he adapted from his play. Mr. Anderson joined the Dramatists Guild in 1941 and was elected to the Dramatists Guild governing council in 1965, serving as DG Council President from 1971 to 1973. He also served on the Board of The Dramatists Guild Fund from 1962 to 1993. His understanding of the playwright's plight in America led to his slyly knowing and oft-quoted observation: "The theater is a place where you can make a killing, but you can't make a living." A gentleman of great dignity, elegance and compassion, Mr. Anderson will be missed. Our deepest sympathies to his loved ones at this difficult time. John Weidman, President Dramatists Guild of America

DIAMOND--Stanley. New York Attorney. Stanley Diamond, prominent attorney and entrepeneur, 79, long time resident of New York City and Amagansett, NY died February 9 of natural causes following a long illness. His death was announced by his wife, Dr. Ethel Person. Mr. Diamond's recent professional efforts were to provide assisted living services in the metropolitan area. He was Director of Strategic Planning for Chelsea Senior Living and Of Counsel at Katten, Muchin, Rosenman L.L.P., and Chairman of Castle Senior Living, LLC. Prior to that, Mr. Diamond was a principal in Clearbrook Partners LP, the developer of some of the leading active adult residential communities in the Northwest. Mr. Diamond was an adjunct Professor of law at the New York University School of Law. He was a member of the American Bar Association and the New York State Bar Association and the New York County Lawyers Association for which he was awarded lifetime membership. He established the Herman Diamond Memorial Scholarship at New York University School of Law. He was also a member of the Board of Overseers at the Brookdale Center for the Aged at Hunter College. Mr. Diamond was the recipient of the New York City Alzheimer's Association 2001 community Leadership Award. Mr. Diamond received his undergraduate degree from City College of NY in 1951 and his law degree from New York University School of Law where he was the Research Editor of the New York University Law Review and a recipient of the Edward H. Dixon Prize scholarship. Mr. Diamond, dedicated family man and friend to many, is survived by his loving wife, Dr. Ethel Spector Person, his four children, Jessica Diamond of Chicago, Nancy Diamond, Lloyd Sherman, Louis Sherman, of New York City and four grandchildren, Jacob Diamond Schaer, Lily Diamond Schaer, Ginger Diamond Atwood, Luke Diamant Sherman. Funeral Services will be held at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street at 9:45am Wednesday, 11 February.

Dr. David C. Sabiston Jr., who led a surgical team in performing an early and daring coronary bypass operation on a human in the 1960s, paving the way for more effective cardiac procedures, died on Jan. 26 in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 84. The cause was a stroke, his family said.

d'AMBOISE--Carolyn George, after a long illness, left her bereaved family and friends on February 10th. She and her sister Marilyn, daughters to C.J. George and Ona Carroll, were born in Dallas, Texas. Carolyn became a professional dancer, performing in Broadway Musicals, San Francisco Ballet and the New York City Ballet. There, she married fellow dancer, Jacques d'Amboise and had four children, George, Christopher, Charlotte and Catherine and later four grandchildren, Shane and Sam Brill and Josephine and Shelby Mann. A world traveler, photographer and teacher, Carolyn formed an exercise dance club in 1976. Known as CARRIE'S MOB, they continue their classes to this day. That same year she and her husband founded the National Dance Institute that flourishes nationally and internationally. A memorial is being planned for March 30th at Symphony Space, 95th and Broadway.

KAZAN--Benjamin, died January 24, 2009, age 91. He received his BS degree from California Institute of Technology in 1938, MA degree from Columbia University in 1940, his Doctor of Science degree from the Technical University Munich, 1961. From 1940-1950 he was a section head at the Signal Corps Engineering Lab concerned with the development of new microwave storage and display tubes. From 1951 to 1958 he was employed at RCA Research Laboratories where he was engaged in color television tubes and solid state image intensifiers. From 1962-1968 he was head of the Solid State Display Group at the Hughes Research Labs continuing work on solid state imaging devices. From 1962-1968 he was employed by Electro-Optical Systems, where he was Chief Scientist of the solid state and electro-optical division. From 1968-1974 he was employed at the IBM Watson Research Center, since then he had been with the Palo Alto Research Center at the Xerox Corporation where he was head of the Display Group. He has published about 25 papers in the field of display and storage and he holds about 80 patents. He was co-author of two books, "Storage Tubes and Electronic Imaging Storage," he was editor of the book series "Advances in Image Pickup and Display," as well as editor of Proceedings of the Society of Information Display. Dr. Kazan was a fellow of SID, and a member of the American Physical Society. He is survived by his wife, his son and daughter-in-law and two grandchildren. Benwillbe missed forever.

The Board of Directors, Chelsea Senior Living.

ALTHOUGH Gladys Puglla-Jimenez came to this country from Ecuador 30 years ago, her kitchen on Putnam Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn is still intimately connected to her homeland, from her stocks of spices like achiote pepper powder to the tropical green of the walls. She craves guatita, a dish of cow tripe in a sauce thickened by peanut butter that she serves over plantains. And for Sundays, after a night spent entertaining friends at home, she prepares a briny, squid-infused version of encebollado, a soup popular in Ecuador's coastal regions. ''It is good for a hangover,'' she promises. ''It will really revive you.''

JONES--Glory. Resnicow Schroeder Associates mourns the passing of our beloved friend and colleague, Glory Jones. A cherished member of the RSA family, Glory was a mentor and friend to all with whom she worked throughout her five years at RSA and her accomplished 25-year career in the arts. Glory's unparalleled insight, expertise and intellect made her an invaluable resource to many museums and cultural institutions across the country. Glory brought joy to our offices with her sparkling wit and infectious laughter. She gave generously of her time and affection, and was a compassionate, thoughtful and fiercely loyal friend. We will remember her for her eloquence with words, her humor, her tireless dedication and her unwavering spirit. We are grateful to have shared so many wonderful experiences together and cherish those memories. Our deepest sympathies and condolences to Ken Flowers and the Jones/Flowers families. David Resnicow, Fred Schroeder, and the staff at Resnicow Schroeder Associates

LOS ANGELES — The producers of “American Idol” had hoped that a new focus this season on the personal stories of the contestants would stem a slide in ratings. But on Wednesday it was one of those personal stories that apparently spawned this season’s first big scandal on “Idol,” the most-watched series on television.

The Shorty Awards, the world’s first-ever prizes for Twitter users, held at the Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo last night, were pretty short on intrigue. The winners were announced beforehand, and in keeping with the tech times, acceptance speeches were limited to 140 characters. There was one bit of drama, though: the identity of @PeggyOlson, who tweets as the fictional character from “Mad Men” and won the award in the advertising category, was revealed; she proved to be Carrie Bugbee, a marketing consultant from Portland, Ore., as Sharon Otterman reported in the Bits Blog.

If you thought competition for the Tony Awards had threatened the solidarity among the young actors in the Broadway musical “Billy Elliot,” fear not: A Tonys committee took the unusual step on Thursday of ruling that the three teenagers who rotate in the title role would be considered jointly for a single nomination for leading actor in a musical.

Where does a housewife go when she’s no longer desperate? ABC has announced that Nicollette Sheridan, a star of its prime-time comedy-drama “Desperate Housewives,” will be leaving the series, The Associated Press said, confirming a report in TV Guide. Ms. Sheridan, who plays the thrice-married temptress Edie Williams (formerly Roswell, McClain and Britt), has been with the series since its 2004 debut, when it made new (or renewed) stars of its principal actors, including Teri Hatcher, Felicity Huffman, Marcia Cross and Eva Longoria Parker. Though “Desperate Housewives” has been a Top 10 show in each of its five seasons, its audience has declined to about 15.6 million viewers from a peak of about 23.7 million. No date was announced for Ms. Sheridan’s final episode.

Jack White and Meg White, the rock duo better known as the White Stripes, will reunite to perform on the Feb. 20 broadcast of NBC’s “Late Night with Conan O’Brien,” the band’s publicist said in an e-mail message. The show is Mr. O’Brien’s final episode as host of “Late Night” before Jimmy Fallon, the “Saturday Night Live” star, takes over on March 2; Mr. O’Brien becomes host of NBC’s “Tonight” show on June 1.

She’s not the first Anne Hathaway linked to Shakespeare — when you last saw this one in Central Park she was most likely racing to complete an errand for the tyrannical Miranda Priestly in “The Devil Wears Prada.” But this summer, you’ll be able to see Ms. Hathaway in the Shakespeare in the Park production of “Twelfth Night,” in which she will play Viola, the Public Theater said in a news release. The play, directed by Daniel Sullivan, will run from June 9 through July 12 at the Delacorte Theater. The season’s second production will be Euripides’ “The Bacchae,” directed by JoAnne Akalaitis and featuring music by Philip Glass.

The Chinese government has asked the estate of Yves Saint Laurent to return two antique bronze sculptures that are to be auctioned this month, Bloomberg News reported. The sculptures, of a rabbit’s head and a rat’s head, were taken from a water fountain at the imperial Summer Palace in Beijing when it was raided by British and French troops in October 1860. The heads are scheduled to be sold at a Feb. 25 auction of the Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berge Collection, held by Christie’s in Paris. “These relics were stolen, robbed and taken away by invaders,” said Jiang Yu, a spokeswoman for the Chinese foreign ministry, according to Bloomberg. In an e-mail message, Christie’s told Bloomberg that given “the public nature of an auction, the return of these works to China is not guaranteed.”

The Connecticut Opera is going out of business, closing its headquarters in Hartford and laying off its entire staff, The Associated Press reported. The company said it was closing after 67 seasons because of the declining economy; it has canceled its two spring productions, including “La Boheme,” and said it would not be giving refunds to its 2,000 subscribers. John Kreitler, the chairman of the opera’s board, said the company was working with creditors to pay back debts. But the Connecticut state attorney general’s office said it was looking into the company’s closure after customers who bought tickets to canceled productions were sent letters suggesting they write off the expenses as a charitable contribution to the opera.

Stephen Rubin, the former publisher of Doubleday Publishing Group who stepped down in December in a restructuring at Random House, has been appointed publisher at large at Random House. Mr. Rubin, 67, will report directly to Markus Dohle, Random House’s chief executive, and will acquire books across the company’s divisions, which include the Knopf Publishing Group and the Crown Publishing Group. According to a statement from Mr. Dohle, Mr. Rubin will also “retain a role in acquiring future projects by several authors with whom he has had a long association, including John Grisham and Pat Conroy.”

Preconcert recitals are hardly anything new — the Mostly Mozart Festival has been offering them for decades — and lots of people skip them. But as the economy tightens, they can seem a welcome bonus, a significant expansion of what you get for the price of a ticket. Sacred Music in a Sacred Space, Kent Tritle’s choral series at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue, offers organ recitals as preludes to the formal programs. The church’s Mander organ, completed with considerable fanfare in 1993, is a magnificent instrument, and the preconcert recitals often include works that aren’t heard much otherwise.

Almost from its inception, the presidency of the United States has been a heavy weight on its occupants. Thomas Jefferson famously called the presidency a "splendid misery." John Quincy Adams described his four years in the White House as "the four most miserable years of my life." Herbert Hoover wrote "The Ordeal of Woodrow Wilson," a sympathetic account of Wilson's troubled presidency, then suffered through his own presidential ordeal. Some presidents, including Hoover and Jimmy Carter, aged noticeably during a single term in the White House.

There are few bars in my native city of St. Petersburg, and none at all, as far as I can tell, in Brighton Beach, the Russian enclave of Brooklyn to which I return whenever the memory of stuffed cabbage dumplings and accordion music begins to beckon. Not that sobriety has too much traction in either: when I returned to St. Petersburg in 2003 for the first time in 20 years, it was much more common to find open beers in the morning crowd than cups of coffee. And in the extravagant cabarets of Brighton Beach ― those gilded mafiya haunts now frequented by well-heeled families from Montclair and Stamford ― each dinner table is marked by an endless cavalcade of Smirnoff and Courvoisier.The notion that Russians love to drink is true, but somewhat misses the point. Russians love abundance, and alcohol ― especially vodka ― has been one of the few steady pleasures in a nation historically steeped in war, poverty and unrest. During the Soviet era, vodka promised a sanctuary from Marxism-Leninism: ideology does not exist at the bottom of a shot glass. Mikhail Gorbachev must have forgotten that when he launched his misguided anti-alcohol campaign during the bleak mid-80s as the Soviet dream was on the verge of unraveling. The historian William Pokhlebkin, in his "A History of Vodka," an amusingly thorough account of Russia's love affair with "the little water," writes: "The clumsy prohibitionist measures taken against vodka were not only ineffective but contributed to the disruption of state finances." When vodka became scarce, many resorted to making their own, known as samogon, which sapped the nation of its sugar reserves and further enraged the thirsty populace, as there was now nothing to sweeten tea.

In the finale of "T Takes: Brooklyn '09," directed by Brody Baker, our protagonist is at last reunited with his wife, played by the up-and-coming ingenue Kate Mara. No stranger to the small screen - Mara has appeared on "24" and "Nip/Tuck" - her film breakthrough came via a supporting part as Heath Ledger's daughter in "Brokeback Mountain." For her role in the 2006 football tragedy "We Are Marshall" with Matthew McConaughey, Mara (the granddaughter of the former New York Giants owner Wellington Mara) drew upon her gridiron lineage to provide unique emotional insight; the movie started filming soon after her grandfather's death in 2005. Up next, Mara will co-star with Justin Timberlake and Jeff Bridges in "The Open Road."

The Valentina exhibit inspires many thoughts. It is a good place to be reminded that good designers design. That's what they do, as stupidly obvious as that sounds. The particular freight of our time is to assume that any old Sam or Sally can do this job. The assumption has led to celebrities doing collections-and ripping off legitimate, bread-winning designers. It has led to celebrities borrowing ridiculously expensive jewelry for red-carpet events-and denying a market for things that people might actually own. Today, the fall collections start in one of the darkest economic periods in years. Designers have seen store orders cut by 30 or 40 percent. They have been forced to let go employees. Many designers are staging small shows, which I think makes sense anyway. A number of fashion chiefs in Paris told me last month: "This year has already been written off."

The Valentina exhibition opens tonight at the Museum of the City of New York, and yesterday I dropped by for a little preview with curators Kohle Yohannan and Phyllis Magidson. They were up to their mannequins, so to speak, in dresses. It is going to be a remarkable, talked-about exhibit. For one thing, the simplicity and innovation of Valentina's clothes will remind people of the 1930s and 40s, and it might put them in a better frame of mind for these hard times. Valentina accomplished so much with her hands, her mind and her personality, which was complemented by her severe beauty. She was stark raving mad, according to some. She was certainly a member of the progressive 20th century. That's the thought that stayed with me as I looked at her wrap-and-tie dresses, her shapely boleros and spare ballerina skirts-how far-sighted she was. And sophisticated. I can imagine that a few designers will gaze at the pieces and think, Boy, can I get the pattern for that? And to look at the colors of her dresses-the distinct shades of plum, mulberry, midnight blue, smoke brown-is to wonder if we have not become color blind. We seem definitely poorer people today without that kind of subtle palette.

The Internet doesn't always have to be serious business. Just ask Tobias Leingruber and Jamie Wilkinson, co-founders of Artzilla, an online repository for plug-ins to Mozilla's Web browser, Firefox. The extensions found on Artzilla won't help you organize bookmarks or add nifty features. They're more likely to scramble Web interfaces, inject misspellings or teleport your browser back to the dark ages of the Internet, you know, circa 1996.

Jacksonville released receiver Jerry Porter and cornerback Drayton Florence, who were signed as high-priced free agents but failed to play up to expectations. Porter caught 11 passes for 181 yards and a touchdown after signing a six-year, $30 million contract that included $10 million guaranteed. Florence never won a starting job after signing a six-year, $36 million deal with $11 million guaranteed. The Jaguars were 5-11 last season.

Venus Williams and women’s tennis are returning to Madison Square Garden for the first time in nearly nine years. Williams will join her top-ranked sister, Serena Williams, Ana Ivanovic and Jelena Jankovic on March 2 in the BNP Paribas Showdown for the Billie Jean King Cup. They will compete for $1.2 million in prize money in a one-set, no-ad scoring semifinal. The winners will play a best-of-three final. The Garden hosted the WTA season-ending championships in 2000.

The America’s Cup holder Alinghi beat its bitter rival BMW Oracle Racing by a second in a tense start to the three-race challenger final at the Pacific Series sailing regatta in Auckland, New Zealand. The quality of superniche scent collections varies hugely. Filmmakers who shoot at their parents' homes and produce on credit-card-financed shoestrings create, for the most part, erratic movies, and independent perfumers generally produce erratic collections. There are the political perfumes ("all natural! all organic!"), which tend to smell like bottled ideologies, and theme collections ("Japan!"), and the slightly trite "I hunt the planet for the most fabulous materials." And if the scents are almost always inferior to the Diors and the Tom Fords, it is due to the fact that perfume is not do-it-yourself. It is an excruciatingly difficult art form that requires trained professionals with access to the materials and technicians. And even then they can bomb. Most niche scent makers do forgettable work.

An obituary on Monday about the singer Blossom Dearie, using information from a relative and reference works, misstated the date she was born — and thus her age — and her full name. She was born on April 28, 1924, not on April 29, 1926, and was 84, not 82. (The headline also misstated her age.) Her full name was Blossom Margrete Dearie, not Marguerite Blossom Dearie.
“And now, at the age of twenty-eight, here I am. Yes, here I am, with perhaps the least-respected job title in my chosen field. Hollywood correspondent.”

A television review on Friday about the “Nature” documentary “Drakensberg: Barrier of Spears” misstated its broadcast history. While the Austrian public broadcaster ORF was a producer, Friday’s showing on PBS was its premiere. It was not originally filmed for Austrian public television.

An article on Jan. 24 about hip-hop in China misstated the family name of a Chinese rapper and of the director of Acupuncture Records, which produces hip-hop recordings. The rapper is Wang Li, not Wong Li, and the director of Acupuncture Records is Wang Miao, not Wong Miao.

An article on Tuesday about a dispute between The Associated Press and the artist Shepard Fairey over his Barack Obama poster, which was based on a photograph taken for The A.P., misstated a title of one of Mr. Fairey’s lawyers, who teaches at the Stanford University Law School and is executive director of the Fair Use Project there. The lawyer, Anthony T. Falzone, is a lecturer at the law school, not a professor.

A music review on Monday about the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of “Adriana Lecouvreur” misstated the given name of the early-18th-century actress on whose life the opera is loosely based. She was Adrienne Lecouvreur, not Adriana.

A headline and a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the leading movies at the box office over the weekend omitted part of the title of the No. 1 film. It is “He’s Just Not That Into You,” not “He’s Not That Into You.”.

An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about Beekman Tower, a skyscraper in Manhattan designed by the architect Frank Gehry, referred incorrectly to the site of the proposed Atlantic Yards project, also designed by Mr. Gehry. The project is near Downtown Brooklyn, not in it.

A chart on Wednesday with an article about the Treasury’s new plans to assist ailing banks misstated the amounts provided under a $125 billion program for big banks and referred incorrectly to the number of banks receiving the money. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/business.
