An article on Jan. 19 about the only street in Brooklyn named for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. misstated part of its former name and overstated the number of New York City boroughs that have no streets named for Dr. King. The street in Brooklyn, Martin Luther King Jr. Place in Bedford-Stuyvesant, was formerly named Reid Avenue, not Reid Street. And one borough, Queens — not two or three — has no street named for Dr. King.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about a police officer’s shooting of a Brooklyn man referred incorrectly in some copies to Operation Impact, in which the officer was taking part. It puts large numbers of officers on the streets in high-crime areas; it is not a stop-and-frisk program.

Brad Paisley was nominated for six awards by the Academy of Country Music, the most of any performer, including entertainer of the year, the academy announced on Wednesday. His fellow finalists in that category are Kenny Chesney, George Strait, Carrie Underwood and Keith Urban; he is also up for male vocalist, and record, song and video of the year (for “Waitin’ on a Woman”). Mr. Paisley has also been nominated with Mr. Urban for vocal event of the year, for their duet “Start a Band.” Winners will be announced on April 5.

While many nonprofits are struggling because of the financial crisis, the New York public radio station WNYC is to announce on Thursday that its capital campaign is complete, having raised $62.9 million, even more than the $57.5 million it had hoped for when the campaign began in 2005. In a sales week that ended on Sunday before the Grammy Awards could drive consumers to stores, the Fray, a Denver band, made its debut at the top of the Billboard chart with its second, self-titled album, on Epic Records. The album sold 179,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping last week’s best seller, Bruce Springsteen’s “Working on a Dream” (Columbia) to No. 2, with 102,000. Dierks Bentley made his debut at No. 3 with “Feel That Fire” (Capitol Nashville), which sold 71,000 units, and Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) fell two spots to No. 4, with 64,000. Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) also dropped two, to No. 5, while Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) fell to No. 6. “Kidz Bop 15” opened at No. 7, the ninth consecutive Top 10 opening for that series.

The Los Angeles County district attorney’s office has asked the police there to collect more evidence before it determines which if any charges to file against the R&B singer Chris Brown, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown was arrested on Sunday night after an altercation early that morning with an unidentified woman in his car; the police initially said they were investigating a battery, but Mr. Brown was instead booked on suspicion of making a criminal threat and released on bail. Mr. Brown and his companion, the singer Rihanna, canceled their appearances at the Grammy Awards. Rihanna has also postponed a concert in Malaysia and one in Indonesia, and Mr. Brown has been dropped from advertisements with Wrigley and Body by Milk. He has also withdrawn from a planned appearance in Phoenix before the N.B.A. All-Star game.

TABACOFF--Seymour, proud WWII veteran died February 10. Beloved husband of the late Fay Tabacoff; father of David, Emily and Risa; father-in-law to Sheri Bloom and Mark Hess; grandfather to nine loving grandchildren. Donations to Jewish War Veterans.

ALLSBROOK--William, in Woburn, MA, unexpectedly, Tuesday, February 10th, Broadway Performer and Tony Award Winner, longtime friend and business partner of David Gilgun of Woburn. Loving brother of Neal Stanfield of North Carolina. Cherished uncle of Gail Stanfield of Florida and Vic Stanfield of North Carolina. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend a Memorial Service on Saturday, February 14th, at 11 am, in St. Charles Church, 280 Main Street, Woburn. Donations may be made in Bill's memory to the William Allsbrook Scholarship, c/o The Woburn High School Scholarship Fund, PO Box 202, Woburn, MA 01801-0302. Funeral services are under the direction of the Lynch-Cantillon Funeral Home, 263 Main Street, Woburn. (Obituary, directions and guest book at www.lynch-cantillon.com)

BOXER--Leonard, a Founding Partner of Liz Claiborne, Inc., dies at 86. As the production pro and Executive Vice President of Manufacturing, Mr. Boxer was a pioneer of overseas manufacturing. He was a warm, gentle and kind man who was loved by all and will be missed by family and friends. Mr. Boxer is survived by his wife Anita, sons Steven and Garry and granddaughters Lauren, Rae and Georgia.
NEWLAND--Isaura. To my eternal love Isaura, from your family. I will miss you so much. From your grandson, George.
FAUGHEY--Kathryn. "Eleven-Eleven" "Night Sweets" "Night Babe"

LUCE--Leila Hadley. With sadness, the Directors and staff of the Henry Luce Foundation record the death of Leila, widow of our longtime chairman, Henry Luce III. Accomplished writer, avid gardener and faithful friend, she will be much missed. To her family and her beloved community, we extend deepest sympathy. Margaret Boles Fitzgerald, Chair Michael Gilligan, President

MEYER--M. Holt, on February 9, 2009. Loving husband of Catherine, devoted father to Christopher and Holt, loving grandfather of Emily, Rachel, Nina and Marie. Educated at Harvard University and Columbia Law School. A dedicated public servant, he served Mayor John Lindsay for 8 years and as family court judge for 22 years. Requiem mass at St. Mary's Episcopal Church on Staten Island, Saturday, February 14, 9:30am.

The American special envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, wound down his whistle-stop tour of Pakistan on Wednesday with a brief visit to the lawless tribal areas, and then dinner with liberal intellectuals at a rooftop restaurant here in Lahore. He had come to listen, not to lecture, Mr. Holbrooke said. What he heard was a familiar list of requests for more money and arms from Pakistan's top leadership, as well as a litany of complaints about American airstrikes in Pakistan's tribal areas using Predator drones.
UNTERBERG--Charles. 100th Birthday. Beloved husband, father, revered grandfather. Always in our hearts.

TERESTMAN--Nettie, D.S.W. The Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research and the Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine mourn the loss of our distinguished colleague. One of our founding faculty, she was a co-investigator on pioneering research on human sexuality. Her warm heart had room for us all. We shall miss her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Eric R. Marcus, M.D. Director CU Psychoanalytic Center Jonah W. Schein, M.D. President, APM
BRODSKY--Milton. The past last forever--> we remember. Love, Grace and Ruth
BRUNNER--Dr. Norman. My brother, my pal, my hero. Oh how I am going to miss our talks. Love, Jackie Warshaw

For one day, at least, Brett Favre challenged Alex Rodriguez for the big headlines. On Wednesday, Favre, one of the N.F.L.'s most exalted quarterbacks, announced his retirement. Again. Hold the video tributes and rocking chairs. We've been down this road before.
GRUNEBAUM--Helen. An inspiration to all. We will forever remember you with great love and affection. The Scheurer, Tabachnick and Hesse families

WEINGARTEN--Edith Appelbaum, died February 10, 2009 after a long battle with cancer. Edith was a schoolteacher for 29 years and was active in Hadassah and the American Cancer Society. Edith's life revolved around her family and friends. Devoted wife of Gabriel, mother of Randi, Jacki and son-in-law Ron, grandmother of Emily, Alex and Ryan. Funeral services will be held today, 11:30am at New City Jewish Center, New City, NY. Memorial contributions should be made in Edith's memory to Hadassah and to American Cancer Society, Rockland County Unit.

d'AMBOISE--Carolyn George. The National Dance Institute family is deeply saddened by the passing of Carrie, beloved wife of our founder, Jacques d'Amboise. We will remember her beauty, grace and kindness forever. We extend our deepest sympathy to Jacques and to their children George, Christopher, Charlotte and Catherine and grandchildren Shane, Sam, Josephine and Shelby.

LILIEN--Frances, February 10, 2009, age 92. Adored wife of the late Aaron Lilien, cherished mother of Barbara and Peter, beloved grandmother of Marjorie, Ilene and Janet, proudest grandmother of Adam, Max, Ali and Leo, and dearly loved by Bernie, Lois, Gretchen, Susan, Ellen and her many wonderful friends. REINHARDT--Lillian Tootle "Solie", died February 4, 2009 in Millbrook, NY. She was 88 years old. Born in Bethany, WV she was the daughter of Harry King Tootle, former Personnel Director of the New York Times and author of Employees are People, and Jessica Campbell Nave. She attended the Mount de Chantal School in Wheeling WV and the Knox School in Cooperstown, NY. During the Second World War Solie worked for the Red Cross in the North African and European theatres and after the war the Marshall Plan in France. In 1998 she published a compendium of her war-time letters to family in a book entitled V Mail. In 1949 she was married to G. Frederick Reinhardt, Jr., a career foreign service officer, who served as US Ambassador to South Viet Nam, Counselor of the State Department, U.S. Ambassador to the United Arab Republic, and U.S. Ambassador to Italy. He died in 1971. Solie is survived by her four children: G. Frederick Reinhardt III of Fairfield, CT, Aurelia Reinhardt Gebauer of Miami, FL, C. Henry "Harry" Reinhardt of Millbrook, NY, and Catherine Reinhardt Traber of New York, NY, and 14 grandchildren. She will be remembered for her abounding energy and sense of adventure, her relentless curiosity and lively spirit. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Peter's Church, Lithgow, Millbrook, NY at 11:00am on Friday, February 13, 2009.

LUCE--Leila Hadley, author, born in New York in 1925 died at home Tuesday, February 10th. An acclaimed author of several books, Leila had two of her books, Give Me the World and A Journey with Elsa Cloud, chosen by the New York Times as notable books of the year. Leila was a dedicated supporter of the Tibetan people serving on the board of Tibet House for many years and was endowed the Leila Hadley Luce Chair for Modern Tibetan Studies at Columbia University. She is the cofounder of Wings WorldQuest, a nonprofit dedicated to women explorers and education. She was a member of PEN, the Fishers Island Conservancy and the Explorer's Club. Leila was particularly proud of her garden on Fishers Island, NY, which was the subject of her last book, A Garden by the Sea. She was the widow of Henry Luce III, son of the founder of Time Magazine. She is survived by her sons Dr. Arthur T. Hadley III, Matthew S. Eliot, DVM, her daughters Victoria S. Barlow and Caroline Nicholson and her eight grandchildren Holly Hadley, Matthew Eliott Jr, Allsion Eliott, Fiona Finlay-Hunt, Whitney Eliott, Faith, Phoebe and George Nicholson. Leila will be profoundly missed by her many dear friends around the world. A memorial service is scheduled for March 10, 2009, 2pm at Saint Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue.

In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to: MSKCC, Attn: Elise Cooke 633 3rd Avenue, 28th Flr, New York, NY 10017, In memory of Louis Burton Bernstein

Six members of Congress from New York asked Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner to ignore demands that Citigroup's $400 million deal to have its name on Citi Field for 20 years be terminated because the bank has received $45 billion in Troubled Asset Relief Program funds. The Treasury Department has said it does not have the power to abrogate the deal. ''We believe this would set a terrible precedent of unfairly singling out a specific company and a particular form of advertising for a politically popular reason,'' the Congress members, all Democrats, said in a letter to Geithner. They were responding to two of their colleagues, Representatives Dennis J. Kucinich, a Democrat from Ohio, and Ted Poe, a Republican from Texas, who last week called on Geithner to dissolve the contract.

Lawyers for a Guantánamo Bay detainee at the center of a diplomatic standoff between Britain and the United States are appealing directly to President Obama as part of a stepped-up campaign to make public classified information about his treatment while in American custody. The lawyers have faxed a letter to the White House asking Mr. Obama to review the case of the detainee, Binyam Mohamed, who they say was tortured ''in truly medieval ways'' over a period of more than two years after rendition to secret prisons overseas. Attached to the letter was a two-page memorandum outlining the torture allegations.

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously to give landmark status to 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza and the Consolidated Edison Building in Manhattan, reported TheRealDeal.com. One Chase Manhattan Plaza, an aluminum-and-glass-skinned skyscraper between Nassau and William Streets in Lower Manhattan, was designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and was the sixth-tallest building in the world when it was completed in 1961. Construction of the Consolidated Edison Building, at 4 Irving Place, between East 14th Street and East 15th Street, began in 1911 and was designed by Henry J. Hardenbergh, who also designed the Dakota and the Plaza Hotel.

Judges at the International Criminal Court have decided to issue an arrest warrant for President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, brushing aside diplomatic requests to allow more time for peace negotiations in the conflict-riddled Darfur region of his country, according to court lawyers and diplomats. It is the first time the court has sought the detention of a sitting head of state, and it could further complicate the tense, international debate over how to solve the crisis in Darfur.

Investors in Kenneth C. Griffin’s Citadel Investment Group have received another round of sour news, coupled with a glimmer of hope. Mr. Griffin has decided to continue suspending redemptions from his two largest funds for another quarter after freezing them last year, but will institute a new program to allow withdrawals.

Joss Whedon, cult series creator (“Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” “Firefly”) and online musical maestro (“Dr. Horrible’s Sing-Along Blog”), returns to network television Friday with “Dollhouse.” The science fiction fantasy, which has its premiere at 9 p.m. on Fox, stars “Buffy” alumna Eliza Dushku as an all-purpose operative whose memory is wiped clean after every job. (Times television critic Alessandra Stanley thinks the show “has an amusing premise, but the universe it inhabits in the early episodes is thin and bland.”)

When it appeared that Lincoln Center Theater’s production of “South Pacific” would be without its most important dame, the Rodgers and Hammerstein revival has cast its new Nellie Forbush — with a bit of finagling. The role of Nellie, which Kelli O’Hara will depart on March 7 as her soft and wavy frame is filled out by a new baby, will be taken over by Laura Osnes, of the recent Broadway revival of “Grease,” beginning on March 10. But Ms. Osnes had been cast in the White Plains Performing Arts Center’s coming production of “A Little Night Music”; her role will instead be taken over by Erin Davie, of the Broadway musicals “Curtains” and “Grey Gardens.” “A Little Night Music” is scheduled from March 5 through 22; “South Pacific” continues at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, where Ms. O’Hara is scheduled to return on Oct. 6.

In a decision that could shave an entire minute off the running time of the Academy Awards broadcast, Peter Gabriel said that he would not perform his Oscar-nominated song, “Down to Earth,” on the show, Variety reported. Mr. Gabriel, who is nominated with Thomas Newman for the song from the animated feature “Wall-E,” withdrew when he learned that he would not be performing the track in its entirety but only a portion of about 60 to 65 seconds in a medley of best-song contenders. In a video on his Web site, petergabriel.com, Mr. Gabriel said the situation was “unfortunate,” adding, “It’s not going to do me any harm to make a little protest, but I think for some of the other artists it’s not so easy.” He said he hoped the Soweto Gospel Choir, which is featured on the song, might perform in his place.

A few weeks after being named an official citizen of Armenia, the singer-songwriter Charles Aznavour has put his new status to good use: he has been named that nation’s ambassador to Switzerland, BBC News reported. Mr. Aznavour, born Shahnour Aznavourian in Paris to Armenian parents, was granted citizenship in Armenia by the decree of that nation’s president in December; he has been the country’s delegate to Unesco and an advocate of charity efforts to benefit Armenia. Mr. Azanvour, who lives in Geneva, told Armenian television that he initially hesitated to accept appointment, adding, “But then I thought that, in the end, what is important for Armenia must be important for all of us,” according to the BBC.

The Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center have announced the lineup for the 2009 New Directors/New Films series. The program, which begins on March 25, will open with Cherien Dabis’s film “Amreeka,” about a Palestinian single mother and her teenage son who move to Illinois. The series will conclude on April 5 with Lee Daniels’s film “Push: Based on the Novel by Sapphire,” about a girl in an abusive family in 1980s Harlem. That film, which won the grand jury prize at the Sundance Film Festival, is being fought over by Lionsgate and the Weinstein Company, which both claim they have rights to distribute it. Other selections include Adam Del Deo’s and James D. Stern’s “Every Little Step,” about the Broadway revival of “A Chorus Line,” and Ondi Timoner’s “We Live in Public,” about the Internet pioneer Josh Harris. More information can be found online at filmlinc.com.

The Columbus Symphony Orchestra said that it would not renew the contract of its executive director, Tony Beadle, when it expires in August, Business First of Columbus reported. The orchestra has been in turmoil for months; in June, the symphony’s management suspended operations after the musicians’ union rejected proposals by the orchestra’s board to cut costs by reducing its roster of full-time musicians, their salaries and performance weeks. A new three-year deal was reached in September, but the music director, Junichi Hirokami, departed in November, having described the orchestra’s board and management as “stupid people” in May. The orchestra said it hoped to find a replacement for Mr. Beadle before August; he is expected to remain in his position until a successor is named.

To the relief of cultural institutions, the economic-stimulus bill approved by Congress on Friday preserved $50 million in financing for the National Endowment for the Arts. While minuscule by comparison with some other allocations in the bill, it is a hefty sum for the endowment, whose annual budget is $145 million. Sixty percent of the new money will go to individual arts projects competing for N.E.A. funds. The remainder will be be distributed to state arts agencies and regional arts organizations for disbursal.

After 77 years, the New Dance Group will close its doors on Sunday, ending a history of providing a space for modern dance lessons. The organization simply ran out of money and could not afford the rent at its building at 305 West 38th Street, said its chairman, Marvin Preston. The staff will be let go, he added. The group is negotiating with other dance studio operators to take over the lease, Mr. Preston said, but there was no guarantee an agreement would be reached. Meanwhile, New Dance Group’s board will continue to function and seek to raise money to preserve its archives digitally and to mount exhibits. “We hope to set a model for other organizations going forward,” Mr. Preston said. “It’s a web 2.0 New Dance Group.” The group outfit was founded in the Depression and provided inexpensive lessons. Choreographers associated with it produced important works, many of them with a populist and activist bent. New Dance Group also sponsored a company, but that arm has been moribund for the past several years.

Catholic churches have recently revived indulgences, a spiritual tradition that faded away in the 1960's after the Second Vatican Council. The indulgence, as Paul Vitello of The New York Times explained in a recent article, is "a sort of amnesty from punishment in the afterlife." Some liberal Catholics see the return of indulgences as a setback to modernization of the church. But church leaders say they deepen the spiritual experience of seeking penance.

In my column this week, I come out solidly in favor of nationalizing insolvent banks. It took me a while to get there; longer than it should have, really. Others, like Nouriel Roubini, who wrote an article in The Washington Post making the case for nationalization recently, Paul Krugman of The Times and other influential academics, have been way ahead in seeing the obviousness of this solution. Really, it's pretty simple. If the government is going to be capitalizing the banks, it really needs to own the common equity -- or warrants that can be converted to common. It is hard to understand why the government has been so concerned about protecting the banks' shareholders and unsecured bondholders.

Imagine our surprise. Not 12 steps from the elevator door at the downtown criminal courts building here stood Marina Zenovich. She would be the filmmaker whose documentary, "Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired," did not make the short list of Oscar-contenders this year, despite excellent reviews and churning up a still-raging storm over alleged wrong-doing by the justice system from which Mr. Polanski fled to France. He did so after pleading guilty to having wrongful sex with a minor three decades ago.

I've said before how often I eat scrambled eggs -- a few times a week, usually for dinner, cooked with whatever cheese I have in the fridge and served with toast and a very simple salad. It's one of my all-time favorite meals. I also love poached eggs, soft-fried eggs, hard- or soft-boiled eggs -- any kind of egg preparation, when it comes down to it, and I'm particularly happy when the egg can be thrown on top of something I'm already making, thereby jazzing up its appearance, flavor and texture.

Something that probably won't be in Hollywood's swag bag next week is a meaningful tax incentive from the state of California for film and television production here. A large credit designed to lure film work back from states that took it away with similar credits -- New York, Louisiana and Michigan among them -- had been on the table through most of the furious back-room battle over the state's budget,. But, as of last night, word among those who monitor such things was that the incentive, often defeated here in the past, was on the ropes again.

In 2007, a college student explained to me that he preferred Facebook to MySpace because MySpace (in his view) was for emo kids who liked Death Cab for Cutie and Facebook was for clever kids who liked words. "The Facebook interface is minimalist and not stupid or smeared with fingerpaint like MySpace," he said, if I remember right. "It leaves room for wit."

I met the photographer Elle Muliarchyk in 2006, when she was being profiled for T. At the time the Belarusian-born Muliarchyk, a former model who was discovered in a SoHo cafe by Patrick Demarchelier, was making a name for herself with her guerrilla-style self-portraits taken in high-fashion dressing rooms without the permission of the boutiques. (She has been thrown out of more prestigious stores than she cares to remember and was arrested on one occasion.) For her latest project, "Begotten," which appears in the new issue of Tar magazine and in an exhibition that opens tonight at Milk Studios, the 24-year-old provocateur has ditched dressing rooms in favor of churches.

Data from two flight-data recorders and a cockpit voice recorder of Continental Flight 3407, which crashed near Buffalo on Thursday night, killing 50 people, revealed that the crew members reported "significant ice buildup" on the windshield and leading edge of the plane's wings and described "severe pitch and roll" in the moments before the deadly crash, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Friday afternoon.

What proud New York City parent hasn't looked at their child's finger-paint work and thought they had a budding Pollock on their hands? Stare at those wobbly stick figures of Mommy and Daddy long enough and you start to see the first strokes of an Ab-Ex genius. As an accomplished artist herself, Rita Ackerman perhaps had a keener insight into the talent of her daughter Marika Thunder, who at age 10, is having her first solo show, "Randomness in the Form of Art," at Half Gallery starting this Sunday, Feb. 15. (Thunder will even get to celebrate at her after-party since Monday's a school holiday.) While her mom's painting and collage images often feature half-naked nymphs, Thunder's subject matter is strictly G-rated. Still, both artists find their inspiration in the fast-paced pop culture that surrounds them: Mom has found her muses in New York's grittier downtown scene and Kate Moss, daughter looks to Japanese anime and the "Twilight" series. Along with her sketches of wide-eyed goth girls and Silly String installations, Thunder has spray-painted and plastered the wall with mashups of magazine cutouts. "It looks really funny," says Thunder, who invited a friend to help "decorate" this tween fantasy romper room. The art has a sweet poutiness to it, but the prices are nothing to sulk about.

Want to write a Valentine's Day poem for your honey but lack basic rhyming skills? Sean Cole of the radio show "Marketplace" has the dirt on various online Cyranos for hire.

I would like to give my support to the Grand Prix Drivers Association in their battle to resolve the problem of the outrageous sums they have to pay for their Formula One super license. I know some of my colleagues in the media think that because people around the world are losing jobs that Grand Prix drivers should not make themselves look like spoiled children by complaining about paying exorbitant sums for their driving licenses. (By the way, I live in France where passing a drivers' license probably costs 10 times more than the super license in proportion to the average worker's salary. Still, here that is done only once in a lifetime and you never have to prove yourself capable of driving again, nor pay anything more.)

In the living room of a home that had recently gone into foreclosure, Koko Barnes listened late into the night as 16 strangers shared their stories of job loss, unpaid bills and damaged credit scores.

Today on The Lede, we have a contribution from John Schwartz, who wrote in Friday's New York Times about Pacer, the Public Access to Court Electronic Records database run by the federal government. Mr. Schwartz focused on efforts by two activists "to push the court records system into the 21st century - by simply grabbing enormous chunks of the database and giving the documents away, to the great annoyance of the government."

CLARENCE CENTER, N.Y. -- Jaimeelynn Trujillo has heard dozens of planes fly overhead since moving into her apartment on Goodrich Street in June, but something about the sound Thursday about 10:15 p.m. concerned her.Mrs. Trujillo was watching television with her family when she heard a low buzzing sound from the sky, a sharp contrast to the higher pitches that most planes make. "I never get scared, but with the sound of the pitch, that's where I got scared," she said Friday afternoon.

The Quad dips into the high school ranks to relay the story of a bizarre basketball game in Sacramento that ended with a Rio Americano High School player at the line, shooting 18 free throws, his team down by 11.
Scenes from the photographer Eric Ray Davidson's exclusive fashion week diary.

Malcolm X and Muhammad Ali flank the steps to the old Public School 90 building on West 147th Street, bringing quiet protection to what was once a dirty, drug-filled stretch. For 10 years, their stoic portraits -- along with one of James Brown frozen in mid-shimmy -- have graced the People's Wall outside the long-empty Harlem school. "We survived the heroin and crack epidemics here," said James Top, a graffiti writer invited by the block association to paint the mural. "This street was the hub where cats used to sell their stuff. Even when we painted the walls, it was never easy. I once went to the store and when I got back the cops had everybody up against the wall. It was scary."
Updated 3:45 p.m.: Added comment from Todd Chaffee of Institutional Venture Partners.

Many of the major technology companies find themselves tumbling quarter-by-quarter through the rings of Dante's Inferno, as customers pull back on their purchases of equipment at a startling rate. And yet there's an eclectic group of smaller high-tech players that have managed to keep posting double-digit growth and attract new business.
There could be fewer newlyweds celebrating their first Valentine's Day this year at chic Manhattan restaurants favored by the Wall Street elite.

A few days before the Super Bowl, John Branch wrote a piece about the official Super Bowl logos through the years. We invited a handful of professional designers to show us what they thought this year's official logo should look like, and the results ranged from simple to absurd. Then we invited everyone else -- any Fifth Down visitors with a few minutes of spare time -- to submit a design.

Another small milestone in the rebuilding of the World Trade Center was passed on Monday. The steel framework of the south core of 1 World Trade Center (called Freedom Tower by former Gov. George E. Pataki) reached a height of more than 100 feet above the Vesey Street sidewalk.

At the behest of a sponsor, Michael Phelps has recorded a video apology to the people of China, expressing his remorse over the recently published pictures of him using a marijuana pipe and thanking them for their support and forgiveness.

A southbound subway train on the D express line derailed while passing by the 81st Street-American Museum of Natural History station on the Upper West Side of Manhattan around 12:35 p.m. Friday. No one was injured, but passengers had to be evacuated from the train.

It was late on Tuesday night and top White House negotiators, including the chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, and the budget director Peter Orszag, had been at the Capitol for many hours negotiating the final deal on the nearly $790 billion economic stimulus bill.

First, thanks to everyone who left comments under the post from yesterday on Ron Jankowski. There's an article on Ronnie in today's Journal News and at the bottom is the information that a memorial fund has been set up in his name through the Briarcliff Manor Fire Department, where he was a captain. The fund will be used for scholarships and community outreach programs, and the article contains an address for those who wish to contribute.
Since back before Frankenstein we have been simultaneously drawn to and frightened by the idea of scientists creating life.

Yves Saint Laurent called himself an acquirer, not a collector - but the buyers who are lining up for what may turn out to be the biggest single-owner sale in auction history might beg to differ. Our new home-page story by Guy Trebay, which also appears in this Sunday's New York Times Magazine, features photographs by the artists Jack Pierson, Massimo Vitali and Louise Lawler, who shot the late designer's apartment before it was dismantled. The extensive trove of art, furniture and bibelots being auctioned over three days by Christie's at the Grand Palais in Paris, starting February 23, betray a certain giddy compulsiveness, but they are also a testament to a life devoted to the pursuit of the exceptional and rare. Our three photographers' points of view are as varied as their subject matter: is it about louche decadence, sheer audacity or calming symmetry? You be the judge.

There's at least one Academy voter who thinks that a Heath Ledger victory in the best supporting actor category may not be such a sure thing: Josh Brolin. In a conversation with the Baguette after the nominations were announced last month, Mr. Brolin said he believed a certain Mr. Brolin has a pretty good shot at the award for his performance in "Milk." The Oscars, he cautioned, have a habit of throwing curveballs. "After what happened to Tilda Swinton last year, I think pretty anything can happened," he said.

In the Washington Post today, Max Boot, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, says that a recent cover story in Newsweek suggesting that Afghanistan might become "Obama's Vietnam" was full of "trite analogies" but "performed a public service by bringing up one of the biggest mistakes the United States made in Vietnam: backing the overthrow of Ngo Dinh Diem, the president of South Vietnam, in 1963."
It's the eve of Valentine's Day and the political operatives at the Republican National Committee are turning cupid's arrow on the Democrats.
A beguiling, orange-scented sauce that can be served with fish or vegetables, or as a topping for crostini.

President Barack Obama traveled the country this week stumping for his stimulus plan, while leaving some of the hour-by-hour negotiations to his top aides and members of Congress in Washington. He made his case to voters in Indiana, Florida, Virginia and Illinois, and is scheduled to promote the plan in Denver and Phoenix next week.

This week: a conversation with the novelist T. C. Boyle; Motoko Rich with Notes From the Field; Carl Hiaasen on his newest novel for young adults; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
If certain board members - including the president of a co-op - do not represent the best interest of shareholders, what is the legal process to remove them?

I live in a free-market apartment. The one-year lease recently expired, and my landlord offered a renewal. I did not sign the renewal. Nonetheless, my landlord has said that I am now under lease for another year. Is this legal? I thought that since I did not agree to the terms of the renewal lease, my status is that of a month-to-month tenant.

Following is the third and final set of responses from Catherine Blyth, who answered selected readers' questions about her book, "The Art of Conversation." The book explores this neglected pleasure, from greetings to small talk to gossip to humor, including shop talk, love talk, compliments, difficult conversation and even shutting people up.

Ivory Tower | You crave immortality, but you're a tad short on funds just now to buy the name of that building. What's an ego to do? Why, have an academic theorem named after you! A Harvard postdoctoral fellow shows how: simply conjure one from your own particular interests! But beware Stigler's Law of Eponymy: "No scientific law is named after its original discoverer" -- a law conceived, of course, by someone else. [Boston Globe]

Here at The Times, we often hear a common story of usage from our customers: Reading the Sunday Times, spreading out the paper on a table while eating brunch. For many of our customers, this ritual is fundamental to their enjoyment of the weekend, and its absence would be jolting.

Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

Beginning last summer and continuing at the Detroit auto show in January, Chrysler rolled out a line of electric cars that the company said it would manufacture soon(ish). It was a surprising announcement because Chrysler had rarely shown interest in electrics in the past, even as concept cars. Its electric-research arm, ENVI, was created only in November 2007, and Jim Press, the president of Chrysler, said at a meeting with the press a few days ago: "I don't think anyone will make any money on electric cars, but we have to have them."

Sirius XM Satellite Radio said Friday that it had refinanced about $172.5 million in outstanding bonds, but that it might be forced to file for bankruptcy by Tuesday if it cannot make further headway in negotiations with its creditors.

No longer will glassy yellow waves carve majestically from the ship's prow of the neon P&G Cafe sign at the corner of 73d Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan. After six decades, the jaunty logo - a backdrop to more than a dozen television shows and films - has yielded to a stony gray expanse as blank as a slap in the face.

Sometimes, the Bagger ends up sitting down to watch a movie and finds himself staring at the credits, open-mouthed at what he has just seen. Many times, he can't articulate why a movie left him so entranced, which is where Manohla Dargis often comes in. Today, Ms. Dargis writes about "Gomorrah," an Italian film that demonstrates how the Comorra, the Neopolitan mafia, slithers into almost all aspects of everyday life.

Other Oscar bloggers are more experienced (like Tom O'Neil), more beloved (Sasha Stone) or more schooled in cinema (Kris Tapley), but none of them gets invited every year to an Oscar party in Sweden. Each year, Christina Jeurling makes sure that the Bagger receives a lovely handcrafted invite. In the year "Departed" won, there was a lovely take on Martin Scorsese as a kind of puppet/action figure, last year's was a mobile that used some strike-themed art, and this year's design is an electoral motif with amazing little custom buttons for each best picture nominee.
The Bagger wrestles with the choice for best actor.

"It is interesting to contemplate an entangled bank, clothed with many plants of many kinds, with birds singing on the bushes, with various insects flitting about, and with worms crawling through the damp earth, and to reflect that these elaborately constructed forms, so different from each other, and dependent on each other in so complex a manner, have all been produced by laws acting around us."

Now that the Neanderthal genome has been reconstructed, my colleague Nicholas Wade reports, a leading genome researcher at Harvard says that a Neanderthal could be brought to life with present technology for about $30 million.

Top-ranked Connecticut is rolling, in large part thanks to Hasheem Thabeet. The praise is widespread, ranging from Jim Boeheim ("He changes the game.") to Jim Calhoun ("He has a regal sense about him.")Although some fans have started worrying that the Huskies are being disrespected, respect is probably not UConn's biggest worry now, with the loss of Jerome Dyson. The Huskies will see how well they do without Dyson when they face Seton Hall on Saturday.

Spend some time near the cash register in a Manhattan hair salon, or peruse the list of prices for various cuts, colorings, blow-dryings or permanents, and you will begin to see, if you didn't already, just how much money local governments can make from taxing those services.

The Bagger put on his curmudgeon suit yesterday and sprayed some bad attitude about this year's Oscars. But in a year when the Super Bowl scored excellent numbers, the Grammys did better than expected, and movie attendance is up significantly, who is to say that the show of shows might not have a little bounce in the ratings? At a time when there is bad news on every horizon, gathering around the tube for a little Oscar song and dance might sound just right.

There are few Oscar savants more stalwart or respected than Dave Karger of Entertainment Weekly, and he is a particular favorite this time of year because his weekly deadlines compel him to do his picking ahead of time. Mr. Karger is going with a "Slumdog Millionaire" sweep of seven awards, including picture, director, adapted screenplay, cinematography, editing, song and score. He's picking Kate Winslet and Sean Penn for lead actors, and Penelope Cruz and Heath Ledger in the supporting category. The Bagger, who doesn't have to lock his picks until next Thursday, is in basic agreement, although he is leaning toward Mickey Rourke in actor and Viola Davis in the supporting female category. This is actually starting to get fun.

"At the center of the effort are a cable channel, scheduled to start at 12:01 Friday morning and offering action-adventure programs and youth-oriented sports news (provided via ESPN, which is owned by Disney), and a Web site offering games, music and social networking tools." "Fringe," which had its premiere in September, was the first test of Fox's fewer-commercials strategy, which the network calls "Remote-Free TV." The second test comes tonight with the premiere of "Dollhouse."

Thanks to everyone for the interesting to & fro on Michelle Obama's wardrobe and Ikram Goldman. A number of people called this way of shopping with one boutique owner modern. It is certainly loyal, but women, whether they are homemakers with children or women with demanding careers, have been relying on specialty stores and personal shoppers for years. Alex A, I appreciate your account from Chicago. Most of us who follow fashion have had the good fortunate to know a lot of savvy retailers. Off the top of my head: Hattie Belkin, Linda Dresner and Lynn Portnoy from Detroit; the late Lynn Manulis of Martha; Ron Herman in L.A. and the super-smart Nina Garduno; Katy and Matthew Culmo in Austin, and of course Marilyn Blaszka and Dominic Marcheschi at Blake in Chicago.

The James Beard Foundation announced the dozens of semifinalists for 9 national and ten regional restaurant and chef awards. On March 23 the five finalists in each category will be announced. The award ceremony will be held on May 3 at Avery Fisher Hall.

On Wednesday's "The Late Show with David Letterman," the actor Joaquin Phoenix "appeared to forget the name of his 'Two Lovers' co-star, Gwyneth Paltrow, stuck gum under the edge of Letterman's desk and apparently cursed at bandleader Paul Shaffer for laughing at him," the Associated Press reports.

Joaquin Phoenix's addled appearance on "Late Show With David Letterman" the other night probably didn't do his already corroded public image much good, even if it is all a hoax. (And it probably didn't do any favors for his new movie, "Two Lovers." But look on the bright side. The Bagger covered him in 2005 when he was up for "Walk the Line," and we can all be thankful he has finally gotten rid of the frogs in his hair.

It was just yesterday that the White House was trumpeting on its blog the 350,000 job applications it received for several thousand positions in the Obama administration, but try as President Obama might, there are at least two top positions in his cabinet he can't seem to fill.

Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner's has been criticized in the media and by critics for failing to present a fully fleshed-out plan to tackle the nation's financial crisis. One of the more vague points in his speech Tuesday was that the government would use "stress tests" to determine the health of banks.

In an age when the president of the United States insists on carrying a BlackBerry and much of the United States Capitol has wireless Internet access, the final draft of the $789 billion economic stimulus measure posted late last night to the Web site of the House Rules Committee looks more like the Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 1979 than of 2009 - filled with hand-written copy-editing marks, insertions scrawled in the margins, deletions of whole paragraphs boxed with X's slashing through them, and a variety of curious hash marks and other annotations.

Richard Corliss is none too impressed with this year's films, suggesting that the contemporary Oscars really have much more in common with the Emmys than the Academy Award's storied history. The Bagger can't find the interview online, but Rolling Stone's chat with Sean Penn included a cool vignette from Mr. Penn. He and Paul Thomas Anderson had both finished their films - "Into the Wild" and "There Will Be Blood," respectively - and were showing the finished work to each other. Mr. Penn made it clear in the interview that part of what drove him to go deep in bringing Harvey Milk alive was watching Daniel Day-Lewis's no-holds-barred, Oscar-winning performance as Daniel Plainview.

You'd think the folks at Fox Searchlight would be at their ease right now, seeming to be riding into Oscar week with a big lead for "Slumdog Millionaire," but someone the Bagger talked to there says the studio is not counting its chickens just yet.

Europe | Since the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, Eastern Europe has seen two waves of nationalism sweep over it, a Hungarian political scientist writes -- anti-Soviet nationalism followed by a second wave feeding off illusory expectations. Better brace for a third, he says. And this time, it's not just low-wage workers losing their jobs, but modernizers and leading industrialists. "Now they can regard the Jew, the Gypsy, the Pole, the Czech, the Slovak, the Hungarian, the European, the American, and anyone else, as the scapegoat who is responsible for their lot." [Salon.eu.sk]
Good news: Congress has defied the efforts of drug companies and medical-device producers to strip comparative effectiveness research from the stimulus bill. One small victory for sanity and justice.

The new Survey of Consumer Finances shows an increase in family net worth between 2004 and 2007 -- but estimates, based on stock and housing prices, that all of that gain and more has been wiped out since then. Adjusted for inflation, families are poorer now than they were in 2001.
A Continental flight from Newark to Buffalo crashed into a house about five miles from Buffalo Niagara International Airport on Thursday night, killing 50 people, officials said.

By any measure, money for mass-transit agencies seems to be a fine form of stimulus. Many local agencies are now facing budget shortfalls, leading them to raise fares, cut services and lay off workers. If the federal government sent money to these agencies, it would prevent some job cuts -- serving as a quick form of stimulus, since a job not lost is just as good as one created. Money for mass transit would also make it easier for low-income workers, who are so far bearing the brunt of the recession, to get to their jobs or to search for new ones.

History | Forget gauzy fantasies of people pulling together in hard times, a writer says. The Depression "was a miserable time for most. Worldwide, slack economic conditions helped plant the seeds for the discontent that led to World War II. Those same conditions gave rise to fascism and anti-Semitism in the United States. People starved ..." [Boston Globe]
The maker of the Tomb Raider games has dodged financial peril through a bid from a major Japanese video game producer.

Journalism | To save itself, the press ought to declare itself a tax-exempt religion, a columnist says in a "modest proposal." After all, American journalism is a "belief system" reflecting an idealized notion of democracy. It's not much different from the clergy of early colonial days, when "the typical sermon reviewed major events of the week (news) and scrutinized them for hints of God's will (editorials)." Praying is another idea. [Slate]

Roche Holding is planning to hold a European roadshow next week for a bond issue to help the Swiss drug maker finance its planned buyout of Genentech, Reuters reported, citing three sources familiar with the situation.

Language | The idea of a comprehensive slang dictionary is a "lexicographical mirage," a reviewer agrees. From "pine drape" (coffin) to "breaking off one's math" (give a person one's phone number) -- "The more one rummages in these two volumes, the more one sees how quickly slang becomes dated. Not all slang is ephemeral, but its essential intimacy and spontaneity make it the most disposable kind of poetry." [Times of London]

After years of struggling with an ever-growing debt burden, Charter Communications is trying to clean up its balance sheet, The New York Times's Michael J. de la Merced writes.

Google has acquired the buildings and premises of a mill site in Finland for around $51.7 million.
Charles W. Ergen's move to snap up Sirius XM Satellite Radio debt has been regarded as shrewd play by the EchoStar chief to take over the struggling satellite radio company on the cheap.

Sumner Redstone said Thursday that negotiations were advancing with creditors to restructure $1.6 billion of debt from National Amusements, a holding company that owns cinema chains and his controlling stakes in Viacom and CBS.

Iran | To understand what makes Iran tick, it helps to be student of Persian poetry, according to a new history. We're in luck, since Rumi is the bestselling poet in translation in the United States -- although, the author notes, "it has been Rumi's misfortune to be befriended by numb-brained New Agery." Still, Persian verse shows that Iran's identity "is much more cultural than political or even geographical in essence." [Times Literary Supplement]

Web-based mail is great - until you don't have an Internet connection. To ease the separation anxiety, Google recently introduced a feature called Offline Gmail that downloads a copy of your mailbox and all the recent messages when you do have Internet access, and then keeps it all available in your Web browser when you don't.

The Justice Department is seeking expanded powers to prosecute offshore tax evasion and other financial crimes, including those related to the mortgage industry and potential misuse of government bailout money, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reports.

Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

As insulation maker Roxul Inc. prepares to double its North American production capacity next month with the opening of a $140 million production plant west of Toronto, the company's president, Trent Ogilvie, wants to see the introduction of home energy labels.

The American International Group's financial products unit, which brought the firm to the verge of collapse with bad bets on credit-default swaps, is being investigated by British prosecutors for possible criminal conduct.

Morgan Stanley recently fired a high-ranking executive working for its real estate subsidiary in China after discovering evidence that he may have violated the United States Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, The New York Times's David Barboza reports.
Snam Rete Gas, owner of the Italian natural gas grid, has agreed to buy Eni's gas retail and storage businesses for 4.72 billion euros ($6.03 billion).

When Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner arrives in Rome for the first official meeting with his Group of 7 counterparts, he will be a bit of an outlier, The New York Times's Landon Thomas Jr. reported.
Just as Wall Street was peering over the abyss, stocks staged a last-minute turnaround, The New York Times's Jack Healy reports.

Swiss-based Herzog & de Meuron, the architects behind the Beijing Olympic stadium known as the Bird's Nest, have been commissioned to design three towers for a new mixed-use project in the heart of London.

The Denver Broncos promoted Brian Xanders to general manager. Xanders joined the Broncos as assistant general manager May 5 after several seasons in the Atlanta Falcons’ organization. He served as assistant general manager in Denver along with Jeff Goodman, whose father, Jim, was the Broncos’ vice president for football operations. The Goodmans were fired when Xanders was promoted. The team owner Pat Bowlen said he was confident Xanders and Josh McDaniels, the new coach, would lead the Broncos back to the playoffs after a three-year drought.

Top-ranked Serena Williams showed no signs of the illness that kept her bedridden last week as she ousted Karolina Sprem, 6-1, 6-2, to reach the quarterfinals of the Paris Open. Williams, after winning the Australian Open, did not practice until Monday and was relieved to get through the first round of this indoor tournament she has won twice. Her second-round match was easier, as Williams took less than an hour to beat Sprem, a qualifier from Croatia, converting her first match point with a forehand return winner down the line. Next up will be the French qualifier Emilie Loit, whom Williams has not met in six years.

Chicago and Tokyo submitted their official bid books to the International Olympic Committee for the 2016 Summer Games. Madrid and Rio de Janeiro delivered their documents on Wednesday as all four candidates met the deadline of midnight Thursday.

A federal judge in Texas dismissed a large portion of a defamation lawsuit filed by Roger Clemens against his chief accuser and former trainer, Brian McNamee. In the ruling, United States District Judge Keith P. Ellison said that statements McNamee made to George J. Mitchell about Clemens’s alleged use of steroids and human growth hormone were privileged because they were made in connection with a federal investigation. All that remained of the lawsuit were Clemens’s accusations that McNamee defamed him when he told Andy Pettitte in 1999 or 2000 that Clemens used performance-enhancing drugs.

Jerry Richardson, the Carolina Panthers owner, cleared another hurdle in his recovery from a heart transplant when he was released from the hospital 12 days after the surgery. Richardson left Carolinas Medical Center in Charlotte and was resting at home after doctors determined his body was accepting the new heart. The full recovery period takes up to six months. Richardson, 72, a former teammate of Johnny Unitas’s with the Baltimore Colts and the first former N.F.L. player since George Halas to own a team, has a history of heart trouble. He underwent quadruple bypass surgery in 2002 and last year had a pacemaker installed.
Shawn Marion’s dunk with 1.1 seconds left gave the Miami Heat a 95-93 victory over the Bulls on Thursday night in Chicago.
The American Classical Orchestra offered prime examples of Haydn’s works on Wednesday evening in its Haydn bicentennial concert.
Phil Carey was best known for his role as the tycoon Asa Buchanan in the ABC soap opera “One Life to Live.”

Employers are not obligated to cover the moving costs and other expenses incurred by many immigrant workers, a federal appeals court has ruled in a case against a New Orleans hotelier that hired dozens of foreign workers after Hurricane Katrina. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ordered the dismissal of a suit that accused Decatur Hotels of exploiting foreign employees recruited in August 2005.

Gov. Ted Strickland spared the life of a death row inmate who killed his mother in a cocaine-induced rage and whose scheduled execution was opposed by his family, including his mother’s siblings. The inmate, Jeffrey Hill, 44, had been scheduled to die March 3. But Mr. Strickland said he agreed with the Ohio Parole Board, which recommended last week that Mr. Hill not be put to death and should eventually be released from prison. Mr. Hill stabbed his mother, Emma Hill, to death in 1991. As she lay dying in her Cincinnati apartment, he took $20 from her to spend on drugs, returning later to take $80. Mr. Hill’s family said they had suffered enough and that putting him to death would only make matters worse.

The Justice Department indicated that it was not backing away from the argument used by the Bush administration that courts should use national security concerns to block a lawsuit brought by an Islamic group that says its rights had been violated. Department lawyers filed papers with a Federal District Court in San Francisco asking for a stay in a judge’s ruling that the “state secrets” doctrine could not be used in the Islamic group’s lawsuit. The group, al-Haramain, has argued that its officers and lawyers were illegally wiretapped in a secret surveillance program by the National Security Administration. The Justice Department under President Bush invoked the state secrets doctrine in asking the court to dismiss the case.

The Arkansas Senate completed action on an increase in state tobacco taxes, granting Gov. Mike Beebe a major victory and the centerpiece of his legislative program. Mr. Beebe, a Democrat, lobbied extensively for the bill, approval of which required an extraordinary three-fourths majority vote in both chambers of the General Assembly. The House of Representatives passed the legislation with the 75 vote minimum, but supporters in the 35-member Senate produced one vote more than the 27 required.
A Continental flight from Newark plunged into a house in Clarence Center, N.Y., near Buffalo, killing 50 people.

Last month, T's fashion director Anne Christensen went down to New Orleans to shoot the best of the New York spring collections. (The results appear this weekend in The New York Times Magazine and on one of our two new home pages.) Extreme fashion finery such as Proenza Schouler's disco ball jumpsuit, Marc Jacobs's Mary Poppins ensembles and Rodarte's shredded bondage dresses often prompt the question, "Where would I possibly wear that?" -- except maybe in the pages of a magazine. But these spring showstoppers looked remarkably at home in what Christensen described as one of the most unforgettable cities she's ever encountered. Of course, the St. Roch neighborhood where the shoot mostly took place is fairly unforgettable even by New Orleans standards. Here, Kirsha Kaechele has been transforming derelict cottages and other ramshackle sites into living works of art. For more about Kaechele KK Projects/Life Is Art Foundation, check out Linda Yablonsky's profile of her in the fall 2008 issue of T Design.
The Treasury secretary hasn’t said how he will induce financial institutions to sell toxic assets and private investors to put up capital.

Foppa is back! Peter Forsberg, who gave up on trying to come back to the N.H.L. this year and who wasn't even able to play for Sweden in the Euro Hockey Tour earlier this month, did finally make it to the ice on Thursday. He played for his hometown club team in the Swedish Elitserien, MODO Hockey Örnsköldsvik -- and he scored the first goal!
“Leaving Las Vegas” works as a character study, pitilessly well observed and intimately familiar with its terrain.
Washington’s Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.
The moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie in “Moonstruck, and a lot of other things do too.
This White House has more alumni of Congress than any in recent memory. They're learning how to exert their power on Capitol Hill.

For years, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation, has been trying to get chess accepted as part of the Olympics. The effort has included instituting drug testing to comply with regulations of the International Olympic Committee. Few think that Ilyumzhinov's crusade will succeed, but someone in upstate New York has borrowed from an existing Olympic sport to create a "sporting" event that at least seems more Olympian.
The cockpit voice recorder indicated the crew reported significant icing on the plane’s windshield and wings.
Starbucks is moving into the instant coffee market as it works to shake off its reputation as a seller of expensive coffee drinks.

An Op-Ed article on Tuesday, about tax incentives for solar water heaters, incorrectly described the federal tax credit for installing photovoltaic solar panels. There is no longer a cap on the credit. The previous cap, which was $2,000, not $5,000, ended on Jan. 1.

Notre Dame shot 54 percent at home Thursday night in a 90-57 victory over No. 5 Louisville that ended a seven-game losing streak.
Daniel Murphy’s sweet left-handed swing and precocious plate discipline fueled his two-year ascent from 13th-round draft pick to the major leagues.
Some antidoping experts say that cycling teams’ internal testing programs are virtually useless in proving that a rider is clean.
Mr. Ritchie played the patriarch Clint Buchanan on the ABC soap opera “One Life to Live” for two decades.
Mr. Leonard was a prolific Irish playwright, memoirist, travel writer and dyspeptic newspaper columnist whose autobiographical play “Da” won four Tony Awards in 1978.
Ms. Rickert starred in several “Our Gang” film comedies as a child and later became a burlesque performer.
The only way to close this chapter is for Major League Baseball to go through a deep and intensive soul-searching.
After inventing the first artificial kidney, Dr. Kolff went on to prove that biomedical engineers could build all sorts of artificial organs.
It's early days yet, but we're falling behind the curve. America just isn't rising to the challenge of the greatest economic crisis in 70 years.
The policy makers may know how to pull economic levers, but what happens when they don’t know how to use those levers to affect social psychology?

All sides of the immigration debate should agree that a new New York State program to end exploitation of low-wage workers is wise and overdue.
Morgan Tsvangirai, Zimbabwe’s new prime minister, promises national reform. But without pressure from African leaders, it is doubtful that Robert Mugabe — the illegitimate president — will allow it.
A federal vaccine court issued verdicts that should help end parents’ lingering fears that childhood vaccines can and have caused autism.
The stimulus and recovery package could have accomplished so much more. The next shot at this puzzle will be President Obama’s first budget bill.
Ten people arrested during a peaceful demonstration in Harare, the capital, on Tuesday, were released on bail Thursday.
The Angels agreed to a one-year, $5 million contract with the veteran outfielder Bobby Abreu on Thursday.
Tomas Vokoun made 42 saves for his fourth shutout of the season on Thursday as the Florida Panthers routed the host Carolina Hurricanes, 5-0.
The unsettling reality is that despite food’s cheery packaging and nutritional labeling, we don’t really know what we’re putting into our mouths.
Medicare has tentatively decided not to pay for virtual colonoscopies, dealing a setback to a technique that medical experts recommend for colon cancer screening.
Brett Ratliff and Kellen Clemens are the top candidates — as of Thursday — to be the Jets’ starting quarterback next season.
Even as clerks were still drafting the measure, a broad array of industries and interest groups scrambled to calculate winners and losers in the final stimulus deal.
Two Pennsylvania judges were accused of taking bribes to send teenagers to private detention centers.
FRONT PAGE.

An obituary on Tuesday about the playwright Robert Anderson misidentified the directors of Broadway productions of “The Gin Game,” by D. L. Coburn, and “The Shadow Box,” by Michael Cristofer. The original Broadway production of “The Gin Game” in 1977 was directed by Mike Nichols, and a revival in 1997 was directed by Charles Nelson Reilly. The original Broadway production of “The Shadow Box,” also in 1977, was directed by Gordon Davidson; a 1994 revival was directed by Jack Hofsiss. Arvin Brown, one of Mr. Anderson’s directors, did not direct Broadway productions of either play. (He was artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, where both plays originated, and was director of a television movie based on “The Gin Game.”).

The Quotation of the Day on Thursday, taken from a front-page article about the challenges facing the ethanol industry, omitted a word in the comment by Aaron Brady, an energy expert at Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm. As the article correctly noted, he said, “Cellulosic ethanol” — not “Ethanol” — “is something that is always five years away and five years later you get to the point where it’s still five years away.” (Ethanol is now blended into gasoline throughout the country. Cellulosic ethanol, made from nonfood materials like switchgrass and scrap wood, is not expected to be readily available at a reasonable price for some years to come.).
Three teenage pedestrians were injured in the Bronx on Thursday after a car that had been stopped by the police drove onto a sidewalk, struck them and hit a concrete wall.
Two mayoral candidates raised thousands of dollars in campaign donations from limited liability corporations shortly before the fund-raising method was banned in 2007.
Sean Avery is working his way back into shape and the league’s good graces, among a group of N.H.L. hopefuls, while being watched carefully by the Rangers.

An article on Monday about the demolition or threatened destruction of buildings commissioned by the Works Progress Administration misstated part of the name of the organization for which Trent Margriff works. Mr. Margriff, who bemoaned damage at the Lost Lake Campground near Rhinelander, Wis., is with the National Trust for Historic Preservation; there is no National Trust for Historic Places.

An article by The Associated Press on Wednesday about a lawsuit by the American Medical Association against the insurers Aetna and Cigna referred incorrectly to a separate $350 million legal settlement between the A.M.A. and another insurer, the UnitedHealth Group. The settlement remains tentative. UnitedHealth has not yet paid the $350 million because some individual doctors have challenged the deal in court.
Geert Wilders, who has compared the Koran to “Mein Kampf,” was ordered to leave Britain on the grounds that his presence endangered public security.
New York State will receive vast sums of money for Medicaid, education, transportation and housing as part of the federal stimulus package.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the reintroduction of the indulgence, a form of amnesty from punishment in the afterlife, in Roman Catholic churches misstated the given name of a worshiper at a church in Queens. She is Octavia Andrade, not Olivia.
Iranian women are showing growing determination to achieve equal status in this conservative Muslim country.
A federal judge in Texas dismissed a portion of a defamation lawsuit filed by Roger Clemens against his chief accuser and former trainer, Brian McNamee.
The Justice Department is seeking expanded powers to prosecute offshore tax evasion and other financial crimes.
Charter Communications said that it would file for bankruptcy by April 1 as part of an effort to handle $21 billion in debt.
A move to create a union at one of the city’s leading charter schools may turn into a protracted battle, as the deadline passed for the school to voluntarily recognize the union.
The emergency cost-cutting program announced last week will also include possibly shorter workweeks and reductions in executive compensation.
Most of us will be able to use at least one of the tax breaks and handouts included in the proposed stimulus bill.
Heath care groups have decided to stop running an advertisement featuring a blind man questioning Gov. David A. Paterson’s health care budget plan.
More peregrine falcons made New York City home in 2008, reflecting a record-setting year in the state’s effort to bring back the birds, an endangered species.
Experts say the situation at some of the nation’s banks demands a more direct government role than in the plan outlined this week.
Tranquil conditions turned the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am into paradise Thursday, especially for the big hitters Robert Garrigus and Dustin Johnson.
New technologies help older people to live alone and avoid trips to hospitals or nursing homes.
Police in South Carolina arrested eight people in connection with the party at which Michael Phelps was photographed using a marijuana pipe.
A woman’s trek to find work in a Texas ranching town has made her a celebrity and a magnet for generosity.
An Ohio court ruling on Thursday could markedly alter negotiations between Major League Baseball draft picks and their teams if it withstands appeal.
President Obama has chosen R. Gil Kerlikowske, the chief of police in Seattle, as his drug czar, an administration official said Thursday.
The company found evidence that a high-ranking executive may have violated the United States Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.
A group of dedicated open-government activists have teamed up to push the federal court records system into the 21st century, much to the annoyance of the government.
In comedy, there is the straight man. In basketball, there are Red Klotz’s Generals, the foils for the Harlem Globetrotters.
The administration is developing a standardized way to fix the mortgages of people near foreclosure.
The negotiations over the largest economic rescue plan since the New Deal offered a window into the relationship between President Obama’s administration and Congress.
The American International Group says it will cooperate with a British inquiry into its financial products group.
The producers would not give a reason for the disqualification of Joanna Pacitti, a semifinalist, who was replaced by someone who was previously eliminated.
President Obama brought his economic recovery road show to East Peoria, Ill., telling workers at a plant there that the recovery effort could bring back some of their jobs.
The Federal Trade Commission said Internet companies are not explaining to users what information they collect about them.
The media conglomerate, controlled by Sumner M. Redstone, reported solid earnings although its profit fell significantly, partly to reflect a big restructuring change.
Police continued to sort out the events that led to the death of Guido Carabajo, who was struck by a car and then dragged for almost 20 miles through Queens and Brooklyn.
Snam Rete, owner of the Italian natural gas grid, has agreed to buy Eni’s gas retail and storage businesses for 4.72 billion euros.
The Walt Disney Company has remade Toon Disney to offer action-adventure programs and sports news for ages 6 to 14.
Fox’s fewer-commercials strategy is based on the theory that with shorter commercial breaks, viewers will be less likely to reach for the remote control.
Some students of Japan’s lost decade say they see the United States making familiar mistakes.
Alex Rodriguez has not yet arrived in Florida for spring training with the Yankees, but the fallout from his steroids confession preceded him.
Jason Logan illustrates some updated meanings for the flowers you’ll be sending (or receiving) on Valentine’s Day.
Now that Alex Rodriguez has admitted to steroid use when he played with the Rangers, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi must help temper a huge distraction.
While the Obama administration says it is not seeking to control financial institutions, there is a growing sense in Europe that banks should be put on a tight leash.
Winds that gusted up to 60 miles an hour killed three people, injured others and caused travel delays and power failures in homes and businesses around New York.
Opposition to the tax, which would raise $1.5 billion a year, is coming from businesses as well as public officials worried about schools and health care.
Authorities wonder whether the high yields offered by Stanford Financial are simply too good to be true.
Their $28-an-hour jobs gone, laid-off workers from a plant in Wisconsin are trying to reinvent themselves.
Researchers are trying to determine if the geese that were sucked into the engine of the plane that pitched into the Hudson River last month were resident or migratory birds.
MOVIES.
“Pitchers and catchers report,” that sacred phrase for baseball fans around the country, will ring hollow for some Yankees fans this year.
Taiwan’s president said he was not concerned that Taiwan was low on Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s list of priorities.
With elections looming, Mexico City’s mayor, Marcelo Ebrard, is giving Viagra away to poor, older men.
The undying “Friday the 13th” franchise gets a surprisingly decent reboot in this stylish, playful example of the decapitated hottie genre.
The Brazilian police said Thursday that it arrested 55 people involved in two crime rings that were smuggling drugs into the country from Europe.
39 Iraqis were also wounded in a spate of attacks that included the assassination of a Sunni Arab political leader in the violent northern city of Mosul.
Members of Congress have raised concerns over whether nonprofit hospitals provide enough free care and other community benefits to justify their tax exemptions.
Just in time for Valentine’s Day, Israel allowed the export of a shipment of flowers from Hamas-run Gaza on Thursday for the first time in roughly a year.
It is the ambition of “Becoming Edvard Munch: Influence, Anxiety and Myth,” a thrilling exhibition at the Art Institute of Chicago, to upend or at least balance Munch’s famous persona.
Gov. John Lynch of New Hampshire proposed closing a quarter of the state’s district courts as part of a plan to deal with a $500 million two-year budget gap.

No computer-designed animatronic invention can begin to match the beauty and grace of the oceanic life photographed in “Under the Sea 3D.”
Emily Jacir, who focuses on the plight of the Palestinian people in her art, is the subject of a thought-provoking exhibition at the Guggenheim.
The work of Italian artist Piero Manzoni, a child of Dada and a father of Conceptualism, is the subject of a retrospective at Gagosian Gallery.
The etiquette of hosting a large weekend party.

As an avid snorkeler and frequent Maui visitor, I enjoyed “A Free Water World: Snorkeling on Maui.” However, I noticed a few omissions that may adversely affect others who try to replicate the writer’s experience. South Maui does indeed offer excellent and plentiful shore snorkeling. However, shore snorkeling conditions are seasonal. In winter, shore snorkeling there is less certain. The sandy areas that create easy entry and exit during calm periods are disturbed by winter patterns of wave action and shore breaks, resulting in poor visibility and difficult entry and exit. Joan D. Winston.
“The International,” a sleek travelogue thriller, at least flirts with timeliness, winking at an angry and anxious public mood.
Azar Nafisi’s deeply felt family memoir is a kind of companion volume to her stunning 2003 account of life in Iran after the Revolution, “Reading Lolita in Tehran.”
In a performance at Birdland on Wednesday evening, Hilary Kole demonstrated that she is a singer with a glowing voice and something to say.

An article on Feb. 6 about snorkeling in Maui gave outdated information for one option that can be used to reach a snorkeling site called the Aquarium at La Perouse Bay. Hiking paths to the site are not currently open. (They have been closed since August and are not expected to reopen until at least the end of July 2010. The Aquarium could still be reached by boat, though motorboats are not allowed.).
Off the coast of British Columbia, life on this island is characterized by the residents’ attitudes on consumerism and the environment.
The N.A.A.C.P. celebrated its centennial by calling on the Obama administration and Congress to ensure that the stimulus package is distributed equitably.
Fractional residences at a Vail ski resort, and a Caribbean condominium-hotel in Barbados.

In Southern Vermont, this ski area was rebuilt with a focus on snow making and terrain parks.
