When some people say they are thrilled just to be nominated, they really mean it, and we should be thrilled along with them.
As goaltender Martin Brodeur prepares to rejoin the Devils for full practices, Scott Clemmensen and Kevin Weekes understand that one of them could soon lose his spot.
On Feb. 24, the raucous Zulu parade will roll down the streets of New Orleans, celebrating years of Mardi Gras tradition.

Jack White and Meg White, the rock duo better known as the White Stripes, will perform for next Friday’s broadcast of NBC’s “Late Night With Conan O’Brien,” the band’s publicist said in an e-mail message. The band has appeared together infrequently since its 2007 album “Icky Thump.” The show is Mr. O’Brien’s final episode as host of “Late Night” before Jimmy Fallon, the former “Saturday Night Live” star, takes over on March 2; Mr. O’Brien becomes host of NBC’s “Tonight Show” on June 1. ... U2 will be the musical guest for a full week on CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman,” from March 2 through 6, The Associated Press reported. The band’s new album, “No Line on the Horizon,” will be released on March 3.

The Connecticut Opera is going out of business, closing its headquarters in Hartford and laying off its entire staff, The Associated Press reported. The company said that it was closing after 67 seasons because of the declining economy; it has canceled its two spring productions, including “La Bohème,” and said it would not give refunds to its 2,000 subscribers. John Kreitler, chairman of the opera’s board, said the company was working with creditors to pay debts. The Connecticut attorney general’s office said it was looking into the company’s closure after customers who had bought tickets to the canceled productions were sent letters suggesting they write off the purchases as charitable contributions to the opera.

A handwritten manuscript of a speech given by Abraham Lincoln in 1864 sold for $3.44 million at an auction on Thursday, the highest price paid at an auction for an American historical document, The Associated Press reported. The speech, delivered by Lincoln at the White House after his re-election, was sold by Christie’s in New York to an anonymous telephone bidder. The price beat the previous record of $3.40 million, set last year for a letter written by Lincoln in 1864. The speech manuscript was put up for sale by the Southworth Library Association in Dryden, N.Y., which plans to use the proceeds to build a new wing.

The producers of “Minsky’s,” a new musical about that Depression-era burlesque impresario, said on Thursday that they were seeking a Broadway house for the 2009-10 theater season, confirming a report by The Associated Press. The musical opened in Los Angeles on Sunday to mixed reviews, but its producers, Kevin McCollum and Bob Boyett, said that they and their investors were enthusiastic about bringing the show to Broadway, despite the declining economy. “It also celebrates the fact that, right now, we need to laugh again,” Mr. McCollum said in an interview. The producers estimated that the budget for a Broadway production would be between $10 million and $12 million. The Los Angeles production of “Minsky’s” is at the Ahmanson Theater until March 1.
ABC has announced that Nicollette Sheridan, a star of “Desperate Housewives,” will leave the series.
Stephen Rubin, who stepped down as publisher of Doubleday Publishing Group in December, has been appointed publisher at large at Random House.

She’s not the first Anne Hathaway linked to Shakespeare — when you last saw this one in Central Park, she was most likely racing to complete an errand for the tyrannical Miranda Priestly in “The Devil Wears Prada.” But this summer you’ll be able to see Ms. Hathaway, left, as Viola in the Shakespeare in the Park production of “Twelfth Night,” the Public Theater announced. The play, directed by Daniel Sullivan, will run from June 9 through July 12 at the Delacorte Theater. The season’s second production will be Euripides’ “Bacchae,” directed by JoAnne Akalaitis with music by Philip Glass. ... Laura Benanti, a Tony Award winner for the recent Broadway revival of “Gypsy,” has joined the cast of the Public’s coming production of Christopher Durang’s new play, “Why Torture Is Wrong, And The People Who Love Them,” the Public announced. The comedy begins previews on March 24 and opens on April 6; its limited run is to end on April 26.

Of the 19th-century ballets that still dominate the classical repertory, “La Sylphide” is the oldest. What’s marvelous is that it often feels the freshest.

Increasingly, many older people who live alone are not truly alone. They are being watched by a flurry of new technologies designed to enable them to live independently and avoid expensive trips to the emergency room or nursing homes. Bertha Branch, 78, discovered the power of a system called eNeighbor when she fell to the floor of her Philadelphia apartment late one night without her emergency alert pendant and could not phone for help.

LUCE--Leila Hadley, author, born in New York in 1925 died at home Tuesday, February 10th. An acclaimed author of several books, Leila had two of her books, Give Me the World and A Journey with Elsa Cloud, chosen by the New York Times as notable books of the year. Leila was a dedicated supporter of the Tibetan people serving on the board of Tibet House for many years and was endowed the Leila Hadley Luce Chair for Modern Tibetan Studies at Columbia University. She is the cofounder of Wings WorldQuest, a nonprofit dedicated to women explorers and education. She was a member of PEN, the Fishers Island Conservancy and the Explorer's Club. Leila was particularly proud of her garden on Fishers Island, NY, which was the subject of her last book, A Garden by the Sea. She was the widow of Henry Luce III, son of the founder of Time Magazine. She is survived by her sons Dr. Arthur T. Hadley III, Matthew S. Eliot, DVM, her daughters Victoria S. Barlow and Caroline Nicholson and her eight grandchildren Holly Hadley, Matthew Eliott Jr, Allsion Eliott, Fiona Finlay-Hunt, Whitney Eliott, Faith, Phoebe and George Nicholson. Leila will be profoundly missed by her many dear friends around the world. A memorial service is scheduled for March 10, 2009, 2pm at Saint Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue.

Strasser, Jr. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Gail and Bob Lederer, Polly and Dennis Selkoe, Ginny Strasser and Tony Cacioppo, adoring grandmother of Rob and Jeff Lederer, Greg and Kim Selkoe, Eric and Alex Cacioppo, great-grandmother of Bradley, Emma and Sadia. Services 11:30am Sunday, February 15, 2009 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations to your favorite charity are appreciated.

The Brazilian police said Thursday that they arrested 55 people in nationwide operations to crack two crime rings that were smuggling Ecstasy, LSD and other synthetic drugs into the country from Europe. The police detained the suspects in eight Brazilian states, 47 of them in Rio de Janeiro, said Chief Enrico Zambrotti, the Federal Police coordinator of Operation Knockout, one of the two police efforts. Most of those arrested were in their 20s from middle-class families with no prior criminal histories, he said.

KENNEDY--Peter, of Big Horn, Wyoming, died peacefully at Yale New Haven Hospital after complications from a sudden heart attack. Peter was born on July 28, 1922. In 1945, he was married to Marie (Lyons) of West Roxbury, Massachusetts, who predeceased him in 2004. He is survived by three sons, Peter (Carroll) of Rye, New York, Paul of Brooklyn, New York, John of Bend, Oregon; nine grandchildren, Sarah (Luke) Dolce of Harrison, New York, Burke, Matthew, Catherine, James, Mary of Rye; Paul of Austin, Texas; Nicholas of Brooklyn; and Hilary of Colorado Springs, Colorado; two great grandchildren, Isabelle and E. Max Dolce of Harrison, New York; a brother John, of Orange, Connecticut, a sister, Helen, of Hamden, Connecticut and brother, William, of San Diego, California. Peter was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Yale University (1944) and the University of Connecticut Law School. During World War II, he was a Captain in the U.S. Army Air Force. He spent virtually his entire career in the investment business and active until his death, having been principal owner of both Dominick & Dominick, and Eighteen Seventy Corporation. A wake will be held at the Wm. Graham Funeral Home, Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 (Ph.: 914-967-0129) from 4-7.30pm on February 15, and a Mass of Christian Burial will take place at Resurrection Church, Boston Post Road, Rye, NY at 10am on February 16. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Yale Eye Institute, on whose board Mr. Kennedy sat for many years.

Graveside services Friday, 10:30am, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. He will be missed.

This 4,000-square-foot house is surrounded by water on two sides. It was designed and built in the 1970s by H. Schubart, an architect who studied with Frank Lloyd Wright, and renovated in the 90s. Situated on just under an acre, the stone, glass and wood house has a separate wing for the master suite. There is a stone fireplace in the great room, and there is stone ornamentation along the walls. There are three and a half bathrooms. The house has 975 square feet of decks, including a small deck off the garden-level bedroom suite. The property includes a two-car garage designed by the architect in the 1990s and a 400-square-foot workshop. It is being offered at 3,300,000 Canadian dollars. Taxes: 7,579 dollars. Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire abruptly withdrew Thursday as the nominee for commerce secretary, saying he had ''irresolvable conflicts'' with President Obama over his economic stimulus plan and a concern over what many fellow Republicans believe is the politicization of the 2010 census. The departure of Mr. Gregg is the latest setback to a White House that has struggled to fill several top positions and to fulfill Mr. Obama's pledge of building a bipartisan administration. He is the third prospective cabinet secretary -- the second for the Commerce Department -- to remove his name from consideration.

McCRARY--Daniel, 77, died January 18, 2009. Dan, a 1953 graduate of Michigan State University, led an interesting life as a journalist. His career started at the Wall Street Journal in Philadelphia. He worked for Lyndon Johnson in Washington and went on to be a correspondent and editor for McGraw Hill World News working in Washington, London and eventually New York City. Dan was an avid supporter of music, news, arts and food. Dan enjoyed singing for years with the West Village Chorale. A son, Timothy and a daughter, Sarah, survive him.

VALENTINE'S DAY SHOWS Hallmark haters will have plenty of company this Valentine's Day, when two shows celebrate the bounty of the lovelorn. The Housing Works Bookstore will let performers unburden their hearts at its Personal Media Mixer and Confessional Culture Variety Show. Representatives from Found Magazine, PostSecret and the Web site cassettefrommyex.com, where the romance of mixtapes is unwound, will share their stories. Michael Hearst, of the literary band One Ring Zero, will also perform. (Above, a sticky note found in Chicago; it's one of the many jettisoned love letters, doodles, poems and other similar ephemera collected by Found.) And at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, the Rejection Show, normally a forum for tales of professional woe, goes all love, or, rather, all breakup. More than a dozen comedians and writers, including Mike Albo (who contributes to the Styles sections of The New York Times), Ophira Eisenberg, Tom McCaffrey and Gabe Delahaye, will find the humor in getting their hearts stomped on.

Israel's election results remained unchanged Thursday after the votes of soldiers and Israelis serving abroad were counted and added to the final tally. The centrist Kadima Party, led by Tzipi Livni, retained its one-seat lead, with 28 seats in the 120-seat Parliament compared with 27 seats for the more conservative Likud Party led by Benjamin Netanyahu, according to the official results of the Central Elections Committee. Avigdor Lieberman's ultra-nationalist Yisrael Beitenu won 15 seats and the center-left Labor Party garnered 13.

A Continental Express flight from Newark to Buffalo crashed into a house about four to six miles from Buffalo Niagara International Airport on Thursday night, killing 49 people, officials said. The plane carried 44 passengers and a crew of 4, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. Ted Lopatkiewicz, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board, said at midnight that he did not know if there were any survivors on the plane. The Erie County executive, Chris Collins, later said at a news conference that 49 people, including one on the ground, were killed.

This two-story house, built in 1991, is on 1.28 wooded acres in the central part of Salt Spring Island. It is about a 6-minute drive from Ganges and a 10-to-15-minute drive from all three ferries that serve Salt Spring Island. The 1,416,-square-foot house has an open plan main floor with large windows, vaulted pine ceilings, an oak staircase, cedar post-and-beam work, cedar interior doors and fir flooring that is 150 years old. There are stained glass panels built into a mezzanine that looks over the dining area and is currently used as an office, and there are two bathrooms. The decision by the producers of this year's Oscars telecast to truncate the best song performances has cost them the services of Peter Gabriel. Mr. Gabriel, annoyed that he would not be able to perform "Down to Earth" in its entirety but only a portion of about 60 to 65 seconds in a medley of best-song contenders, withdrew altogether. Mr. Gabriel, who is nominated with Thomas Newman for the song from the animated feature "Wall-E," said in a video on his Web site that the situation was "a bit unfortunate," adding, "It's not going to do me any harm to make a little protest, but I think for some of the other artists it's not so easy." He said he hoped the Soweto Gospel Choir, which is featured on the song, might perform in his place. But if the producers don't go for that, the song's absence could shave an entire minute off the running time of the Academy Awards broadcast.

The wheels are still turning in the California budget deal, and the latest turn may put a meaningful tax credit for film and television production in California back on track. As of Friday night, funding had been restored for a credit totaling $100 million a year, over five years. That's much smaller than originally planned, but having the funds restored would help the state lure some productions, and jobs, back from competing states that have used credits to snatch them. But the entire budget deal still has to be voted on, so nothing is certain.

Before Yves or Karl, Miuccia or Marc, there was Valentina: perhaps the first designer so boldfaced that adding a surname seemed beside the point. As New York's reigning couturière in the 1930s and '40s, Valentina both dressed and topped the A-list. In ''Valentina: American Couture and the Cult of Celebrity'' (Rizzoli), Kohle Yohannan has revived the legend of a woman who - as much as her clients Katharine Hepburn, Marlene Dietrich and Greta Garbo - was a legend in her own time. Blessed with exotic beauty, impeccable taste and an unfailing instinct for self-promotion, Valentina Schlee was, Yohannan says, ''the first designer not just to make fashion a red-carpet affair, but to be a red-carpet affair in her own right.''

Ted Ligety won the bronze medal in a giant slalom at the world championships in Val d’Isère, France, the first medal by the American men this week. Carlo Janka of Switzerland won gold with a two-run time of 2 minutes 18.82 seconds down the Face de Bellevarde course. An obituary on Tuesday about the playwright Robert Anderson misstated part of the final line of his play “Tea and Sympathy.” It is “Years from now — when you talk about this — and you will — be kind,” not “when you talk of this.”.

The “Tax Tips” article in the special Your Taxes report last Sunday, about help for homeowners, misstated the amount of the new 2008 tax credit for a single person who is buying a home for the first time. The buyer may claim a credit of up to $7,500, the same as married couples; they are not limited to $3,750. (Married taxpayers who file separately may claim no more than $3,750 each. For 2009, the tax credit is being revised as part of the new stimulus legislation.).

(Starz) THE VISITOR (2008) In the role that has earned him an Oscar nomination for best actor, Richard Jenkins (above left, with Haaz Sleiman) plays a widowed, depressed professor of economics at Connecticut College who finds that his Manhattan apartment has been illegally rented to a drummer from Syria (Mr. Sleiman) and his Senegalese girlfriend (Danai Gurira). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that Tom McCarthy, the film's director, ''with impressive grace and understatement'' resists ''potential triteness and phony uplift.'' Mr. Scott called Mr. Jenkins's performance one of ''quiet precision'' in which he ''manages at once to deflect and to earn the audience's sympathy, and to convey an inner transformation brought about by a shy, unselfish engagement with other people.'' After being traumatized when Congress suddenly slashed research budgets for science agencies last year, scientists were pleasantly surprised to find that they did not lose out again in the last round of negotiations on the stimulus plan. The plan largely restores research and development money for the basic sciences in the House version of the bill, while keeping $10 billion for the National Institutes of Health, championed by Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, a cancer survivor and one of three Republican votes for the plan.

He was a graduate of Harvard University and Harvard Law School and an author of children's books. KAUFMAN--Maurice. February 12, age 94. Beloved husband of Elaine, brother, father, stepfather, cousin, uncle and proud grandfather. His wit and humor will be missed forever. Services at Rone Funeral Home will be held Monday at noon in Vineland, NJ. Contributions to the Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Research Foundation.

GITTER--Marion Singer. Born December 5, 1924. Died January 29, 2009. Marion was the youngest of seven children born to Pearl and James Snoddy of Cross Anchor, South Carolina. She married Alexander (Allie) Singer in 1942 and later lived in Lake Success, NY with their three children, Carolyn, Ben, and Andrew. Following Singer's death in 1967, she married Harry Gittler of Queens in 1972. The couple remained in Lake Success until retirement to Solana Beach, Calif. in 1986. She is survived by her three children, a step-son, Mark Gittler, ten grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She is remembered as a loving parent, grandmother, aunt, sister-in-law and dear friend. A memorial service will be held at El Camino Memorial Cemetery's Sorrento Valley Chapel, Sunday, February 15 in San Diego. The family requests in lieu of flowers, a donation may be made in support of her granddaughter and great-grandson to: United Cerebral Palsy - Orange County, 9800 Roosevelt, Suite 100, Irvine, CA, 92618. Phone: (949) 333-6430 or by visiting www.ucp-or.org.

The risks and responsibilities of a life in photojournalism are the subject of ''Time Stands Still,'' the reflective but low-key new drama by Donald Margulies that opened on Wednesday night at the Geffen Playhouse here. Mr. Margulies, the author of the Pulitzer Prize winner ''Dinner With Friends'' and ''Sight Unseen,'' among other plays, has always been interested in the ways that the passage of time and the arc of a career imprint their stresses upon relationships. Whether they are rushing headlong toward achievement or settling into diminished expectations, people who have found an easy rhythm with a lover or spouse in their youth may begin to move through life at a different speed, and connections are lost. Life has suddenly and traumatically stalled for the couple at the center of the new play, the photographer Sarah (Anna Gunn) and her reporter partner, James (David Harbour). Sarah has been seriously wounded while reporting from Iraq. Her beautiful face is streaked with scar tissue, and she has an arm and a leg both temporarily out of commission.

LEBENSTEIN--Mary (nee Attas), 87, February 12, after a long illness. Survived by sons David and Daniel, grandchildren Lisa and Adam, two great grandchildren, and sister Sarah Kapnek. Donations to Kehila Kedosha Janina Synagogue and Museum (www.kkjsm.org). S'agapo.

MODELL--William D. May 13, 1921 - Feb. 14, 2008. With the greatest of love comes the deepest of sorrow. A year ago, I lost the love of my life, my darling Bill. I remember each treasured moment we shared and mourn your loss with enduring sadness. You were my guiding light and I am lost without you. With each passing day, the memory of our life together becomes even more precious. I will love you and miss you forever. Your Shelby

BERK--Charles. September 3, 1947 - February 14, 2008. It was a year ago, that you silently, peacefully, slipped away from us in your sleep. Too soon and too suddenly. And on that day a great void opened in our lives and in our hearts - places that cannot be filled. This journey that we've begun without you hasn't gotten easier as the days pass, as some have said it would. It sometimes seems to get harder. Though we cherish every precious memory and will carry them with us always, we miss your smile, your laugh, your touch and your love more with each passing day. We miss you Chuck! Your so hard to live without! Now and forever you will stay in our hearts. Joan and Samantha
BERNSTEIN--Sol. Your life remains in the past but the memory lives on. Honoring you, Daddy, on your 109th year. Love, B.

By one measure, the public- works spending in the stimulus package exceeds the promises President Obama made as a candidate. But by another, it falls short. The agreement calls for spending $120 billion on infrastructure, almost double the $60 billion Mr. Obama promised during the campaign. But it does not create the national infrastructure bank he had called for to set national priorities and get big projects done.

BOXER--Leonard, a Founding Partner of Liz Claiborne, Inc., dies at 86. As the production pro and Executive Vice President of Manufacturing, Mr. Boxer was a pioneer of overseas manufacturing. He was a warm, gentle and kind man who was loved by all and will be missed by family and friends. Mr. Boxer is survived by his wife Anita, sons Steven and Garry and granddaughters Lauren, Rae and Georgia. Services Sunday February 15, 11:45 AM at "The Riverside" 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

The United Nations Security Council voted 15-0 on Friday to keep cease-fire observers along the border of Georgia's breakaway region of Abkhazia for another four months. The future of some 150 observers and police officers was left in limbo last summer after the brief war in South Ossetia, another autonomy-seeking Georgian territory. After routing Georgia in the war, Russia recognized both territories as independent. The extension leaves the force in place until June, while negotiations between Russia and Georgia continue.

MILBANK--Molly Wetmore, 91, died peacefully at home in New York City on February 12. Born in Santiago, Cuba she was the daughter of Robert C. Wetmore, one of Teddy Roosevelt's Rough Riders, and granddaughter of a founder of the United Fruit Company. She was a direct descendent of Philip Livingston a signatory of the Declaration of Independence and Robert Livingston who arranged the Louisiana Purchase. She also was a descendent of the Wetmore family which had been residents of New York City when it was under Dutch rule. She was married to Samuel R. Milbank an investment banker and philanthropist who predeceased her. She will be missed by her survivors who include her daughter, Elenita M. Drumwright, her son Samuel L. (Tony) Milbank, seven grandchildren, six great-grandchildren and one great-great-grandchild.

President Obama promised to increase education greatly, and the stimulus bill does that, providing about $100 billion in emergency money over two years for public schools, universities and child care centers. More than half comes in a $54 billion fiscal stabilization fund for states, which are grappling with $132 billion in budget shortfalls. Governors are to channel most of that money to school districts and colleges, to avert teacher layoffs. They may also use some of it to modernize school buildings.

BOXER--Leonard. Our beloved friend has left us. We will miss you and think of you always. Susan and Dan Stone

Roughly $282 billion of the stimulus package, or about 35 percent, is made up of tax cuts for individuals and businesses, including tax breaks for buyers of homes and cars. The centerpiece is President Obama's ''Making Work Pay'' income tax credit of up to $400 for individuals and $800 for couples in 2009 and 2010. The money will mostly be distributed through reduced paycheck tax withholdings, adding $8 or so a week that officials hope will be spent not saved. Individuals earning up to $75,000 and couples up to $150,000 will qualify for a full credit.

Programs to promote energy efficiency and renewable energy sources are big winners in the stimulus package, receiving more than $45 billion in new spending and tax breaks. Included is more than $13 billion to make federal buildings and public housing more efficient and to weatherize as many as one million homes. The bill also provides more than $10 billion to modernize the electricity grid and install ''smart'' meters in homes and as much as $20 billion in tax incentives for wind, solar, hydro and other renewable power sources. Proponents say these provisions will create as many as 500,000 jobs.

In a signal that blockbuster trades they made in the last year have not worked out, the Miami Heat and the Toronto Raptors engineered another one Friday, swapping frontcourt players with sterling résumés who have occasionally underwhelmed this season. The Heat agreed to send Shawn Marion to the Raptors for Jermaine O'Neal, forward Jamario Moon and a lottery-protected first-round draft pick. The Raptors also received the reserve point guard Marcus Banks.

A provision buried deep inside the $787 billion economic stimulus bill would impose restrictions on executive bonuses at financial institutions that are much tougher than those proposed 10 days ago by the Treasury Department. The provision, inserted by Senate Democrats over the objections of the Obama administration, is aimed at companies that have received financial bailout funds. It would prohibit cash bonuses and almost all other incentive compensation for the five most senior officers and the 20 highest-paid executives at large companies that receive money under the Treasury's Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP.

Many part-time, low-income and female workers who have lost their jobs stand to benefit from the federal stimulus bill. Under the legislation, approved by Congress on Friday, not only would workers who already receive unemployment benefits get some additional money in their checks, but also many workers who have fallen through the cracks could soon be brought into the system. About 500,000 more people could become eligible for benefits, according to the National Employment Law Project.

McCRARY--Daniel, 77, died January 18, 2009. Dan, a 1953 graduate of Michigan State University, led an interesting life as a journalist. His career started at the Wall Street Journal in Philadelphia. He worked for Lyndon Johnson in Washington and went on to be a correspondent and editor for McGraw Hill World News working in Washington, London and eventually New York City. Dan was an avid supporter of music, news, arts and food. Dan enjoyed singing for years with the West Village Chorale. A son, Timothy and a daughter, Sarah, survive him.
GROSSMAN--Louis. We thought we'd get to see forever. Your Loving Family

The safety-net provisions of the stimulus bill mingle two aims: to jump-start the economy and to protect the most vulnerable people as hardships intensify. Supporters say the missions coincide, since poor people are quick to spend. Opponents see a backdoor expansion of welfare. The package provides an extra $20 billion for food stamps over several years. For the average family of three, that means a 19 percent increase this year, or an extra $63 a month.

Two years ago the American authorities arrested Sheik Mazin al-Saedi, a senior aide to the anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr, accusing him of organizing kidnappings and killings. This week in Baghdad, the city once terrorized by those killings, Sheik Mazin mingled in a white-walled art gallery as the patron of an exhibition of paintings and sculptures that would not, exactly, be out of place in Chelsea or SoHo: abstract art, expressionist paintings and conceptual works larded with symbols of Iraq's ancient history and today's reality.

KENNEDY--Peter, of Big Horn, Wyoming, died peacefully at Yale New Haven Hospital after complications from a sudden heart attack. Peter was born on July 28, 1922. In 1945, he was married to Marie (Lyons) of West Roxbury, Massachusetts, who predeceased him in 2004. He is survived by three sons, Peter (Carroll) of Rye, New York, Paul of Brooklyn, New York, John of Bend, Oregon; nine grandchildren, Sarah (Luke) Dolce of Harrison, New York, Burke, Matthew, Catherine, James, Mary of Rye; Paul of Austin, Texas; Nicholas of Brooklyn; and Hilary of Colorado Springs, Colorado; two great grandchildren, Isabelle and E. Max Dolce of Harrison, New York; a brother John, of Orange, Connecticut, a sister, Helen, of Hamden, Connecticut and brother, William, of San Diego, California. Peter was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Yale University (1944) and the University of Connecticut Law School. During World War II, he was a Captain in the U.S. Army Air Force. He spent virtually his entire career in the investment business and active until his death, having been principal owner of both Dominick & Dominick, and Eighteen Seventy Corporation. A wake will be held at the Wm. Graham Funeral Home, Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 (Ph.: 914-967-0129) from 4-7.30pm on February 15, and a Mass of Christian Burial will take place at Resurrection Church, Boston Post Road, Rye, NY at 10am on February 16. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Yale Eye Institute, on whose board Mr. Kennedy sat for many years.

Marvel Comics will commemorate the presidential holiday Monday by offering “Gettysburg Distress,” a new six-page adventure featuring Captain America and Spider-Man as they witness Abraham Lincoln deliver the Gettysburg Address. The comic, written by Matt Fraction with art by Andy MacDonald, will be available online here. Also available will be the story from Amazing Spider-Man No. 583, in which the wall-crawler met President Barack Obama. That issue, which went on sale Jan. 14, was the top-selling comic book in the month of January, with more than 300,000 copies sold. On Feb. 25, President Obama will be making two more comic book appearances. In Savage Dragon No. 145, written and drawn by Erik Larsen, Mr. Obama returns to Chicago, the home base of the title superhero, who helps provide security for the visit. In issue No. 8 of Youngblood, about a group of government run heroes, the president puts the finishing touches on the team’s new roster.

“The Milk of Sorrow,” the first Peruvian film in the main competition at the Berlin International Film Festival, won the top prize on Saturday, the Golden Bear for best picture. The film, about a young woman who was born as a result of her mother’s rape, was directed by Claudia Llosa. It beat out “My One and Only,” starring Renée Zellweger, and “The Messenger,” starring Woody Harrelson. “The Messenger,” about an army officer charged with informing next of kin when soldiers die in combat, won a Silver Bear for the script by Oren Moverman and Alessandro Camon. The Silver Bear for best director was presented to the Iranian director Asghar Farhadi for “About Elly,” about a group of Iranians who take a trip to the Caspian Sea that turns tragic.
In the Wings

Jason Voorhees is still unstoppable. It was a bloodbath at the weekend box office when the remake of the 1980 horror movie “Friday the 13th” slashed its way to No. 1, earning $42.5 million in its first weekend in theaters, more than double the total of the No. 2 movie, “He’s Just Not That Into You.” Both are Warner Brothers pictures, though, so it was a lucrative weekend for the company. “He’s Just Not That Into You,” the romantic comedy with an ensemble cast including Ginnifer Goodwin and Bradley Cooper, made $20.3 million in it second week, for a total of $55.8 million to date, according to the box office tracking firm Media by Numbers. The action movie “Taken” (20th Century Fox), starring Liam Neeson, fell from second place to third, earning $19.3 million (for a total of $77.9 million to date). The new comedy “Confessions of a Shopaholic” (Disney), starring Isla Fisher, came in fourth with $15.4 million, and “Coraline” (Focus), the 3D animated feature based on a novel by Neil Gaiman, placed fifth with $15.3 million in its second week, up to $35.6 million to date.

After being as closely associated with the Atlanta Braves as any current player was with a team, he is now with the Boston Red Sox.

Last week's column about Denis Rancourt, a University of Ottawa professor who is facing dismissal for awarding A-plus grades to his students on the first day of class and for turning the physics course he had been assigned into a course on political activism, drew mostly negative comments.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- Since the Mets acquired Johan Santana, I cannot hear a song by Carlos Santana without thinking of Johan. Is it a blessing or a curse? I don't know. And now that they have brought in Livan Hernandez, I cannot say his first name without thinking of Elton John's song, "Levon."

Today's noisy puzzle by David Kwong has all the recommended daily allowance of goodness you expect from a morning crossword, but before diving into it, I want to dig a little into the past. Mr. Kwong's small portfolio includes a few very memorable creations.

I just came from Diane Von Furstenberg's show, where Diana Ross was in the front row and on the soundtrack, a symmetry that generally suited this easy-to-please collection. Cocooning, friendly clothes was the starting point, and I have to say, Ms. Von Furstenberg and her team provided a good antidote for the recession. Here were lots of great things for women (of any age) to wear: woolly leggings in camo and leopard prints, oversized cardigans, a boxy black wool jacket with dolman sleeves, funky plaid coats, slinky leopard sheaths in velvet, and the odd mini or tunic in midnight blue sequins. The models had on fuzzy pompom hats, and either platforms or a black suede wedge. In most of the jumbled-up looks was an old-favorite that claimed your girlish heart. At the same time, DVF was hardly playing it safe with basics.

A look back at the stage design for the Academy Awards of years past.

They say that tough times make fashion more creative. So far, men's designers seem to be doing everything except playing it straight - and we mean that quite literally. Patrik Ervell said he was inspired by "mannish lesbians," especially as portrayed by the Dutch photographer Gon Buurman, when he was working on his denim shearling jackets, loosely structured blazers and slim pants pegged at the ankle. (There was also a pearl-accented Fair Isle sweater, cool enough to defy any kind of gender categorization.) Ervell sent down his runway just one woman, in a speckled suit, to make his masculine-girls-will-be-boys point - but one can't help but wonder whether that foray doesn't signal a tentative interest in women's wear.

Every time I enter the subway after a show-Ruffian, say, with its campy French fashion queens-I wonder how I could possibly explain the clothes to mere mortals. Wool suits with rounded skirts and ruffled red satin dresses, all with black point d'esprit bodysuits under them, might be unusually pleasing to a crowd in Times Square on Valentine's night. Such outfits, bordering on drag (a golden leopard knit minidress over the point d'esprit), might satisfy the public fantasy of fashion, just as the few remaining peep shows and dirty magazine shops still convey what this part of town used to be like. I had the feeling several times over the weekend-at the Vena Cava presentation, at Christian Cota-that each audience represented a separate tribe, and had come to look at the clothes and grab a free drink just as they would attend an art opening. Sometimes the clothes and the crowd seem unrelated.

The Yankees' daily workout is over, and just five people remain on the field: Manager Joe Girardi, his wife Kim, and their three children. Young Dante Girardi, 7, may have the best gig of any baseball-loving kid in America. He's hitting the heck out of the ball as I write this.

President Obama is expected to sign the economic recovery package, which passed the House and Senate with little Republican support, in Denver on Tuesday. One way to look at our current predicament is through the lens of Irving Fisher's theory of debt deflation: as everyone tries to work off excessive debt, the combination of a contracting economy and falling prices puts everyone deeper in the hole. But how do you get out? I've drawn the above chart using debt data from Historical Statistics of the United States Millennial; it shows the debt-deflation spiral of 1929-1933, and the partial recovery of the New Deal years.

Economy | Uh-oh, the American economist who two weeks before the Crash of '29 declared that stocks had reached a "permanently high plateau" is back in vogue. Yes, Irving Fisher -- contemporary of John Maynard Keynes, eugenics dabbler and self-important health nut -- is now relevant for his insights into the danger of debt-deflation spirals, "the mass effect of the stampede to liquidate." Never popular in life, but (sigh) today a guide for the likes of Ben Bernanke and Larry Summers. [Economist]

Maddy Loftus of Parsippany, N.J., was on her way to a college alumnae reunion game in Buffalo when she died Thursday night in the crash of Continental Express Flight 3407. Loftus, 24, played for the Buffalo State Bengals women's hockey team for two seasons.

History | However immoral it may have been, the horrific 1945 bombing of Dresden had a clear military rationale, a British historian says, because it was "a major transport and communication hub less than 120 miles from the advancing Russians." Each February, he says, protesting German neo-Nazis inflate "the myth that it was of no military or industrial importance" as "a tool to relativize Adolf Hitler's Holocaust." [Spiegel]
Books | This week from the Book Review: a conversation with the novelist T. C. Boyle, and Carl Hiaasen on his latest novel for young adults. [Book Review podcast]
Stephanie Reveron met Cristian Andree Farias in fall 2004 after she was invited to sing at his church. After a first date on Valentine's Day, the two realized they had a special connection.

Stewart-Haas Racing, the team owned by the two-time Cup champion Tony Stewart that includes driver Ryan Newman, is off to a rough start in its first season. The drivers wrecked at Daytona International Speedway and will be forced to use backup cars for Sunday’s Daytona 500. Newman, the defending Daytona 500 champion, blew a right rear tire while in front of Stewart during a practice session. Newman’s car spun and Stewart’s car could not avoid it. Under Nascar rules, they will have to start at the rear of the field. Hours after his practice crash, Stewart held off Kyle Busch on the last lap to win the Camping World 300, the season-opening Nationwide Series race.

In his first race this year, the Olympic star Usain Bolt won the 400 meters in 46.35 seconds Saturday at the Jamaica Camperdown Classic in Kingston. Bolt slowed in the last 50 meters, smiling while looking right and left in winning for the second straight year. Bolt set world records at the Beijing Games in the 100 (9.69) and the 200 (19.30).

Angela Stanford spoiled Michelle Wie’s bid for a victory in her first start as an L.P.G.A. Tour member, overcoming a three-stroke deficit to win the season-opening SBS Open by three shots at Turtle Bay in Kahunu, Hawaii. Stanford closed with a two-under-par 70 for a 10-under 206 total. It was her fourth career victory and third in seven starts. Wie, 19, had a 73 for her second straight runner-up finish in the tournament. Angela Park had a 75, tying for third with Na Yeon Choi (69) at 212. ¶Gil Morgan shot a seven-under 65 and finished tied with Tom Jenkins after two rounds of the Allianz Championship in Boca Raton, Fla. Jenkins shot a 67 for the second straight day, matching Morgan at 10 under through 36 holes. Mike Goodes (68) and Jerry Pate (71) are one shot off the lead. Bernhard Langer, fell apart over the last four holes — with two bogeys and a double-bogey — to finish with a 73. He finished the round three shots behind. allianz (AP).

The Mets added to their inventory of starting pitchers by signing the right-hander Liván Hernández to a minor league contract. The move reunites Hernández with General Manager Omar Minaya, who acquired him in 2003 with Montreal and has tried several times to bring him to the Mets. He will compete with Tim Redding and Freddy García for the fifth spot in the rotation.
Jonny Flynn and Eric Devendorf combined for 48 points, including 15 in overtime, as No. 23 Syracuse beat Georgetown, 98-94, on Saturday.

Pittsburgh kicker Jeff Reed has been cited for disorderly conduct and criminal mischief after the Pennsylvania state police said he threw a tantrum at a convenience store because its restroom did not have towels. The police said Reed broke the towel dispenser, then used profane language to an employee. Each offense carries a maximum fine of $300 and 90 days in jail.

Taylor Phinney of the United States won the one-kilometer time trial for his second gold at cycling’s Track World Cup Finals, and the four-time Olympic champion Chris Hoy of Britain was not hurt after a high-speed crash in the keirin final in Copenhagen. Phinney, the 18-year-old son of the 1984 Olympic medalists Connie Carpenter-Phinney and Davis Phinney, edged Michael D’Almeida of France in the final.

The Los Angeles Angels have signed the right-hander Ervin Santana to a four-year deal through 2012. Santana, 26, is the youngest active pitcher with at least 50 victories. He rebounded from a subpar season in 2007 to go 16-7 with a 3.49 earned run average.
When Yves Saint Laurent died last June, he left behind a fashion legacy beyond measure — and a lifetime’s accumulation of important furniture and art.
Nate Robinson, the Knicks’ 5-foot-9 guard, literally soared over his competition to win a slam-dunk contest tinged with comic-book themes.

An article on Feb. 1 about the selection of a successor to the Dalai Lama may have left the incorrect impression that Staten Island’s Todt Hill has one of the Tibetan centers and flies prayer flags that the Dalai Lama inspired around the world. While such prayer flags have indeed been seen flying on Todt Hill, there is no Tibetan center on Todt Hill. (Staten Island does have the Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art, located on Lighthouse Hill. But it was founded before the Dalai Lama began his worldwide campaign to promote the cause of Tibetan Buddhism.).

The “Tax Tips” article in the special Your Taxes report last Sunday, about help for homeowners, misstated the amount of the new 2008 tax credit for a single person who is buying a home for the first time. Single homebuyers may claim a credit of up to $7,500, the same as married couples; they are not limited to $3,750. (Married taxpayers who file separately may claim no more than $3,750 each. For 2009, the tax credit is being altered by fiscal stimulus legislation that was being debated in Congress last week.).

An article last Nov. 2 about renovations at the Fontainebleau hotel in Miami Beach referred incorrectly to a scene from the movie “Goldfinger,” which featured the hotel. Sean Connery, portraying James Bond, receives a massage at a poolside cabana; he does not jump off a diving board. A reader pointed out the error shortly after the article was published, but editors did not follow through with research.

An article last Sunday about living in Manhattan on a $500,000 salary misstated the Social Security deduction on those wages. This year, the maximum annual Social Security deduction for salaried employees is $6,621.60 — not $596 a week for 52 weeks, or a total of $30,992.

An article on Feb. 1 about the artist Ryan Trecartin may have left the incorrect impression about the role of the Moore Space in a project that Mr. Trecartin undertook at that gallery’s request. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. BERK--Charles. September 3, 1947 - February 14, 2008. It was a year ago, that you silently, peacefully, slipped away from us in your sleep. Too soon and too suddenly. And on that day a great void opened in our lives and in our hearts - places that cannot be filled. This journey that we've begun without you hasn't gotten easier as the days pass, as some have said it would. It sometimes seems to get harder. Though we cherish every precious memory and will carry them with us always, we miss your smile, your laugh, your touch and your love more with each passing day. We miss you Chuck! Your so hard to live without! Now and forever you will stay in our hearts. Joan and Samantha

LAKE--Jean Compo Sedlmayr, 87, died peacefully on February 3, 2009. A former Conover model, she was married to George Sedlmayr until his death in 1965. In 1970, she married David Lake. She is survived by her four children, five stepchildren, 15 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She approached life with charm, grace and enthusiasm and will be greatly missed.

With long flight delays increasingly common, many aviation experts argue that a complete overhaul of the air traffic control system is needed. For more than a decade the Federal Aviation Administration has talked about what it calls NextGen -- a plan to move from the current radar-based system to satellite navigation, in which airplanes would use G.P.S.-like technology to find their positions and broadcast that information to other planes and to controllers on the ground. Backers say that the new technology would relieve congestion delays by allowing planes to fly closer together and to chart more direct flight paths. But the plan would require substantial investment not only by the government, but by the airlines as well.
BOXER--Leonard. Our beloved friend has left us. We will miss you and think of you always. Susan and Dan Stone

The elevated highway that runs along Seattle's waterfront, the Alaskan Way Viaduct, is considered near the end of its useful life. It has been worn down by more traffic than was anticipated when it opened in 1953, damaged by a past earthquake, and deemed vulnerable should another one hit. Last month, state and local officials in Washington announced that they want to tear it down and replace it with a 1.7-mile tunnel, while strengthening the sea wall and expanding transit in the area. Supporters say the project, which still needs legislative and environmental approval, will make drivers safer while easing access to the city's waterfront. Skeptics warn about the delays and huge cost overruns Boston faced when it sank its highway in the Big Dig.

100 DAYS For Barack Obama, the first president of the Internet age, staying in touch means holding onto his BlackBerry. It's a healthy sign that he overcame security and bureaucratic reservations to keep this device, for he is quite right in saying that it is too easy for presidents to become isolated in ''the bubble'' of the presidency. Being comfortable in one's own skin does not guarantee a successful presidency. If it did, George W. Bush would be accorded higher marks than he receives from most historians and the American people. But optimism, a sense of normalcy, and a determination to keep in touch with the people you have inspired are useful attributes for any president. They helped F.D.R. become, in his words, first ''Dr. New Deal'' and then ''Dr. Win the War.'' They helped Ronald Reagan overcome the pessimism of malaise and the dismay of recession. And they have kept Americans rooting for Mr. Obama despite some early stumbles.

THERE is no shortage of big dreams or grand schemes as the United States struggles to rebuild itself for the 21st century. But many of the most ambitious projects in the country -- a representative sample of which are listed below -- stand to get only modest amounts of money, if any, from the economic stimulus package that Congress approved on Friday. From a public works perspective, the $789 billion stimulus package is unlikely to transform the physical fabric of the nation as the New Deal did when it built hundreds of airports, tens of thousands of bridges, and hundreds of thousands of buildings and miles of roads.

To the Sports Editor: The chart accompanying the article ''Rodriguez, With an Apology, Says He Used Banned Drugs'' (Feb. 10) could mislead readers into seeing a causal connection between whatever substances Alex Rodriguez used from 2001 to 2003 and his increased home runs in those seasons. It omitted any context of Rodriguez's achievements, the most important of which is the home field, at which he played half his games.

ADAM--Nina, died Wednesday February 11th in New York. The daughter of Alexander Reitzmann and Nadeijda Lowenthal both of whom perished in the Holocaust. Nina was an artist, a trend setter, a jewelry designer and a journalist. She had the most beautiful smile. She was the widow of Jacob Adam, a captain in the young Israeli Navy and on merchant ships. She is survived by her nephew Alexander Reitzmann, the son of her brother Joseph Reitzmann, and by her grandnephew Leo Reitzmann.

NEMERSON--Yale R.,77. "Dr. Clot." He created revolutionary change in our understanding of the blood clotting mechanism. President and board member of the International Society of Thrombosis and Haemostasis. Professor of medicine at Yale, Stony Brook, and Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Never "just" a scientist, Bronx-born Yale loved the arts (especially opera), travel, politics, the Yankees, the Giants, tennis, his dog, his children Matthew, Andrea, and David, and his grandchildren Elana, Joy, Arlo, Avram, and Lilah. Memorial service at 2pm. Sunday, February 15th at his apartment in New York City. A service in New Haven is being organized. Donations to the American Heart Association appreciated.

Several ports on the Gulf of Mexico have begun ambitious expansion plans, which they say will put them in contention to handle more cargo from Asia after the Panama Canal finishes a widening project that will allow bigger ships through. The Port of New Orleans has a billion-dollar expansion to help anchor the economy of a region still battered by Hurricane Katrina. And the port in Gulfport, Miss., has its own billion-dollar plan to rebuild itself above sea level. It plans to pay for part of it with money from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, to the dismay of local housing advocates. Proponents say that both plans could save and add jobs in the hurricane-ravaged region, but there have been indications that less cargo is coming in because of the economic downturn, and they would still have to compete with the West Coast ports, which get most of the cargo from Asia, and, closer to home, Houston's bustling port.

HUNSBERGER--Ruth Pedersen, 97, community activist, writer, of Lexington, MA; widow of economist W.S. Hunsberger; survived by children Ellen Hume, Newton, MA; David Hunsberger, Arlington, VA and Peter Hunsberger, Seattle, WA, and seven grandchildren. Her motto: "Think positively and always put yourself in the way of new experience." A celebration of her life will be held at Brookhaven, 1010 Waltham Street, Lexington, MA, February 28 at 2pm.

February Means Points With February being the shortest month, some of the N.B.A.'s best players seem to have decided that they need to be in a rush to put points together. In the season's first three months, not a single player averaged 30 or more points for an entire month. But through six games this month, four players are topping the mark, with Kobe Bryant leading with 35.5 points a game.

Last week, expressions of love were everywhere. A few women were walking valentines in coats with heart and lip cutouts. And as the thermometer climbed above 50 degrees, an affair was revived as stylish men traded heavy coats for beloved sports jackets. Some have worn tweed jackets all winter, even on single-digit days.

JONES--Glory. Media wordsmith for the arts world, sterling mentor and poet, died February 7 at 57. Press and public relations voice for the Guggenheim, the Morgan Library, and the Hirshhorn Museum, Glory last joined Resnicow Schroeder Associates as consultant to the arts and culture. She served for years as the media contact of the Venice Biennale for both the US and Italian offices. Later, Glory wrote poetry now accepted by journals for posthumous publication. Glory is survived by her husband Kenneth Flowers, her sisters, Beverly Reid of Prescott Valley, AZ, Janice Newman of Perris, CA, Susan Smith of San Diego, Cynthia DeLanty of Riverside, CA, and a brother Gerard Jones of Seattle, eleven nieces and nephews, and eleven grandnieces and nephews. Visitation at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St., on Tuesday, February 17, 2009 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A memorial service will be held at Symphony Space Thalia at a time to be determined. Burial in Cornwall, CT will be private. Donations may be made to the Oncology Department, Herbert Irving Pavilion, Columbia University Medical Center.

AT FIREFLY, NOËL COWARD'S FORMER RESIDENCE, PORT MARIA, JAMAICA, OCT. 21, 2008Peter Graf, 42, an executive vice president of SAP, a German software company, with his wife, Anke Doerzapf, Germans living in Redwood City, Calif. ''We like seeing the tradition of the island, and the nature, but also the influence of the English -- some of that celebrity feeling. At Firefly, we learned Coward and Ian Fleming were friends. They're obviously both from England, and I can very much relate to how you would cling together in a foreign place because I enjoy the German community in the Bay Area. It hasn't to do with isolation, it's just enjoying a little bit of home abroad. On vacation, my wife and I always look for special places: serenity, the great view that sticks in your mind so you can go back later when you close your eyes. There's a bronze statue of Coward on the mountain. When you stand next to it and look over this bay, it's one of the most beautiful things you could see. It's just bursting with life. Germany gets not as green. California? Definitely not.'' As told to Seth Kugel

It is one of the nation's busiest border crossings, but Detroit is linked to Canada only by a tunnel and an 80-year-old privately owned bridge. The United States and Canada are working together to build what they are calling the Detroit River International Crossing, a new six-lane bridge, and last month they got the final environmental clearance from the federal government. (They still need some local government approvals to acquire some land.) But the owner of the current bridge, the Ambassador Bridge, is moving ahead with a plan to build a new, privately owned bridge to replace the one he owns. With border crossings down these days, it is unclear if the Detroit River needs two new bridges, though state officials say it does. And officials say the severely depressed local economy could use the 10,000 jobs they say the public bridge project would generate on the Michigan side of the border.

A quarter of the nation's rail freight rolls through Chicago, but the rail network there has become so snarled that it can sometimes take longer for freight trains to make it through Chicago than to reach Chicago from the West Coast in the first place -- slowing the movement of goods across the country and adding to their cost. For years there have been plans to untangle the system, but they have faced problems getting financing. Now some projects are getting started, but there is a long way to go.

To the Editor: One other detail to consider when deciding which card to take: What happens if it's lost or stolen? I usually take a Visa, credit-union ATM and an Amex card. The Amex card is not as widely accepted, but a few years ago in Venice it proved its worth otherwise. I lost my cards in Venice early in my trip. After a lengthy hem-and-haw with my Visa bank (one of the largest), it became apparent that they really couldn't -- and didn't want to -- do anything to replace the card in transit.

Officials say that a major source of drinking water for about 25 million Californians is at risk. That water currently comes from the delta where the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers meet, and the levees that protect the region are more than 100 years old and are vulnerable to earthquakes. A state task force recommended restoring the delta's endangered habitat and building a new aqueduct to bring water from Northern California to the arid south, without passing through the delta. A similar proposal was voted down in 1982 because northerners viewed it as a water grab by the south, and farmers in the delta region feared losing their water. But the current drought, and climate change, have provided a new sense of urgency. The bill included $50 million that can be used in the delta region, but that is only a tiny fraction of what the state estimates it will eventually need.

HAMES--Richard Christopher "Chris" Hames, M.D.,55, a native of Claxton, GA, died after a brief illness on January 27, 2009 in New York, NY. Dr. Hames graduated from Emory University's School of Medicine 1979, completed a Psychiatry Residency at NYU's Bellevue Hospital 1982, a Child and Adolescent Fellowship at Harvard's McLean Hospital and studies in France and California, and practiced in NYC for 24 years. He loved world travel, culture and art and delighted in sharing his adventures with loved ones. His steadfast love and devotion to family and lifelong friends and his kindness to all who met him will forever be missed. Survivors include his mother, Betty C. Hames; brother, Curtis G. Hames Jr., M.D.; sister-in-law, Edwina N. Hames; niece, Elizabeth Hames Baltz; great -niece, Ellee Hames Baltz; and many dear, close friends. He was preceded in death by his father, Curtis G. Hames Sr., M.D. A memorial ceremony will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Hames Chair at the Medical College of Georgia Foundation, 1021 15th Street, Suite 6, Augusta, GA 30901.

Two missiles fired from American drone aircraft killed more than 30 people, including Qaeda and Taliban fighters, near the Pakistani border with Afghanistan on Saturday, according to a Pakistani intelligence official and residents of the area. The missiles struck three compounds, including one where the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, Baitullah Mehsud, and foreign and local fighters loyal to him sometimes gather, the official and residents said.

HAUGH--Sharon L. A trailblazer among women at top ranks of the investment management industry, died Tuesday, February 10th after a long and valliant struggle with illness. Born and raised in the San Fernando Valley area of Los Angeles, California, Sharon attended the University of Arizona before moving to New York in 1968. From 1995-2002, she was the Chairman of Schroder Investment Management North America. In her twenty year career with the firm, Ms. Haugh led Schroders to a preeminent position in the United States. Under her leadership, Schroders was consistently ranked as one of the top international money managers in the country. In 2002, she was the first woman honored by the Association of Investment Management Sales Executives ("AIMSE") with the Richard A. Lothrop Award in recognition of both her outstanding contributions to the industry, as well as her involvement in community affairs and charitable endeavors. Prior to joining Schroders in 1982, Ms. Haugh held positions with New Court Securities (Rothschild, Inc.) and Soros Fund Management. Her last executive position in the industry was as Chief Executive at Pequot Capital Management. She is a past President of AIMSE, and has served on the Board of the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, American Ballet Theatre, and Met Life Investors. Sharon will be remembered for her passion for living life to the fullest, her intelligence, her wit, and her generosity towards those she loved. She loved, and was beloved by, many friends in Anguilla, BWI, where she visited regularly for over twenty years. She will be sorely missed and mourned by her beloved daughter Alexis Stein, her sister, brother and family, and her many, many friends. A small private service was held on Friday, February 13, 2009. In Lieu of flowers, donations in her memory should be made to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 14 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10122, Attn: Sherry Jacobson or online at www.ocrf.org

JAMES SETS RECORD Goalkeeper David James set a record by playing his 536th Premier League game as Portsmouth defeated Manchester City, 2-0. Glen Johnson and Hermann Hreidarsson scored in the second half as Portsmouth won in its first game since Manager Tony Adams was fired five days ago. The home victory at Fratton Park lifted Portsmouth to 15th place with 27 points, 4 points above the three-team relegation zone in English soccer's top division. James, 38, broke the Premier League appearance mark held by Gary Speed. His career includes spells at Liverpool, Aston Villa, West Ham and Manchester City. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

LUCE--Leila Hadley, author, born in New York in 1925 died at home in New York on Tuesday February 10th. An acclaimed author, Leila had two of her books, Give Me the World and A Journey with Elsa Cloud, chosen by the New York Times as notable books of the year. Leila was a dedicated supporter of the Tibetan people serving on the board of Tibet House for many years and endowed the Leila Hadley Luce Chair for Modern Tibetan Studies at Columbia University. She is the co-founder of Wings WorldQuest a nonprofit dedicated to women explorers and education. She was a member of PEN, the Fishers Island Conservancy and the Explorer's Club, and was an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Canadian Geographical Society. Leila was particularly proud of her garden on Fishers Island, NY, which was the subject of her last book, A Garden by the Sea. She was the widow of Henry Luce III, son of the founder of Time Magazine. She is survived by her sons Dr. Arthur T. Hadley III, Matthew S. Eliott, DVM, her daughters Victoria S. Barlow and Caroline Nicholson and her eight grandchildren Holly Hadley, Matthew Eliott Jr, Allison Eliott, Fiona Finlay-Hunt, Whitney Eliott, Faith, Phoebe and George Nicholson. Leila will be profoundly missed by her many dear friends around the world A memorial service is scheduled for March 10, 2009, 2pm at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue.

There are not a whole lot of stylistic changes when it comes to the Yankees. They are not going to add an alternate jersey or a two-tone batting helmet anytime soon. But every year, there are subtle changes, like Chien-Ming Wang's Nike baseball glove. Wang showed off his new glove, which includes a giant Chinese character for his name that covers the outer webbing. Wang, who is from Taiwan, said it was Nike's idea, and he likes it.

DETROIT has long been the subject of hit songs -- think of ''Detroit City (I Wanna Go Home)'' by Bobby Bare, ''Doctor Detroit'' by Devo and ''Motor City Madhouse'' by Ted Nugent. But now, the country singer John Rich is joining them by venting his frustration over the plight of auto workers and Wall Street bailouts. Earlier this month, Mr. Rich -- half of the duo Big & Rich -- released ''Shuttin' Detroit Down,'' which is rising rapidly on the country charts.

GREEN--Sidney W. One of the country's top fund raisers and a publicist for progressive causes died Saturday February 7th in Brooklyn, New York just 4 days after his 76th birthday. He succumbed to the complications of Alzheimer's disease. Born in Brooklyn, he was the son of Nathan Green and Helen Honig. The family owned a popular neighborhood candy store on Clinton St. in the Red Hook section. Educated at the local public school and Erasmus High School in Brooklyn, Mr. Green attended CCNY where he earned a BA and a Master's in English Literature from Columbia University. After serving in the Navy, stationed off the coast of Korea in the mid-1950's, he worked as a Civil Rights activist and for the Antioch Law Review. In 1962 joined the consulting firm then known as Harold L. Oram, Inc. today The Oram Group, Inc. The Oram firm worked for liberal and leftist causes and one of his early clients was Robert Hutchins Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, in Santa Barbara, California. He served many other nonprofit clients and also served as fund raising consultant to both Eugene McCarthy's and George McGovern's presidential bids. He left Oram in 1970 and set up Sidney W. Green Associates, working as an independent fund raising and public relations consultant. His company raised hundreds of millions of dollars for major public and private sector clients. In 1994 he founded Cyber Financial, a boutique merchant bank and equity and debt funds for intellectual property projects, internet startups, healthcare, hi-tech software and entertainment companies. From 1984 to 1994, Mr. Green was a public and financial affairs consultant to the Belzberg family of Vancouver, Canada. During this time he worked directly with family members as an advisor on their public and private interests. One major concern was helping to develop the Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles, a world-renowned museum that took 10 years to complete. The lead family member, Samuel Belzberg, is the museum's Chairman of the Board. As principal advisor, Sidney Green was chief fundraiser and design originator, helping to raise over US $50 million for this innovative interactive, multimedia multicultural educational program. He also scouted investment opportunities for the Belzberg family companies through First City Merchant Bank, Inc. of New York. Mr. Green is survived by his wife of 25 years, Candida McCollam, a daughter Amy LeBlanc, and three grandchildren, Nicholas, Nathaniel and Joanetta. A memorial service will be held at 2 pm, March 1 at the New York Tolerance Center. The family requests that any donations in Sidney's memory be made to the Simon Wiesenthal Center or the Alzheimer's Association.

A poet's efforts produced ''high 10s,'' signifying a perfect score, from fellow poets at the most recent slam and openmike night for teenagers, on Wednesday at the White Plains Public Library. Teenage poets meet there about once a month; a slam open to all comers takes place on the first Wednesday of every month at the library.

The American midfielder Michael Bradley capped a week in which he scored both goals for the United States in a win over Mexico in a World Cup qualifying game by scoring the tying goal Saturday as last-place Borussia Mönchengladbach earned a 1-1 tie at Werder Bremen in the German Bundesliga. Three minutes after Claudio Pizarro had given Bremen the lead, Bradley used his chest to direct a free kick by Marko Marin into the goal. It is Bradley's first season with Mönchengladbach, which seems headed for relegation. In Berlin, Hertha striker Andrey Voronin scored both goals as his team took over first place with a 2-1 win over Bayern Munich. Voronin scored his first in the 38th minute before Bayern's Miroslav Klose tied the score in the 61st minute. Ten minutes later, midfielder Franck Ribéry went on a darting run, and put striker Landon Donovan, who entered the match in the first half for the injured Luca Toni, into a perfect position to score. ROSENTHAL--Rolf Werner, beloved husband of Elizabeth and father of Erika, admired colleague, mentor and friend to so many, passed away on February 11th. He was the founder and president of Rolf Werner Rosenthal, Inc., a highly successful medical advertising agency, and World Health, a continuing education service for health care professionals. The agency had more than 130 employees, and Rolf proudly and passionately promoted both diversity and creativity in the workplace. In 1997 he was among the first to be elected to the Medical Advertising Hall of Fame. Rolf loved and sought beauty in all its forms<--music, ballet, literature, opera and nature. He was a philanthropist, a talented writer and an avid art collector, but his joy in working in his garden surpassed all else. We're convinced that his final wishes are something along the lines of: actively support the Obama administration; do the things you love while you can; and, get out and plant something in the earth. Rolf's gracious and generous spirit will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Think of him in the spring when the dogwoods bloom. Donations in his memory to Doctors without Borders will be gratefully appreciated.
Art Robin Pogrebin

NEMERSON--Yale, M.D. The Department of Medicine of The Mt. Sinai Medical Center mourns the passing of Yale Nemerson, M.D., and internationally reknowned expert on blood coagulation. Dr. Nemerson pioneered the concept that tissue factor plays a key role in clot formation, a discovery with clinical implacations. He was Professor of Medicine in the division of Hematology and Medical Oncology at Mt. Sinai from 1977 to his death. He published extensively in peer-reviewed journals and served in national and international organizations devoted to studying blood coagulation and prothrombotic syndromes. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family and friends. Paul Klotman, M.D., Chair of Medicine

To the Editor: I canceled my Citibank Visa because of the requirement that I call whenever I am traveling or using the card someplace deemed unusual. As someone who used to travel frequently for work, I was always on the road. So suddenly finding out that my Visa was rejected in Paris or Panama was a major hassle. Oddly, I didn't have the same problem with my MasterCard. Citibank would promise to put me on a special list, but the problem recurred, most notably at a Target store in Kingston, N.Y. The argument is they are protecting you. But their excess of caution is all about protecting themselves.

BECK--Elsa "Bimba" was born on April 18, 1918 to Edmund and Helene Beck and grew up in Indija, Serbia. Bimba studied art in Vienna and Paris until the start of World War II, at which time she fled to Sarajevo. Bimba and her mother were survivors; her beloved father and younger brother Dragutin Beck perished in the Holocaust. The story of her family has been archived in an interview with the Survivors of the Shoah Foundation. Following World War II, Bimba worked in Rome, Italy for HIAS (the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society), an agency that helped migrate European Jews to the US. Bimba emigrated to the United States with her mother and settled in Manhattan where she managed Jolie Gabor's Jewelry Boutique on Madison Avenue. Bimba's creativity and artistic sense was well channeled as she designed unique jewelry pieces for the Gabor line. Most of all, her love of art, literature, travel and music will be remembered by all those whose lives she touched. Bimba passed away peacefully in her home on Monday, February 2nd. Donations can be made in Bimba's memory to: The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th St.,

STEIN--Sharon Haugh, passed away at Midnight, Tuesday, February 10, 2009. She was a beautiful and extraordinarily talented woman. Sharon came to New York in 1968 and worked as a receptionist at Dominick & Dominick LLC before going to work for George Soros. For the following eight years she excelled at the hugely successful Soros Fund until she received an offer to become marketing executive at another firm. She went to work for Schroeders International and during 20 plus years with the firm, rose to become Chairman and CEO. She will be sorely missed and mourned by her family: beloved daughter, Alexis Stein, sister, Chris Haugh and family, brother, Richard Haugh and family. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 14 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10122, Attn: Sherry Jacobsen. Fred Stein

THE NEWS The Senate's version of the economic stimulus package cleared a key procedural hurdle on Monday and was assured of passage by the aye votes of three moderate Republicans. BEHIND THE NEWSPresident Obama set aside his efforts to coax bipartisan support for the stimulus plan, which bore meager fruit (the House version passed with no Republican votes at all). Instead, he slammed critics of the plan and pressed for swift approval as he visited recession-battered Elkhart, Ind., and held his first formal news conference since taking office. Though ''no plan is perfect,'' he said, there was no time to lose in nitpicking it. ''Failure to act will only deepen the crisis,'' he said.

The Big Fix The key question David Leonhardt raises (Feb. 1) is, ''How should the new American economy be made?'' Given the fact that Wall Street is unlikely to provide the remedy for the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression, I feel it's time we let go of Wall Street and, as the writer David Korten (''Agenda for a New Economy'') argues, develop a Main Street economy that is ''locally based, community-oriented and devoted to creating a better life for all, not simply increasing profits.'' He suggests an agenda that includes supporting local businesses owned by local stakeholders that employ local labor and use environmental resources responsibly as well as restructuring financial services to serve Main Street and restoring our national economic sovereignty.

SEABROOK--John Martin, a New Jersey farm boy who became a corporate titan, influential sportsman, and international icon of Saville Row style, died at his home in Aiken, SC, on February 11. He was 91. Mr. Seabrook was born on April 16, 1917, in Bridgeton, NJ, the youngest of four children. His father, Charles F. Seabrook, and grandfather built a small Cumberland County farm into Seabrook Farms, one of the largest industrialized farms in the world, with interests in growing, canning and eventually freezing vegetables. Upon graduating from Princeton University in l939, he went to work at Seabrook Farms, becoming president in l954. Under his leadership, Seabrook Farms developed the boil in the pouch method of cooking its popular frozen creamed spinach, as well as pioneering frozen entrees that would become known as "TV dinners". By 1959, some 25,000 acres of South Jersey farmland were either owned or leased by the company. That same year, Mr. Seabrook had a falling out with his father, who sold the company, and Seabrook resigned. Mr. Seabrook soon regained his footing, however, becoming by the mid-1960's the chief executive of I.U. International, a utilities company headquartered in Philadelphia. Mr. Seabrook built I.U. into a global corporation with interests in energy, mining, shipping, transportation, and food products. In 1956 Mr. Seabrook married Elizabeth Ann Toomey, a newspaper reporter whom he had met earlier that year, while aboard the U.S. Constitution, en route to Grace Kelly's wedding to Prince Rainer of Monaco. Seabrook was a guest of the Kelly family; his future bride was covering the wedding for United Press International. By the early 1960's, when Esquire Magazine first named him to its Best Dressed Men in American list, Mr. Seabrook was recognized as one of the country's most stylish devotees of the British Saville Row look. To accommodate his wardrobe, he installed a revolving dry cleaner's carousel in the attic of the 18th century farmhouse in Salem, NJ where he and his family lived. Mr. Seabrook was also instrumental in reviving the sport of horse drawn "coaching" in the U.S. He often conducted business from the box seat of a road coach. Richard Fain, who as a young executive worked under Seabrook at I.U, and later became the CEO of Royal Caribbean Cruise Line, recalled, "He would be holding four reins in one hand, a coaching whip and champagne glass in the other, driving four horses through farm roads lined with vegetables, remarking on the state of the crops, while simultaneously discussing how best to finance the five new supertankers the company was getting ready to order". After retiring from I.U. in 1981, Mr. Seabrook and his wife began to spend more time in Aiken, SC, where he pursued his interest in coaching and lent his time to preserving the Hitchcock Woods, a 2,000-acre urban park in the middle of Aiken. They moved there permanently in 2000; Mrs. Seabrook died in 2005. The last great enterprise of his life was devoted to ensuring that the nearly 2000 acres he still owned in New Jersey would be preserved as farmland in perpetuity. In November, 2008, the state announced the purchase of the development rights-the largest preservation deal in New Jersey history. Mr. Seabrook is survived by his four children Carol Boulanger, Lizanne Brooke, and John Seabrook, Jr., all of Manhattan, and Bruce Seabrook, of Miami, FL and by five grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held on Tuesday, February 17, at the Deerfield Presbyterian Church, in Deerfield, NJ. Memorial contributions can be made to the Brandywine Conservancy, P.O. Box 141, Chadds Ford, PA 19317, or to the Hitchcock Woods Foundation, P.O. Box 1702, Aiken, SC 29802.

At rush hour, the railway tunnels under the Hudson River between Manhattan and New Jersey operate at peak capacity, so there is no way to run more trains back and forth even though the demand is great. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and New Jersey Transit have been planning to build a second tunnel, which they estimate could take 22,000 automobiles off the streets at rush hour. The project has federal approval, and is mostly locally financed. An infusion of federal money could get the project well on its way to reality.
