MILBANK--Molly Wetmore, 91, died peacefully at home in New York City on February 12. Born in Santiago, Cuba she was the daughter of Robert C. Wetmore, one of Teddy Roosevelt's Rough Riders, and granddaughter of a founder of the United Fruit Company. She was a direct descendent of Philip Livingston a signatory of the Declaration of Independence and Robert Livingston who arranged the Louisiana Purchase. She also was a descendent of the Wetmore family which had been residents of New York City when it was under Dutch rule. She was married to Samuel R. Milbank an investment banker and philanthropist who predeceased her. She will be missed by her survivors who include her daughter, Elenita M. Drumwright, her son Samuel L. (Tony) Milbank, seven grandchildren, six great-grandchildren and one great-great-grandchild.

In its heyday in the 1980s, General Motors' main Pontiac plant in Pontiac, Mich., had trouble keeping up with demand. Back then, G.M. employed about 20,000 people across three shifts to help produce a wide range of vehicles. Now the plant produces two trucks -- the full-size Silverado and the GMC Sierra -- during one shift, and the remaining 850 workers worry about the future. As Pontiac the brand suffers, so does Pontiac the city, which has a population of more than 60,000. An audio slide show about Pontiac is at nytimes.com/business.

High-speed trains are increasingly common in Asia and Europe, but they have yet to make it to the United States. Now Californians are trying to change that. In November, California's voters approved a measure authorizing $10 billion in borrowing to begin work on an 800-mile high-speed train capable of going more than twice as fast as the average speed of the Acela trains on the East Coast, and which could make the trip from San Francisco to Los Angeles in 2 hours and 40 minutes. Supporters say that the plan would reduce congestion on highways and at airports and invigorate the economy; skeptics question whether the plan makes economic sense. The final bill includes $8 billion for high-speed rail; but there are 11 regions that could compete for the money, which would at most be a small down payment on what promises to be a costly project.
WEYSER--Shirley C.,81, died on February 10, 2009 in her home in Coconut Creek, Florida. She is survived by two sons, Marc and Perry, and three grandchildren, Rebecca, William, and Sammy.

KAZAN--Benjamin, died January 24, 2009, age 91. He received his BS degree from California Institute of Technology in 1938, MA degree from Columbia University in 1940, his Doctor of Science degree from the Technical University Munich, 1961. From 1940-1950 he was a section head at the Signal Corps Engineering Lab concerned with the development of new microwave storage and display tubes. From 1951 to 1958 he was employed at RCA Research Laboratories where he was engaged in color television tubes and solid state image intensifiers. From 1962-1968 he was head of the Solid State Display Group at the Hughes Research Labs continuing work on solid state imaging devices. From 1962-1968 he was employed by Electro-Optical Systems, where he was Chief Scientist of the solid state and electro-optical division. From 1968-1974 he was employed at the IBM Watson Research Center, since then he had been with the Palo Alto Research Center at the Xerox Corporation where he was head of the Display Group. He has published about 25 papers in the field of display and storage and he holds about 80 patents. He was co-author of two books, "Storage Tubes and Electronic Imaging Storage," he was editor of the book series "Advances in Image Pickup and Display," as well as editor of Proceedings of the Society of Information Display. Dr. Kazan was a fellow of SID, and a member of the American Physical Society. He is survived by his wife, his son and daughter-in-law and two grandchildren. Benwillbe missed forever.

Margaret Boles Fitzgerald, Chair Michael Gilligan, President

New York is moving ahead with its long-delayed plans to build its first new subway line in generations, restarting a project that was last halted during the 1970s fiscal crisis, leaving unused, unfinished tunnels beneath city streets. Work is going on now, but the question is whether the project can weather yet another fiscal crisis. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is under considerable financial stress and is looking for sources of money to keep its ambitious capital program going forward.

My job at the magazine keeps me on my toes. Literally. Last fall, I bought two pairs of Christian Louboutin ankle boots and by February I had worn them both into the ground. I had been putting off having them resoled because my shoe repairman uses black rubber replacement soles -- and we all know that the beauty of Louboutins is the scarlet undercarriage. I shared my predicament with my friend Ruth, who in turn introduced me to her shoe repairman, Ariel Castellanos. After a one-day turnaround, and $26, my Louboutins look as good -- and red -- as new.

ING, the Dutch financial services company, is moving faster than it said it would only three weeks ago. When ING announced on 26 Jan. a cut in its F1 sponsorship program for 2009 of 40 percent, it also said it would stick to its long-held plan of reassessing the F1 program in mid-year 2009. This morning ING made a statement that it would withdraw from F1 at the end of this season, which is the end of the three-year contract it signed in the first place.

This week's guest blogger is none other than the éminence grise of Italian design, Giorgio Armani. As the president, chief executive and sole shareholder of the multi-billion-dollar company he founded in 1975, Armani is the wealthiest fashion designer on the planet. He has defined the working wardrobe of the late-20th century and will go down in history as the man who taught Hollywood how to dress.

In this week's issue of The New Yorker, Kate Boo offers a deep, hard look into the slums of Mumbai. (Unfortunately, reading the full article online requires registration.) Ms. Boo, whom the Bagger knew back when print journalism was still considered an occasionally heroic activity, does not disappoint in "Opening Night," in which she takes a long walk with Sunil, a 13-year-old entrepreneur/thief who lives in Gautam Nagar, around one of 30 or so slums that surround and in a way, define, Mumbai.

World | The middle class: a term of vagueness, but politicians know it when they see votes. Rare is the news source that tries to define it, but this series of articles does so and suggests why the term is so hard to nail down: its meaning varies among economists and around the world. What's clear is that the middle classes have grown so much that "the developing world is no longer simply poor." And that in a downturn, a nation's middle class, with further to fall than the poor, often makes history, peacefully or otherwise. [Economist]

Environment | Libertine drunken sailors aren't the only trouble with port calls. Ships pick up (and leave) strange organisms too via the ballast water they take in and expel, researchers say -- so much so that global shipping is making the world flat, biologically, and confounding the study of species and evolution. Is that why they call them tramp steamers? [Wired]

This week, Cheryl Lynn Greenberg, professor of history at Trinity College in Hartford, and the author of "'Or Does It Explode?': Black Harlem in the Great Depression" and the forthcoming "To Ask for an Equal Chance: African Americans During the Depression," answered selected readers questions about African-Americans during the Great Depression.

Wednesday, 11 a.m. The indignity of losing a job is probably matched only by the indignity of trying to find one. That psychic ordeal is typically a process of extended humiliation wherein large doses of soul selling are spoon-fed to employers whom you'd probably rather garrote than actually work for. It is not your fault that they hold all the cards; the American dream is real, but it cannot be obtained by flattering business morons. It may not seem so, but your worth transcends your résumé. Keep looking. The New York Career Fair, Radisson Martinique on Broadway Hotel, 49 West 32nd Street, Manhattan.

Culture | Americans are curious about the world in a curious way, an Israeli-American writer says. "Suddenly we want to hear as much as possible from people who grew up in two worlds at once" -- think Obama -- yet we shun original works from other lands. "We seem to want someone else to do the ­heavy ­lifting required to make a cultural connection." We congratulate ourselves on "our globalized worldview, our ethnic restaurants in every downtown," but "it's a bit like learning about the Middle East by listening to Shakira, a ­Colombian/Italian/­Lebanese pop singer." [Wilson Quarterly]

DICHTER--Norman P.,94, after a spirited battle with lymphoma died February 15, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Estelle. Adored father of Stephen (Joan), Fredric (Barbara) and Joel (Vivianne). Cherished grandfather of Jessica (Jason), Daniel, Erica (Chuck) and Ronald (Diana). Proud great-grandfather of seven, Jennifer, Noah, Andie, Matthew, Chloe, Stiles and Emmy. Dearest brother of Lionel. A man of unflinching integrity, Gramps had three loves-his family, music and baseball. Donations in his memory may be sent to Comprehensive Community Hospice, 1 Delaware Drive, Lake Success, NY 11042.

Nelson Mandela, now a frail man at age 90, emerged from retirement on Sunday to make a surprise appearance at a campaign rally for Jacob Zuma, the current leader of the African National Congress. Mr. Mandela did not say much at the event in Eastern Cape Province. He merely thanked the crowd for braving a rainstorm, and, with family members at his side, said, ''Long live the A.N.C.!''

Great museums engender great debate, and there is no exception for Iraq. Officials here are at odds over the reopening of Iraq's National Museum, the renowned institution that was pillaged after the American invasion in 2003 and has been closed to the public ever since. Last week, Iraq's state minister for tourism and antiquities announced that next Monday the museum would reopen, an eagerly anticipated event seen as a milestone in the country's recovery. In a statement on Sunday, though, the Culture Ministry overruled the decision and put off indefinitely the chance for Iraqis to return to a museum that holds a rich collection of archaeological relics and art.

Straight to video used to carry the taint of poor quality and low demand. Now, sales of nontheatrical DVDs include popular sequels like ''Kung Fu Panda: Secrets of the Furious Five'' and well-regarded television series like ''John Adams'' and ''The Office.'' Disney did well last year, with four titles in the top five (Fox owns ''Family Guy''). ''High School Musical 3: Senior Year,'' with Zac Efron and Vanessa Hudgens, above, will be released on Tuesday. With it, Disney can only hope to match the success of ''High School Musical 2,'' which led sales of nontheatrical DVDs in 2007. SHELLY FREIERMAN

DREXLER--David, 84, of Aventura, FL, on Friday, February 13, 2009; beloved husband of Annette; devoted father of Gail Filiberto and the late Leslie Levine; dear father-in-law of Dan and David; cherished grandfather of Jeffrey and Meredith, Taryn and Joshua and Courtney. Graveside service Tuesday, February 17 at 11am in Mount Freedom Hebrew Cemetery, Randolph, NJ. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

The coffin of Ali Hussein, a bodyguard for Afghanistan's justice minister, Mohammad Sarwar Danesh, was accompanied by relatives Sunday on a helicopter ride from the capital, Kabul, to his home village, Daykondi, for burial. Mr. Hussein was killed Wednesday during an attack on government buildings in Kabul. The suicide bombers and gunmen killed at least 20 people.

When Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez acknowledged his use of steroids last week on ESPN, he accused a writer who broke the story, Selena Roberts of Sports Illustrated, of stalking him and trying to break into his home. But those claims were false, and Rodriguez has apologized to Roberts in a telephone call. Roberts, whose book on Rodriguez will be published in April, said she would attend Rodriguez's news conference Tuesday.

MILBANK--Molly Wetmore, 91, died peacefully at home in New York City on February 12. Born in Santiago, Cuba she was the daughter of Robert C. Wetmore, one of Teddy Roosevelt's Rough Riders, and granddaughter of a founder of the United Fruit Company. She was a direct descendent of Philip Livingston a signatory of the Declaration of Independence and Robert Livingston who arranged the Louisiana Purchase. She also was a descendent of the Wetmore family which had been residents of New York City when it was under Dutch rule. She was married to Samuel R. Milbank an investment banker and philanthropist who predeceased her. She will be missed by her survivors who include her daughter, Elenita M. Drumwright, her son Samuel L. (Tony) Milbank, seven grandchildren, six great-grandchildren and one great-great-grandchild.

Congratulations to Congress for stimulating America's most innovative financial wizards at the economy's greatest time of need. Thanks to an 11th-hour amendment to the stimulus bill in the Senate, the fiscal alchemists of Wall Street are mobilizing their forces en masse. Unfortunately, their imminent objective will not be to fix the financial system and get the global economy moving again. Rather it will be to find ways around this misguided piece of populist legislation and pay back government funds prematurely -- a decision that risks bringing the banking system back into panic mode.

GREENBERG--Jack, 78, of Yonkers, NY died on February 13, 2009. Born April 24, 1930 in Yonkers, NY, Jack became an entrepreneur after marrying his beloved wife Barbara in 1950. He was the founder and president of Petway Products and co-founder of the Yeshivah Day School at the Lincoln Park Jewish Center in Yonkers, NY. He is survived by his wife Barbara, three sons, Dr. Andrew, Stuart and David, daughters-in-law Lisa, Joan and Edda, two grandsons and five granddaughters. Funeral services were held at the Lincoln Park Funeral Home on Sunday, February 15th. Jack will be missed by his family, who know that his uniqueness was unmatched.
Twitter Raises $35 Million Twitter has raised $35 million in venture capital, bringing the microblogging start-up's total financing to $55 million.

Venezuelans Vote On Term Limits Images of Venezuelans voting on a referendum that did away with term limits on elected officials, and cleared the way for President Hugo Chávez to run for re-election indefinitely. The vote also amounted to a test of his power after a steep fall in the price of oil; oil revenue has financed Mr. Chávez's broadly popular poverty-reduction projects.

STRAUSS--Lauri. 25 years! Your love & laughter are always with us. Lentch-Bentch. Love, Mom, Dad (In Memoriam), Julie, David, Gregory & Emily
BARTH--Edith B. 2/16/1997. Forever mourned, forever missed, forever loved. Your Family

TEXON--Ami Gold. Inseparable and beloved wife of 64 years of her late husband, Dr. Meyer Texon, pioneer in the field of cardiology. Became engaged to Meyer on the day they met. Cherished and adored mother of Sylvia Rogers of Larchmont, NY and Stephen Texon of Miami, FL. Devoted grandmother of Robert, Jessica, and Jason Rogers and Raphael Texon. Daughter of the esteemed rabbi and physician the late Dr. Henry Raphael and Sylvia Gold. Ami was the first woman trustee of the Kehilath Jeshurun Synagogue of Manhattan, former president of the Ramaz Parents Council, and president of the KJ Sisterhood, among many other civic activities. She will live on in our hearts and minds forever and ever. Her love of family and love of Torah, and her graciousness and warmth to all she encountered, will always be remembered. Service today at Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan, at 12 noon.

Assemblymen Hector De La Torre, left, and William W. Monning, both Democrats, sleep at their desks in the California Capitol after the speaker locked down the chamber early Sunday in an effort to forge a deal on a new budget. The state is facing a $42 billion deficit, bringing warnings that insolvency is possible.

KOVEN--Joan Cummings. Beloved wife of the late Leo J. Koven, M.D., cherished daughter of the late Col. Samuel N. and Molly D. Cummings; loving mother of David and Diane, Richard and Melinda, Suzanne and Carlo; adored grandmother of Julia, Rachel, Sophie, Lily, Tony, Giancarlo, and Sam; ecstatic great-grandmother of Ella. Sister of the late Roberta Cummings. Born and raised in Brooklyn, educated at Skidmore College and Columbia Teachers' College. After many years serving in leadership positions with the League of Women Voters, Local School Board 22 of New York City and other civic organizations, at age 43 she entered Brooklyn Law School where she was an editor of the Law Review. From 1974-6 she clerked for Federal judge Hon. Orrin G. Judd of the Eastern District of New York. After working as an associate at the New York law firm Poletti, Friedin, Prashker, Feldman, and Gartner she taught at and then became Associate Dean at Brooklyn Law School until her retirement in 1995. Smart, elegant, stylish, articulate, always good company and endlessly loyal to family, friends, and community she will be greatly missed. Services Tuesday, February 17, 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Greater Washington Coalition for Jewish Life, P.O. Box 1456, Washington, CT 06793, or Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11225.

NEMERSON--Yale R.,77. "Dr. Clot." He created revolutionary change in our understanding of the blood clotting mechanism. President and board member of the International Society of Thrombosis and Haemostasis. Professor of medicine at Yale, Stony Brook, and Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Never "just" a scientist, Bronx-born Yale loved the arts (especially opera), travel, politics, the Yankees, the Giants, tennis, his dog, his children Matthew, Andrea, and David, and his grandchildren Elana, Joy, Arlo, Avram, and Lilah. Memorial service at 2pm. Sunday, February 15th at his apartment in New York City. A service in New Haven is being organized. Donations to the American Heart Association appreciated.

TEXON--Ami. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the passing of Ami Texon, a woman of valor. We extend our condolences to the Texon and Rogers families. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, Pres. & CEO

With spring training under way, and taking a break from dissecting the latest steroid report, here are 25 Random Facts About 25 Random Yankees, culled from hanging around the clubhouse over the last seven years on the beat. PERPER--William. Dorie Coleman, James Coleman and Victoria Rose are saddened by the passing of their relative and friend. He was a gentle and thoughtful man.

Walberg, the host, and the appraiser Nicholas Lowry take in vintage air travel posters at the Kansas Aviation Museum. ROSENTHAL--Rolf Werner, beloved husband of Elizabeth and father of Erika, admired colleague, mentor and friend to so many, passed away on February 11th. He was the founder and president of Rolf Werner Rosenthal, Inc., a highly successful medical advertising agency, and World Health, a continuing education service for health care professionals. The agency had more than 130 employees, and Rolf proudly and passionately promoted both diversity and creativity in the workplace. In 1997 he was among the first to be elected to the Medical Advertising Hall of Fame. Rolf loved and sought beauty in all its forms<--music, ballet, literature, opera and nature. He was a philanthropist, a talented writer and an avid art collector, but his joy in working in his garden surpassed all else. We're convinced that his final wishes are something along the lines of: actively support the Obama administration; do the things you love while you can; and, get out and plant something in the earth. Rolf's gracious and generous spirit will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Think of him in the spring when the dogwoods bloom. Donations in his memory to Doctors without Borders will be gratefully appreciated.

DINSTMAN--Ethel, passed peacefully on February 14, 2009 in New York City. Predeceased by her husband Harvey and their beloved Nancy. Survived by her daughter Carole, who cared for her mother tirelessly until the end, and siblings Sylvia Lisman and Martin Schwartz. Her spirit, humor and warmth were the heart of her family.

RYAN LESLIE (Next Selection/Atlantic) Ryan Leslie must think it's charming when he tells his ''Diamond Girl'' -- the one he wants to marry -- that ''You would know if you read the news/I could be with any other fine girl 'stead of you.'' Trying to be a manly, sweet-talking R&B smoothie, Mr. Leslie comes off more as self-absorbed.
TEXON--Ami. Ami brought love and tradition to family and friends. She was a warm, gentle and kind woman who was loved by all. She will be missed. The Reingold Family

Americans know what they think about Abraham Lincoln. But what does the world think about him? To mark Presidents' Day, and Lincoln's 200th birthday, which took place last week, the Op-Ed editors asked four writers from around the world to describe how Lincoln has influenced their countries.

TANNENBAUM--Leonard, 88. Died in Greenwich Hospital February 13th from complications of a fall. Beloved husband of the late Gloria, brother to Gloria Okin, father to Cara and Saul (Genevieve), grandfather to Leah and Sophie Byland. Civil engineer who left a legacy of schools, hospitals and sewage treatment plants. Donations may be made to the Bruce Byland Anthropology Award of the Lehman College Foundation, 250 Bedford Park Blvd West, Bronx NY 10468. Services will be held at the Zion Memorial Chapel Mamaroneck NY on Sunday February 15th at 11:30 AM. Shiva through Tuesday at the home of Cara Tannenbaum.

HAUGH--Sharon L. A trailblazer among women at top ranks of the investment management industry, died Tuesday, February 10th after a long and valliant struggle with illness. Born and raised in the San Fernando Valley area of Los Angeles, California, Sharon attended the University of Arizona before moving to New York in 1968. From 1995-2002, she was the Chairman of Schroder Investment Management North America. In her twenty year career with the firm, Ms. Haugh led Schroders to a preeminent position in the United States. Under her leadership, Schroders was consistently ranked as one of the top international money managers in the country. In 2002, she was the first woman honored by the Association of Investment Management Sales Executives ("AIMSE") with the Richard A. Lothrop Award in recognition of both her outstanding contributions to the industry, as well as her involvement in community affairs and charitable endeavors. Prior to joining Schroders in 1982, Ms. Haugh held positions with New Court Securities (Rothschild, Inc.) and Soros Fund Management. Her last executive position in the industry was as Chief Executive at Pequot Capital Management. She is a past President of AIMSE, and has served on the Board of the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, American Ballet Theatre, and Met Life Investors. Sharon will be remembered for her passion for living life to the fullest, her intelligence, her wit, and her generosity towards those she loved. She loved, and was beloved by, many friends in Anguilla, BWI, where she visited regularly for over twenty years. She will be sorely missed and mourned by her beloved daughter Alexis Stein, her sister, brother and family, and her many, many friends. A small private service was held on Friday, February 13, 2009. In Lieu of flowers, donations in her memory should be made to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 14 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10122, Attn: Sherry Jacobson or online at www.ocrf.org

Faith Prince, who won many a Broadway heart – as well as a Tony Award – as Miss Adelaide in the 1992 Broadway revival of “Guys and Dolls,” is now preparing to step into a notably less lovable role this spring: Ursula the sea witch in the Disney musical “The Little Mermaid.”

After an Off-Broadway run in 2008 and some subsequent retooling during a recent production in Washington, D.C., the domestic-drama-cum-musical “Next to Normal” is returning to New York – and Broadway – with previews scheduled to begin March 27 and an opening night of April 15 at the Longacre Theater.

A high school in Newport Beach, Calif., has become the latest to cancel a student production of “Rent,” though the reasons for its cancellation remain murky, The Orange County Register reported. Corona del Mar High School in Southern California was scheduled to perform the school edition of “Rent,” an edited version of the Jonathan Larson musical about downtown Manhattanites living with the specter of AIDS, on April 23. Ron Martin, the drama instructor at the school, said the production was canceled by the principal, Fal Asrani, who objected to its gay characters. Ms. Asrani told The Register that Mr. Martin stopped the show because there was not enough time to revise the script. Mr. Martin said that was not true, adding that scripts for the play had not yet been ordered. In December, Rowlett High School in Rowlett, Tex., canceled its planned production of “Rent” after parents and community members objected to the content of the show, though its cast members performed a version of the show at nearby Southern Methodist University.

After serving for just seven months as the executive director of the Pasadena Museum of California Art, Christopher Mount has been replaced at the museum, The Los Angeles Times reported. Mr. Mount, who took the job in July, had previously served as a curator at the Museum of Modern Art and was the director of exhibitions and public programs at Parsons The New School for Design. A spokeswoman for the museum told The Times that Mr. Mount left in mid-January “to pursue other things.” Mr. Mount will be succeeded by Jenkins Shannon, a former entertainment executive who has worked for the Disney Channel, as well as MGM and Sony Television. More recently, Ms. Shannon has worked as the museum’s associate director and its acting director.

In a surprise move, Geoffrey Gilmore, the long-time director of the Sundance Film Festival, has agreed to become the chief creative officer of Tribeca Enterprises, which owns and operates the Tribeca Film Festival, among other ventures. Mr. Gilmore, one of the independent film world’s best known executives, had been with Sundance for 19 years and helped turn it into what is arguably the defining annual event in the independent film world. Tribeca announced on Tuesday morning that Mr. Gilmore was joining its ranks. The annual Tribeca festival was initially founded by Robert De Niro, Jane Rosenthal and Craig Hatkoff as a way to revitalize downtown Manhattan in the wake of the 9/11 terror attacks, but has since been working to rival Sundance as a force in independent film.

For some viewers, the idea of another Jane Austen-inspired period drama is sufficiently monstrous, but a coming film project seeks to update the formula with actual monsters, Variety reported. The movie “Pride and Predator,” directed by Will Clark and written by Mr. Clark with Andrew Kemble and John Pape, will juxtapose brooding aristocrats with a brutal alien that lands in 1800s-era Britain, attacking residents and leaving them with neither sense nor sensibility. The film, to be produced by Elton John’s Rocket Pictures, is the latest work to mix the hoary costume genre with elements of horror. A book called “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies,” credited to Jane Austen and Seth Grahame-Smith and published by Quirk Books, will combine the Austen novel with “all-new scenes of bone-crunching zombie mayhem.” And a coming novel by Michael Thomas Ford called “Jane Bites Back” depicts the 19th-century author as a frustrated vampire, taking revenge on those who have made money from her work.

Not quite 10 years after they ended, the 1990s are back: the bands Nine Inch Nails and Jane’s Addiction, whose clothing, attitudes and, by the way, music helped define the decade, plan to tour together later this year, Billboard reported. On the official Web site of Nine Inch Nails, nin.com, the group’s front man, Trent Reznor, wrote that the musicians “decided to book a last run of shows across the globe this year.” (“Will it resonate in the marketplace?” he added. “Who knows. Are there big record label marketing dollars to convince you to attend? Nope.”) The bands previously performed together in the early years of Lollapalooza, the 1990s concert series, leading to a joint tour on which Jane’s Addiction broke up. (The band reunited in 1997, broke up again, and re-reunited in 2001.) No dates were announced for the 2009 tour.
It comes as no surprise that in Manhattan, where George W. Bush was not exactly the most popular of presidents, a Broadway show lampooning Mr. Bush would do brisk business. But how brisk?

Daptone Records, the Brooklyn-based soul label that releases albums by Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings, and the Budos Band among others, was burglarized over the Presidents’ Day weekend, the label’s co-founder, Gabriel Roth, said in an e-mail message, which was reported on the Web site BrooklynVegan.com. Mr. Roth wrote that numerous items were stolen or damaged, including computers, turntables, amplifiers, guitars and other instruments. In an interview, the other founder, Neal Sugarman, said workers were still cleaning up label’s office, in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, and assessing what was taken, adding: “It’s hard to tell whether they knew what they wanted to get or not.” He said that police were investigating and that the label would remain shut for several days, though it hoped to reopen by Friday for a planned recording session for Rod Stewart.

The same groups that unleashed a series of television and radio advertisements to pressure Republicans into supporting the economic stimulus package -- or to shame them for voting against it -- are back on the air with another television spot. Now that President Obama has signed a $787 stimulus package into law and weighed tens of billions more to aid homeowners and banks, he will take a break next Monday to consider just how the government can get a grip on its increasingly ugly balance sheet.

This week's guest blogger is none other than the éminence grise of Italian design, Giorgio Armani. As the president, chief executive and sole shareholder of the multi-billion-dollar company he founded in 1975, Armani is the wealthiest fashion designer on the planet. He has defined the working wardrobe of the late-20th century and will go down in history as the man who taught Hollywood how to dress.

The Italian designer and billionaire Giorgio Armani celebrated Fashion Week on Tuesday with the announcement of a $1 million donation to promote arts programs in New York City public schools.The money will be used to create the Armani Arts Institute, an umbrella program that will fund arts initiatives in schools serving some of the city's most disadvantaged populations.

As part of its restructuring plan to make a case for more loans from the federal government, General Motors will cut its work force further, shutter more plants in North America and reduce its lineup of eight brands to four by phasing out Saturn entirely, ending Pontiac as a full division, and selling off Saab and Hummer.

Psychology | Look at the bright side of stress, says an article that comes along none too soon. "Good stress" in the right amounts "can motivate us to do better at jobs we care about," making us "more resilient." In fact, against a near-consensus that all stress is bad, "some psychologists are starting to define a phenomenon called post-traumatic growth." If only the economists could discern the same thing ... [Newsweek]

Releasing the TimesPeople API (now available) is a big step for us. Back when we first came up with TimesPeople, we were trying to answer the question, "How can we give back to the Social Web?" We realized that we could only represent the user in the context of NYTimes.com. The first step was aggregating a user's public actions and making it possible to share those activities with other TimesPeople users. This didn't really "give back" to the social Web, but now the API is available - and that means your TimesPeople data can be syndicated and used all over the Web.

The co-chief executives of the BlackBerry maker Research in Motion and two other senior executives have agreed to pay fines totaling more than $1.4 million to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that they backdated millions of dollars in stock options to benefit themselves and other employees.

John Singleton's heavily hyped trailer for the 81st Academy Awards was finally released in 11,000 theaters around the country on Friday, and has made its way to YouTube. Sid Ganis, the president of Academy, described it as "a powerful spot that will whet movie lovers appetites for a terrific show." The number of civilians killed in Afghanistan leaped by about 40 percent last year over the previous one, according to a survey by the United Nations.

A report from Science News(via Food Times) argues that beef produces 19 kilograms of CO2 for every kilogram served; that grass-fed beef is worse -- yes, worse -- for global warming than feed-lot beef; and that for every percentage reduction we make in meat consumption we'll see a corresponding reduction in its contribution to global warming.

You might have been to a party where the host slips a charm in the shape of a root vegetable or constellation onto the stem of your wineglass. On top of remembering everyone's name at the party, you now have to keep track of whether you're the shooting star or the star triad, the race car or the garbage truck.

Media | It looks like the Internet is accelerating a change in news consumption begun back in the 1970's when cable TV splintered the networks' captive news audience, an article says. Like cable, the Web is fostering a two-tiered information society: a small audience of "news junkies" who tend to want their views ratified, and a much larger group of entertainment-oriented "news dropouts." It's bad news for general-interest newspapers, print or online. But they're used to that. [New Republic]

Amy Thomas has written a delightful article about using the Velib system in Paris to hunt down chocolates. I wish I, too, could bike happily around Paris but every time I have tried, the Velib machine refuses my credit card. I am afraid other readers of this article will have the same distressing experience. American credit cards do not have an embedded chip or 'puce' readable by the Velib kiosk. Our old fashioned magnetic strip technology just does not work with the more modern systems available in France. How did Amy Thomas manage her bike rental? Can you let us know?

The combination of Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation is a relative rarity these days. It is a merger of equals. Merger of equals are a means for companies to combine with no designated "acquirer." Instead, the companies publicly proclaim that this is a strategic combination without the need for such formalities. In pursuit of this equality, the board of directors of the combined company is split equally between directors from each company. There is also typically a brokered power-sharing arrangement among the chief executives. The shareholders from each company retain ownership in the combined entity since these deals are structured as stock-for-stock tax-free exchanges.

World | World stability is threatened by a looming "axis of upheaval" -- potentially Russia, Somalia, Mexico and many more countries -- and it's "reminiscent of the decade before the outbreak of World War II, when the Great Depression unleashed a wave of global political crises," Niall Ferguson writes in a specially themed issue of Foreign Policy. This is true even of the United States ..." [Foreign Policy]

The cratering economy has delivered a swift kick in the gut to the trend-a-minute women's-wear market, so for now, fashion is a man's world. Sales of guy-gear have grown steadily over the last five or so years, and currently the category is even outpacing the ladies. So for every "It" bag that isn't sold to a woman, it looks like the new logic is to sell one to a man. Or at least that's Carlos Falchi's approach. Today's WWD reports the upscale department store staple will soon offer designs in exotic skins like python, ostrich and buffalo in neutrals and kicky reds and greens. Falchi takes inspiration from the man-bag-friendlier terrain of Europe, saying, "American men are just starting" to love them. Are they really? The more important question: should they? Falchi's line features duffels and messenger bags, but certainly a sport clutch can't be too far off.

The British sailor Dee Caffari became the first woman to have sailed around the world solo in both directions when she finished sixth in the Vendee Globe. Caffari, 36, finished the race in 99 days 1 hour 10 minutes 57 seconds in her Vendee Globe debut. Aboard Aviva, she circled the three great capes: Good Hope, Leeuwin and Horn, the southernmost tips of Africa, Australia and the Americas. In May 2006, Caffari became the first woman to sail solo around the world, against the prevailing winds and currents. That trip took nearly twice as long, 178 days 3 hours 5 minutes.

The Swedish wrestler Ara Abrahamian lost his appeal to win back the bronze medal he discarded in protest at the Beijing Games. The Court of Arbitration for Sport said it rejected Abrahamian’s appeal of the International Olympic Committee’s decision to disqualify him from the Greco-Roman competition. Abrahamian, 33, was disqualified after throwing his medal down at the awards ceremony to protest the refereeing of his semifinal.

Running back Fred Taylor wanted to end his career in Jacksonville, hoping to join a small list of standout N.F.L. players who spent an entire career with the same team, but the Jaguars released him, parting ways with their career leading rusher after 11 seasons. Coach Jack Del Rio flew to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to deliver the news. Taylor, 33, was scheduled to make $6 million next season. ¶The Baltimore Ravens released cornerback Chris McAlister, a 10-year veteran and 3-time Pro Bowler. McAlister, 31, who started for Baltimore’s Super Bowl winner in 2001, ranked third on the Ravens’ career list with 26 interceptions. He started five games last season before being benched and was placed on injured reserve with an injury to his right knee Nov. 11. He was to make $8 million this year. ravens.

The Phoenix Suns suspended Jason Richardson for one game without pay after he was clocked by the police in Scottsdale, Ariz., driving 55 miles per hour above the limit with his unrestrained 3-year-old son in the car. In a statement, the Suns said Richardson would miss Tuesday night’s home game against the Los Angeles Clippers “for conduct detrimental to the team.” The police said an officer saw Richardson driving 67 m.p.h. in a 40 m.p.h. zone Sunday night, followed him and clocked him at 90 m.p.h. in a 35 m.p.h. zone and pulled him over. The officer saw Richardson’s son in the back seat of the car and that he was not in a child seat.

EMENY--Barbara Cox (September 18, 1909 February 15, 2009), passed away peacefully into her 99th year. Mrs. Emeny was the widow of the late Brooks Emeny, a prominent international relations scholar and lecturer who specialized in American foreign policy and was President of the Foreign Policy Association. Mrs. Emeny, or "Bobbie" as she was affectionately known, was born in New York City, educated in Florence, Italy and was a resident of Princeton, NJ. She was a prominent interior designer, member of The National Society of Colonial Dames, involved in numerous charitable and civic endeavors, and continued to play her favorite game of bridge with her friends weekly until the end. As the widow of Brooks Emeny, she continued his tradition of caring for Princeton University and was elected an honorary member of the Class of 1924. Mrs. Emeny is survived by her stepdaughter Faith E. Conger and grandnephews Lee C. Hansen, William P. Taft and Timothy E. Taft. A private service will be held in Locust Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Phippsburg Historical Society, 24 Parker Head Road, Phippsburg, ME 04562.

BMW, the German luxury car maker, announced Monday that it would eliminate 850 jobs at a plant that makes the Mini car in Oxford, England, in response to the slump in demand. At the beginning of March, the Oxford plant will switch to two shifts a day from three and operate five days a week, from seven, BMW said in a statement. ''Sacking an entire shift like this, and targeting agency workers who have no rights to redundancy pay, is blatant opportunism on BMW's part and nothing short of scandalous,'' Tony Woodley, the joint general secretary of Unite, the biggest union in Britain, said in a statement. The carmaker is the latest in Britain to announce plant closures and job cuts. Honda has closed its plant in Swindon for four months from February to May. Nissan Motor said in January that it would cut 1,200 jobs at its plant in Sunderland.

Audio excerpts from opera recordings that, in 1907, were carefully wrapped in wax and stored in lead and iron containers beneath the Paris Opera, left, with instructions that they should remain undisturbed for 100 years. One hundred years later, the vault was opened, and the containers were exhumed, right. And, after lengthy examination, cleaning and digitizing of the records, EMI, the heir to the Gramophone Company that supplied the recordings in 1907, is reissuing them on three CDs. The collection will be released in France later this month as ''Les Urnes de l'Opéra'' and in the United States in early April with the English subtitle ''Treasures From the Paris Opera Vaults.'' nytimes.com/music

HAUGH--Sharon L. A trailblazer among women at top ranks of the investment management industry, died Tuesday, February 10th after a long and valliant struggle with illness. Born and raised in the San Fernando Valley area of Los Angeles, California, Sharon attended the University of Arizona before moving to New York in 1968. From 1995-2002, she was the Chairman of Schroder Investment Management North America. In her twenty year career with the firm, Ms. Haugh led Schroders to a preeminent position in the United States. Under her leadership, Schroders was consistently ranked as one of the top international money managers in the country. In 2002, she was the first woman honored by the Association of Investment Management Sales Executives ("AIMSE") with the Richard A. Lothrop Award in recognition of both her outstanding contributions to the industry, as well as her involvement in community affairs and charitable endeavors. Prior to joining Schroders in 1982, Ms. Haugh held positions with New Court Securities (Rothschild, Inc.) and Soros Fund Management. Her last executive position in the industry was as Chief Executive at Pequot Capital Management. She is a past President of AIMSE, and has served on the Board of the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, American Ballet Theatre, and Met Life Investors. Sharon will be remembered for her passion for living life to the fullest, her intelligence, her wit, and her generosity towards those she loved. She loved, and was beloved by, many friends in Anguilla, BWI, where she visited regularly for over twenty years. She will be sorely missed and mourned by her beloved daughter Alexis Stein, her sister, brother and family, and her many, many friends. A small private service was held on Friday, February 13, 2009. In Lieu of flowers, donations in her memory should be made to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 14 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10122, Attn: Sherry Jacobson or online at www.ocrf.org

Louie Bellson, a crisp and dazzling drummer who worked with many of the major figures of the swing era and a gracious entertainer who made frequent appearances at the White House and on ''The Tonight Show,'' died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 84 and lived in Los Angeles. His death was announced by Remo, the drum company for which he was a vice president. Matt Connors, the company's manager for artist relations, said Mr. Bellson had been recovering from a broken hip since November.

YAVITZ--Boris. Columbia Business School notes with great sadness the passing of Boris Yavitz, the Paul Garrett Professor Emeritus of Public Policy and Business Responsibility and dean of Columbia Business School from 1975 to 1982. Born in Russia and educated at Cambridge University, Professor Yavitz served as a lieutenant in the British Royal Navy. He earned his masters in industrial engineering from Columbia's School of Engineering and Applied Science and a Ph.D. from Columbia Business School in 1964, after which he joined the faculty and built a long and storied career. Professor Yavitz also served as a director and deputy chairman of the New York Federal Reserve from 1977 to 1982, and as a director on several boards of major companies. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife of 59 years, Irene Bernhard, their three daughters, Jessica, Judy and Emily, and the family. In lieu of flowers, the family gratefully appreciates donations to the Dr. Boris Yavitz Scholarship Fund at Columbia Business School. For information, call Rebekkah Brown at 212-854-3427. Glenn Hubbard, Dean Henry R. Kravis, Co-chair Arthur J. Samberg, Co-chair Board of Overseers Columbia Business School

BAILEY--Katharine Palmer, 64, of Millerton, NY, and Lakeville, CT, died peacefully on February 14, 2009 of cancer, after years during which she displayed such courage and composure that few knew she was ill. She was the deeply loved wife of Albert Francke, of Millerton, NY, and sister of Charles Bailey, of Sidney, VA, and Robert Bailey, of Oak Park, IL. Ms. Bailey graduated from Miss Porter's School in 1961, and, after years of adventurous travel through Latin America, Africa and Southeast Asia, received her BA in nursing at Boston University School of Nursing. Then, in 1979, she received her MS in psychiatric nursing at Boston College. She spent 25 years in psychiatric nursing practice, published several monographs and articles on psychopharmacology, and ended her career as an assistant professor at Yale University School of Nursing. She spent her last four years in a joyful marriage to Albert Francke. She was deeply loved by many, and will be missed by all who knew her high intelligence, deep sympathy and caring for others. A memorial service will be held for her at a later date. In her memory please make donations to the Katharine P. Bailey Memorial Fund at Health and Empowerment for African Lives (HEAL) attn. Martha Schnell, 1603 W. Taylor MC 923, Chicago, IL 60612 or www.Healpartners.org.

DOLAN--Kevin L.,71, of Boston's Beacon Hill, died February 13, 2009, surrounded by his loving family. Son of the late Matthew and Helen (nee Flaherty) Dolan. Loving husband of Janet E. Dolan for 42 years. Devoted father of Kerry Dolan Slater and Tracy Dolan, cherished grandfather of Alec, Katie, and Megan, and beloved brother of the Rev. Mary Ellen Dolan. Mr. Dolan was a graduate of Framingham High School and Boston College, and served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army. In 1965, he graduated from Columbia University Graduate School of Business and went to work at Time, Inc in New York City, where he ultimately rose to Vice President and Controller. In 1985, he moved to Boston to become President and later also CEO of Little, Brown and Company. He was a valued trustee of Huntington Theater Company in Boston, the National MS Society-Central New England Chapter, and Bennington College in Vermont. And also a longtime member of The Union Club of Boston, The Groucho Club in London, and The Publishers Lunch Club in New York City. His great passion was traveling the world with his family. A memorial service will be held at Mount Auburn Cemetery Bigelow Chapel 580 Mount Auburn Street, Cambridge, MA on Friday, February 20, 2009 at 11am. All are requested to meet at the Main Gate area at 10:45am. Memorial Contributions can made in Mr. Dolan's name to the National MS Society-Central New England Chapter P.O. Box 845945 Boston, MA 02284-5945 or Huntington Theater Company 281 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA 02115 c/o Lisa McColgan. Boston Harborside Home J.S. Waterman & Sons-Waring-Langone 617-536-4110.

MOSBACHER--Patricia. The Board of Trustees, medical staff, administration and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Patricia Mosbacher, a cherished member and Vice Chair Emerita of our Board of Trustees. A committed member of the Board since 1987, Pat played a pivotal role in raising funds for the Hospital as the longtime chair of our Annual Tribute Dinners. Her memory lives on with the annual Patricia Mosbacher Honorary Lecture in Orthopaedic Trauma that was created in her honor at HSS. We will long remember her grace and wit, as well as her style and dedication to our mission. We extend our deepest condolences to her son Bruce and daughter-in-law Nancy and to grandchildren Jack and Emily, and to her son Emil III (Tripp). She will be greatly missed. Dean R. O'Hare Aldo Papone Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Thomas P. Sculco, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief Louis A. Shapiro President and CEO

WEISS--Janis Cecily, beloved wife of Edward Weiss for 54 years. Devoted mother to Peter and Judi. Loving mother-in-law to Bettina and grandmother to Alex. Adoring sister, aunt and great aunt. Devoted friend. Die-hard Red Sox fan. A woman of valor and distinction. For years she served her community in numerous capacities including terms as President of The League of Women Voters and 27 years as an elected member and officer of the Cresskill Board of Education. Thousands of students and teachers were influenced by her commitment to education. She was a graduate of Cushing Academy and Smith College She led by example, lived with commitment and graced us with wisdom and optimism. Services will be held at Temple Beth El, 221 Schraalenburgh Road, Closter, NJ at 10:00am on Tuesday, February 17th. Shiva minyan will be at 7:30pm Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at the Weiss residence. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Cresskill Education Foundation, P.O. Box 445, Cresskill, NJ 07626.

There will be much celebrating around the Party Tree in Hobbiton tonight: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt said in a email message that it plans to release a previously unpublished book by J.R.R. Tolkien that predates his novel “The Hobbit” and his fantasy epic, “The Lord of the Rings.” The book, “The Legend of Sigurd and Gudrún,” was written during the 1920s and 30s, while Tolkien held the Rawlinson and Bosworth Professorship of Anglo-Saxon at Oxford University; it is his English-language narrative of the Norse hero Sigúrd the Völsung, whose Middle Ages adventures were — of course — populated by magic horses, dwarves, dragons and gods with mischievous motives. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt said it planned to publish the book, with commentary from Tolkien’s son Christopher, on May 5.

The author Herman Rosenblat, whose memoir “Angel at the Fence” was canceled after he admitted that portions of the story were falsified, said in interviews that he invented his tale to give people hope and promote understanding about the Holocaust. In his memoir, Mr. Rosenblat wrote that he met his wife, Roma, while a prisoner of a German concentration camp during the Holocaust, where Roma would throw him apples from outside the camp’s fence; Holocaust scholars disputed these details and Berkley Books halted publication of the memoir. In an interview Wednesday on ABC’s “Good Morning America,” Mr. Rosenblat said, “It wasn’t a lie. It was my imagination. And in my imagination, in my mind, I believed it. Even now I believe it, that she was there and she threw the apple to me.” Mr. Rosenblat made similar statements in a video circulated on YouTube. A film version of his story and a novel adapted from the film’s screenplay are still planned.

Should Heath Ledger be named best supporting actor at the Oscars on Sunday, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said that the statuette would eventually become the possession of Matilda Rose Ledger, the daughter of the late actor and Michelle Williams, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ledger, who died in January 2008 of an accidental drug overdose, is nominated for his performance in “The Dark Knight.” By academy tradition, posthumous Oscars are generally given to a winner’s spouse or oldest child. Mr. Ledger was not married to Ms. Williams, but Matilda, who is 3, is legally ineligible to sign the contract the academy mandates for all Oscar recipients, which limits their ability to resell the statuette. Hence, if Mr. Ledger wins, the award will be given to Ms. Williams, in trust for Matilda until she turns 18. The academy has not said who would accept the Oscar for Mr. Ledger at the ceremony. A Golden Globe for Mr. Ledger in January was accepted by Christopher Nolan, director of “The Dark Knight.”

Several performances scheduled by the Concert Association of Florida, a longtime producer of classical music and dance events, will go forward as planned even though the company filed for bankruptcy. In a release, the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts of Miami-Dade County said that it would host six of seven events scheduled for the coming weeks by the Concert Association of Florida, which filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy protection on Friday. The events include a concert by the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Lorin Maazel, on Feb. 26, as well as performances by the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Pinchas Zukerman (March 12), and the National Philharmonic of Russia (April 10).

A vodka named for Jimi Hendrix will probably never be experienced by consumers after a judge ruled that the product infringes on the musician’s trademarks. In a release issued by Experience Hendrix and Authentic Hendrix, which own and license Hendrix’s likeness and music, the companies said they had won a $3.2 million judgment against Craig Dieffenbach and his Electric Hendrix Spirits, maker of Hendrix Electric Vodka. Electric Hendrix Spirits had described the liquor as inspired “by the innovative spirit of legendary musician Jimi Hendrix,” but the judge, Thomas S. Zilly of federal District Court in western Washington State, prohibited the company from using any Hendrix products for commercial purposes, and ordered that the vodka and any related advertising be pulled.

Art Moscow, the annual Russian contemporary art fair usually held in the spring, has been postponed to September because its organizers hope to capitalize on a second art fair already scheduled for that month, Bloomberg News reported. The 13th annual Art Moscow fair, originally scheduled to begin May 14, was pushed back to a Sept. 24 opening date to coincide with the Moscow Biennale of Contemporary Art. If the global economy has not recovered, then “by September, everyone will have gotten used to the new reality of the crisis,” said Vasily Bychkov, the general director of Expo Park Exhibition Projects, which stages the Art Moscow event, according to Bloomberg News. Last month, the Moscow World Fine Art Fair, an annual event planned for the last week of May, was canceled.

Touch and Go Records, the independent record label that has provided a home for aggressively energetic acts like the Jesus Lizard and Big Black and helped foster the careers of artists like the Yeah Yeah Yeahs and TV on the Radio, said that it would cease its operations as a manufacturer and distributor for other small labels like Merge Records and Kill Rock Stars. Confirming a report that appeared on the Web site of The Chicago Tribune, the label’s owner, Corey Rusk wrote in a statement that “the current state of the economy has reached the point where we can no longer afford to continue this lesser known, yet important part of Touch and Go’s operations.” Touch and Go, which celebrated its 25th anniversary in 2006, said it would scale back to “an appropriate smaller size” and continue to run as an independent label.

The coming Broadway transfer of “Rock of Ages,” the improbably successful musical pieced together from power-chord ballads by Journey, Bon Jovi and other ’80s-era bands, has announced its complete cast. Constantine Maroulis, the “American Idol” finalist who starred in the show’s Off-Broadway run at New World Stages, will return in the lead role of Drew, the aspiring Los Angeles rock star. He’ll be joined by Amy Spanger (of Broadway’s “The Wedding Singer” and “Kiss Me Kate”) and James Carpinello (Broadway’s “Saturday Night Fever”). Previews for “Rock of Ages” are scheduled to begin March 17 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, and the show is slated to open on April 7.

There's almost a science to a good Michael Kors show. Open with Carmen K (naturally), play some feel-good music, and add sex to an American classic. Today's show was tops. I put it down to the tailoring-that (relatively) new take on the one-shoulder dress now in dark felted wool. Jessica Stam's version in a charcoal trompe l'oeil silk tweed looked just as fresh. Kors just got the mood right. He didn't give you too much; he gave you what you needed. There were some good-looking suits with cutout necklines and skirts slit up the leg. Shades of Balenciaga's black sculptural dresses from last fall? Maybe, but the precise line works with his suits. And I loved the classic gray trousers-slim, elongating, shown with an ivory silk crepe T-shirt. They're the kind you can never seem to find. By the way, Richard Chai also had some great pants in his show today-slouchy, extra long. The rest of his collection was a bit murky

City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. unveiled a Web tool on Wednesday that allows residents to enter their Zip code and see a table, and download an accompanying map, showing how the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's proposed package of 318 service cuts would affect their particular neighborhood. Users can also specify their particular subway or bus route to see how it would be affected by the proposed reductions.If anything, the Web-based tool demonstrates how extensive the cuts would be, reaching across all five boroughs and every mode of transit. Mr. Thompson, who plans to run for mayor this fall, has been urging riders to protest the proposed cuts. The tool allows users to e-mail the information about their service cuts to friends and to post the information on Facebook and other social networking sites.

The federal Department of Agriculture announced Tuesday that 13 maple trees on Staten Island had been infested by the Asian longhorn beetle, prompting an expansion of a tree quarantine area that was first established in the borough in 2007.Initial examination of the trees estimated that the infestation has lasted about four years. All 13 Staten Island trees all had the tell-tale exit holes, three-eighths of an inch in diameter and perfectly round, as well as sites indicating that beetles had laid eggs, according to the Agriculture Department.
The Peter J. Solomon Company said Wednesday that Frederic M. Seegal, a longtime investment banker involved in mergers and acquisitions, had joined the firm as a senior adviser.

At the start of his presidential term in 1913, Woodrow Wilson said prophetically, "It would be the irony of fate if my administration had to deal chiefly with foreign affairs." Although he managed to win passage of major progressive reforms, including the Federal Reserve Act, his presidency was soon overwhelmed by problems abroad: first in Mexico, with American troops seizing the port of Vera Cruz in April 1914, and then in Europe, where the First World War erupted that August.

Don and Tanyeil General had tried everything they could think of to get their 15-year-old son, Trenton, to take his school work seriously. They punished him often - taking away his video games and his cell phone for up to two weeks at a time. They warned about his bleak future, "with a work-for-food sign around his neck, or worse yet in an orange jumpsuit" in prison, his father says. His parents took him to doctors who said the boy was just fine - no learning disabilities, no ADHD. Still, Trenton was failing English and algebra and barely passing science.

The Atomic is one of the coffee world's cultiest machines, a vintage stovetop macchinetta-like contraption with enough style to hold its own against other icons of postwar Italian design. Patented by Giordano Robbiati in the 1940s, it was produced in various official and knock-off editions around the world until the 1980s. A few days ago I was rewatching "Paris Is Burning," one of my all-time favorite films. For the uninitiated, it's a 1991 documentary by Jennie Livingston about the drag balls in the Harlem of the late 1980s, which were celebrated mostly by marginalized African-American and Latino gay and transgender communities. "Paris Is Burning" brought vogueing, a series of elaborate dance moves based on poses borrowed from fashion magazines, to the mainstream. (Madonna cashed in on the movement with her hit "Vogue.") As the movie ended with Willi Ninja, the mother of the House of Ninja, announcing that he had purchased a Jean-Paul Gaultier earring and was taking Paris by storm, it occurred to me that Beyoncé should be practicing her vogueing moves.

The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Tao Okamoto of Supreme Model Management gets reinvented nine times. See previous model, Amanda Laine.

As Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week rolls forward, some of the most important reviews are starting to appear in print. Which big-name designer will be framing his WWD write-up? Who will be torching her I.H.T.? We know. Today Scorecard summarizes fashion reviews of Altuzarra, Betsey Johnson, Boy by Band of Outsiders, Carlos Miele, Carolina Herrera, Chris Benz, Cynthia Rowley, Diane Von Furstenberg, DKNY, Donna Karan, Elie Tahari, Erin Fetherston, Hervé Léger by Max Azria, Jeremy Laing, Jill Stuart, Jonathan Saunders, Lela Rose, Luca Luca, Marc Jacobs, Miss Sixty, Organic by John Patrick, Preen, Reem Acra, Thakoon, Tracy Reese, Tuleh, Victoria Beckham, William Rast, Y-3, and Zero + Maria Cornejo. Jonathan Saunder's architectural shoulders missed the cut, but the jury's still out on whether fashion's perennial darling's '80 riff hit the Marc -- you decide!
InContention pointed us to this gorgeous, hilarious look back in The Guardian about presentations past that left the room gasping for air or just plain gasping.
Updated, Feb. 19 | The New York Post issued an apology on Thursday night "to those who were offended," while maintaining that the cartoon was not intended to be racist.
Images from three of the commercials in the exhibition “Forty Years of Ads on TV" at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris.

Nature | "The Superorganism" -- a book about the social organization of ants -- prompts a reviewer to wonder if the Internet "is leading to a similar social evolution of our own species?" Perhaps not, he says, given our propensity for war. Yet "as we strive to avert a global economic disaster or agree on a global treaty to prevent catastrophic climate change, we inevitably build structures that, as with the ants, allow the superorganism to function more efficiently." Or are we too smart for that? [New York Review of Books]
Rich Cohen's books include "Tough Jews," "Lake Effect" and "Sweet and Low: A Family Story." His new book, "Israel Is Real," will be published this summer.

Mudhafer al-Husaini has applied for a program which allows Iraqi employees of American media companies to apply for refugee status in the United States. Changing circumstances at home and in the U.S. have prompted some to reconsider, although they have long dreamed of escape.
Images of the art and antiques from Yves St. Laurent and Pierre Berge’s collection to be offered up at an auction by Christie’s in Paris.
The players of the week have been selected in the Western and Ontario Hockey Leagues.

Yesterday, the Bagger solicited possible questions that he might crib for carpet duty this Sunday and ended up being hooked up to a firehouse of responses (200 and counting). Apart from the haters, who always punch in when there is a hanging piñata, there were a number of really thoughtful and/or hilarious queries that could end up in play on Sunday.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: President Obama today signed his trillion dollar economic stimulus bill into law. The spending package passed through Congress with almost no Republican support, but Obama says he's still focused on bringing real bipartisanship to government. He even went so far as to send every Republican in Congress today a jar of peanuts, which I thought was nice.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: We have four shows left, including tonight. It's weird, I was thinking about it today. When we went on the air in 1993, I had no way of knowing that 16 years later we'd have an African-American president. Then again, Barack Obama had no way of knowing that an albino would be taking over "The Tonight Show."
After Deadline examines questions of grammar, usage and style encountered by writers and editors of The Times.

The Bloomberg re-election machine has officially rolled out a flashy new Web site with a 32-second video and links the campaign's pages on Facebook, YouTube and Twitter. But for some New Yorkers -- say, an elderly homemaker in Middle Village, Queens, who has just begun exploring the Web -- the site might be a little too flashy.
Update | Feb. 19 Tumblr reversed itself on the shuttered blogs late on Wednesday. See a more recent post on The Lede for later developments in this story.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: A new study says that the bad economy can lower testosterone levels in men. Scientists say at this rate, by the end of the decade, Ann Coulter could be a woman!

Less than a year has passed since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, a pioneering giant of the private equity world, made an alliance with the Environmental Defense Fund. But the unusual partnership is already showing green results, in both the monetary and eco-friendly sense, according to the two partners.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. - Fernando Martinez's locker is located next to Tobi Stoner's, which is next to Adam Bostick's, which is next to Dillon Gee's and Mike Antonini's. They're all situated in the bank reserved for the Mets' top nonroster prospects, with the exception of Bostick.

Where's Osama? Using principles for predicting the distribution of wildlife, geographers at U.C.L.A. have identified what they say is the most logical hiding place for Osama bin Laden: Parachinar, a town in the mountains of Pakistan south of the Khyber Pass. And they've even identified the most likely buildings in town.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: You remember Hillary Clinton? She has been married to Bubba for quite a while. Well, she is now the Secretary of State, and she is on her first big round the world tour. She is on her big Asian tour. She wants to normalize relations with North Korea. No word yet about normalizing relations with Bill.
The YouTubers are calling Madin Mohammed the next Zinedine Zidane. But it may be more accurate to call the 6-year-old Algerian-born youngster from France the latest Rhain Davis.
The Bagger arrives in Los Angeles to cover the Oscars.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Yesterday, of course, Presidents Day. And Congress commemorated George Washington's throwing a dollar across the Potomac by tossing $787 billion down a rat hole.
Hollywood Life suggests that if Kate Winslet wins for what some people think is the wrong movie, she will have plenty of company. (Scroll down a ways to find the item.)
I recently received an email from a Manhattan server that I found interesting and that I wanted to share. It maintains that diners are tipping less during these tough economic times.

A group of Chinatown residents filed a lawsuit against a New York private equity group on Tuesday in Manhattan, under a recently passed law that allows tenants to sue landlords in Housing Court for using threats and other forms of harassment to force them out. The case is one of the first formal exercises of the new protections of the Tenant Protection Act, which the City Council passed overwhelmingly last March.
Shares in MBIA rose on Wednesday after the bond insurer said it would separate its municipal-bond business from its battered mortgage-bond operations.

Aha. My colleagues at Freakonomics are running a contest to provide a new motto for the United States. What this brought to mind was the neglected classic, Culture Made Stupid -- which included, among other things, a proposed corporate redesign for America.

Bill Condon and Laurence Mark sounded exhilarated, if somewhat worn out, when they hopped on the phone with Bagger last night from what they called "the bowels of the Kodak Theater." The Bagger said it sounded as if they were sitting almost precisely where he would be on Sunday night.
As General Motors seeks to retool itself to qualify for more government aid, the company has cited progress in talks with its bondholders. But how much progress has been made? That isn't clear yet.
Writing in the American Lawyer, Aric Press surveys the economic landscape for big law firms, and finds no good news to report:

Martin Wolf channels Richard Koo, whose balance-sheet analysis of Japan's lost decade does indeed provide one of the best road maps to the mess the world as a whole is now in. And Koo's counterintuitive praise for Japan -- while it had a bad decade, it did not have a depression -- is a useful corrective to the constant claims that fiscal policy failed.
Health news from around the Web.
Here. Truly, it's amazing how compelling the logic of temporary nationalization is. How long will it be before the Obama administration is ready to take the plunge?
BearingPoint has reached the breaking point.

Regular readers of the Frugal Traveler may recall my experiments with using GPS. Back in 2007, when I drove cross-country, I hung a Sony GPS-CS1KASP from my rearview mirror; it tracked my progress for 12,000 miles, recording every wrong turn and gas station stop with remarkable accuracy. (Zoom in deep to the cross-country Google map, and you'll see what I mean.)

The White House road show pulls into Phoenix on Wednesday as President Obama gets ready to discuss the details of his plan to help struggling homeowners. The plan will spend up to $75 billion and help up to 9 million Americans stay in their homes, according the summary released Wednesday by the White House.

Be warned. This is a screed, a post I never intended to write, about the reaction in some quarters to a plan by the Obama administration to conduct so-called "comparative effectiveness research" on medical procedures, pharmaceuticals and devices. This research should help us discover those treatments that are costing a bundle, aren't effective, and have inflated health care costs beyond reason. Among other things, these rising costs will doom Medicare if someone doesn't have to courage to say, "No -- just because we know how to do that doesn't mean we should."

In 2003, Sakia Gunn, a 15-year-old lesbian high school student, was fatally stabbed in downtown Newark by a man who had approached her in the street and made sexual advances to her and her friends, which they declined.
Scenes from the photographer Eric Ray Davidson's exclusive fashion week diary.

As resistance to foreclosure evictions grows, a broad civil disobedience campaign is starting in New York and other cities to support families who refuse orders to vacate their homes. Through phone trees, Web pages and text-messaging networks, the effort will connect families facing eviction with volunteers who will stand at their side as officers arrive, even if it means risking arrest.The community organizing group Acorn unveiled the campaign, called Home Defenders, on Friday and will roll it out in at least 22 other cities in the coming weeks. In cities like Orlando, Fla., which has one of the nation's highest foreclosure rates - and Boston; Houston; Baltimore; Oakland, Calif.; and Tucson - Acorn organizers have been creating networks to alert a homeowner's neighbors when an eviction has been scheduled or deputies are on the way. Some volunteers will summon friends and relatives to converge at the home, while others will be in charge of notifying the news media. Organizers are also recruiting lawyers willing to defend for no fee those who are arrested.
