I just heard, from jpkang on Twitter, about a new online-video guitar prodigy. Sungha Jung: Somehow I had missed him. He has all the hallmarks of a YouTube great. He's young. He plays acoustic fingerstyle, which is complex and thus interesting to watch. And he has already inspired cases of mistaken identity. (Read his YouTube channel's program notes for more information.)

The talk of Britain this past weekend was whether or not a 13-year-old boy named Alfie is the father of a one-week-old baby girl. Alfie and Chantelle, the 15-year-old mother, say the baby is his, but two other teenagers have been stepping forward to say that they, too, had sex with the girl around the time that the child was conceived.

Danny Cepero burst on the scene during the 2008 Major League Soccer season when he found himself starting in goal for the New York Red Bulls late in the season. And it was quite a professional debut when the native of Baldwin, N.Y., became the first goalkeeper in league history to score a goal. Cepero went on to backstop the Red Bulls through two rounds of the playoffs before losing to Columbus in M.L.S. Cup '08.

Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, told The Financial Times on Tuesday that short-term nationalization of some United States banks might be the "least bad solution" for the nation's banking crisis.

General Electric's chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, has waived his right to a bonus and $11.7 million in performance-based pay, the company said in a proxy statement filed with regulators on Wednesday.
Timothy Geithner, the Treasury secretary, has pledged that the second bank bailout will be characterized by far greater transparency than the first on the part of the financial institutions.

World | When it comes to measuring human progress, dry macroeconomic measures of growth and trade no longer cut it, an article says. More government statisticians are taking a cue from the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan, which measures Gross National Happiness, figuring "economic growth is not the end in itself but a means to achieve other aims, such as peace, security, greater well-being and happiness." Although you may not be thrilled by its surveys that take half a day to complete. [Financial Times]

Science | Missed amid all the anniversary encomiums to Darwin last week: this article arguing that Victorian values and the "censoring presence" of Darwin's prudish daughter blinded the naturalist to female animals' promiscuity (to insure the fertilization of eggs), thereby delaying the study of sperm competition for 100 years. "Did Darwin not recognize that it takes two to perform an Argentine tango?" [Times Higher Education Supplement]

Many Americans are angry at banks for taking bailout money while still cutting back on lending. But the government is also to blame. For reasons that remain unclear, the Troubled Asset Relief Program has channeled aid to bank holding companies rather than banks.
Ben Muessig, 23, is right out of New York University with a bachelor's degree in journalism. He is a year into his first real job -- as a reporter with the The Brooklyn Paper, a weekly.
In Texas, Robert Allen Stanford was just another wealthy financier.

BG Group has raised its hostile bid for an Australian coal seam gas producer, Pure Energy, to 449 million pounds ($637 million), in a effort to beat out a rival bid from Royal Dutch Shell's Australian partner Arrow Energy.

Ferrovial, the Spanish infrastructure giant, may face fresh calls to dispose of some of the British airports it owns, as its efforts to unload Gatwick airport have run into roadblocks, The Telegraph reported. A report from the British Competition Commission, expected to be published in the next two weeks, is likely to demand the sale of Stansted and either Edinburgh or Glasgow airports, the newspaper said.

Just as office towers appreciated in value faster in Manhattan than elsewhere during the boom years, now their decline is outpacing the rest of the nation, The New York Times's Terry Pristin writes, citing brokers and analysts.

Candover, one of Britain's biggest private equity firms, is preparing to hand back to investors much of the 3 billion euros ($3.8 billion) it raised for its latest buyout fund, The Financial Times reported. The buyout shop may also hold a rights issue and renegotiate its bank debt as it seeks to shore up its finances, the newspaper said.
Société Générale said Wednesday that it expected the market environment to remain challenging throughout 2009, after posting fourth-quarter profits that came in below market expectations.
Teck Cominco of Canada confirmed that is trying to sell an interest in its coal operations to strategic partners in Brazil, China and Japan, to pay off its huge debt load.
Wall Street, Breakingviews says, may have to prepare for another headache: stepped-up antitrust enforcement.
Can renewable energy reduce emissions and save money at the same time?

Stock markets in the Asia-Pacific region on Wednesday continued a slide that began in the United States and Europe Tuesday amid renewed concerns over whether U.S. efforts to shore up the economy would succeed. But the declines in Asia were more muted than elsewhere, with key indexes down by between 0.5 and 2 percent, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.
The next wave of losses for the banking sector could be coming from Eastern Europe.

Credit Suisse, under a widening investigation into foreign banks with offshore private banking services, is working to avert a potential standoff with federal authorities like the one faced by the rival Swiss bank UBS.
Even the billionaire Bill Gates may be feeling the pinch these days.

The billionaire Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway reduced stakes in the health care company Johnson & Johnson and the consumer products company Procter & Gamble, as he found high-yielding investments elsewhere, and suffered big paper losses by holding onto investments in big United States financial companies.
Advanced Micro Devices is feeling cautious ahead of its second try to get shareholder approval for the planned spinoff of its manufacturing business.
Countrywide, Britain's largest real estate agent, got a 75 million pound ($107 million) bailout from a group of creditors including Oaktree Capital Management and Alchemy Partners.
A former Morgan Stanley vice president has been arrested on charges of embezzling more than $2.5 million from the investment bank.
A British lawyer, David Mills, has been sentenced to more than four years in prison for accepting a $600,000 bribe from Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy in 1997.
Insituform Technologies, which repairs sewer, water and other piping systems, raised $127.8 million in a public offering Tuesday to help finance several acquisitions.

Exalt Communications, a company that transmits wireless data through microwave radio systems to relieve congestion on regular networks, announced on Tuesday that it brought in $15 million in third-round funding to expand its "backhauling" systems globally.

Phreesia, maker of electronic tablets to replace those pesky intake clipboards in doctor office waiting rooms, announced Tuesday that it brought in $11.6 million in a round led by BlueCross BlueShield Venture Partners and Sandbox Industries.
Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.
From Jenna Wortham at Bits:
Is a cracked laptop screen worth fixing?
Listings site Properazzi has been reborn as Enormo, which is billed as the world's "largest international real estate search engine."

Chelsea of the English Premier League will come to the United States to play the expansion Seattle Sounders of Major League Soccer in an exhibition game this summer. Chelsea lost to the M.L.S. All-Star team in 2006, and played the Los Angeles Galaxy in 2007. Chelsea has played in Seattle three times, against Scotland’s Celtic in 2004, against the Sounders of the North American Soccer League in 1977, and against an amateur team in 1967.

Florida Marlins Manager Fredi González signed a contract extension through 2011, which was announced shortly before the team’s first full-squad workout. The Marlins were 71-91 in his first season and 84-77 last year. González needs 86 wins to match Jack McKeon’s franchise record of 241.

The Tampa Bay Rays bolstered their infield depth, signing second baseman Adam Kennedy to a minor league contract. Kennedy was released by St. Louis last week, leaving the Cardinals’ starting job up for grabs heading into spring training. He was scheduled to make $4 million this season, but the Rays would have to pay him only the major league minimum $400,000 if he makes the team.

The Minnesota Twins’ Francisco Liriano and the Tampa Bay Rays’ Scott Kazmir said they would not play in the World Baseball Classic. Liriano, who would have played for the Dominican Republic, had a rocky start last season while recovering from Tommy John surgery in his pitching elbow.

The first game of a semifinal match for the world championship was an interesting battle of wills and nerve in which neither Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria nor Gata Kamsky of the United States blinked or backed down. Topalov, the No. 1 ranked player in the world, had White and uncorked a theoretical novelty on move 17 of the Grunfeld Defense, which is known to be one of Kamsky's favorite openings. The move gave Topalov a dangerous initiative, but Kamsky, who is ranked No. 17, responded well, carefully defusing the pressure on his position. Topalov eventually ran out of pieces to send at Kamsky's king and so he forced a sequence of moves that led to a perpetual check and a draw.

Now that Michael Jackson is holding a fire sale of his personal memorabilia, that makes two high-profile collections coming under the hammer this season. On Feb. 23 to 25, the auction of Yves St. Laurent's Mondrians and Limoges, collected with Pierre Bergé, is set to become the highest grossing private sale in history. Come April, Jacko will be offering up some really cool rhinestone tube socks. Here, a vernissage of comparable items from both auctions (St. Laurent on the left; Jackson on the right).

A total of 120 golfers would compete in four-round stroke-play competitions under a proposal to add golf to the 2016 Olympics. The International Golf Federation submitted its plan to the International Olympic Committee on Feb. 15. Under the plan, the top 60 men’s and women’s golfers, based on the official world rankings, would participate. The top 15 players would automatically be eligible. A maximum of two players from each country that did not already have two or more among the top 15 would also be eligible. (The United States has five men’s players ranked in the top 15, including No. 1 Tiger Woods and No. 5 Phil Mickelson.) A three-hole playoff would break any ties for the gold, silver and bronze medals. As part of its bid, the golf federation said the sport’s leading organizations would adjust their schedules to avoid conflicts during the Games.

Reliever Eric Gagné and the Milwaukee Brewers agreed to a minor league contract that included an invitation to spring training. Gagné would receive $1.5 million if he is added to the major league roster, and he can earn an additional $3 million in bonuses.

Running back Deuce McAllister was released by the New Orleans Saints, the only N.F.L. team he has played for. McAllister, the Saints’ career rushing leader with 6,069 yards, was due more than $7 million next season — part of an eight-year contract for more than $50 million that he signed in 2005, before the first of his two reconstructive knee operations. McAllister played a limited role last season with 107 carries for 418 yards.
After record earnings, Wal-Mart Stores resolved to hang on to its new customers and widen its influence on national issues like the environment and health care.
After an Off Broadway run in 2008 and some retooling at a production in Washington, the musical “Next to Normal” is returning to New York — this time to Broadway.
G.M. once ruled the American car market, but is now cutting its brands in half.
Quick thought: Does spending a little more for Derrick Ward seem like a lot when Ahmad Bradshaw goes to jail every off-season?
The final piece of Shea Stadium was torn down Feb. 18, two months before the Mets open their new ballpark, Citi Field.
My maternal grandmother tooled happily around town for nearly 30 years in her 1939 Pontiac Deluxe Eight. I loved that big old sedan, with its 100-horsepower straight-8 engine.

An article last Wednesday about the use of 25-year-old frozen sperm in the breeding of Yes, the black standard poodle who won the nonsporting group at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, may have left an incorrect impression about one laboratory’s role in the dog’s development. As the article correctly mentioned, sperm from Yes’s father, Snapper, was collected and preserved by the International Canine Semen Bank in Oregon. After publication, Canine Cryobank in California, another laboratory that had also preserved some of Snapper’s sperm, pointed out that it was that sperm that produced Yes.
Mr. Cuba became known as the father of Latin boogaloo because of a string of innovative hits in the 1960s and ’70s that fused Latin and soul elements.

Ms. Svetlova played an important role in American dance education after a wide-ranging performing career in international ballet from the 1930s to the 1960s.
Wesley Matthews scored 24 points and No. 10 Marquette opened the second half with a decisive run to pull away from Seton Hall.
Mr. Blank introduced the concept of using logolike images behind anchors as signatures for major news coverage.

The nave of the Grand Palais will soon play host to what Christie's is calling the first auction in the history of the famed site. The collection being auctioned is fittingly famous: that of Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergé, who shared a relationship that Guy Trebay, writing in The New York Times Magazine, called "emotionally baroque but enduring."
Among today's headlines:
In Wyoming, environmentalists are challenging a century-old program of feeding the elk, saying it harms them and other animals.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
In the sober aftermath of their previous losses to the Lakers, the Cavaliers and the Celtics, the Knicks regrouped after the All-Star break and beat the Spurs.
Yao Ming had 20 points and 12 rebounds and Shane Battier scored a season-high 19 points as the Houston Rockets beat the Nets.
The departments charged with executing one of the largest spending projects in American history are operating largely with career stand-ins without the authority of political appointees.
A former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who subsequently joined the Yemeni branch of Al Qaeda returned to Saudi Arabia and was in the custody of the authorities.
An impasse that held up Kansas income tax refunds and threatened to delay state employees’ next paychecks ended when Gov. Kathleen Sebelius signed a budget-balancing bill.
NATO warned that a truce between the Pakistani government and Taliban militants in a restive region near the Afghan border risked giving the extremists a “safe haven.”
Parliament’s lower house voted to extend benefits for those who take time off from work to care for dying relatives at their homes.
Arenda Troutman, who admitted taking payoffs from developers and hiding money from the Internal Revenue Service, was sentenced to four years in prison.
President Álvaro Colom of Guatemala apologized to Cuba on Tuesday for his country’s role in the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961.
A senior Supreme Court judge whose son has been charged with accepting a bribe of almost $30,000 resigned, a court spokesman said.
In Egypt, there is relative freedom to criticize the government, but not to act against it.
A man accused of plotting with a teenager to carry out an attack on an Indiana school pleaded guilty to a lesser charge.
The Justice Department is assigning the corruption case of former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska to a different legal team to handle accusations of prosecutorial misconduct.
The prisoners, who had been arrested in Afghanistan, were sent to Iraq more than a month ago, according to a senior American defense official.
Tomas Vokoun stopped 36 shots for his fifth shutout of the season, and the Florida Panthers snapped the Devils’ seven-game road winning streak.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine proposed a two-day furlough for state workers to help close a widening budget gap and threatened layoffs if their unions do not agree to wage freezes starting in the summer.
A second soldier, Pvt. Randy Stabnick, stationed at Fort Leonard Wood has died of meningitis.
A man who founded a Muslim American television station to help fight Muslim stereotypes will face charges that he decapitated his wife last week.
The Environmental Protection Agency inched closer to the possible regulation of emissions of heat-trapping gases from coal-fired power plants.
Despite there being no ban on subway photography, people taking pictures in the subways are regularly stopped by the police and sometimes arrested.
It remains unclear when Rodriguez stopped using steroids, because his failed test came during the 2003 testing.
Dr. Yang was a reproductive biologist who did early work on the cloning of farm animals and helped establish the safety of meat and milk produced by cloned cattle.
Alaska is fast becoming an experiment in oil-state support for renewable energy.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Beverly Eckert, an advocate for the families of 9/11 victims who died in Thursday’s plane crash near Buffalo, misattributed the confirmation of her death. It came from friends of Ms. Eckert as well as a presidential statement, not from the National Transportation Safety Board. The obituary, using information from a relative, also misidentified the college from which she graduated and misstated the year she received her degree. Ms. Eckert graduated from Buffalo State College, not the State University of New York at Buffalo, and received her degree in 1975, not 1974.

Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the appearance of President Obama in coming issues of two comic books, Savage Dragon and Youngblood, misidentified the publisher of those titles. It is Image Comics, not Marvel.

An article on Saturday about Jodie Meeks, a star basketball player at Kentucky who is among the nation’s top scorers, referred incorrectly to the university’s recent development of similarly talented players who went on to become first-round N.B.A. draft picks. Two Kentucky players — Tayshaun Prince in 2002 and Rajon Rondo in 2006 — have been drafted in the first round since Jamaal Magloire’s selection in 2000; the program has not failed to produce any first-round picks in that time. The article also misstated the surname of Kentucky’s head coach. He is Billy Gillispie, not Gillespie.

An article on Saturday about financial difficulties that are facing so-called destination clubs, whose members share access to luxury residences in prime resort areas, misidentified the state in which Kiawah Island, one such area, is located. It is in South Carolina, not Georgia.

A headline on Saturday with an article about PepsiCo’s fourth-quarter earnings misstated the company’s results. As the article correctly reported, Pepsi’s profit fell 43 percent; it did not suffer a 43 percent loss.
At 17, Japanese golfer Ryo Ishikawa looks right at home on the big stage.

A report by The Associated Press in the National Briefing column on Thursday about the conversion of a stern-wheel steamboat to a floating hotel on the Tennessee River misidentified the group that classified the boat as a registered historic treasure. It is the National Register of Historic Places, not the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

An article on Friday about the N.A.A.C.P.’s centennial omitted four of the group’s founders. Besides W.E.B. DuBois and Ida Wells-Barnett, the N.A.A.C.P. includes Henry Moscowitz, Mary White Ovington, Oswald G. Villiard and William E. Walling among the original founders.

An article on Feb. 7 about an Italian man who was detained by bewildered Iraqi police after they found him wandering around Falluja as a tourist, without guards or a translator, rendered part of an Italian phrase incorrectly. It is bel viaggio (nice trip), not bella viaggio.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the passengers killed when Continental Connection Flight 3407 crashed into a house near Buffalo misidentified, in some editions, the alma mater of one passenger, Maddy Loftus, who was headed to a reunion of her women’s ice hockey team. (The error also appeared in a picture caption in some editions.) Ms. Loftus was a former student at Buffalo State College, not SUNY Buffalo or Buffalo State University.
FRONT PAGE.
The recession has quickly transformed the attitude of the Madison Avenue work force from impenetrable to inviting, seemingly overnight.
People in their 20s who lack insurance may try everything from self-diagnoses to borrowing medications.
Just after 3 a.m. Tuesday, the police went to investigate a report of an armed robbery in a Midtown subway station. But they happened upon another crime in progress.
The judge presiding over Barry Bonds’s perjury case said on Tuesday that she would like Greg Anderson, Bonds’s former trainer, to appear in court.
Andy Pettitte met with federal prosecutors who are determining whether to indict Roger Clemens on perjury charges, according to a person familiar with the investigation.
A key to understanding the housing bailout is that two very different groups of homeowners face foreclosure.
While a drastic reduction in military spending is unlikely, several high-dollar, high-tech weapons systems will be under the most scrutiny.
The Oklahoma City Thunder have acquired Tyson Chandler from New Orleans in a deal that sends the veterans Joe Smith and Chris Wilcox to the Hornets.
Maybe Alex Rodriguez’s venture into the wonderful world of performance-enhancing drugs could help save a few young people.

A provision in President Obama’s stimulus package, extending food stamp benefits for able-bodied adults, has revived a dispute in New York City between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and advocates for the poor.
The scope and reach that the Obama administration will have in the nation’s auto industry is unprecedented.

One of the great mysteries of the Bush presidency is whether W. ever had an epiphany when he realized that he had been manipulated by Dick Cheney, and if it ever hit him that he trusted the wrong father figure.
Leaders of both parties readied for a battle over who was responsible for the economy’s problems and whether the $787 billion stimulus legislation was the solution.
Giants running back Ahmad Bradshaw is serving the final portion of a 60-day jail sentence in Tazewell County, Va., his lawyer said Tuesday.
Floyd Landis, the defrocked 2006 Tour de France champion, is at his first professional road race since he wore the yellow jersey.
According to the panel, New York City must prepare for higher temperatures, more rain and an increased risk of coastal flooding in the coming decades.
General Motors’ expansive lineup was once its primary weapon, but it plans to cut four brands.
The defiance of Islamist terrorists by Indian Muslims stands out against a dismal landscape of Sunni Muslim suicide murderers who have been treated by Arab media as “martyrs.”

A high school in Newport Beach, Calif., has become the latest to cancel a student production of “Rent,” though the reasons for its cancellation remain murky, The Orange County Register reported. Corona del Mar High School was scheduled to perform the school edition of “Rent,” an edited version of the Jonathan Larson musical about downtown Manhattanites living with the specter of AIDS, on April 23. Ronald K. Martin, the school’s drama instructor, said the production was canceled by the principal, Fal Asrani, who objected to its gay characters. Ms. Asrani told The Register that Mr. Martin stopped the show because there was not enough time to revise the script. Mr. Martin said that was not true, adding that scripts for the play had not yet been ordered. In December Rowlett High School in Rowlett, Tex., canceled its planned production of “Rent” after parents and community members objected to the content of the show, though its cast members performed a version of the show at nearby Southern Methodist University.
After serving for seven months as executive director of the Pasadena Museum of California Art, Christopher Mount has been replaced, The Los Angeles Times reported.

For some viewers the idea of another Jane Austen-inspired period drama is sufficiently monstrous, but a coming film project seeks to update the formula with actual monsters, Variety reported. The movie “Pride and Predator,” directed by Will Clark and written by Mr. Clark with Andrew Kemble and John Pape, will juxtapose brooding aristocrats with a brutal alien that lands in 1800s-era Britain, attacking residents and leaving them with neither sense nor sensibility. The film, to be produced by Elton John’s Rocket Pictures, is the latest work to mix the hoary costume genre with elements of horror. A book called “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies,” credited to Jane Austen and Seth Grahame-Smith and published by Quirk Books, will combine the Austen novel with “all-new scenes of bone-crunching zombie action.” And a coming novel by Michael Thomas Ford called “Jane Bites Back” depicts Austen as a frustrated vampire, taking revenge on those who have made money from her work.

Daptone Records, the Brooklyn soul label that releases albums by Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings and the Budos Band among others, was burglarized over the Presidents’ Day weekend, the label’s co-founder, Gabriel Roth, said in an e-mail message reported on BrooklynVegan.com. Mr. Roth wrote that numerous items had been stolen or damaged, including computers, turntables, amplifiers, guitars and other instruments. In an interview, the other founder, Neal Sugarman, said workers were still cleaning up the label’s office, in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, and assessing what was taken, adding, “It’s hard to tell whether they knew what they wanted to get or not.” He said that police were investigating and that the label would remain closed for several days, though it hoped to reopen by Friday for a planned recording session for Rod Stewart.

Not quite 10 years after they ended, the 1990s are back: the bands Nine Inch Nails and Jane’s Addiction, whose clothing, attitudes and, by the way, music helped define the decade, plan to tour together later this year, Billboard reported. On the Nine Inch Nails Web site nin.com, the group’s frontman, Trent Reznor, top, wrote that the musicians “decided to book a last run of shows across the globe this year.” (“Will it resonate in the marketplace?” he added. “Who knows. Are there big record label marketing dollars to convince you to attend? Nope.”) The bands performed together in the early years of Lollapalooza, the 1990s concert series, leading to a joint tour on which Jane’s Addiction, with Perry Farrell, above, broke up. (The band reunited in 1997, broke up again and then re-reunited in 2001.) No dates were announced for the 2009 tour.

Faith Prince, a Tony Award winner for the 1992 Broadway revival of “Guys and Dolls,” will join “The Little Mermaid” as Ursula the sea witch, Disney Theatrical Productions said in a release. Ms. Prince, who starred in “A Catered Affair” on Broadway last season, will begin performances on April 7. The role, originated by Sherie Rene Scott, has been played by Heidi Blickenstaff (“[title of show]”) since Jan. 27. ... Roundabout Theater Company has announced dates for its production of “After Miss Julie,” the Patrick Marber play that will star Sienna Miller in her Broadway debut. The drama, which will be at the American Airlines Theater, begins previews on Sept. 18 and opens on Oct. 22. Its limited run is scheduled through Dec. 6. ... Ballet British Columbia, the Vancouver dance company, has appointed Andrew Wilhelm-Boyles its interim executive director, the company announced in a release. The troupe, which canceled productions and fired its staff last year amid economic woes, was able to rehire its dancers and its artistic director, John Alleyne, after creditors approved a repayment plan in January. Mr. Wilhelm-Boyles, former executive director of the Greater Vancouver Alliance for Arts and Culture, is expected to remain with the troupe through the end of its 2008-9 season. ...The comedian Judy Gold and the reality-television star Carson Kressley have been named the hosts of “Defying Inequality: The Broadway Concert, a Celebrity Benefit for Equal Rights,” a one-night benefit for groups promoting gay rights and gay marriage. New additions to the lineup include Cyndi Lauper and Al Sharpton. The event is scheduled for Monday at the Gershwin Theater in New York.

Officials have said that the toll will continue to rise as more bodies are recovered in the areas hardest hit by the fires.

NORDLINGER--Lewis Emil, 89, passed away on February 13, 2009. He was the beloved husband of the late Joyce Marilyn. He was President for more than 50 years of Steinhardter & Nordlinger Inc., food brokers, and a longstanding director and former President of the Association of Food Industries. He was a leader of his community, having served as President and treasurer of the Five Towns, Long Island, chapter of B'nai B'rith and a committee member of the Five Towns chapter of the Democratic Party, among many other community volunteer activities. He is survived by his loving children, Alice and Douglas, his loving daughter-in-law, Margaret, and son-in-law, Isaac, and grandchildren Leigh, Rachel, Jessie, Danny, and David.

Hearth Restaurant recently held a dinner featuring modestly priced Burgundy wines. Among the dishes paired with them were sautéed sweetbreads served on scrambled eggs seasoned with black truffles. Sweetbreads are a superb choice with red Burgundies. I wanted to pick up the cherry flavors that showed up in the Côte Chalonnaise wines we tasted, so I skipped the eggs and instead added dried cherries.

Giants running back Ahmad Bradshaw is serving the final portion of a 60-day jail sentence in Tazewell County, Va., his lawyer, Charles Stacy, said Tuesday. Bradshaw's stay of about one month was arranged last year when Bradshaw served the first half of the sentence for a violation of probation from Juvenile Court for a past offense.

GRAHAM--Walton, passed away in his sleep at the age of 84 after a prolonged struggle with Parkinson's disease. Quiet and sheltering like the old growth trees he loved, Walton was a gifted talker who preferred to listen, a lover of people, not things, who coveted only firelight, a view of the woods and water in the company of family and friends. A man of principle rather than creed, Walton lived an exemplary life dedicated to an ever widening circle of family and to the pursuit of his core values: integrity, modesty, simplicity, and fairness. Ambitious and accomplished in his youth, in middle age Walton retired from a career as an aviation safety analyst and engineer to pursue a wide variety of cultural interests with his new bride Joan at his side. Walton loved his wife's children, Amy, Douglas, and Ellen, like his own, Derek and Wendy. He was a father to his niece Lorna and a devoted grandfather to Emily, Jordan, Jackson, Graham, Ava, Julia, Kate, and Sun. While all of us mourn the loss of this beautiful spirit, Walton's death divides asunder a loving couple. Now, I understand the meaning of the verses he taught me as a child: "To me the meanest flower that blows can give thoughts that do often lie too deep for tears." Services will be held at the Noland Taylor-Howe Funeral Home at 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport NY, at 2pm on Saturday, February 21, 2009.

GLASSMAN--Daniel, on February 17, 2009. Beloved husband of Iris; loving children Stacey, Heath and Bradley; cherished grandchildren Lexi, Morgan, Mackenze, Sadie, Lulu and Luke; honored sister Leila and Diane. Services Thursday, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

SPIEGEL--Emily Joy, 80, of Kings Point, New York, passed away on February 16, 2009. Our extraordinary mother lived every moment of her life to the fullest. Charming, graceful and beautiful in every way, her boundless energy and spirit touched everyone she knew. Her passion for the simple wonders of life, art and music enriched us all. She shared a profound and special love with our father. Her selfless devotion to him and to our family will forever remain in our hearts and minds and will serve as an inspiration. We, her children and grandchildren, will miss her deeply, and we will live our lives with her love, kindness and generosity as our guiding spirit. She is survived by husband Jerry Spiegel, daughters Pamela Sanders and Lise Wilks, sons-in-law Arthur Sanders and Jeffrey Wilks, grandchildren Jordan, Remy, Erin, David, Andrew and Jack. Services will be held on Wednesday, February 18, 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at West 76th Street. The family will be sitting shiva from Wednesday, 5:30 to 9:00pm, Thursday 2:00 to 8:00pm and Friday from 2:00 to 5:00pm at the home of Jerry Spiegel. Donations in her memory may be made to: Parkinsons Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, New York, 10018.

9 P.M. (13, 49) JEROME ROBBINS: SOMETHING TO DANCE ABOUT Robbins, left, redefined dance and musical theater through his choreography for Broadway shows like ''West Side Story,'' ''Gypsy'' and ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and his works for American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet. But he was also contradictory and controversial, noted for unforgiving perfectionism and haunted by his decision in 1953 to name names in his testimony before the House Un-American Activities Committee. This ''American Masters'' documentary features excerpts from Robbins's work and rare rehearsal footage, as well as interviews with his colleagues Mikhail Baryshnikov, Jacques d'Amboise, Suzanne Farrell, Arthur Laurents, Peter Martins, Chita Rivera, Stephen Sondheim, Jerry Bock, Sheldon Harnick and Joseph Stein. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYSteve Harvey discusses his new book, ''Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man.'' In another segment, real-life shopaholics confess.

NICHOLAS--Robert Bates, 79, of Vero Beach, FL and Edgartown, MA on February 13, 2009. Robert retired as a Senior Vice President from Aetna Life & Casualty 1988. His career spanned executive positions with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Mobil Oil and Atlantic Richfield. He served on the boards of MBIA Inc., Hartford Graduate Center, Hartford Dispensary and Hartford Stage Company in Connecticut. He was a member of the Denison University Board of Trustees serving as Vice-Chairman of the Finance & Audit Committee and Chairman of the Annual Fund Campaign. He was also a member of the US Chamber of Commerce Council on Trends and Perspectives. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 21, 2009 at Faith Community Church in Edgartown, MA at 11:00am.

A total of 120 golfers would compete in four-round stroke-play competitions under a proposal to add golf to the 2016 Olympics. The International Golf Federation submitted its plan to the International Olympic Committee on Sunday. Under the plan, the top 60 men's and women's golfers, based on the official world rankings, would participate. The top 15 players would automatically be eligible. A maximum of two players from each country that did not already have two or more among the top 15 would also be eligible. (The United States has five men's players ranked in the top 15, including No. 1 Tiger Woods and No. 5 Phil Mickelson.) A three-hole playoff would break any ties for the gold, silver and bronze medals.

TOOKER Audrey, a lady of fierce determination and extraordinary passions, passed away on January 29 in New York City at age 81. A descendant of the earliest Dutch settlers of Staten Island, her ancestors included Evert Bancker, Mayor of Albany (1694 to 1695/1707 to 1709), and the famous Colonial silversmith Adrian Bancker, Audrey was born on November 27, 1927 in Mineola, LI, New York to Jean (nee Monahan) and Adrian Bancker. She was raised in an old farm house in Plandome, New York and eduacted at a number of girls' boarding schools and Finch College. She lived for many years in Locust Valley, NY while married to Bill Tooker, an entertaining cross between Cary Grant and Jackie Gleason. Upon the dissolution of her first marriage, Audrey moved to Aspen, Colorado where she met and married Jim Snobble, Vice President of the Aspen Ski Corporation and first Mountain Manager of Snowmass Ski Area. Together they camped and skied in beautiful off the grid locations in Canada and Alaska. At the conclusion of that relationship, Audrey became a "Roads Scholar," moving to Whitefish, MT; Dorset, and Burlington, VT; Cold Spring, NY and eventually Boulder, Colorado. She loved a good argument and a great ski run in that order. She is survived by her daughters Tracey, Holly, Paige and Robin, all of New York metropolitan area, and her sister Patricia Duane of Boynton Beach, FL.

MONCURE--Margot Graham, 62, of Bedford, NY, and Wayland, MA died Sunday, February 15, 2009 at her home. Margot was a noted equestrian and Women's Golf Champion of the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club. A Memorial service will be held Saturday, February 21, at 11:00am at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

SPIEGEL--Emily. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art deeply mourn the loss of Honorary Trustee Emily Spiegel. A longtime and beloved friend of the Museum, Emily was an avid art collector and patron of the arts, as well as a generous friend to artists, curators, and collectors. At MoMA she provided important support to the capital campaign, painting and sculpture collection, and to many other areas of the Museum. She was wonderfully caring and truly committed to the arts, and she will be missed deeply. We extend our most heartfelt sympathies to her husband, Jerry Spiegel, and to her daughters Pam Sanders and Lise Wilkes and their families. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

Lori Siegel did not even wait for her hair to grow back. Still feeling the effects of radiation treatments, she sent her résumé to potential employers, bought a new suit and a wig that does not look like a wig, and started going on job interviews. But so far there have been no offers, and she is convinced that the nine-month gap in her work history gives her away. ''It's like I'm hiding something awful because I got sick,'' said Ms. Siegel, 51, who lives on Long Island and is recovering from breast cancer. ''I don't want to bring it up, but I don't want to lie.''

A small Web site operator filed an antitrust suit against Google on Tuesday, accusing it of unfairly manipulating its advertising system to harm a potential competitor. TradeComet.com, which operates a site called SourceTool.com, a vertical search engine for those seeking business products and services, accused Google of raising the advertising rates it charged the company after it realized that SourceTool was a potential competitor.

The Spiegel family's thoughtful philanthropy has focused on support of brain stem cell replacement therapy, launched through the establishment of the Jerry and Emily Spiegel Laboratory. SAND--Edward A. Former Chairman and CEO of Parents Magazine Enterprises died on Friday, February 13. He was 97 and lived in Sarasota, Florida. The cause of death was complications from a fall in his home. Mr. Sand joined Parents Magazine in 1944 and along with the publication's founder George J. Hecht, built the company into a multi-faceted media and retail operation which included five adult and children's magazines; a children's book business; the FAO Schwartz toy stores; Baker and Taylor, the worlds largest book distributor; and Family Publication Service, which was co-owned with Time Inc. The company remained privately held until Mr. Sand negotiated its sale to the W R Grace Company and to the German publisher Bertelsmann in the late 1970's. After graduating New York University Mr. Sand launched The Literary Workshop where he edited and published the stories of prominent young writers including H. L. Mencken, Sherwood Andersen and Erskine Caldwell. After The Literary Workshop had to be discontinued because of lack of advertising, Mr. Sand worked briefly as a newspaper reporter and a magazine circulation director. After retiring from Parents in 1979, Mr. Sand was a frequent contributor to the Sarasota Tribune where he wrote a periodic column on family issues and to the Longboat Key Observer. He was an active collector of American art and a contributor to numerous charitable causes. Mr. Sand is survived by his son Thomas Sand, daughter-in-law Mary L. Sand and granddaughter Jennifer Robin Sand.

SPIEGEL Emily. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of Emily, wife of our esteemed member, Jerry, and extend our heartfelt sympathy to their family. Board of Governors Stuart B. Wilkins, President

The Spiegels, dear friends and longtime supporters of UJA-Federation, are inspirational leaders in the New York community, devoted to social and humanitarian causes. Emily's commitment to UJA-Federation lives on through her generous Lion of Judah Endowment, which provides support to the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our deepest condolences to Jerry; to their children, Pamela and Arthur Sanders and Lise and Jeffrey Wilks; to their grandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

HAUGH--Sharon L. A trailblazer among women at top ranks of the investment management industry, died Tuesday, February 10th after a long and valliant struggle with illness. Born and raised in the San Fernando Valley area of Los Angeles, California, Sharon attended the University of Arizona before moving to New York in 1968. From 1995-2002, she was the Chairman of Schroder Investment Management North America. In her twenty year career with the firm, Ms. Haugh led Schroders to a preeminent position in the United States. Under her leadership, Schroders was consistently ranked as one of the top international money managers in the country. In 2002, she was the first woman honored by the Association of Investment Management Sales Executives ("AIMSE") with the Richard A. Lothrop Award in recognition of both her outstanding contributions to the industry, as well as her involvement in community affairs and charitable endeavors. Prior to joining Schroders in 1982, Ms. Haugh held positions with New Court Securities (Rothschild, Inc.) and Soros Fund Management. Her last executive position in the industry was as Chief Executive at Pequot Capital Management. She is a past President of AIMSE, and has served on the Board of the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, American Ballet Theatre, and Met Life Investors. Sharon will be remembered for her passion for living life to the fullest, her intelligence, her wit, and her generosity towards those she loved. She loved, and was beloved by, many friends in Anguilla, BWI, where she visited regularly for over twenty years. She will be sorely missed and mourned by her beloved daughter Alexis Stein, her sister, brother and family, and her many, many friends. A small private service was held on Friday, February 13, 2009. In Lieu of flowers, donations in her memory should be made to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 14 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10122, Attn: Sherry Jacobson or online at www.ocrf.org

A leader of the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, appeared before a magistrate in Mutare on Tuesday for a preliminary hearing on charges that he had sought to leave the country illegally and had conspired to buy arms to commit acts of sabotage against the state. The leader, Roy Bennett, the party's nominee for deputy agriculture minister, has denied the charges and called them political. The magistrate is expected to decide on Wednesday whether Mr. Bennett should be tried.

FAIRCHILD--Robert F. of New York and Quogue died suddenly on February 16th, after enjoying a wonderful weekend fishing on his boat, The Grand Cru. Beloved father of Stephanie and Roger Griswold, Suzie and Bruce Kovner, Samantha and Chris Storkerson, Serena and Tyler Sheldon; cherished grandfather of Caroline, Olivia, Liam, Oscar, Roger, and Margaux. Born and raised in New York City, Bob graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and went to work for the family's firm, Fairchild Publications. Bob joined The House of Burgundy in 1971, and is the President and Chief Executive Officer. In May of 1994, he founded the Maison des Grands Crus, in Santenay, France. On July 16, 1987 in recognition of his efforts on behalf of French wines, Bob was made a Chevalier of the Ordre du Merite Agicole, by the French Parliament. Bob is a member of the Board of Overseers of the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, and the Board of Trustees of the Avon Old Farms School. A former member of the Board of Governors of the Union League Club of New York, he also belongs to the Leash Club of New York, Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach, Quogue Field Club and Quogue Beach Club and the Long Island Wyandanch Club. Family will receive friends on Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service will be held on Saturday at 10:30am at St. Thomas More, 89th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues). In lie of flowers, please make donations to The University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine of Avon Old Farms School.

Even at an awards ceremony where Robert Plant and Alison Krauss weren’t nominated for anything, Coldplay was nonetheless shut out at the Brit Awards, England’s equivalent of the Grammys, as Duffy won nearly everything but the catering cart, Reuters reported. Coldplay, which was nominated for four awards, including best British group and British live act, won no awards, while Duffy, the Welsh soul singer of “Mercy” fame, won awards for British female and British breakthrough act, as well as British album for her solo debut “Rockferry.” The heavy-metal band Iron Maiden was the surprise winner of in the British group category, while Kings of Leon won for international act and international album (for “Only by the Night”); Katy Perry won international female artist and Kanye West won in the international male category.

Though the life of Tupac Shakur has spawned at least a dozen documentaries, a planned biographical film about the rapper, who was killed in 1996, has been bogged down by a legal dispute, The Hollywood Reporter said. The production company Morgan Creek has filed suit against Amaru Entertainment, the company run by Mr. Shakur’s mother, Afeni, saying it reneged on an agreement to sell the hip-hop performer’s life rights for a movie. Morgan Creek’s complaint said a written contract was in place, according to The Hollywood Reporter, but a lawyer for Amaru Entertainment said, “There is no agreement with Morgan Creek, there never was, and there never will be.” Relations between the two companies were said to have broken down last month around the time of release of “Notorious,” the biographical movie about a rival rapper, Notorious B.I.G.

Actors’ Equity on Feb. 26 will hold a hearing on the grievance filed against the actor Jeremy Piven by the producers of the Broadway play “Speed-the-Plow,” which Mr. Piven quit suddenly in December because of what his doctor said was mercury poisoning. Both sides are expected to present their cases at the hearing, which is closed to the public. It is not clear if Mr. Piven will attend; his representatives have not responded to phone or e-mail messages seeking comment. A spokeswoman for Mr. Piven has previously called the grievance “absurd and outrageous.” A spokeswoman for Actors’ Equity said that its grievance committee could resolve the complaint that day or hold more meetings. The two sides could also pursue arbitration. The production is scheduled to end its limited run on Sunday.

Three weeks after the death of John Updike, the publisher HarperCollins said in a release that it had acquired a biography of the Pulitzer Prize- and National Book Award-winning author to be written by Adam Begley, the books editor of The New York Observer. In an interview, Mr. Begley said he had twice profiled Mr. Updike, for Mirabella magazine in the 1990s and for The Observer in 2003. “He was the world’s smoothest interview,” Mr. Begley said. “Almost every word out of his mouth was quotable.” Additionally, Mr. Begley said, his father, the novelist Louis Begley, and Mr. Updike had been classmates at Harvard University, where they both received degrees in English literature. Adam Begley said that although he had written a letter of condolence to Mr. Updike’s widow, Martha, it was “too soon” to ask her about access to the author’s papers at Harvard’s Houghton Library. The biography is expected to be published in 2011.

The economy may be in the dumps, but the Great White Way continues to thrive. Broadway will host a slew of new openings, ranging from intimate plays to splashy revivals, many with celebrities (Jane Fonda, Susan Sarandon, Jeremy Irons, James Gandolfini) along for the ride.

It may be tempting to imagine that Kathleen Turner is now wearing a knee brace and walking with a cane because of a backstage catfight with Charles Busch, the playwright, actor and fellow diva with whom Ms. Turner is starring in “The Third Story.” But Ms. Turner, who suffers from rheumatoid arthritis, injured her knee while offstage at Tuesday night’s performance of the play, leading to the cancellation of shows Wednesday, tonight and Friday. (The production does not have understudies.) It initially looked as if Ms. Turner might not be able to return, a senior member of the production’s management team said in an interview, and Mr. Busch – who already plays three characters in the play – had begun preparing to take over Ms. Turner’s lead role as well. But Ms. Turner plans to return, with a knee brace and cane, at the Saturday matinee, a spokeswoman for the production said. The show, at the Lucille Lortel Theater, is scheduled to run through March 15.

The 2009 race for the Tony Awards has a late entry: The Goodman Theater’s production of Eugene O’Neill’s “Desire Under the Elms,” starring Brian Dennehy and Carla Gugino, will be transferring from Chicago to the St. James Theater. Previews are scheduled to start April 14, with opening night set for April 27. The cut-off date for Tony eligibility is April 30. The lead producer, Jeffrey Richards – who also has “Hair,” “Reasons to Be Pretty,” “Blithe Spirit,” and Will Ferrell’s one-man show on his plate right now – said it would be a limited 13-week engagement with a budget of $1.9 million. Robert Falls, the director, said that Ms. Gugino – who recently left the Goodman production to promote film projects – would return for the Broadway run.

Will Ferrell‘s current Broadway play, “You’re Welcome America. A Final Night With George W Bush,” has recouped its original investment of $2.09 million, one of the show’s producers, Jeffrey Richards, said Thursday.

I set off on foot this morning for the Times at my usual predawn hour to make the donuts. The pavement was wet, the air strangely warm, and the lights in Times Square were cranking away like a Broadway hoofer. It all feels right at that hour. The models for Vera Wang's show would be just arriving for hair and makeup; her show was at 9 a.m. on Mercer Street in SoHo. I picked up a coffee and went up to the office and got the review going. I was thinking about how serious and mature designers are acting nowadays-and how many great designers were crazy as loons and full of passion. For a decade we've talked proudly of branding and luxury groups. But fashion is not really a business; some of the greats have made very little money or been total failures. Maybe the more sober business climate will put more emphasis on creativity. But that could be wishful thinking.
The documentary “Must Read After My Death” raises unsettling questions about the erosion of the private sphere.

I got off to a good start on today's crossword by Paula Gamache. As it happens, I've seen Twelfth Night a couple of times recently so I knew Viola disguised herself AS A MAN. In my youth, I adored The Daughter of Time by Josephine TEY. (The bed-ridden protagonist tries to solve the age-old mystery of whether Richard III murdered the princes in the tower.) "Slowing in music" is either RALL or RIT, and only one of those fit. "Hyphenated IDs" are SSNS. And we're off.

My beekeeping mentor Gary used to warn about ramping up a bee hive too soon in the season. By feeding a hive too much too soon, a beekeeper runs the risk of sending a message that food is plentiful. In response, the queen may begin building the hive at a rate that cannot be sustained by bottles of sugar water.

The Bagger is locking down his picks for Friday's print issue of the House of Many Doors, so he knows it is put-up-or-shut-up time, but Time magazine is making a bigger bet than most. The new issue of the magazine puts Kate Winslet on the cover. The cover line (just above her right ear) simply says, "Best Actress." A little lower down, in much smaller type, it adds, "Why It's Kate Winslet." Mark Harris, the author of "Pictures at a Revolution: Five Movies and the Birth of the New Hollywood," as well as a welcome contributor to Arts & Leisure, wrote the article. Hanging out with her, Mr. Harris experienced something the Bagger has noticed as well, namely her unflagging energy and good spirits in the marathon that is Oscar campaigning. And like the Bagger, Mr. Harris is a fan of Mrs. Sam Mendes.

The owners of three gas stations, two in Queens and one in the Bronx, have agreed to pay a $325,000 civil penalty to settle federal claims that they failed to properly handle a total of 27 underground storage tanks, which typically contain large quantities of gasoline and waste oil and can cause serious damage to soil and groundwater if allowed to leak.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation found the Texas financier Robert Allen Stanford in Virginia on Thursday and served him with civil legal papers from the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Among writers of a certain renown, it's more common than you might think to pretend their early careers never existed - Tobias Wolff and Michael Cunningham routinely omit their first novels from lists of previously published works, like suitors too embarrassed to mention a failed marriage, and they're far from the only ones. So it's not surprising to learn that John Cheever disowned much of his first story collection, "The Way Some People Live" (1943), or that he expunged some of its parts from his Pulitzer-winning omnibus, "The Stories of John Cheever" (1978). But this is the digital age, when nothing is lost. Now, with Blake Bailey's long-awaited Cheever biography hitting stores next month and the literary world bracing for the first big Cheever revival since the amazing "Journals of John Cheever" appeared in 1991, the Web site FiveChapters.com has exhumed one of those apprentice stories, "Of Love: A Testimony," which it is publishing online in daily chunks through tomorrow.

Updated, Apr. 17, 11:00 p.m. | The Environmental Protection Agency today officially designated carbon dioxide and five other heat-trapping gases to be dangerous pollutants. This is the first step in a process that will lead to the regulation of the gases for the first time in the United States. Our colleague Andrew C. Revkin, at Dot Earth, looks at the impact this regulation might or might not have.

City and transit officials gathered on Thursday morning as a giant piece of equipment known as a cutter head -- 22 feet in diameter and having 44 rotating discs -- was lowered into the ground on the Far West Side of Manhattan. The cutter head will be mounted at the front of a 100-ton tunnel-boring machine that will drill a tunnel to Times Square as part of the $2.1 billion extension of the No. 7 subway line.

The Iraqi journalist Muntader al-Zaidi appeared in court in Baghdad Thursday for the start of his trial for throwing shoes at President George W. Bush in December, and delivered a speech trying to justify his actions. As his defense lawyers seek to get the charges against him reduced, his unorthodox act of protest has led to copycat shoe-hurling around the world, including Britain, Argentina, Lebanon, India and Mexico. Many, but not all, were demonstrations against Israel's December-January offensive in Gaza, during which memories of Mr. al-Zaidi's brief outburst were particularly fresh.

ABC's "Lost" delivered its highest ratings of the season on Wednesday, according to Nielsen's estimates. Update | 7:20 p.m. While many American states have struggled with problems caused by the economic slowdown, the signs have been out there for a while that California is in danger of imploding -- sinking into itself, collapsing under the weight of its problems. Though it finally passed a budget today, it is moving ahead with a plan to force more than 200,000 state employees to take unpaid furloughs to save state money.

In the 1970s, Ralph Lauren - as all designers do - sold the rights to a licensee to make perfumes under his name in exchange for a royalty. (Usually 2 percent to 7 percent of the return.) The trick is selling to the right licensee, one who employs good creative execs who then hire good perfumers to make juices that are both artistically solid and commercially successful. Among the major licensees are Estée Lauder, LVMH, BPI, Clarins, Coty, Interparfums and L'Oréal.

Fashion editors are not as nasty as the media would have you believe. But you would be cranky too if your feet were always killing you. Yesterday, I pushed the limits of my own good humor by wearing what had always seemed to be a very manageable pair of platform boots. (Note to self: never start the day by hoofing from 8th Avenue and 37th Street to 5th Avenue and 41st Street in 5-inch heels.) By evening I was practically crawling on my hands and knees to the six presentations I still had to attend -- all of which were, natch, within walking distance. Then I remembered that I had left a pair Kushyfoot insole socks at the office and so I ran -- okay, hobbled -- back to grab them. Slipping into these funny little padded socklets was one of the best experiences of my week -- if not my year or my life. The socks come in black nylon and even lace, and are discreet enough not stick out of your shoe, though if they did you could always just smile and tell people they're Prada.

History | It sure looks like the end of market capitalism and the rise of the state. But it looked that way back in 1938 too, when the journalist Walter Lippman and other intellectuals met in Paris to revive 19th century liberalism -- a meeting that foreshadowed the influential, free-market Mont Pelerin Society. Their views then have an eerie echo now, an article says. "Today such men seem in short supply." [Standpoint]

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on NBC: As you may have heard, the state of California is broke. So you're looking at massive state layoffs now because the legislature hasn't been able to come up with a budget. The state is $42 billion in the hole. You know, I'm no financial expert, but if you have no money and no prospects of making money and you owe $42 billion, you're way beyond putting yourself on a budget, O.K.? I think you're looking at faking your own death at this point.
